<a name="4.100"></a>
<p><h3>4.100 Design Workshop: Fabricating Function
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 0-3-0 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Through design and making, students discover the relationship between mind and hand and acquire the elemental skills necessary to research, conceptualize, represent, develop and fabricate design solutions to real-world problems. Covers the steps to creating and fabricating a functional object critical to understanding design and provides useful tools for problem solving in general. Lab fee. Limited to 15; preference to freshmen.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.101"></a>
<p><h3>4.101 Design Studio: Introduction to Design Techniques and Technologies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-4-6
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4101">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4101</a>
<br><b>Design:</b> <i>TR3-5</i> (STUDIO)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces core principles, techniques and technologies for design across a wide range of media in a studio environment. Explores ideas related to form, materials, tools, systems, and structures through project-based exercises. Develops familiarity with design process, critical observation, and tools for the translation of design concepts into digital and physical constructs. Utilizing traditional and contemporary tools, faculty across various design disciplines expose students to a unique cross-section of inquiry.
<br><I>J. Jih</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.105"></a>
<p><h3>4.105 Geometric Disciplines and Architecture Skills I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-2-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Intensive introduction to architectural design tools and process, taught through a series of short exercises. Together with 4.107, covers a broad range of topics relating to the discourse of geometry as the basis of architectural design process. Focuses on projective drawings, explicit 3D modeling, and the reciprocity between representation and materialization. Lectures, workshops, and pin-ups address the architectural arguments intrinsic to geometry and its representation. Restricted to level one MArch students.
<br><I>J. Lamere</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.109"></a>
<p><h3>4.109 Materials and Fabrication for Architecture
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 0-3-3
<br>IAP URL: <a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/iap-2018-4109">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/iap-2018-4109</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides the material system knowledge and fabrication process skills to successfully engage with all areas of the shop, from precision handwork to multi-axis computer numerically controlled (CNC) machining. Progresses through a series of basic exercises that introduce the material and workflow, concluding with more complex problems that explore opportunities and issues specific to architecture. Lab fee. Limited to 12; preference to first-year MArch students.
<br><I>J. Lavallee</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.110"></a>
<p><h3>4.110 Design Across Scales and Disciplines
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mMASa.html#MAS.650">MAS.650</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-10
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4110">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4110</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T10-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E14">E14-633</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W EVE (7-9 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=9">9-217</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=9">9-450A</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=9">9-450B</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Inspired by Charles and Ray Eames' canonical <i>Powers of Ten</i>, explores the relationship between science and engineering through the lens of design. Examines how transformations in science and technology have influenced design thinking and vice versa. Provides interdisciplinary skills and methods to represent, model, design and fabricate objects, machines, and systems using new computational and fabrication tools. Aims to develop methodologies for design research of interdisciplinary problems. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version of the subject. Enrollment limited; preference to Course 4 minors.
<br><I>N. Oxman</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.117"></a>
<p><h3>4.117 Creative Computation
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Architecture has a deep history of integrating drawing and making; however, the Albertian orthographic mandate has produced a schism in this reciprocal relationship. It has relegated architects to producing representations of architectural intent while handing over the responsibility of means and methods of making to builders. With recent advances in digital technologies, this relationship is once again becoming entangled. In doing so, it brings into question the renewed roles of architects, designers, creators, computers, and makers. Subject disputes the compartmentalization present in architectural practice today. Through the tools of computation and fabrication, it empowers students to design as architect, engineer, and craftsman.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.119"></a>
<p><h3>4.119 Preparation for Undergraduate Architecture Design Thesis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4a.html#4.024">4.024</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-10
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Selection of thesis topic, defining method of approach, and preparation of thesis proposal for BSA degree in architecture. Weekly class meeting as well as individual conference with faculty.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.120"></a>
<p><h3>4.120 Furniture Making Workshop
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-2-5
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4120">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4120</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>WF9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=N51">N51-160</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides instruction in designing and building a functional piece of furniture from an original design. Develops woodworking techniques from use of traditional hand tools to digital fabrication. Gives students the opportunity to practice design without using a building program or code. Surveys the history of furniture making and includes site visits to local collections and artists/craftsmen. Limited to 12; preference to Course 4 students.
<br><I>C. Dewart</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.123"></a>
<p><h3>4.123 Architectural Assemblies
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-2-5
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4123">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4123</a>
<br><b>Design:</b> <i>F9-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-133</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Fosters a holistic understanding of the architectural-building cycle, enabling students to build upon the history of design and construction to make informed decisions towards developing innovative building systems. Includes an overview of materials, processing methods, and their formation into building systems across cultures. Looks at developing innovative architectural systems focusing on the building envelope. Seeks to adapt processes from the aerospace and automotive industries to investigate buildings as prefabricated design and engineering assemblies. Synthesizes knowledge in building design and construction systems, environmental and structural design, and geometric and computational approaches.
<br><I>J. Klein</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.130"></a>
<p><h3>4.130 Architectural Design Theory and Methodologies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies design as an interrogative technique to examine material sciences, media arts and technology, cultural studies, computation and emerging fabrication protocols. Provides in-depth, theoretical grounding to the notion of 'design' in architecture, and to the consideration of contemporary design methodologies, while encouraging speculation on emerging design thinking. Topical focus varies with instructor. May be repeated for credit with permission of department.
<br><I>J. Leung</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.140"></a>
<p><h3>4.140[J] How to Make (Almost) Anything
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6c.html#6.943">6.943[J]</A>, <A HREF="mMASa.html#MAS.863">MAS.863[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-9-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a practical hands-on introduction to digital fabrication, including CAD/CAM/CAE, NC machining, 3-D printing and scanning, molding and casting, composites, laser and waterjet cutting, PCB design and fabrication; sensors and actuators; mixed-signal instrumentation, embedded processing, and wired and wireless communications. Develops an understanding of these capabilities through projects using them individually and jointly to create functional systems.
<br><I>N. Gershenfeld</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.141"></a>
<p><h3>4.141 How to Design (almost) Anything
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4a.html#4.142">4.142</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-9-6
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4141">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4141</a>
<br><b>Design:</b> <i>MW3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=N52">N52-GARAGE</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces fundamental design principles and practices, such as seeing, sketching, storytelling, prototyping and performing, as a way to demystify design as a discipline. Taught by a diverse group of faculty, students dive deeply into design through lectures, labs, and weekly project assignments. Technique-based class intended for students without a design background enables more effective collaboration with designers and the ability to apply the foundations of design to any discipline. Additional work required of students taking graduate version.
<br><I>S. Tibbitts</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.142"></a>
<p><h3>4.142 How to Design (almost) Anything
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4a.html#4.141">4.141</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="mMASa.html#MAS.863">MAS.863</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-9-6
<br><b>Design:</b> <i>MW3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=N52">N52-GARAGE</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces fundamental design principles and practices, such as seeing, sketching, storytelling, prototyping and performing, as a way to demystify design as a discipline. Taught by a diverse group of faculty, students dive deeply into design through lectures, labs, and weekly project assignments. Technique-based class intended for students without a design background enables more effective collaboration with designers and the ability to apply the foundations of design to any discipline. Additional work required of students taking graduate version.
<br>Staff<br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.151"></a>
<p><h3>4.151 Architecture Design Core Studio I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 0-12-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Establishes foundational processes, techniques and attitudes towards architectural design. Includes projects of increasing scope and complexity engaging issues of structure, circulation, program, organization, building systems, materiality and tectonics. Develops methods of representation that incorporate both analogue and digital drawings and models. First in a sequence of design subjects, which must be taken in order. Limited to first-year MArch students.
<br><I>W. O'Brien</I><br>
<a name="4.152"></a>
<p><h3>4.152 Architecture Design Core Studio II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4a.html#4.151">4.151</a>
<br>Units: 0-12-9
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4152">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4152</a>
<br><b>Design:</b> <i>TRF1-5</i> (STUDIO) or <i>TRF1-5</i> (STUDIO) or <i>TRF1-5</i> (STUDIO)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Builds on Core I skills and expands the constraints of the architectural problem to include issues of urban site logistics, cultural and programmatic material (inhabitation and human factors), and long span structures. Two related projects introduce a range of disciplinary issues, such as working with precedents, site, sectional and spatial proposition of the building, and the performance of the outer envelope. Emphasizes the clarity of intentions and the development of appropriate architectural and representational solutions. Limited to first-year MArch students.
<br><I>M. Ibanez</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
<a name="4.153"></a>
<p><h3>4.153 Architecture Design Core Studio III
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4a.html#4.152">4.152</a>
<br>Units: 0-12-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Interdisciplinary approach to design through studio design problems that engage the domains of building technology, computation, and the cultural/historical geographies of energy. Uses different modalities of thought to examine architectural agendas for 'sustainability'; students position their work with respect to a broader understanding of the environment and its relationship to society and technology. Students develop a project with a comprehensive approach to programmatic organization, energy load considerations, building material assemblies, exterior envelope and structure systems. Limited to second-year MArch students.
<br><I>S. Kennedy</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.154"></a>
<p><h3>4.154 Architecture Design Option Studio
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4a.html#4.153">4.153</a>
<br>Units: 0-10-11
<br><a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/subjects">http://architecture.mit.edu/subjects</a>
<br><b>Design:</b> <i>TR EVE (1-6 PM)</i> (STUDIO) or <i>TR EVE (1-6 PM)</i> (STUDIO) or <i>TR EVE (1-6 PM)</i> (STUDIO) or <i>TR EVE (1-6 PM)</i> (STUDIO) or <i>TR EVE (1-6 PM)</i> (STUDIO) or <i>TR EVE (1-6 PM)</i> (STUDIO) or <i>TR EVE (1-6 PM)</i> (STUDIO)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Offers a broad range of advanced-level investigations in architectural design in various contexts, including international sites. Integrates theoretical and technological discourses into specific topics. Studio problems may include urbanism and city scale strategies, habitation and urban housing systems, architecture in landscapes, material investigations and new production technologies, programmatic and spatial complex building typologies, and research centered studies. Mandatory lottery process.
<br>Fall: <I>C. Stewart</I><br>Spring: <I>C. Stewart</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.162"></a>
<p><h3>4.162 Introductory Urban Design Studio
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 0-10-11
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Project-based introduction to urban observation, research, analysis, and design. Focuses on urban elements, urban and architectural interventions, and landscape in existing cities. Emphasizes city form, sustainability, and social conditions. Projects require both conventional and digital techniques. Preference to Urbanism SMArchS students.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.163"></a>
<p><h3>4.163[J] Urban Design Studio
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.332">11.332[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4a.html#4.162">4.162</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>The design of urban environments. Strategies for change in large areas of cities, to be developed over time, involving different actors. Fitting forms into natural, man-made, historical, and cultural contexts; enabling desirable activity patterns; conceptualizing built form; providing infrastructure and service systems; guiding the sensory character of development. Involves architecture and planning students in joint work; requires individual designs or design and planning guidelines.
<br><I>R. Segal</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.173"></a>
<p><h3>4.173[J] Beijing Urban Design Studio
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.307">11.307[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 0-18-0
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Design studio that includes architects and city planners working in teams on a contemporary development project of importance in China. Students analyze conditions, explore alternatives, and synthesize architecture, city design, and implementation plans. Lectures and brief study tours expose students to history and contemporary issues of urbanism in China. Offered every other summer in residence at Tsinghua University, Beijing, involving students and faculty from both schools. Limited to 10.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.180"></a>
<p><h3>4.180 Architectural Design Workshop
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4a.html#4.023">4.023</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Subject in design inquiry taught in studio format treating selected issues of the built world in depth. The problem may be prototypical or a particular aspect of a whole project, but always interdisciplinary in nature.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.181"></a>
<p><h3>4.181 Architectural Design Workshop
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>

<a name="4.189"></a>
<p><h3>4.189 Preparation for MArch Thesis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-1-5
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4189">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4189</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-442</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Preparatory research development leading to a well-conceived proposition for the MArch design thesis. Students formulate a cohesive thesis argument and critical project using supportive research and case studies through a variety of representational media, critical traditions, and architectural/artistic conventions. Group study in seminar and studio format, with periodic reviews supplemented by conference with faculty and a designated committee member for each individual thesis. Restricted to MArch students.
<br>Fall: <I>L. Norford</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Dutta</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.190"></a>
<p><h3>4.190 Practical Experience in Architecture
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Practical experience through summer internships secured by the student in the field of architecture, urbanism, digital design, art, or building technology. Before registering for this subject, students must have an employment offer and complete an application signed by the advisor. Upon completion of the work, students must submit an employer evaluation form available from the departmental academic office. Registration limited to two summers. Restricted to Course 4 students
<br>Fall: <I>R. Caso</I><br>IAP: <I>P. Pettigrew</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.191"></a>
<p><h3>4.191 Independent Study in Architecture Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Supplementary work on individual or group basis. Registration subject to prior arrangement for subject matter and supervision by staff.
<br>Fall: <I>R. Caso</I><br>IAP: <I>R. Caso</I><br>Spring: <I>R. Caso</I><br>No textbook information available (IAP 2018); No required or recommended textbooks (Spring 2018)
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.192"></a>

<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Course 4: Architecture<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/"><i>Course 4 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course4.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=4&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=+++4&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4a.html">Architecture Design</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>Architecture Studies</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4c.html">Art, Culture and Technology</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4d.html">Building Technology</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4e.html">Computation</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4f.html">History, Theory and Criticism of Architecture and Art</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4g.html">Thesis and UROP</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<h2>Architecture Studies</h2>
<a name="4.210"></a>
<p><h3>4.210 Precedents in Critical Practice
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Through formal analysis and discussion of historical and theoretical texts, seminar produces a map of contemporary architectural practice. Examines six pairs of themes in terms of their recent history: city and global economy, urban plan and map of operations, program and performance, drawing and scripting, image and surface, and utopia and projection. Restricted to year-one MArch students.
<br><I>A. Miljacki</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.211"></a>
<p><h3>4.211[J] The Once and Future City
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11a.html#11.016">11.016[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-485</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the evolving structure of cities, the dynamic processes that shape them, and the significance of a city's history for its future development. Develops the ability to read urban form as an interplay of natural processes and human purposes over time. Field assignments in Boston provide the opportunity to use, develop, and refine these concepts. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>A. Spirn</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=4.211');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.213"></a>
<p><h3>4.213[J] Ecological Urbanism Seminar
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.308">11.308[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the urban environment as a natural phenomenon, human habitat, medium of expression, and forum for action. Subject has two related, major themes: how ideas of nature influence the way cities are perceived, designed, built, and managed; and how natural processes and urban form interact and the consequences of these for human health safety and welfare. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>A. Spirn</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.214"></a>
<p><h3>4.214[J] Water, Landscape and Urban Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.314">11.314[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Workshop surveys how water affects the design of buildings, landscapes and cities in aesthetic, functional and symbolic ways. Combines the systematic study of water issues with urban design projects in South Asia and the US. Covers topics such as rainwater harvesting, water use efficiency, wastewater reuse, stormwater management, floodplain design, constructed wetlands, and waterfront development. Students work together to integrate these design concepts at the site, urban, and international scales. Limited to 15.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.215"></a>
<p><h3>4.215[J] Sensing Place: Photography as Inquiry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.309">11.309[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores photography as a disciplined way of seeing, of investigating urban landscapes and expressing ideas. Readings, observations, and photographs form the basis of discussions on light, detail, place, poetics, narrative, and how photography can inform design and planning. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>A. Spirn</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.216"></a>
<p><h3>4.216[J] Landscape and Urban Heritage Conservation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.316">11.316[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on cultural landscape history, theory, and heritage issues and projects in the Indo-Islamic realm. Landscape and urban heritage inquiry go beyond monuments to encompass sites, cites, and regions. Combines the study of conservation theory and practice with an exploration of active urban landscape planning and design projects. Limited to 15.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.217"></a>
<p><h3>4.217[J] Disaster Resilient Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.315">11.315[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar examines the linkages between natural hazards and environmental design. Engages theoretical debates about landscapes of risk, vulnerability, and resilience. Participants generate proposals for disaster resilience through combinations of retrofit, reconstruction, resettlement, commemorative, and anticipatory design. Methods include rapid bibliographic search, risk analysis, landscape synthesis, and comparative international methods. Projects vary and may focus on current crises or involve collaboration with the Aga Khan Development Network and other humanitarian organizations. Limited to 15.
<br><I>J. Wescoat</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.221"></a>
<p><h3>4.221 Architecture Studies Colloquium
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-1-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Series of open lectures, presented as an introduction to the diverse academic and creative community of MIT and the region, at which discipline groups of the SMArchS program converge and exchange ideas. Organized thematically, guest speakers from cultural and scientific fields present viewpoints in areas of emerging interest within design, building technology, architectural computation, history, and art. Encourages discourse with speakers and among students from different disciplines. Students initiate online debates among their peers and respond to an evolving series of discussions resulting in publication.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.222"></a>
<p><h3>4.222 Professional Practice
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Gives a critical orientation towards a career in architectural practice. Uses historical and current examples to illustrate the legal, ethical and management concepts underlying the practice of architecture. Emphasis on facilitating design excellence and strengthening connections between the profession and academia.
<br><I>R. Mohr</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.225"></a>
<p><h3>4.225 Urban Design Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces theories, concepts and precedents in urban design. Emphasizes traditional, modern and contemporary values and approaches to urban design. Research projects required. Preference to Urbanism SMArchS students.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.227"></a>
<p><h3>4.227 Landscapes of Energy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Spatializes large technological systems of energy, analyzes existing and speculative energy visions, and imagines energy futures in relation to concerns of ecology, politics, and aesthetics. Identifies different scales of thinking about the territory of energy from that of environmental systems, to cities, regions, and global landscapes. Readings and students' research projects draw on critical geography, history of technology, environmental history to synthesize energy attributes within the design disciplines.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.230"></a>
<p><h3>4.230[J] SIGUS Workshop
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.468">11.468[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4b.html#4.231">4.231</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Interdisciplinary projects and interactive practices in urban settlement issues as investigated by MIT's SIGUS (Special Interest Group in Urban Settlements), with a focus on developing countries throughout the world. Participation by guest practitioners. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version.
<br>Fall: <I>R. Goethert</I><br>IAP: <I>R. Goethert</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.231"></a>
<h3>4.231 SIGUS Workshop
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Interdisciplinary projects and interactive practices in urban settlement issues as investigated by MIT's SIGUS (Special Interest Group in Urban Settlements), with a focus on developing countries throughout the world. Participation by guest practitioners. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version.
<br><I>R. Goethert</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.232"></a>
<p><h3>4.232[J] The New Global Planning Practitioner
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.444">11.444[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4232">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4232</a>
<br>1st mtg Feb 15 at 3.30 pm. In room 3-329. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TBA</i> <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Considers a new interdisciplinary paradigm of practice that regards dialogue among practitioners and users essential for efficacious and creative design and planning process. Focuses on non-traditional client groups: communities, the poor, and the generally excluded middle-income. Explores key issues confronting development practitioners, with stress on practical exercises drawn from current national and international case studies; e.g., an investigative comparison of cities or tools in coping with impending rapid and massive growth and expansion. Engages those with a design and community service orientation.
<br><I>R. Goethert</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
<a name="4.236"></a>
<p><h3>4.236[J] Structuring Low-Income Housing Projects in Developing Countries
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.463">11.463[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines dynamic relationship among key actors: beneficiaries, government, and funder. Emphasis on cost recovery, affordability, replicability, user selection, and project administration. Extensive case examples provide basis for comparisons.
<br><I>R. Goethert</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.240"></a>
<p><h3>4.240[J] Urban Design Skills: Observing, Interpreting, and Representing the City
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.328">11.328[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-2-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces methods of recording, evaluating, and representing the urban environment. Through visual observation, field analysis, measurements, interviews, and other means, students draw on their senses and develop their ability to deduce, conclude, question, and test conclusions about how the environment is used and valued. Using representational tools such as drawing, photographing, computer modeling and desktop publishing, students communicate what they observe along with their impressions and design ideas. Intended as a foundation for future studio work in urban design. Includes design-based projects.
<br><I>E. Ben-Joseph</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.241"></a>
<p><h3>4.241[J] The Making of Cities
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.330">11.330[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4b.html#4.251">4.251</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4b.html#4.252">4.252</a>, <a href="m11a.html#11.001">11.001</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4241">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4241</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-261</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the complex development of cities through history by tracing a diachronic accumulation of forms and spaces in specific cities, and showing how significant ideas were made manifest across distinct geographies and cultures. Emphasizes how economic, spiritual, political, geographic and technological forces have simultaneously shaped and, in turn, been influenced by the city. Additional work required of students taking graduate version.
<br><I>R. Segal</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.244"></a>
<p><h3>4.244[J] Urban Design Seminar: Perspectives on Contemporary Practice
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.333">11.333[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W9-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-401</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines innovations in urban design practice occurring through the work of leading practitioners in the fields of architecture, landscape architecture, and urban planning. Features lectures by major national and global practitioners in urban design. Projects and topics vary based on term and speakers but may cover architectural urbanism, landscape and ecology, arts and culture, urban design regulation and planning agencies, and citywide and regional design. Focuses on analysis and synthesis of themes discussed in presentations and discussions.
<br><I>A. Vanky</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.245"></a>
<p><h3>4.245[J] DesignX Entrepreneurship
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11b.html#11.245">11.245[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 6-0-0 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students work in teams to create their own design and business narrative, technology and social strategies, and preliminary plan for moving their innovation forward. Lectures and workshops are interspersed with one-on-one critiques with instructors and outside mentors in specific areas of student interest. Students visit SA+P alumni firms to learn how principals have developed their own business, technology, design, and civic platforms. End-of-term presentation highlights important features of their venture. Limited to 30; preference to students in DesignX Program.
<br><I>D. Frenchman</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.246"></a>
<p><h3>4.246[J] DesignX Accelerator
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11b.html#11.246">11.246[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-4-6 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W EVE (5-7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=9">9-450A</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>F9-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=9">9-450A</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students work in entrepreneurial teams to advance innovative ideas, products, services, and firms oriented to design and the built environment.  Lectures, demonstrations, and presentations are supplemented by workshop time, when teams interact individually with instructors and industry mentors, and by additional networking events and field trips.  At the end of the term, teams pitch for support of their venture to outside investors, accelerators, companies, or cities. Limited to 30; preference to students in DesignX Program.
<br><I>D. Frenchman</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.247"></a>
<p><h3>4.247[J] Urban Design Ideals and Action
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.337">11.337[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-7
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i> <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the relationship between urban design ideals, urban design action, and the built environment through readings, discussions, presentations, and papers. Analyzes the diverse design ideals that influence cities and settlements, and investigates how urban designers use them to shape urban form. Provides a critical understanding of the diverse formal methods used to intervene creatively in both developed and developing contexts, especially pluralistic and informal built environments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.250"></a>
<p><h3>4.250[J] Introduction to Urban Design and Development
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11a.html#11.001">11.001[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the evolving structure of cities and the way that cities, suburbs, and metropolitan areas can be designed and developed. Surveys the ideas of a wide range of people who have addressed urban problems. Stresses the connection between values and design. Demonstrates how physical, social, political and economic forces interact to shape and reshape cities over time.
<br><I>L. Vale</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.251"></a>
<p><h3>4.251 The Making of Cities
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">

<br>Units: 3-0-9

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">

Emphasizes how economic, spiritual, political, geographic and technological forces have simultaneously shaped and, in turn, been influenced by the city. Additional work required of students taking graduate version.

<a name="4.252"></a>
<p><h3>4.252[J] Introduction to Urban Design and Development
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.301">11.301[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines both the physical and social structure of cities and ways they can be changed. Includes historical forces that have produced cities, models of urban form analysis, contemporary theories of urban design, implementation strategies. Core lectures supplemented by student projects analyzing the evolution of urban place, and factors of high quality urban design and development. Guest speakers present cases involving current projects illustrating the scope and methods of urban design practice.
<br><I>A. Vanky</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.253"></a>
<p><h3>4.253[J] Urban Design Politics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.302">11.302[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M EVE (3-6 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-401</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines ways urban design contributes to distribution of political power and resources in cities. Investigates the nature of relations between built form and political purposes through close study of a wide variety of situations where public sector design commissions and planning processes have been clearly motivated by political pressures. Lectures and discussions focus on specific case studies of 20th-century government-sponsored designs carried out under diverse regimes in the US, Europe, and elsewhere.
<br><I>L. Vale</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.254"></a>
<p><h3>4.254[J] Real Estate Development Studio
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.303">11.303[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 6-0-12
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2.30-5.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-485</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>M EVE (6-7.30 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-485</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the synthesis of urban, mixed-use real estate projects, including the integration of physical design and programming with finance and marketing. Interdisciplinary student teams analyze how to maximize value across multiple dimensions in the process of preparing professional development proposals for sites in US cities and internationally. Reviews emerging real estate products and innovative developments to provide a foundation for studio work. Two major projects are interspersed with lectures and field trips. Integrates skills and knowledge in the MSRED program; also open to other students interested in real estate development.
<br><I>D. Frenchman</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.255"></a>
<p><h3>4.255[J] Site and Environmental Systems Planning
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.304">11.304[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 6-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W EVE (5.30-7.30 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-485</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F9-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-485</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces a range of practical approaches involved in evaluating and planning sites within the context of natural and cultural systems. Develops the knowledge and skills to analyze and plan a site for development through exercises and an urban design project. Topics include land inventory, urban form, spatial organization of uses, parcelization, design of roadways, grading, utility systems, off-site impacts, and landscape architecture.
<br><I>M. Ocampo</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.264"></a>
<p><h3>4.264[J] Advanced Seminar in Landscape and Urbanism
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.334">11.334[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i>  <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores theories, practices, and emerging trends in the fields of landscape architecture and urbanism, such as systemic design, landscape urbanism, engineered nature, drosscapes, urban biodiversity, urban mobility, megaregions, and urban agriculture. Lectures, readings, and guest speakers present a wide array of multi-disciplinary topics, including current works from P-REX lab. Students conduct independent and group research that is future-oriented.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.270"></a>
<p><h3>4.270 Innovation for Disaster Relief and Preparedness
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores innovative solutions for disaster relief and preparedness through both design and engineering. Interactive exercises provide an overview of large-scale disaster relief issues, including response communities, operating environments, logistics and technical challenges. Projects will be developed through hands-on prototyping, emphasizing the importance of system-oriented, sustainable design. Speakers from organizations such as FEMA and The Red Cross will contribute.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.280"></a>
<p><h3>4.280 Undergraduate Architecture Internship
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>IAP URL: <a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/iap-2017-4280">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/iap-2017-4280</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students work in an architect's office to gain experience, improve skills, and see the inner workings of an everyday architectural practice. Internships possible in all sizes of firms and in public and nonprofit agencies. During IAP, a full-time, 4-week internship is required; maximum IAP credit, 6 units.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.286"></a>
<p><h3>4.286 SMArchS Urbanism Pre-Thesis Preparation
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-0 [P/D/F]
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4286">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4286</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M11-2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-329</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores initial thesis ideas and bases for choosing among multiple interests. Assessment of design research strengths and weaknesses. Overview of conceptual frameworks and research methods. Preparation for summer field research and proposal development.
<br><I>J. Wescoat</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.287"></a>
<p><h3>4.287 Graduate Architecture Internship
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>IAP URL: <a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/iap-2017-4287">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/iap-2017-4287</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Work in an architect's office to gain experience, improve skills, and see the inner workings of an everyday architectural practice. Internships possible in all sizes of firms and in public and nonprofit agencies. During IAP, a full-time, 4-week internship is required; maximum IAP credit, 6 units.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.288"></a>
<p><h3>4.288 Preparation for SMArchS Thesis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4288">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4288</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>F9-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-329</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students select thesis topic, define method of approach, and prepare thesis proposal for SMArchS degree. Faculty supervision on an individual or group basis. Intended for SMArchS program students prior to registration for 4.ThG.
<br>Fall: <I>C. Stewart</I><br>Spring: <I>C. Stewart</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->

<h1 align="center">Course 4: Architecture<br>IAP / Spring

<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<h2>Art, Culture and Technology</h2>
<a name="4.301"></a>
<p><h3>4.301 Introduction to Artistic Experimentation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4301">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4301</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TW2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-207</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces artistic practice and critical visual thinking through three studio-based projects using different scales and media, for instance, "Body Extension," "Shaping Time," "Public Making," and/or "Networked Cultures." Each project concludes with a final presentation and critique. Students explore sculptural, architectural, performative artistic methods; video and sound art; site interventions and strategies for artistic engagement in the public realm. Lectures, screenings, guest presentations, field trips, readings, and debates supplement studio practice.  Also introduces students to the historic, cultural, and environmental forces affecting both the development of an artistic vision and the reception of a work of art. Limited to 20.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Aksamija</I><br>Spring: <I>M. Jahn</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.302"></a>
<p><h3>4.302 Foundations in Art, Design, and Spatial Practices
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4a.html#4.021">4.021</a> or <a href="m4a.html#4.02A">4.02A</a>
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4302">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4302</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-207</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops an introductory foundation in artistic practice and its critical analysis, and develops artistic approaches and methods by drawing analogies to architectural thinking, urbanism, and design practice. Covers how to communicate ideas and experiences on different scales and through two-dimensional, three-dimensional, and time-based media in new genres. Uses artistic methods that engage the public realm through spatial, sculptural, performative, and process-oriented practices. Instruction components include video screenings, guest lectures, visiting artist presentations, and field trips. Instruction and practice in written and oral communication provided. Enrollment limited; preference to Course 4 majors and minors.
<br><I>T. Putrih</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.307"></a>
<p><h3>4.307 Art, Architecture, and Urbanism in Dialogue
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4c.html#4.308">4.308</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4c.html#4.301">4.301</a>, <a href="m4c.html#4.302">4.302</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Initiates a dialogue between architecture, urbanism, and contemporary art by focusing on the work of practitioners who intertwine the three disciplines in a critical spatial practice. Investigates themes and works ranging from early modernist practices to the contemporary and research based. Lectures, screenings, readings, and discussions with guests and faculty contribute to the development of group and individual projects and their presentation. Additional work required of students taking graduate version. Limited to 20.
<br><I>A. Aksamija</I><br>
<a name="4.308"></a>
<h3>4.308 Art, Architecture, and Urbanism in Dialogue
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4c.html#4.307">4.307</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Initiates a dialogue between architecture, urbanism, and contemporary art by focusing on the work of practitioners who intertwine the three disciplines in a critical spatial practice. Investigates themes and works ranging from early modernist practices to the contemporary and research based. Lectures, screenings, readings, and discussions with guests and faculty contribute to the development of group and individual projects and their presentation. Additional work required of students taking graduate version. Limited to 20.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.312"></a>
<p><h3>4.312 Advanced Studio on the Production of Space
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4c.html#4.313">4.313</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4c.html#4.301">4.301</a>, <a href="m4c.html#4.302">4.302</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces historical and contemporary spatial concepts from various cultures and geo-political settings, and examines how they relate to artistic process and production. Explores the relational qualities of spatial concepts and reflects on their producers and proponents; investigates the notion of utopian, dystopian and heterotopian space, inner and outer space, the void, the vacuum, the in-between, and "real" versus "virtual" space. Lectures, readings, screenings, presentations, and guest speakers from various disciplines support the development of individual and collective projects. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version. Limited to 20.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.313"></a>
<h3>4.313 Advanced Studio on the Production of Space
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4c.html#4.312">4.312</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces historical and contemporary spatial concepts from various cultures and geo-political settings, and examines how they relate to artistic process and production. Explores the relational qualities of spatial concepts and reflects on their producers and proponents; investigates the notion of utopian, dystopian and heterotopian space, inner and outer space, the void, the vacuum, the in-between, and "real" versus "virtual" space. Lectures, readings, screenings, presentations, and guest speakers from various disciplines support the development of individual and collective projects. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version. Limited to 20.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.314"></a>
<p><h3>4.314 Advanced Workshop in Artistic Practice and Transdisciplinary Research
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4c.html#4.315">4.315</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4c.html#4.301">4.301</a>, <a href="m4c.html#4.302">4.302</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines artistic practice as a form of critical inquiry and knowledge production. Offers opportunity to develop art as a means for addressing the social, cultural, and ecological consequences of technology, to build bridges between industry and culture, and to challenge the boundaries between public and private, and human and non-human. Provides instruction in evaluating models of experimentation, individual research, and collaboration with other disciplines in the arts, culture, science, and technology. Supports the development of individual and collective artistic research projects. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version. Limited to 20.
<br><I>L. Knott</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.315"></a>
<h3>4.315 Advanced Workshop in Artistic Practice and Transdisciplinary Research
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4c.html#4.314">4.314</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6

Offers opportunity to develop art as a means for addressing the social, cultural, and ecological consequences of technology, to build bridges between industry and culture, and to challenge the boundaries between public and private, and human and non-human. Supports the development of individual and collective artistic research projects. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version. Limited to 20.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.320"></a>
<p><h3>4.320 Introduction to Sound Creations
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4c.html#4.321">4.321</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4320">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4320</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-001</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops a critical awareness of how sound art as a field for artistic exploration is performed, produced, and distributed. Explores contemporary and historical practices that emerge outside of purely musical environments and investigates specific compositional developments of post-war modernity and electro-acoustic music, as well as non-musical disciplines related to the psychophysics of hearing and listening. Lectures, screenings, readings, and discussions with guests and faculty contribute to the development of group and individual projects. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version. Limited to 20.
<br><I>R. Smite</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.321"></a>
<p><h3>4.321 Introduction to Sound Creations
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4c.html#4.320">4.320</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4320">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4320</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-001</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops a critical awareness of how sound art as a field for artistic exploration is performed, produced, and distributed. Explores contemporary and historical practices that emerge outside of purely musical environments and investigates specific compositional developments of post-war modernity and electro-acoustic music, as well as non-musical disciplines related to the psychophysics of hearing and listening.
