<br>Staff<br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.322"></a>
<p><h3>4.322 Introduction to Three-Dimensional Art Work
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4c.html#4.323">4.323</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores three-dimensional art work, including sculptures and installations, from design to model to finished piece. Addresses challenges associated with design and fabrication, process, context, and relationships between objects, the body, and physical or cultural environments. Lectures, screenings, field trips, readings, and debates supplement studio practice. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version. Limited to 20.
<br><I>T. Putrih</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.323"></a>
<p><h3>4.323 Introduction to Three-Dimensional Art Work
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4c.html#4.322">4.322</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores three-dimensional art work, including sculptures and installations, from design to model to finished piece. Addresses challenges associated with design and fabrication, process, context, and relationships between objects, the body, and physical or cultural environments. Lectures, screenings, field trips, readings, and debates supplement studio practice. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version. Limited to 20.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.341"></a>
<p><h3>4.341 Introduction to Photography and Related Media
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4c.html#4.342">4.342</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4341">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4341</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-054</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces history and contemporary practices in artistic photography through projects, lectures, artist visits, group discussions, readings, and field trips. Fosters visual literacy and aesthetic appreciation of photography/digital imaging, as well as critical awareness of how images in our culture are produced and constructed. Provides instruction in the fundamentals of different camera formats, film exposure and development, lighting, black and white darkroom printing, and digital imaging. Assignments allow for incorporation of a range of traditional and experimental techniques, development of technical skills, and personal exploration. Throughout the term, present and discuss projects in a critical forum. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version. Limited to 20.
<br>Fall: <I>L. Baladi</I><br>Spring: <I>L. Baladi</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.342"></a>
<h3>4.342 Introduction to Photography and Related Media
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4c.html#4.341">4.341</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4341">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4341</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-054</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces history and contemporary practices in artistic photography through projects, lectures, artist visits, group discussions, readings, and field trips. Fosters visual literacy and aesthetic appreciation of photography/digital imaging, as well as critical awareness of how images in our culture are produced and constructed. Provides instruction in the fundamentals of different camera formats, film exposure and development, lighting, black and white darkroom printing, and digital imaging. Assignments allow for incorporation of a range of traditional and experimental techniques, development of technical skills, and personal exploration. Throughout the term, present and discuss projects in a critical forum. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version. Limited to 20.
<br>Staff<br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.344"></a>
<h3>4.344 Advanced Photography and Related Media
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4c.html#4.345">4.345</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4c.html#4.341">4.341</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4344">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4344</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T9.30-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-054</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R9.30-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-054</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Fosters critical awareness of how images in our culture are produced and constructed. Covers a range of experimental techniques and camera formats, advanced traditional and experimental black-and-white darkroom printing, and all aspects of digital imaging and output. Includes individual and group reviews, field trips, and visits from outside professionals. Topical focus changes each term; coursework centers on student-initiated project with emphasis on conceptual, theoretical, and technical development. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version. Equipment available for checkout. Limited to 20.
<br>Fall: <I>L. Baladi</I><br>Spring: <I>L. Baladi</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.345"></a>
<p><h3>4.345 Advanced Photography and Related Media
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4c.html#4.344">4.344</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4c.html#4.342">4.342</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4344">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4344</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T9.30-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-054</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R9.30-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-054</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Fosters critical awareness of how images in our culture are produced and constructed. Covers a range of experimental techniques and camera formats, advanced traditional and experimental black-and-white darkroom printing, and all aspects of digital imaging and output. Includes individual and group reviews, field trips, and visits from outside professionals. Topical focus changes each term; coursework centers on student-initiated project with emphasis on conceptual, theoretical, and technical development. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version. Equipment available for checkout. Limited to 20.
<br>Staff<br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.352"></a>
<p><h3>4.352 Advanced Video and Related Media
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4c.html#4.353">4.353</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4c.html#4.354">4.354</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4352">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4352</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-070</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces advanced strategies of image and sound manipulation, both technical and conceptual. Covers pre-production planning (storyboards and scripting), refinement of digital editing techniques, visual effects such as chroma-keying, post-production, as well as audio and sonic components. Context provided by regular viewings of contemporary video artworks and other audio-visual formats. Students work individually and in groups to develop skills in media literacy and communication. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version. Limited to 20.
<br><I>N. Sinnokrot</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
<a name="4.353"></a>
<h3>4.353 Advanced Video and Related Media
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4c.html#4.352">4.352</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4c.html#4.355">4.355</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4352">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4352</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR EVE (7-10 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-070</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces advanced strategies of image and sound manipulation, both technical and conceptual. Covers pre-production planning (storyboards and scripting), refinement of digital editing techniques, visual effects such as chroma-keying, post-production, as well as audio and sonic components. Context provided by regular viewings of contemporary video artworks and other audio-visual formats. Students work individually and in groups to develop skills in media literacy and communication. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version. Limited to 20.
<br>Staff<br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.354"></a>
<p><h3>4.354 Introduction to Video and Related Media
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4c.html#4.355">4.355</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4354">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4354</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-283A</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the technical and conceptual variables and strategies inherent in contemporary video art practice. Analyzes structural concepts of time, space, perspective, and sound within the art form. Building upon the historical legacy of the moving the image, students render self-exploration, performance, social critique, and manipulation of raw experience into an aesthetic form. Emphasizes practical knowledge of lighting, video capturing and editing, and montage. Presentation and critique of student work, technical workshops, screenings, and reading discussions assist students with final project. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version. Limited to 20.
<br><I>N. Sinnokrot</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.355"></a>
<h3>4.355 Introduction to Video and Related Media
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4c.html#4.354">4.354</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4354">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4354</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-283A</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the technical and conceptual variables and strategies inherent in contemporary video art practice. Analyzes structural concepts of time, space, perspective, and sound within the art form. Building upon the historical legacy of film and other time-based image media, students render self-exploration, performance, social critique, and manipulation of raw experience into an aesthetic form. Emphasizes practical knowledge of lighting, video capturing and editing, and montage. Includes presentation and critique of student work, technical workshops, screenings, and readings with the objective of a final creative project. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version. Limited to 20.
<br>Staff<br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.356"></a>
<p><h3>4.356 Cinematic Migrations
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4c.html#4.357">4.357</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4c.html#4.301">4.301</a>, <a href="m4c.html#4.302">4.302</a>, <a href="m4c.html#4.354">4.354</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores ideas and contexts behind moving images through a multifaceted look at cinema's transmutations, emergence on local and national levels, and global migrations. Examines the transformation caused by online video, television, spatial installations, performances, dance, and many formats and portable devices, as well as the theory and context of film's categorization, dissemination, and analysis. Presentations, screenings, field trips, readings, visiting artists, and experimental transdisciplinary projects broaden the perception of present cinema. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version. Limited to 12.
<br><I>E. Green</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.357"></a>
<h3>4.357 Cinematic Migrations
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">

Examines the transformation caused by online video, television, spatial installations, performances, dance, and many formats and portable devices, as well as the theory and context of film's categorization, dissemination, and analysis. Presentations, screenings, field trips, readings, visiting artists, and experimental transdisciplinary projects broaden the perception of present cinema. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version. Limited to 12.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.361"></a>
<p><h3>4.361 Performance Art Workshop
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4c.html#4.362">4.362</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4c.html#4.301">4.301</a>, <a href="m4c.html#4.302">4.302</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Surveys performance in relation to media and to spatial structures imagined as settings for narrative movements, and uses video to explore the perception of sounds and images and how they are altered by various devices. Students design visual forms and performative actions, and make props or objects that embody aspects of their narratives. Activities include readings and screenings on the theoretical and historical background of performance art. Assignments lead to a final performance project. Additional work required of students taking graduate version. Limited to 20.
<br><I>K. Nipper</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.362"></a>
<h3>4.362 Performance Art Workshop
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4c.html#4.361">4.361</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Surveys performance in relation to media and to spatial structures imagined as settings for narrative movements, and uses video to explore the perception of sounds and images and how they are altered by various devices. Students design visual forms and performative actions, and make props or objects that embody aspects of their narratives. Activities include readings and screenings on the theoretical and historical background of performance art. Assignments lead to a final performance project. Additional work required of students taking graduate version. Limited to 20.

<a name="4.368"></a>
<p><h3>4.368 Studio Seminar in Art and the Public Sphere
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4c.html#4.369">4.369</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4c.html#4.301">4.301</a> or <a href="m4c.html#4.302">4.302</a>
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4368">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4368</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M9.30-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-001</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>W9.30-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-001</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the production of artistic interventions in public space. Explores ideas, situations, objects, and materials that shape public space and inform the notion of publicness, with an emphasis on coproduction and cooperative ethics. Examines forms of environmental art in comparison to temporal and critical forms of art and action in the public sphere. Historical models include the Russian Constructivists, the Situationists International, ecosystematic aesthetics, conceptual art, and contemporary interventionist tactics and artistic strategies. Helps students develop an initial concept for a publicly-situated project. Includes guest lectures, visiting artist presentations, and optional field trips. Additional work required of students taking graduate version. Limited to 20.
<br><I>G. Urbonas</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
<a name="4.369"></a>
<h3>4.369 Studio Seminar in Art and the Public Sphere
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>

Explores ideas, situations, objects, and materials that shape public space and inform the notion of publicness, with an emphasis on coproduction and cooperative ethics. Examines forms of environmental art in comparison to temporal and critical forms of art and action in the public sphere. <a name="4.373"></a>
<p><h3>4.373 Advanced Projects in Art, Culture and Technology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4c.html#4.374">4.374</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4c.html#4.301">4.301</a>, <a href="m4c.html#4.302">4.302</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4373">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4373</a>
<br><b>Design:</b> <i>MW9.30-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-283A</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Investigates conceptual and formal issues in a variety of media. Explores representation, interpretation and meaning, and how these relate to historical, social and cultural contexts. Helps students develop an initial concept for a publicly situated project. Includes guest lectures and  visiting artist presentations. Additional work required of students taking graduate version. Limited to 20.
<br><I>A. Aksamija</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->

<a name="4.388"></a>
<p><h3>4.388 Preparation for SMACT Thesis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4388">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4388</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>F9-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-207</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Aids students in the selection of a thesis topic, development of an approach method, preparation of a proposal that includes an outline for their thesis. Explores artistic practice as a method of critical inquiry and knowledge production/dissemination. Students examine artist writings and consider academic formats and standards. Regular group meetings, including peer reviews, are supplemented by independent study and individual conferences with faculty. Restricted to first-year SMACT students.
<br><I>M. Caro</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.389"></a>
<p><h3>4.389 Tutorial for SMACT Thesis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4c.html#4.388">4.388</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m4g.html#4.THG">4.THG</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4389">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4389</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>F9-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-207</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Series of tutorials that includes regular presentations of student writing in group critiques and supports independent thesis research and development by providing guidance on research strategy and written presentation. Sessions supplemented by regular individual conferences with thesis committee members. Restricted to second-year SMACT students.
<br><I>M. Caro</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.390"></a>
<p><h3>4.390 Art, Culture and Technology Studio
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4390">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4390</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MF2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E15">E15-001</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the theory and criticism of intersections between art, culture, and technology in relation to contemporary artistic practice, critical design, and media. Students consider methods of investigation, documentation, and display and explore modes of communication across disciplines. Students develop projects in which they organize research methods and goals, engage in production, cultivate a context for their practice, and explore how to compellingly communicate, display, and document their work. Regular presentation and peer-critique sessions, as well as reviews involving ACT faculty and fellows, and external guest reviewers provide students with ample feedback as their projects develop. Restricted to SMACT students.
<br>Fall: <I>T. Putrih</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Barry</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.391"></a>

<a name="4.394"></a>
<h3>4.394 Independent Study in Art, Culture and Technology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Supplementary work on individual basis. Registration subject to prior arrangement for subject matter and supervision by staff.
<br>Fall: <I>R. Caso</I><br>IAP: <I>R. Caso</I><br>Spring: <I>R. Caso</I><br>No textbook information available (IAP 2018); No required or recommended textbooks (Spring 2018)
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.S30"></a>
<p><h3>4.S30 Special Subject: Art, Culture and Technology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar or lecture on a topic in visual arts that is not covered in the regular curriculum. Requires original research and presentation of oral and written reports and/or design projects, varying at the discretion of the instructor.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.S31"></a>
<p><h3>4.S31 Special Subject: Art, Culture and Technology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department

<h1 align="center">Course 4: Architecture<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/"><i>Course 4 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course4.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=4&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=+++4&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4a.html">Architecture Design</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4b.html">Architecture Studies</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4c.html">Art, Culture and Technology</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>Building Technology</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4e.html">Computation</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4f.html">History, Theory and Criticism of Architecture and Art</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4g.html">Thesis and UROP</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<h2>Building Technology</h2>
<a name="4.401"></a>
<p><h3>4.401 Environmental Technologies in Buildings
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4d.html#4.464">4.464</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the study of the thermal and luminous behavior of buildings. Examines the basic scientific principles underlying these phenomena and introduces students to a range of technologies and analysis techniques for designing comfortable indoor environments. Challenges students to apply these techniques and explore the role energy and light can play in shaping architecture. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version.
<br><I>C. Reinhart</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.411"></a>
<p><h3>4.411[J] D-Lab Schools: Building Technology Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mECa.html#EC.713">EC.713[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 2-3-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the design, analysis, and application of technologies that support the construction of less expensive and better performing schools in developing countries. Prepares students to design or retrofit school buildings in partnership with local communities and NGOs. Strategies covered include daylighting, passive heating and cooling, improved indoor air quality via natural ventilation, appropriate material selection, and structural design. Investigations are based on application of engineering fundamentals, experiments and simulations. Case studies illustrate the role of technologies in reducing barriers to improved education.
<br><I>L. Norford</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.42"></a>
<p><h3>4.42[J] Fundamentals of Energy in Buildings
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1a.html#1.044">1.044[J]</A>, <A HREF="m2b.html#2.66">2.66[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Design-based introduction to energy and thermo-sciences, with applications to sustainable, energy-efficient architecture and building technology. Covers introductory thermodynamics, air/water/vapor mixtures, and heat transfer. Studies leading order factors in building energy use. Includes several building design projects in which students creatively employ energy fundamentals and building energy use.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.424"></a>
<p><h3>4.424[J] Modeling and Approximation of Thermal Processes
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.52">2.52[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2b.html#2.51">2.51</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides instruction on how to model thermal transport processes in typical engineering systems such as those found in manufacturing, machinery, and energy technologies. Successive modules cover basic modeling tactics for particular modes of transport, including steady and unsteady heat conduction, convection, multiphase flow processes, and thermal radiation. Includes a creative design project executed by the students.
<br><I>L. Glicksman</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.430"></a>
<p><h3>4.430 Daylighting and Solar Gain Control
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4d.html#4.464">4.464</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies natural and electric lighting in an architectural context. Promotes the integration of occupant comfort, energy efficiency and daylight availability throughout the design process, with an emphasis on the role light can play in shaping architecture. Through group and individual projects, students practice design techniques, from rule of thumb simulations to high dynamic range photography and physical model building. Offered for 9 or 12 units.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.431"></a>
<p><h3>4.431 Architectural Acoustics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4431">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4431</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W9.30-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-415</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Describes interactions between people and sound, indoors and outdoors, and uses this information to develop acoustical design criteria for architecture and planning. Principles of sound generation, propagation, and reception. Properties of materials for sound absorption, reflection, and transmission. Design implications for performance and gathering spaces. Use of computer modeling techniques.
<br><I>B. Markham</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.432"></a>
<p><h3>4.432 Modeling Urban Energy Flows for Sustainable Cities and Neighborhoods
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4d.html#4.433">4.433</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4432">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4432</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-150</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-150</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies energy flows in and around groups of buildings from individual buildings to complete large-scale neighborhoods. Students use emerging digital techniques to analyze and influence building design interventions in relation to energy use for construction (embodied energy) and operation, access to daylight, and assessing walkability and outdoor comfort at the neighborhood scale. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version.
<br><I>C. Cerezo Davila</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.433"></a>
<h3>4.433 Modeling Urban Energy Flows for Sustainable Cities and Neighborhoods
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4d.html#4.432">4.432</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-2-4
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4432">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4432</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-150</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-150</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies energy flows in and around groups of buildings from individual buildings to complete large-scale neighborhoods. Students use emerging digital techniques to analyze and influence building design interventions in relation to energy use for construction (embodied energy) and operation, access to daylight, and assessing walkability and outdoor comfort at the neighborhood scale. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version.
<br>Staff<br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.440"></a>
<p><h3>4.440[J] Building Structural Systems I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1a.html#1.056">1.056[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4d.html#4.462">4.462</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4440">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4440</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-333</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>F9.30-11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=8">8-205</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the design and behavior of large-scale structures and structural materials. Emphasizes the development of structural form and the principles of structural design. Presents design methods for timber, masonry, concrete and steel applied to long-span roof systems, bridges, and high-rise buildings. Includes environmental assessment of structural systems and materials. In laboratory sessions, students solve structural problems by building and testing simple models. Graduate and undergraduate students have separate lab sections.
<br><I>J. Carstensen</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=4.440');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.450"></a>
<p><h3>4.450[J] Computational Structural Design and Optimization
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1c.html#1.575">1.575[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Research seminar focusing on cutting-edge applications of computation for creative, early-stage structural design and optimization for architecture. Incorporates computational design fundamentals, including problem parameterization and formulation; design space exploration strategies, including interactive, heuristic, and gradient-based optimization; and computational structural analysis methods, including the finite element method, graphic statics, and approximation techniques. Case studies introduce and investigate a range of historical and contemporary examples of structural optimization in theory and practice.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.462"></a>
<p><h3>4.462 Building Structural Systems I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m1a.html#1.056">1.056[J]</A>, <A HREF="m4d.html#4.440">4.440[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-2-4
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4440">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4440</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-333</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>W EVE (4-6 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-134</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the design and behavior of large-scale structures and structural materials. Emphasizes the development of structural form and the principles of structural design. Introduces design methods for timber, masonry, concrete, and steel applied to long-span roof systems, bridges, and high-rise buildings. Includes environmental assessment of structural systems and materials. Laboratory to solve structural problems by building and testing simple models. Graduate and undergraduate students have separate lab sections.
<br>Staff<br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=4.462');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
<a name="4.463"></a>
<p><h3>4.463 Building Structural Systems II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4d.html#4.440">4.440</a>, <a href="m4d.html#4.462">4.462</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-2-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Addresses advanced structures, exterior envelopes, and contemporary production technologies. Continues the exploration of structural elements and systems, expanding to include more complex determinate, indeterminate, long-span, and high-rise systems. Topics include reinforced concrete, steel and engineered-wood design, and an introduction to tensile systems. The contemporary exterior envelope is discussed with an emphasis on the classification of systems,  performance attributes, and analysis techniques, material specifications and novel construction technologies.
<br><I>C. Mueller</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.464"></a>
<p><h3>4.464 Environmental Technologies in Buildings
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4d.html#4.401">4.401</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-2-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the study of the thermal and luminous behavior of buildings. Examines the basic scientific principles underlying these phenomena and introduces students to a range of technologies and analysis techniques for designing comfortable indoor environments. Challenges students to apply these techniques and explore the role energy and light can play in shaping architecture. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.481"></a>
<p><h3>4.481 Building Technology Seminar
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-1
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Fundamental research methodologies and ongoing investigations in building tehnology to support the development of student research projects. Topics drawn from low energy building design and thermal comfort, building systems analysis and control, daylighting, structural design and analysis, novel building materials and construction techniques and resource dynamics. Organized as a series of two- and three-week sessions that consider topics through readings, discussions, design and analysis projects, and student presentations.
<br><I>L. Norford</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.488"></a>

<p><h3>4.S40 Special Subject: Building Technology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department

<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">

<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
