<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Course 4: Architecture<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/"><i>Course 4 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course4.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=4&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=+++4&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4a.html">Architecture Design</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4b.html">Architecture Studies</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4c.html">Art, Culture and Technology</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4d.html">Building Technology</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>Computation</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4f.html">History, Theory and Criticism of Architecture and Art</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4g.html">Thesis and UROP</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<h2>Computation</h2>
<a name="4.500"></a>
<p><h3>4.500 Introduction to Design Computing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4e.html#4.512">4.512</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-2-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces 3-D CAD modeling to students with little or no experience in design or computation. Teaches surface, solid and mesh modeling techniques combined with a variety of modeling applications, from 3D printing to CNC fabrication and 3D rendering. Includes weekly modeling assignments leading up to a final project. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version. Enrollment limited; preference to Course 4 majors and minors.
<br><I>L. Sass</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.501"></a>
<p><h3>4.501 Creative Design Prototyping
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4e.html#4.500">4.500</a>
<br>Units: 2-2-8
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4501">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4501</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=N52">N52-399</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to digital fabrication and online presentation as a single design process. Project-based class that integrates iterative design on paper with physical prototyping across many scales. Hands on learning of fabrication lab equipment integrated with design studio. It starts with machine learning through exercises quickly moving to a stepped design to production process: 3D printings, CNC machining and robotic finishing. The final product is an individually designed and fabricated functional piece of furniture. Preference to Course 4 majors and minors.
<br><I>L. Sass</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.502"></a>
<p><h3>4.502 Advanced Visualization: Architecture in Motion Graphics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4e.html#4.562">4.562</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4e.html#4.500">4.500</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Advanced projects in architectural visualization with an emphasis on the use of computer graphics animation and video production media. Workshop introduces advanced visualization software and teaches exploration of spatial expressions in motion graphics format. Students review and discuss selected literature and video materials on architecture and film.   Additional work required of students taking the graduate version. Preference to Course 4 majors and minors.
<br><I>T. Nagakura</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.504"></a>
<p><h3>4.504 Design Scripting
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4e.html#4.564">4.564</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4e.html#4.500">4.500</a>
<br>Units: 2-2-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces fundamental ideas of computer programming and demonstrates their application to the process of visual and spatial design. Teaches methods for algorithmically modeling visual and spatial forms, evaluating their conditions, building interface, and processing formal data for prototyping, manufacturing, rendering, and other design tools. Proceeds through a sequence of scripting exercises in application programming environments. Each exercise requires a student to articulate computational tasks in the context of a design, and to write codes that produce graphic solutions. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.507"></a>
<p><h3>4.507 Introduction to Building Information Modeling in Architecture
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4e.html#4.567">4.567</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4507">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4507</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-246</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-246</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Addresses fundamental methods, theories, and practices that engage contemporary modeling tools in the context of architectural design. Introduces selected academic and professional topics through lectures, demonstrations, and  assignments. Topics include parametric modeling, component types and assembly, prototyping, scripting, and simulations. Initiates intellectual explorations in the use of building information modeling in research projects and design practices. Additional work required of students taking graduate version.
<br><I>T. Nagakura</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.511"></a>
<p><h3>4.511 Advanced Projects in Digital Fabrication
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4511">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4511</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>F9-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=N51">N51-350</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Independent projects in the study of digital fabrication as it relates to architecture design. Students propose a project within one of the following areas of investigation: new materials, software design for makers, fabrication based modeling, robotic fabrication.
<br><I>L. Sass</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.512"></a>
<p><h3>4.512 Introduction to Design Computing
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4e.html#4.500">4.500</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-2-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces 3-D CAD modeling to students with little or no experience in design or computation. Teaches surface, solid and mesh modeling techniques combined with a variety of modeling applications, from 3D printing to CNC fabrication and 3D rendering. Includes weekly modeling assignments leading up to a final project. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version. Enrollment limited
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.520"></a>
<p><h3>4.520 Visual Computing I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4e.html#4.521">4.521</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4520">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4520</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T9.30-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-231</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces a visual-perceptual, rule-based approach to design using shape grammars. Covers grammar fundamentals through lectures and in-class, exercises. Focuses on shape grammar applications, from stylistic analysis to creative design, through presentations of past applications and through short student exercises and projects. Presents computer programs for automating shape grammars. Additional work required of students taking graduate version.
<br><I>T. Knight</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
<a name="4.521"></a>
<h3>4.521 Visual Computing I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4e.html#4.520">4.520</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4520">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4520</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T9.30-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-231</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces a visual-perceptual, rule-based approach to design using shape grammars. Covers grammar fundamentals through lectures and in-class, exercises. Focuses on shape grammar applications, from stylistic analysis to creative design, through presentations of past applications and through short student exercises and projects. Presents computer programs for automating shape grammars. Additional work required of students taking graduate version.
<br>Staff<br>No required or recommended textbooks
<a name="4.522"></a>
<p><h3>4.522 Visual Computing II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4e.html#4.523">4.523</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4e.html#4.520">4.520</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces advanced topics in shape grammar theory and applications. Includes an introductory component on shape grammars for students new to the area. Discusses generalizations of the shape grammar formalism that provide alternative ways of computing and representing designs. These include parametric grammars and parametric design, parallel grammars, and color grammars. Presents material through lectures and in-class, applied exercises. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.523"></a>
<h3>4.523 Visual Computing II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4e.html#4.522">4.522</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4e.html#4.520">4.520</a>, <a href="m4e.html#4.521">4.521</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces advanced topics in shape grammar theory and applications. Includes an introductory component on shape grammars for students new to the area. Discusses generalizations of the shape grammar formalism that provide alternative ways of computing and representing designs. These include parametric grammars and parametric design, parallel grammars, and color grammars. Presents material through lectures and in-class, applied exercises. Additional work required of graduate students.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.540"></a>
<p><h3>4.540 Introduction to Shape Grammars I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>An in-depth introduction to shape grammars and their applications in architecture and related areas of design. Shapes in the algebras Ui j, in the algebras Vi j and Wi j incorporating labels and weights, and in algebras formed as composites of these. Rules and computations, shape and structure, designs.
<br><I>G. Stiny</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.541"></a>
<h3>4.541 Introduction to Shape Grammars II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4e.html#4.540">4.540</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4541">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4541</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M9.30-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-242</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>An in-depth introduction to shape grammars and their applications in architecture and related areas of design. Shapes in the algebras Ui j, in the algebras Vi j and Wi j incorporating labels and weights, and in algebras formed as composites of these. Rules and computations. Shape and structure. Designs.
<br><I>G. Stiny</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.542"></a>
<p><h3>4.542 Background to Shape Grammars
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4e.html#4.541">4.541</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4542">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4542</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T9.30-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-232</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>An advanced examination of the shape grammar formalism and its relationship to some key issues in a variety of other fields, including art and design, philosophy, history and philosophy of science, linguistics and psychology, literature and literary studies, logic and mathematics, and artificial intelligence. Student presentations and discussion of selected readings are encouraged. Topics vary from year to year. Can be repeated with permission of instructor.
<br><I>G. Stiny</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.550"></a>
<p><h3>4.550 Computational Design Lab
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4e.html#4.570">4.570</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><b>4.550:</b> <a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4550">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4550</a>
<br><b>4.550:</b> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>M11-2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-144</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>T EVE (7-8.30 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-329</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides students with an opportunity to explore projects that engage real world problems concerning spatial design, technology, media, and society. In collaboration with industry partners and public institutions, students identify topical issues and problems, and also explore and propose solutions through the development of new ideas, theories, tools, and prototypes. Industry and academic collaborators act as a source of expertise, and as clients and critics of projects developed during the term. General theme of workshop varies by semester or year. Open to students from diverse backgrounds in architecture and other design-related areas. Additional work required of students taking graduate version.
<br><I>T. Nagakura</I><br><b>4.550:</b> No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.552"></a>
<p><h3>4.552 Workshop in Architectural Computation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Opportunity for exploration of a topic in computation through research-focused design projects or exercises.  Registration subject to prior arrangement of topic and supervision by staff.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.553"></a>
<h3>4.553 Workshop in Architectural Computation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Opportunity for exploration of a topic in computation through research-focused design projects or exercises. Registration subject to prior arrangement of topic and supervision by staff.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.557"></a>
<p><h3>4.557[J] City Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mMASa.html#MAS.552">MAS.552[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i>  <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on architectural and mobility interventions that respond to changing patterns of living, working, and transport. Emphasizes mass-customized housing, autonomous parking, charging infrastructure, and shared-use networks of lightweight electric vehicles (LEVs). Students work in small teams and are lead by researchers from the Changing Places group. Projects focus on the application of these ideas to case study cities and may include travel. Invited guests from academia and industry participate. Repeatable for credit with permission of instructor.
<br><I>K. Larson, R. Chin</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.562"></a>
<p><h3>4.562 Advanced Visualization: Architecture in Motion Graphics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4e.html#4.502">4.502</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Advanced projects in architectural visualization with an emphasis on the use of computer graphics animation and video production media. Introduces advanced visualization software and teaches exploration of spatial expressions in motion graphics format. Students review and discuss selected literature and video materials on architecture and film. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.564"></a>
<p><h3>4.564 Design Scripting
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4e.html#4.504">4.504</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-2-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces fundamental ideas of computer programming and demonstrates their application to the process of visual and spatial design. Teaches methods for algorithmically modeling visual and spatial forms, evaluating their conditions, building interface, and processing formal data for prototyping, manufacturing, rendering, and other design tools. Proceeds through a sequence of scripting exercises in application programming environments. Each exercise requires a student to articulate computational tasks in the context of a design, and to write codes that produce graphic solutions. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.566"></a>
<p><h3>4.566 Advanced Projects in Digital Media
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4e.html#4.562">4.562</a>, <a href="m4e.html#4.564">4.564</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4566">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4566</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W EVE (5-7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=7">7-304</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develop independent projects in the study of digital media as it relates to architectural design. Students propose a project topic such as digital design tool, modeling and visualization, motion graphics, design knowledge representation and media interface.
<br>Fall: <I>T. Nagakura</I><br>Spring: <I>T. Nagakura</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.567"></a>
<p><h3>4.567 Introduction to Building Information Modeling in Architecture
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4e.html#4.507">4.507</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4507">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4507</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-246</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-246</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Addresses fundamental methods, theories, and practices that engage contemporary modeling tools in the context of architectural design. Introduces selected academic and professional topics through lectures, demonstrations, and  assignments. Topics include parametric modeling, component types and assembly, prototyping, scripting, and simulations. Initiates intellectual explorations in the use of building information modeling in research projects and design practices. Additional work required of students taking graduate version.
<br>Staff<br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.569"></a>
<p><h3>4.569[J] Designing Interactions
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.834">CMS.834[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mCMSa.html#CMS.634">CMS.634</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i> <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the future of mobile interactions and pervasive computing, taking into consideration design, technological, social and business aspects. Discusses theoretical works on human-computer interaction, mobile media and interaction design, and covers research and design methods. Students work in multidisciplinary teams and participate in user-centric design projects aimed to study, imagine and prototype concepts illustrating the future of mobile applications and ubiquitous computing. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Repeatable for credit with permission of instructor. Limited to 12.
<br>Fall: <I>F. Casalegno</I><br>Spring: <I>F. Casalegno</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.570"></a>
<p><h3>4.570 Computational Design Lab
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4e.html#4.550">4.550</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4550">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4550</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M11-2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-144</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>T EVE (7-8.30 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-329</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides students with an opportunity to explore projects that engage real world problems concerning spatial design, technology, media, and society. In collaboration with industry partners and public institutions, students identify topical issues and problems, and also explore and propose solutions through the development of new ideas, theories, tools, and prototypes. Industry and academic collaborators act as a source of expertise, and as clients and critics of projects developed during the term. General theme of workshop varies by semester or year. Open to students from diverse backgrounds in architecture and other design-related areas. Additional work required of students taking graduate version.
<br>Staff<br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.580"></a>
<p><h3>4.580 Inquiry into Computation and Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the varied nature, history and practice of computation in design through lectures, readings, small projects, discussions, and guest visits by Computation group faculty and others. Topics may vary from year to year.  Aims to help students develop a critical awareness of different approaches to and assumptions about computation in design beyond the specifics of techniques and tools, and to open avenues for further research.
<br><I>T. Knight</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.581"></a>

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to traditions of research in design and computation scholarship.

</p><!--end-->

<a name="4.S54"></a>
<h3>4.S54 Special Subject: Architectural Computation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar or lecture on a topic in computation and design that is not covered in the regular curriculum. Requires original research and presentation of oral and written reports and/or design projects, varying at the discretion of the instructor.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.S55"></a>

<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar or lecture on a topic in computation and design that is not covered in the regular curriculum. Requires original research and presentation of oral and written reports and/or design projects, varying at the discretion of the instructor.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->

<h1 align="center">Course 4: Architecture<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/"><i>Course 4 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course4.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=4&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=+++4&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4a.html">Architecture Design</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4b.html">Architecture Studies</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4c.html">Art, Culture and Technology</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4d.html">Building Technology</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4e.html">Computation</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>History, Theory and Criticism of Architecture and Art</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m4g.html">Thesis and UROP</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<h2>History, Theory and Criticism of Architecture and Art</h2>
<a name="4.601"></a>
<p><h3>4.601 Introduction to Art History
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the history and interpretation of western art that explores painting, graphic arts and sculpture from the Renaissance to the present. Engages diverse methodological perspectives to examine changing conceptions of art and the artist, and to investigate the plural meaning of artworks within the larger contexts of culture and history. Subject includes trips to local museums.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.602"></a>
<p><h3>4.602 Modern Art and Mass Culture
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4f.html#4.652">4.652</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4602">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4602</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-133</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-216</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-231</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to theories of modernism and postmodernism and their related forms (roughly 18th century to present) in art and design. Focuses on how artists use the tension between fine art and mass culture to critique both. Examines visual art in a range of genres, from painting to design objects and "relational aesthetics." Works of art are viewed in their interaction with advertising, caricature, comics, graffiti, television, fashion, "primitive" art, propaganda, and networks on the internet. Additional work required of students taking graduate version.
<br><I>R. Uchill</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=4.602');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.603"></a>
<p><h3>4.603 Understanding Modern Architecture
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4f.html#4.604">4.604</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines modern architecture, art, and design in the context of the political, economic, aesthetic, and cultural changes that occurred in the twentieth century. Presents foundational debates about social and technological aspects of modern architecture and the continuation of those debates into contemporary architecture. Incorporates varied techniques of historical and theoretical analysis to interpret exemplary objects, buildings, and cities of modernity. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version. Preference to Course 4 majors and minors.
<br><I>T. Hyde</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.604"></a>
<h3>4.604 Understanding Modern Architecture
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4f.html#4.603">4.603</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines modern architecture, art, and design in the context of the political, economic, aesthetic, and cultural changes that occurred in the twentieth century. Presents foundational debates about social and technological aspects of modern architecture and the continuation of those debates into contemporary architecture. Incorporates varied techniques of historical and theoretical analysis to interpret exemplary objects, buildings, and cities of modernity. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version. Preference to Course 4 majors.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.605"></a>
<p><h3>4.605 A Global History of Architecture
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4f.html#4.650">4.650</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4605">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4605</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-133</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-216</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-216</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an outline of the history of architecture and urbanism from ancient times to the early modern period. Analyzes buildings as the products of culture and in relation to the special problems of architectural design. Stresses the geopolitical context of buildings and in the process familiarizes students with buildings, sites and cities from around the world. Additional work required of graduate students.
<br><I>M. Jarzombek</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=4.605');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.606"></a>
<p><h3>4.606 Visual Perception and Art
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces visual perception from neurological, cultural, and artistic vantage points. Examines aspects of visual culture ranging from body adornment to public spaces, and from logotypes to moving images. Topics range from ritual space to forensics to machine-aided vision (cameras, radar devices, robotic scanners). Designed to develop skills in visual analysis and interpretation through lectures, oral presentations, field trips, and written essays. Enrollment limited.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.607"></a>
<p><h3>4.607 Thinking About Architecture: In History and At Present
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m4f.html#4.645">4.645</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies the interrelationship of theory, history, and practice. Looks at theory not as specialized discourse relating only to architecture, but as touching on many issues, whether they be cultural, aesthetic, philosophical, or professional. Topics and examples are chosen from a wide range of materials, from classical antiquity to today.
<br><I>M. Jarzombek</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.608"></a>
<p><h3>4.608 Seminar in the History of Art and Architecture
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4f.html#4.609">4.609</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examination of historical method in art and/or architecture, focusing on periods and problems determined by the research interest of the faculty member leading the seminar. Emphasizes critical reading and viewing and direct tutorial guidance. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version. Limited to 15.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.609"></a>
<p><h3>4.609 Seminar in the History of Art and Architecture
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4f.html#4.608">4.608</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examination of historical method in art and/or architecture, focusing on periods and problems determined by the research interest of the faculty member leading the seminar. Emphasizes critical reading and viewing and direct tutorial guidance. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version. Limited to 15.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.610"></a><a name="4.611"></a>
<p><h3>4.610 Civic Islamic Architecture
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4f.html#4.611">4.611</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>In-depth analysis of selected examples of architecture in the Islamic world from the 7th to the 21st century. Examines the effects of politics, culture, religion, technology, and fashion on the formation and development of Islamic architectural traditions and situates them diachronically and synchronically in world context. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.610"></a><a name="4.611"></a>
<h3>4.611 Civic Islamic Architecture
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4f.html#4.610">4.610</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>In-depth analysis of selected examples of architecture in the Islamic world from the 7th to the 21st century. Examines the effects of politics, culture, religion, technology, and fashion on the formation and development of Islamic architectural traditions and situates them diachronically and synchronically in world context. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.612"></a>
<p><h3>4.612 Islamic Architecture and the Environment
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies how Islamic architecture, landscape architecture, and urban planning reflect and transform environmental processes in various regions and climates of the Islamic world, from Andalusia to Southeast Asia, with an emphasis on South Asia, Central Asia, and the Middle East. Using systematic approaches to environmental data collection and analysis, examines strategies behind the design of selected architectural elements and landscape design types, ranging in scale from the fountain to the garden, courtyard, city, and agrarian region. Critically explores cultural interpretations of Islamic environmental design (e.g., paradise gardens), as they developed over time in ways that enrich, modify, or obscure their historical significance.
<br><I>J. Wescoat</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.614"></a>
<p><h3>4.614 Building Islam
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the history of Islamic architecture and culture spanning fifteen centuries on three continents - Asia, Africa, Europe. Students study a number of representative examples, from the 7th century House of the Prophet to the current high-rises of Dubai, in conjunction with their urban, social, political, and intellectual environments at the time of their construction.
<br><I>N. Rabbat</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.616"></a>
<p><h3>4.616 Selected Topics on Culture and Architecture
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><a href="https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4616">https://architecture.mit.edu/subject/spring-2018-4616</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-216</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar on how culture interacts with architecture. Analyzes architecture as a conveyor of messages that transcend stylistic, formal, and iconographic concerns to include an assessment of disciplinary, political, ideological, social, and cultural factors. Critically reviews methodologies and theoretical premises of studies on culture and meaning.  Focuses on examples from Islamic history and establishes historical and theoretical frameworks for investigation.
<br><I>N. Rabbat</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.617"></a>
<p><h3>4.617 Topics in Islamic Urbanism
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar on selected topics from the history of Islamic urbanism. Examines patterns of settlement, urbanization, development, and architectural production in various places and periods, ranging from the formative period in the 7th century to the new cities emerging today. Discusses the leading factors in shaping and transforming urban forms, design imperatives, cultural and economic structures, and social and civic attitudes. Critically analyzes the body of literature on Islamic urbanism. Research paper required.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.619"></a>
<p><h3>4.619 Historiography of Islamic Architecture
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Critical review of literature on Islamic art and architecture in the last two centuries. Analyzes the cultural, disciplinary, and theoretical contours of the field and highlights the major figures that have influenced its evolution. Challenges the tacit assumptions and biases of standard studies of Islamic art and architecture and addresses historiographic and critical questions concerning how knowledge of a field is defined, produced, and reproduced.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.621"></a>
<p><h3>4.621 Orientalism and Representation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar on the politics of representation with special focus on Orientalist traditions in architecture, art, literature, and scholarship. Critically analyzes pivotal texts, projects, and artworks that reflected the encounters between the West and the Orient from Antiquity to the present. Discusses how political, ideological, and religious attitudes informed the construction and reproduction of Western knowledge about the Islamic world as well as revisionist Eastern self-representations. Research paper required.
<br><I>N. Rabbat</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.622"></a>
<p><h3>4.622 Islamic Gardens and Geographies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4f.html#4.623">4.623</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar focuses on the historical geography of Islamic gardens, from Andalusia to Southeast Asia, with an emphasis on the Indian subcontinent. Critically engages evidence from archaeological, art historical, and cartographic sources, and explores strategies for generating integrative accounts of historical landscapes. Topics include gardens, cities, cultural landscapes, and political territories, along with their contemporary significance for cultural heritage conservation and design. Additional work required of graduate students. Limited to 15.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.623"></a>
<p><h3>4.623 Islamic Gardens and Geographies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4f.html#4.622">4.622</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i> <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">

Critically engages evidence from archaeological, art historical, and cartographic sources, and explores strategies for generating integrative accounts of historical landscapes. <a name="4.625"></a>
<p><h3>4.625[J] Water Planning, Policy, and Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.378">11.378[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on water in environmental planning, policy, and design. Draws together faculty and students who are working on water-related research projects to develop and maintain a current perspective on the field from the site to metropolitan and international scales. Limited to 15.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.633"></a>
<p><h3>4.633 Locating Capitalism: Producing Cities and Objects
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores what defines the parameters of a profit economy in historic Europe. Discusses major interpretive frameworks that historically have guided scholarship in architectural, art, and economic history.  Traces the core themes of commodification, production, and consumption - analyzing the relevance of studies on pre- and early modern globalization - to the culture and time under consideration. Can be taken for 9 or 12 units.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.634"></a>
<p><h3>4.634 Early Modern Architecture and Art
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4f.html#4.635">4.635</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents a history, from the 14th through the early 17th century, of architectural practice and design, as well as visual culture in Europe with an emphasis on Italy. Topics include the production and reception of buildings and artworks; the significance of a reinvigorated interest in antiquity; and representation of the individual, the state, and other institutions.Examines a variety of interpretive methods. Graduate students are expected to complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.635"></a>
<h3>4.635 Early Modern Architecture and Art
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4f.html#4.634">4.634</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">

Topics include the production and reception of buildings and artworks; the significance of a reinvigorated interest in antiquity; and representation of the individual, the state, and other institutions.Examines a variety of interpretive methods. <a name="4.636"></a>
<p><h3>4.636 Topics in Western Medieval Architecture and Art
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4f.html#4.637">4.637</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Investigates architecture and art in medieval Europe, including significant monuments, art objects, themes, and developments from late antiquity through the rise of European cities in the 13th century. Considers a variety of media, ranging from stone- and metalwork to parchment and glass. Topics include sacred places and spaces; pilgrimage; relics and souvenirs; iconoclasm; questions of materiality, agency, and the power associated with objects; nature and magic; visions; medieval conceptions of temporality; and the construct of feudalism. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>L. Jacobi</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.637"></a>
<p><h3>4.637 Topics in Western Medieval Architecture and Art
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)

Considers a variety of media, ranging from stone- and metalwork to parchment and glass. Topics include sacred places and spaces; pilgrimage; relics and souvenirs; iconoclasm; questions of materiality, agency, and the power associated with objects; nature and magic; visions; medieval conceptions of temporality; and the construct of feudalism. <a name="4.640"></a>
<p><h3>4.640 Advanced Study in Critical Theory of Architecture
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">

<br><I>M. Jarzombek</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.641"></a>
<p><h3>4.641 19th-Century Art
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassA.gif" alt="HASS Arts" title="HASS Arts" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4f.html#4.644">4.644</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Survey of visual culture from the late 18th century to 1900 with an emphasis on Western Europe and its global points of contact. Topics include art and revolution, empire and its image, mythologies of the artist, gender and representation, public exhibitions, the dealer/critic system, and the emergence of the avant-garde. Strikes a balance between historical and contemporary critical perspectives to assess art's engagement with social and political experience of modernity. Additional work required of students taking the graduate version.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="4.644"></a>
<h3>4.644 19th-Century Art
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m4f.html#4.641">4.641</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Survey of visual culture from the late 18th century to 1900 with an emphasis on Western Europe and its global points of contact. Topics include art and revolution, empire and its image, mythologies of the artist, gender and representation, public exhibitions, the dealer/critic system, and the emergence of the avant-garde. Strikes a balance between historical and contemporary critical perspectives to assess art's engagement with social and political experience of modernity.
