<h2>Undergraduate Laboratory Subjects</h2>
<a name="6.100"></a>
<p><h3>6.100 Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Project
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Individual experimental work related to electrical engineering and computer science. Student must make arrangements with a project supervisor and file a proposal endorsed by the supervisor. Departmental approval required. Written report to be submitted upon completion of work.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Hunter</I><br>IAP: <I>A. Hunter</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Hunter</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.101"></a>
<p><h3>6.101 Introductory Analog Electronics Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.002">6.002</a>
<br>Units: 2-9-1
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-304</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introductory experimental laboratory explores the design, construction, and debugging of analog electronic circuits. Lectures and laboratory projects in the first half of the course investigate the performance characteristics of semiconductor devices (diodes, BJTs, and MOSFETs) and functional analog building blocks, including single-stage amplifiers, op amps, small audio amplifier, filters, converters, sensor circuits, and medical electronics (ECG, pulse-oximetry). Projects involve design, implementation, and presentation in an environment similar to that of industry engineering design teams. Instruction and practice in written and oral communication provided. Opportunity to simulate real-world problems and solutions that involve tradeoffs and the use of engineering judgment.
<br><I>G. Hom</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.111"></a>
<p><h3>6.111 Introductory Digital Systems Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.002">6.002</a> or <a href="m16a.html#16.004">16.004</a>
<br>Units: 3-7-2
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Lectures and labs on digital logic, flip flops, PALs, FPGAs, counters, timing, synchronization, and finite-state machines prepare students for the design and implementation of a final project of their choice: games, music, digital filters, wireless communications, video, or graphics. Extensive use of Verilog for describing and implementing digital logic designs.
<br><I>G. Hom</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.115"></a>
<p><h3>6.115 Microcomputer Project Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6a.html#6.1151">6.1151</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.002">6.002</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.004">6.004</a>, or <a href="m6a.html#6.007">6.007</a>
<br>Units: 3-6-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-101</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-101</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces analysis and design of embedded systems. Microcontrollers provide adaptation, flexibility, and real-time control. Emphasizes construction of complete systems, including a five-axis robot arm, a fluorescent lamp ballast, a tomographic imaging station (e.g., a CAT scan), and a simple calculator. Presents a wide range of basic tools, including software and development tools, programmable system on chip, peripheral components such as A/D converters, communication schemes, signal processing techniques, closed-loop digital feedback control, interface and power electronics, and modeling of electromechanical systems. Includes a sequence of assigned projects, followed by a final project of the student's choice, emphasizing creativity and uniqueness. Provides instruction in written and oral communication. To satisfy the independent inquiry component of this subject, students expand the scope of their laboratory project.
<br><I>S. B. Leeb</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=6.115');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.1151"></a>
<p><h3>6.1151 Microcomputer Project Laboratory - Independent Inquiry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6a.html#6.115">6.115</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.002">6.002</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.004">6.004</a>, or <a href="m6a.html#6.007">6.007</a>
<br>Units: 3-9-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-101</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-101</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces analysis and design of embedded systems. Microcontrollers provide adaptation, flexibility, and real-time control. Emphasizes construction of complete systems, including a five-axis robot arm, a fluorescent lamp ballast, a tomographic imaging station (e.g., a CAT scan), and a simple calculator. Presents a wide range of basic tools, including software and development tools, programmable system on chip, peripheral components such as A/D converters, communication schemes, signal processing techniques, closed-loop digital feedback control, interface and power electronics, and modeling of electromechanical systems. Includes a sequence of assigned projects, followed by a final project of the student's choice, emphasizing creativity and uniqueness. Provides instruction in written and oral communication.  Students taking independent inquiry version 6.1151 expand the scope of their laboratory project.
<br><I>S. Leeb</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.117"></a>
<p><h3>6.117 Introduction to Electrical Engineering Lab Skills
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-3-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces basic electrical engineering concepts, components, and laboratory techniques. Covers analog integrated circuits, power supplies, and digital circuits. Lab exercises provide practical experience in constructing projects using multi-meters, oscilloscopes, logic analyzers, and other tools. Includes a project in which students build a circuit to display their own EKG. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>G. Hom</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.123"></a>
<p><h3>6.123[J] Bioinstrumentation Project Lab
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m20a.html#20.345">20.345[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, and <a href="m2a.html#2.004">2.004</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a>; or <a href="m20a.html#20.309">20.309</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-7-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TRF12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-336</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TBA</i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>In-depth examination of instrumentation design, principles and techniques for studying biological systems, from single molecules to entire organisms. Lectures cover optics, advanced microscopy techniques, electronics for biological measurement, magnetic resonance imaging, computed tomography, MEMs, microfluidic devices, and limits of detection. Students select two lab exercises during the first half of the semester and complete a final design project in the second half. Lab emphasizes design process and skillful realization of a robust system. Enrollment limited; preference to Course 20 majors and minors.
<br><I>E. Boyden, A. Jasanoff, P. So, M. Jonas, J. Sutton, S. Wasserman</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.129"></a>
<p><h3>6.129[J] Biological Circuit Engineering Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m20a.html#20.129">20.129[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 2-8-2
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-121</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>MW1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-077</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students assemble individual genes and regulatory elements into larger-scale circuits; they experimentally characterize these circuits in yeast cells using quantitative techniques, including flow cytometry, and model their results computationally. Emphasizes concepts and techniques to perform independent experimental and computational synthetic biology research. Discusses current literature and ongoing research in the field of synthetic biology. Instruction and practice in oral and written communication provided. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>J. Niles, R. Weiss</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.131"></a>
<p><h3>6.131 Power Electronics Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6a.html#6.1311">6.1311</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.002">6.002</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a>, or <a href="m6a.html#6.007">6.007</a>
<br>Units: 3-6-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the design and construction of power electronic circuits and motor drives.  Laboratory exercises include the construction of drive circuitry for an electric go-cart, flash strobes, computer power supplies, three-phase inverters for AC motors, and resonant drives for lamp ballasts and induction heating. Basic electric machines introduced include DC, induction, and permanent magnet motors, with drive considerations. Provides instruction in written and oral communication. Students taking independent inquiry version 6.1131 expand the scope of their laboratory project.
<br><I>S. B. Leeb</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.1311"></a>
<p><h3>6.1311 Power Electronics Laboratory - Independent Inquiry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6a.html#6.131">6.131</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.002">6.002</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a>, or <a href="m6a.html#6.007">6.007</a>
<br>Units: 3-9-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the design and construction of power electronic circuits and motor drives. Laboratory exercises include the construction of drive circuitry for an electric go-cart, flash strobes, computer power supplies, three-phase inverters for AC motors, and resonant drives for lamp ballasts and induction heating. Basic electric machines introduced include DC, induction, and permanent magnet motors, with drive considerations. Provides instruction in written and oral communication. To satisfy the independent inquiry component of this subject, students expand the scope of their laboratory project.
<br><I>S. Leeb</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.141"></a>
<p><h3>6.141[J] Robotics: Science and Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m16a.html#16.405">16.405[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m1a.html#1.00">1.00</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.0001">6.0001</a>; <a href="m2a.html#2.003">2.003</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.006">6.006</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.009">6.009</a>, or <a href="m16a.html#16.06">16.06</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-6-4
<br><a href="http://stellar.mit.edu/S/course/6/sp18/6.141/ ">http://stellar.mit.edu/S/course/6/sp18/6.141/ </a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-155</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>MW3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-082</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents concepts, principles, and algorithms for sensing and computation related to the physical world. Topics include motion planning, geometric reasoning, kinematics and dynamics, state estimation, tracking, map building, manipulation, human-robot interaction, fault diagnosis, and embedded system development. Students specify and design a small-scale yet complex robot capable of real-time interaction with the natural world. Students engage in extensive written and oral communication exercises. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>J. How, L. Carlone</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=6.141');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
<a name="6.146"></a>
<p><h3>6.146 Mobile Autonomous Systems Laboratory: MASLAB
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-2-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Autonomous robotics contest emphasizing technical AI, vision, mapping and navigation from a robot-mounted camera. Few restrictions are placed on materials, sensors, and/or actuators enabling teams to build robots very creatively. Teams should have members with varying engineering, programming and mechanical backgrounds. Culminates with a robot competition at the end of IAP. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>A. Hunter</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->

<a name="6.150"></a>
<p><h3>6.150 Mobile Applications Competition
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>

Lectures and labs led by experienced students and leading industry experts, covering the basics of Android development, concepts and tools to help participants build great apps. <a name="6.151"></a>
<p><h3>6.151 iOS Game Design and Development Competition
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department

<br>Units: 2-2-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to iOS game design and development for students already familiar with object-oriented programming. Provides a set of basic tools (Objective-C and Cocos2D) and exposure to real-world issues in game design. Working in small teams, students complete a final project in which they create their own iPhone game. At the end of IAP, teams present their games in competition for prizes awarded by a judging panel of gaming experts.

<a name="6.152"></a>
<p><h3>6.152[J] Micro/Nano Processing Technology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m3a.html#3.155">3.155[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-4-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the theory and technology of micro/nano fabrication. Includes lectures and laboratory sessions on basic processing techniques such as vacuum processes, lithography, diffusion, oxidation, and pattern transfer. Students fabricate solar cells, MEMS cantilevers, and microfluidic mixers. Emphasizes interrelationships between material properties and processing, device structure, and the electrical, mechanical, optical, chemical  or biological behavior of devices. Provides background for thesis work in micro/nano fabrication. Students engage in extensive written and oral communication exercises.
<br><I>J. Scholvin</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.161"></a>
<p><h3>6.161 Modern Optics Project Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6b.html#6.637">6.637</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a>
<br>Units: 3-5-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Lectures, laboratory exercises and projects on optical signal generation, transmission, detection, storage, processing and display. Topics include polarization properties of light; reflection and refraction; coherence and interference; Fraunhofer and Fresnel diffraction; holography; Fourier optics; coherent and incoherent imaging and signal processing systems; optical properties of materials; lasers and LEDs; electro-optic and acousto-optic light modulators; photorefractive and liquid-crystal light modulation; display technologies; optical waveguides and fiber-optic communication systems; photodetectors. Students may use this subject to find an advanced undergraduate project. Students engage in extensive oral and written communcation exercises. Recommended prerequisites: 6.007 or 8.03.
<br><I>C. Warde</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.163"></a>
<p><h3>6.163 Strobe Project Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-8-2
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-149</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TBA</i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Application of electronic flash sources to measurement and   photography. First half covers fundamentals of photography and   electronic flashes, including experiments on application of electronic   flash to photography, stroboscopy, motion analysis, and high-speed   videography. Students write four extensive lab reports.  In the second half, students work in small groups to select, design,   and execute independent projects in measurement or photography that apply learned techniques. Project planning and execution skills are discussed and developed over the term.  Students engage in extensive written and oral communication exercises. Enrollment limited.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Bales</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Bales</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.169"></a>

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department

<a name="6.170"></a>
<p><h3>6.170 Software Studio
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.006">6.006</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.031">6.031</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers design and implementation of software systems, using web applications as the platform. Emphasizes the role of conceptual design in achieving clarity, simplicity, and modularity. Students complete open-ended individual assignments and a major team project. Enrollment may be limited.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.172"></a>
<p><h3>6.172 Performance Engineering of Software Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.871">6.871</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.004">6.004</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.006">6.006</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.031">6.031</a>
<br>Units: 3-12-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Project-based introduction to building efficient, high-performance and scalable software systems. Topics include performance analysis, algorithmic techniques for high performance, instruction-level optimizations, vectorization, cache and memory hierarchy optimization, and parallel programming. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>C. Leiserson</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.175"></a>
<p><h3>6.175 Constructive Computer Architecture
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.004">6.004</a>
<br>Units: 3-8-1
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Illustrates a constructive (as opposed to a descriptive) approach to computer architecture. Topics include combinational and pipelined arithmetic-logic units (ALU), in-order pipelined microarchitectures, branch prediction, blocking and unblocking caches, interrupts, virtual memory support, cache coherence and multicore architectures. Labs in a modern Hardware Design Language (HDL) illustrate various aspects of microprocessor design, culminating in a term project in which students present a multicore design running on an FPGA board.
<br><I>M. Arvind</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.176"></a>
<p><h3>6.176 Pokerbots Competition
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-0-5 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Build autonomous poker players and aquire the knowledge of the game of poker. Showcase decision making skills, apply concepts in mathematics, computer science and economics.  Provides instruction in programming, game theory, probability and statistics and machine learning. Concludes with a final competition and prizes. Enrollment limited
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.177"></a>
<p><h3>6.177 Building Programming Experience in Python
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-0-5 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Preparation for 6.01 aimed to sharpen skills in program design, implementation, and debugging in Python. Programming intensive, with one short structured assignment and a supervised, but highly individual, mandatory project presentation. Intended for students with some elementary programming experience (equivalent to AP Computer Science). Enrollment limited.

<a name="6.178"></a>
<p><h3>6.178 Introduction to Software Engineering in Java
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-1-4 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers the fundamentals of Java, helping students develop intuition about object-oriented programming. Focuses on developing working software that solves real problems. Designed for students with little or no programming experience. Concepts covered useful to 6.005. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>A. Hunter</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.179"></a>
<p><h3>6.179 Introduction to C and C++
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-0 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Fast-paced introduction to the C and C++ programming languages. Intended for those with experience in other languages who have never used C or C++. Students complete daily assignments, a small-scale individual project, and a mandatory online diagnostic test. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>A. Hunter</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.182"></a>
<p><h3>6.182 Psychoacoustics Project Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-6-3
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i>  <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the methods used to measure human auditory abilities. Discusses auditory function, principles of psychoacoustic measurement, models for psychoacoustic performance, and experimental techniques. Project topics: absolute and differential auditory sensitivity, operating characteristics of human observers, span of auditory judgment, adaptive measurement procedures, and scaling sensory magnitudes. Knowledge of probability helpful. Students engage in extensive written and oral communication exercises.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.S183"></a><a name="6.S184"></a><a name="6.S185"></a><a name="6.S186"></a><a name="6.S187"></a><a name="6.S188"></a><a name="6.S189"></a><a name="6.S190"></a><a name="6.S191"></a><a name="6.S192"></a>

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.UAT">6.UAT</a>
<br>Units: 0-6-0
<br>IAP URL: <a href="http://www.eecs.mit.edu/ug/uap.html">http://www.eecs.mit.edu/ug/uap.html</a><br>Spring URL: <a href="http://www.eecs.mit.edu/ug/uap.html">http://www.eecs.mit.edu/ug/uap.html</a>

<a name="6.UAR"></a>
<p><h3>6.UAR Seminar in Undergraduate Advanced Research
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6c.html#6.UR">6.UR</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><a href="https://superurop.eecs.mit.edu/">https://superurop.eecs.mit.edu/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-123</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Instruction in effective undergraduate research, including choosing and developing a research topic, surveying previous work and publications, research topics in EECS, industry best practices, design for robustness, technical presentation, authorship and collaboration, and ethics.  Students engage in extensive written and oral communication exercises, in the context of an approved advanced research project. A total of 12 units of credit is awarded for completion of the Fall and subsequent Spring term offerings. Application required; consult EECS SuperUROP website for more information.
<br>Fall: <I>D. Freeman</I><br>Spring: <I>D. Freeman</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->

<h2>Advanced Undergraduate Subjects and Graduate Subjects by Area</h2>
<h3>Systems Science and Control Engineering</h3>
<a name="6.207"></a>
<p><h3>6.207[J] Networks
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m14a.html#14.15">14.15[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.041B">6.041B</a> or <a href="m14a.html#14.30">14.30</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-190</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-370</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Highlights common principles that permeate the functioning of diverse technological, economic and social networks. Utilizes three sets of tools for analyzing networks--random graph models, optimization, and game theory--to study informational and learning cascades; economic and financial networks; social influence networks; formation of social groups; communication networks and the Internet; consensus and gossiping; spread and control of epidemics; control and use of energy networks; and biological networks.
<br><I>M. Roozbehani, E. Sadler</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.215"></a>
<p><h3>6.215 Optimization Methods
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6a.html#6.255">6.255[J]</A>, <A HREF="m15a.html#15.093">15.093[J]</A>, <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.200">IDS.200[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the principal algorithms for linear, network, discrete, robust, nonlinear, and dynamic optimization. Emphasizes methodology and the underlying mathematical structures. Topics include the simplex method, network flow methods, branch and bound and cutting plane methods for discrete optimization, optimality conditions for nonlinear optimization, interior point methods for convex optimization, Newton's method, heuristic methods, and dynamic programming and optimal control methods. Expectations and evaluation criteria differ for students taking graduate version; consult syllabus or instructor for specific details.
<br><I>S. Shtern</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.231"></a>
<p><h3>6.231 Dynamic Programming and Stochastic Control
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.041B">6.041B</a> or <a href="m18b.html#18.600">18.600</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.100A">18.100A</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100B">18.100B</a>, or <a href="m18a.html#18.100Q">18.100Q</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/6.231/www/6231.html">http://web.mit.edu/6.231/www/6231.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Sequential decision-making via dynamic programming. Unified approach to optimal control of stochastic dynamic systems and Markovian decision problems. Applications in linear-quadratic control, inventory control, resource allocation, scheduling, and planning. Optimal decision making under perfect and imperfect state information. Certainty equivalent, open loop-feedback control, rollout, model predictive control, aggregation, and other suboptimal control methods. Infinite horizon problems: discounted, stochastic shortest path, average cost, and semi-Markov models. Value and policy iteration. Abstract models in dynamic programming. Approximate/neurodynamic programming. Simulation based methods. Discussion of current research on the solution of large-scale problems.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.241"></a>
<p><h3>6.241[J] Dynamic Systems and Control
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m16a.html#16.338">16.338[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-303</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-372</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-372</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Linear, discrete- and continuous-time, multi-input-output systems in control, related areas. Least squares and matrix perturbation problems. State-space models, modes, stability, controllability, observability, transfer function matrices, poles and zeros, and minimality. Internal stability of interconnected systems, feedback compensators, state feedback, optimal regulation, observers, and observer-based compensators. Measures of control performance, robustness issues using singular values of transfer functions. Introductory ideas on nonlinear systems. Recommended prerequisite: 6.302.
<br><I>A. Megretski</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.245"></a>
<p><h3>6.245 Multivariable Control Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.241">6.241</a> or <a href="m16a.html#16.31">16.31</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Computer-aided design methodologies for synthesis of multivariable feedback control systems. Performance and robustness trade-offs. Model-based compensators; Q-parameterization; ill-posed optimization problems; dynamic augmentation; linear-quadratic optimization of controllers; H-infinity controller design; Mu-synthesis; model and compensator simplification; nonlinear effects. Computer-aided (MATLAB) design homework using models of physical processes.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.246"></a><a name="6.247"></a>
<p><h3>6.246, 6.247 Advanced Topics in Control
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Advanced study of topics in control. Specific focus varies from year to year.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.248"></a><a name="6.249"></a>
<p><h3>6.248, 6.249 Advanced Topics in Numerical Methods
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor

<br>Advanced study of topics in numerical methods. Specific focus varies from year to year.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.251"></a>
<p><h3>6.251[J] Introduction to Mathematical Programming
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m15a.html#15.081">15.081[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to linear optimization and its extensions emphasizing both methodology and the underlying mathematical structures and geometrical ideas. Covers classical theory of linear programming as well as some recent advances in the field. Topics: simplex method; duality theory; sensitivity analysis; network flow problems; decomposition; integer programming; interior point algorithms for linear programming; and introduction to combinatorial optimization and NP-completeness.
<br><I>I. Paschalidis</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.252"></a>
<p><h3>6.252[J] Nonlinear Optimization
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m15a.html#15.084">15.084[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.100A">18.100A</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100B">18.100B</a>, or <a href="m18a.html#18.100Q">18.100Q</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-111</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F10.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-303</a>) or <i>F11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-303</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Unified analytical and computational approach to nonlinear optimization problems. Unconstrained optimization methods include gradient, conjugate direction, Newton, sub-gradient and first-order methods. Constrained optimization methods include feasible directions, projection, interior point methods, and Lagrange multiplier methods. Convex analysis, Lagrangian relaxation, nondifferentiable optimization, and applications in integer programming. Comprehensive treatment of optimality conditions and Lagrange multipliers. Geometric approach to duality theory. Applications drawn from control, communications, power systems, and resource allocation problems.
<br><I>B. Van Parys</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.254"></a>
<p><h3>6.254 Game Theory with Engineering Applications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.041B">6.041B</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to fundamentals of game theory and mechanism design with motivations for each topic drawn from engineering applications (including distributed control of wireline/wireless communication networks, transportation networks, pricing). Emphasis on the foundations of the theory, mathematical tools, as well as modeling and the equilibrium notion in different environments. Topics include normal form games, supermodular games, dynamic games, repeated games, games with incomplete/imperfect information, mechanism design, cooperative game theory, and network games.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.255"></a>
<p><h3>6.255[J] Optimization Methods
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m15a.html#15.093">15.093[J]</A>, <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.200">IDS.200[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6a.html#6.215">6.215</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the principal algorithms for linear, network, discrete, robust, nonlinear, and dynamic optimization. Emphasizes methodology and the underlying mathematical structures. Topics include the simplex method, network flow methods, branch and bound and cutting plane methods for discrete optimization, optimality conditions for nonlinear optimization, interior point methods for convex optimization, Newton's method, heuristic methods, and dynamic programming and optimal control methods. Expectations and evaluation criteria differ for students taking graduate version; consult syllabus or instructor for specific details.
<br><I>S. Shtern</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.256"></a>
<p><h3>6.256 Algebraic Techniques and Semidefinite Optimization
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.251">6.251</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.255">6.255</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i>  <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Theory and computational techniques for optimization problems involving polynomial equations and inequalities with particular, emphasis on the connections with semidefinite optimization. Develops algebraic and numerical approaches of general applicability, with a view towards methods that simultaneously incorporate both elements, stressing convexity-based ideas, complexity results, and efficient implementations. Examples from several engineering areas, in particular systems and control applications. Topics include semidefinite programming, resultants/discriminants, hyperbolic polynomials, Groebner bases, quantifier elimination, and sum of squares.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.260"></a><a name="6.261"></a>
<p><h3>6.260, 6.261 Advanced Topics in Communications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Advanced study of topics in communications. Specific focus varies from year to year.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.262"></a>
<p><h3>6.262 Discrete Stochastic Processes
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.041B">6.041B</a>, <a href="m6b.html#6.431B">6.431B</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.204">18.204</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Review of probability and laws of large numbers; Poisson counting process and renewal processes; Markov chains (including Markov decision theory), branching processes, birth-death processes, and semi-Markov processes; continuous-time Markov chains and reversibility; random walks, martingales, and large deviations; applications from queueing, communication, control, and operations research.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.263"></a>
<p><h3>6.263[J] Data-Communication Networks
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m16a.html#16.37">16.37[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.041B">6.041B</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.204">18.204</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to data networks with an analytic perspective, using  telephone networks, wireless networks, optical networks, the Internet and data centers as primary applications. Presents basic tools for modeling and performance analysis accompanied by elementary, meaningful simulations. Develops insights for large networks by means of simple approximations. Draws upon concepts from queueing theory and optimization.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.265"></a>
<p><h3>6.265[J] Advanced Stochastic Processes
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m15a.html#15.070">15.070[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6b.html#6.431B">6.431B</a>, <a href="m15a.html#15.085">15.085J</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100A">18.100A</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100B">18.100B</a>, or <a href="m18a.html#18.100Q">18.100Q</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-154</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analysis and modeling of stochastic processes. Topics include measure theoretic probability, martingales, filtration, and stopping theorems; elements of large deviations theory; Brownian motion and reflected Brownian motion; stochastic integration and Ito calculus; functional limit theorems. Applications to finance theory, insurance, queueing and inventory models.
<br><I>D. Gamarnik</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=6.265');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.267"></a>
<p><h3>6.267 Heterogeneous Networks: Architecture, Transport, Proctocols, and Management
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.041B">6.041B</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.042">6.042</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to modern heterogeneous networks and the provision of heterogeneous services. Architectural principles, analysis, algorithmic techniques, performance analysis, and existing designs are developed and applied to understand current problems in network design and architecture. Begins with basic principles of networking. Emphasizes development of mathematical and algorithmic tools; applies them to understanding network layer design from the performance and scalability viewpoint. Concludes with network management and control, including the architecture and performance analysis of interconnected heterogeneous networks. Provides background and insight to understand current network literature and to perform research on networks with the aid of network design projects.
<br><I>V. Chan</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.268"></a>
<p><h3>6.268 Network Science and Models
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.041B">6.041B</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-149</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the main mathematical models used to describe large networks and dynamical processes that evolve on networks. Static models of random graphs, preferential attachment, and other graph evolution models.  Epidemic propagation, opinion dynamics, social learning, and inference in networks. Applications drawn from social, economic, natural, and infrastructure networks, as well as networked decision systems such as sensor networks.
<br><I>P. Jaillet</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=6.268');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
</td></tr></table>
