<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://groups.csail.mit.edu/gdpgroup/6838_spring_2017.html">http://groups.csail.mit.edu/gdpgroup/6838_spring_2017.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>In-depth study of an active research topic in computer graphics. Topics change each term. Readings from the literature, student presentations, short assignments, and a programming project.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.839"></a>
<p><h3>6.839 Advanced Computer Graphics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.031">6.031</a>, <a href="m6c.html#6.837">6.837</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i>  <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A graduate level course investigates computational problems in rendering, animation, and geometric modeling.  The course draws on advanced techniques from computational geometry, applied mathematics, statistics, scientific computing and other.  Substantial programming experience required.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.840"></a>
<p><h3>6.840[J] Theory of Computation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m18a.html#18.4041">18.4041[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m18a.html#18.404">18.404</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.200">18.200</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.062">18.062J</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A more extensive and theoretical treatment of the material in 6.045J/18.400J, emphasizing computability and computational complexity theory. Regular and context-free languages. Decidable and undecidable problems, reducibility, recursive function theory. Time and space measures on computation, completeness, hierarchy theorems, inherently complex problems, oracles, probabilistic computation, and interactive proof systems. Students in Course 18 must register for the undergraduate version, 18.404.
<br><I>M. Sipser</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.841"></a>
<p><h3>6.841[J] Advanced Complexity Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m18a.html#18.405">18.405[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.404">18.404</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Current research topics in computational complexity theory. Nondeterministic, alternating, probabilistic, and parallel computation models. Boolean circuits. Complexity classes and complete sets. The polynomial-time hierarchy. Interactive proof systems. Relativization. Definitions of randomness. Pseudo-randomness and derandomizations. Interactive proof systems and probabilistically checkable proofs.
<br><I>R. Williams</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.842"></a>
<p><h3>6.842 Randomness and Computation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.046">6.046</a>, <a href="m6c.html#6.840">6.840</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>The power and sources of randomness in computation. Connections and applications to computational complexity, computational learning theory, cryptography and combinatorics. Topics include: probabilistic proofs, uniform generation and approximate counting, Fourier analysis of Boolean functions, computational learning theory, expander graphs, pseudorandom generators, derandomization.
<br><I>R. Rubinfeld</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.845"></a>
<p><h3>6.845 Quantum Complexity Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.045">6.045</a>, <a href="m6c.html#6.840">6.840</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.435">18.435</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to quantum computational complexity theory, the study of the fundamental capabilities and limitations of quantum computers. Topics include complexity classes, lower bounds, communication complexity, proofs and advice, and interactive proof systems in the quantum world; classical simulation of quantum circuits. The objective is to bring students to the research frontier.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.846"></a>
<p><h3>6.846 Parallel Computing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.004">6.004</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to parallel and multicore computer architecture and programming.  Topics include the design and implementation of multicore processors; networking, video, continuum, particle and graph applications for multicores; communication and synchronization algorithms and mechanisms; locality in parallel computations; computational models, including shared memory, streams, message passing, and data parallel; multicore mechanisms for synchronization, cache coherence, and multithreading.  Performance evaluation of multicores; compilation and runtime systems for parallel computing.  Substantial project required.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.849"></a>
<p><h3>6.849 Geometric Folding Algorithms: Linkages, Origami, Polyhedra
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.046">6.046</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://courses.csail.mit.edu/6.849/">http://courses.csail.mit.edu/6.849/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers discrete geometry and algorithms underlying the reconfiguration of foldable structures, with applications to robotics, manufacturing, and biology. Linkages made from one-dimensional rods connected by hinges: constructing polynomial curves, characterizing rigidity, characterizing unfoldable versus locked, protein folding. Folding two-dimensional paper (origami): characterizing flat foldability, algorithmic origami design, one-cut magic trick. Unfolding and folding three-dimensional polyhedra: edge unfolding, vertex unfolding, gluings, Alexandrov's Theorem, hinged dissections.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.850"></a>
<p><h3>6.850 Geometric Computing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.046">6.046</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-124</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the design and analysis of algorithms for geometric problems, in low- and high-dimensional spaces. Algorithms: convex hulls, polygon triangulation, Delaunay triangulation, motion planning, pattern matching. Geometric data structures: point location, Voronoi diagrams, Binary Space Partitions. Geometric problems in higher dimensions: linear programming, closest  pair problems. High-dimensional nearest neighbor search and low-distortion embeddings between metric spaces. Geometric algorithms for massive data sets: external memory and streaming algorithms. Geometric optimization.
<br><I>P. Indyk</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.851"></a>
<p><h3>6.851 Advanced Data Structures
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.046">6.046</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>More advanced and powerful data structures for answering several queries on the same data. Such structures are crucial in particular for designing efficient algorithms. Dictionaries; hashing; search trees. Self-adjusting data structures; linear search; splay trees; dynamic optimality. Integer data structures; word RAM. Predecessor problem; van Emde Boas priority queues; y-fast trees; fusion trees. Lower bounds; cell-probe model; round elimination. Dynamic graphs; link-cut trees; dynamic connectivity. Strings; text indexing; suffix arrays; suffix trees. Static data structures; compact arrays; rank and select. Succinct data structures; tree encodings; implicit data structures. External-memory and cache-oblivious data structures; B-trees; buffer trees; tree layout; ordered-file maintenance. Temporal data structures; persistence; retroactivity.
<br><I>E. Demaine</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.852"></a>
<p><h3>6.852[J] Distributed Algorithms
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m18a.html#18.437">18.437[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.046">6.046</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Design and analysis of concurrent algorithms, emphasizing those suitable for use in distributed networks. Process synchronization, allocation of computational resources, distributed consensus, distributed graph algorithms, election of a leader in a network, distributed termination, deadlock detection, concurrency control, communication, and clock synchronization. Special consideration given to issues of efficiency and fault tolerance. Formal models and proof methods for distributed computation.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.853"></a>
<p><h3>6.853 Topics in Algorithmic Game Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.006">6.006</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.046">6.046</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="https://stellar.mit.edu/S/course/6/sp17/6.853/index.html">https://stellar.mit.edu/S/course/6/sp17/6.853/index.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents research topics at the interface of computer science and game theory, with an emphasis on algorithms and computational complexity. Explores the types of game-theoretic tools that are applicable to computer systems, the loss in system performance due to the conflicts of interest of users and administrators, and the design of systems whose performance is robust with respect to conflicts of interest inside the system. Algorithmic focus is on algorithms for equilibria, the complexity of equilibria and fixed points, algorithmic tools in mechanism design, learning in games, and the price of anarchy.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.854"></a>
<p><h3>6.854[J] Advanced Algorithms
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m18a.html#18.415">18.415[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.041B">6.041B</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.042">6.042</a>, or <a href="m18b.html#18.600">18.600</a>; <a href="m6a.html#6.046">6.046</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>First-year graduate subject in algorithms. Emphasizes fundamental algorithms and advanced methods of algorithmic design, analysis, and implementation. Surveys a variety of computational models and the algorithms for them. Data structures, network flows, linear programming, computational geometry, approximation algorithms, online algorithms, parallel algorithms, external memory, streaming algorithms.
<br><I>D. Karger</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.856"></a>
<p><h3>6.856[J] Randomized Algorithms
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m18a.html#18.416">18.416[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6c.html#6.854">6.854J</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.041B">6.041B</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.042">6.042J</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies how randomization can be used to make algorithms simpler and more efficient via random sampling, random selection of witnesses, symmetry breaking, and Markov chains. Models of randomized computation. Data structures: hash tables, and skip lists. Graph algorithms: minimum spanning trees, shortest paths, and minimum cuts. Geometric algorithms: convex hulls, linear programming in fixed or arbitrary dimension. Approximate counting; parallel algorithms; online algorithms; derandomization techniques; and tools for probabilistic analysis of algorithms.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.857"></a>
<p><h3>6.857 Network and Computer Security
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.033">6.033</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.042">6.042J</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><a href="http://courses.csail.mit.edu/6.857/2017/">http://courses.csail.mit.edu/6.857/2017/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=54">54-100</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=54">54-100</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Emphasis on applied cryptography and may include: basic notion of systems security, crypotographic hash functions, symmetric crypotography (one-time pad, stream ciphers, block ciphers), cryptanalysis, secret-sharing, authentication codes, public-key cryptography (encryption, digital signatures), public-key attacks, web browser security, biometrics, electronic cash, viruses, electronic voting, Assignments include a group final project. Topics may vary year to year.
<br><I>R. Rivest</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=6.857');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.858"></a>
<p><h3>6.858 Computer Systems Security
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.033">6.033</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.031">6.031</a>
<br>Units: 3-6-3
<br><a href="http://css.csail.mit.edu/6.858/">http://css.csail.mit.edu/6.858/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-111</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Design and implementation of secure computer systems.  Lectures cover attacks that compromise security as well as techniques for achieving security, based on recent research papers.  Topics include operating system security, privilege separation, capabilities, language-based security, cryptographic network protocols, trusted hardware, and security in web applications and mobile phones.  Labs involve implementing and compromising a web application that sandboxes arbitrary code, and a group final project.
<br><I>N. Zeldovich</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.860"></a>
<p><h3>6.860[J] Statistical Learning Theory and Applications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9b.html#9.520">9.520[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6c.html#6.867">6.867</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.041B">6.041B</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides students with the knowledge needed to use and develop advanced machine learning solutions to challenging problems. Covers foundations and recent advances of machine learning in the framework of statistical learning theory. Focuses on regularization techniques key to high-dimensional supervised learning. Starting from classical methods such as regularization networks and support vector machines, addresses state-of-the-art techniques based on principles such as geometry or sparsity, and discusses a variety of algorithms for supervised learning, feature selection, structured prediction, and multitask learning. Also focuses on unsupervised learning of data representations, with an emphasis on hierarchical (deep) architectures.
<br><I>T. Poggio</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.861"></a>
<p><h3>6.861[J] Aspects of a Computational Theory of Intelligence
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9b.html#9.523">9.523[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Integrates neuroscience, cognitive and computer science to explore the nature of intelligence, how it is produced by the brain, and how it can be replicated in machines. Discusses an array of current research connected through an overarching theme of how it contributes to a computational account of how humans analyze dynamic visual imagery to understand objects and actions in the world.
<br><I>T. Poggio</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.862"></a>
<p><h3>6.862 Applied Machine Learning
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6a.html#6.036">6.036</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-100</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>T11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-501</a>) or <i>T1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-501</a>) or <i>T2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-501</a>) or <i>R9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-501</a>) or <i>R11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-501</a>) or <i>R1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-501</a>) or <i>R2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=34">34-501</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces principles, algorithms, and applications of machine learning from the point of view of modeling and prediction; formulation of learning problems; representation, over-fitting, generalization; clustering, classification, probabilistic modeling; and methods such as support vector machines, hidden Markov models, and Bayesian networks. Students taking graduate version complete different assignments. Meets with 6.036 when offered concurrently. Enrollment may be limited.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.863"></a>
<p><h3>6.863[J] Natural Language and the Computer Representation of Knowledge
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9b.html#9.611">9.611[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.034">6.034</a>
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br>1st mtg at 1.00 in 10-250. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW12.30-2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=6">6-120</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the relationship between the computer representation and acquisition of knowledge and the structure of human language, its acquisition, and hypotheses about its differentiating uniqueness.  Emphasizes development of analytical skills necessary to judge the computational implications of grammatical formalisms and their role in connecting human intelligence to computational intelligence. Uses concrete examples to illustrate particular computational issues in this area.
<br><I>R. Berwick</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.864"></a>
<p><h3>6.864 Advanced Natural Language Processing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.806">6.806</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.046">6.046</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the study of human language from a computational perspective, including syntactic, semantic and discourse processing models. Emphasizes machine learning methods and algorithms. Uses these methods and models in applications such as syntactic parsing, information extraction, statistical machine translation, dialogue systems, and summarization. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.865"></a>
<p><h3>6.865 Advanced Computational Photography
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.815">6.815</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.031">6.031</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents fundamentals and applications of hardware and software techniques used in digital and computational photography, with an emphasis on software methods. Provides sufficient background to implement solutions to photographic challenges and opportunities. Topics include cameras and image formation, image processing and image representations, high-dynamic-range imaging, human visual perception and color, single view 3-D model reconstruction, morphing, data-rich photography, super-resolution, and image-based rendering. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.866"></a>
<p><h3>6.866 Machine Vision
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.801">6.801</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Intensive introduction to the process of generating a symbolic description of the environment from an image. Students expected to attend the 6.801 lectures as well as occasional seminar meetings on special topics. Material presented in 6.801 is supplemented by reading from the literature. Students required to implement a project on a topic of their choice from the material covered.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.867"></a>
<p><h3>6.867 Machine Learning
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.041B">6.041B</a> or <a href="m18b.html#18.600">18.600</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Principles, techniques, and algorithms in machine learning from the point of view of statistical inference; representation, generalization, and model selection; and methods such as linear/additive models, active learning, boosting, support vector machines, non-parametric Bayesian methods, hidden Markov models, and Bayesian networks. Recommended prerequisite: 6.036.
<br><I>D. Shah</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.868"></a>
<p><h3>6.868[J] The Society of Mind
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mMASa.html#MAS.731">MAS.731[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Must have read "The Society of Mind" and "The Emotion Machine"; permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-10
<br><a href="http://web.media.mit.edu/~dustin/6.868/">http://web.media.mit.edu/~dustin/6.868/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to a theory that tries to explain how minds are made from collections of simpler processes. Treats such aspects of thinking as vision, language, learning, reasoning, memory, consciousness, ideals, emotions, and personality. Incorporates ideas from psychology, artificial intelligence, and computer science to resolve theoretical issues such as wholes vs. parts, structural vs. functional descriptions, declarative vs. procedural representations, symbolic vs. connectionist models, and logical vs. common-sense theories of learning. Enrollment limited.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.869"></a>
<p><h3>6.869 Advances in Computer Vision
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.819">6.819</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.041B">6.041B</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.042">6.042</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Advanced topics in computer vision with a focus on the use of machine learning techniques and applications in graphics and human-computer interface. Covers image representations, texture models, structure-from-motion algorithms, Bayesian techniques, object and scene recognition, tracking, shape modeling, and image databases. Applications may include face recognition, multimodal interaction, interactive systems, cinematic special effects, and photorealistic rendering. Covers topics complementary to 6.866. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.870"></a>
<p><h3>6.870 Advanced Topics in Computer Vision
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6c.html#6.801">6.801</a>, <a href="m6c.html#6.869">6.869</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar exploring advanced research topics in the field of computer vision; focus varies with lecturer. Typically structured around discussion of assigned research papers and presentations by students. Example research areas explored in this seminar include learning in vision, computational imaging techniques, multimodal human-computer interaction, biomedical imaging, representation and estimation methods used in modern computer vision.
<br><I>B. Horn</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.871"></a>
<p><h3>6.871 Performance Engineering of Software Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6a.html#6.172">6.172</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.004">6.004</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.006">6.006</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.031">6.031</a>
<br>Units: 3-12-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Project-based introduction to building efficient, high-performance and scalable software systems. Topics include performance analysis, algorithmic techniques for high performance, instruction-level optimizations, vectorization, cache and memory hierarchy optimization, and parallel programming. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.872"></a>
<p><h3>6.872[J] Biomedical Computing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mHSTb.html#HST.950">HST.950[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.034">6.034</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.036">6.036</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analyzes computational needs of clinical medicine, reviews systems and approaches that have been used to support those needs, and the relationship between clinical data and gene and protein measurements to support precision medicine. Topics include the nature of clinical data, architecture and design of healthcare information systems, privacy and security issues, medical expert systems, predictive models and machine learning from big data in healthcare, and an introduction to bioinformatics. Case studies and guest lectures describe contemporary institutions, systems, and research projects. Term project using large clinical and genomic data sets integrates classroom topics.
<br><I>P. Szolovits</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.874"></a>
<p><h3>6.874[J] Computational Systems Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.506">HST.506[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.802">6.802[J]</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.390">20.390[J]</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.490">20.490</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18b.html#18.600">18.600</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.041B">6.041B</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents advanced machine learning and algorithmic approaches for contemporary problems in biology drawing upon recent advances in the literature.   Topics include biological discovery in heterogeneous cellular populations; single cell data analysis; regulatory factor binding; motif discovery; gene expression analysis; regulatory networks (discovery, validation, data integration, protein-protein interactions, signaling, chromatin accessibility analysis); predicting phenotype from genotype; and experimental design (model validation, interpretation of interventions).  Computational methods presented include deep learning, dimensionality reduction, clustering, directed and undirected graphical models, significance testing, Dirichlet processes, and topic models. Multidisciplinary team-oriented final research project.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.875"></a>
<p><h3>6.875[J] Cryptography and Cryptanalysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m18a.html#18.425">18.425[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.046">6.046J</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-370</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A rigorous introduction to modern cryptography. Emphasis on the fundamental cryptographic primitives of public-key encryption, digital signatures, pseudo-random number generation, and basic protocols and their computational complexity requirements.
<br><I>S. Goldwasser</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.876"></a>
<p><h3>6.876 Advanced Topics in Cryptography
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6c.html#6.875">6.875</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Recent results in cryptography, interactive proofs, and cryptographic game theory.
<br><I>V. Vaikuntanathan</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.878"></a>

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>

<a name="6.901"></a>
<p><h3>6.901[J] Innovation Engineering: Moving Ideas to Impact
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m15b.html#15.359">15.359[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Designed for students to gain the perspective of a Chief Technology Officer of a start-up, large corporation, or a not-for-profit. Details the innovation process, from an idea's inception through impact in the economy, regardless of organizational setting. Explores how solutions are developed to become ready for broader market deployment. Includes testing and development of the problem-solution fit, probing of solutions for robustness, and testing of both technical and operational scaling of proposed solutions. Examines the human aspects of innovation, specifically issues of team building and readiness. Considers the broader system for innovation, including the role of key stakeholders in shaping its success in order to arrive at an impactful solution. Addresses intellectual property, the effect of regulations and social and cultural differences across varied global markets, and the personal skillset necessary to align and manage these issues.
<br><I>F. Murray</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.902"></a>
<p><h3>6.902 Engineering Innovation and Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Engineering School-Wide Elective Subject. <br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m2b.html#2.723">2.723</A>, <A HREF="m6c.html#6.902">6.902</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.662">16.662</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-1-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M EVE (7-9 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-155</a>) <b>Design:</b> <i>M EVE (9 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-155</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Project-based seminar in innovative design thinking develops students' ability to conceive, implement, and evaluate successful projects in any engineering discipline. Lectures focus on the iterative design process and techniques to enhance creative analysis. Students use this process to design and implement robust voice recognition applications using a simple web-based system. They also give presentations and receive feedback to sharpen their communication skills for high emotional and intellectual impact. Guest lectures illustrate multidisciplinary approaches to design thinking.
<br>Fall: <I>C. Kotelly</I><br>Spring: <I>C. Kotelly</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.903"></a>
<p><h3>6.903 Patents, Copyrights, and the Law of Intellectual Property
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=38">38-166</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Intensive introduction to the US law of intellectual property with major emphasis on patents, including the process of patent application and the remedies for patent infringement.  Also focuses on copyrights and provides a brief look at trademarks and trade secrets. Presents comparisons of what can and cannot be protected, and what rights the owner does and does not obtain. Highlights issues relating to information technology, biogenetic materials, and business methods. Readings include judicial opinions and statutory material. No listeners.
<br><I>S. Bauer</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.904"></a>
<p><h3>6.904 Ethics for Engineers
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Engineering School-Wide Elective Subject. <br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m1a.html#1.082">1.082</A>, <A HREF="m2c.html#2.900">2.900</A>, <A HREF="m6c.html#6.904">6.904</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.01">10.01</A>, <A HREF="m22a.html#22.014">22.014</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.9041">6.9041</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-168</a>) or <i>T3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-168</a>) or <i>T EVE (7.30-9.30 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-144</a>) or <i>W3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>) or <i>T EVE (7.30-9.30 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-156</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Integrates classical readings that provide an overview of ethics with a survey of case studies that focus on ethical problems arising in the practice of engineering. Readings taken from a variety of sources, such as Aristotle, Machiavelli, Bacon, Hobbes, Locke, the Founding Fathers, and the Bible. Case studies include written analyses and films that address engineering disasters, biotechnology, court cases, ethical codes, and the ultimate scope and aims of engineering. Students taking independent inquiry version 6.9041 expand the scope of their term project.
<br>Fall: <I>B. Trout</I><br>Spring: <I>B. Trout</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.9041"></a>
<p><h3>6.9041 Ethics for Engineers - Independent Inquiry
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m1a.html#1.082">1.082[J]</A>, <A HREF="m2c.html#2.900">2.900[J]</A>, <A HREF="m6c.html#6.904">6.904[J]</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.01">10.01[J]</A>, <A HREF="m22a.html#22.014">22.014[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-10
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-168</a>) or <i>T3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-168</a>) or <i>T EVE (7.30-9.30 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-144</a>) or <i>W3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Integrates classical readings that provide an overview of ethics with a survey of case studies that focus on ethical problems arising in the practice of engineering. Readings taken from a variety of sources, such as Aristotle, Machiavelli, Bacon, Hobbes, Locke, the Founding Fathers, and the Bible. Case studies include written analyses and films that address engineering disasters, biotechnology, court cases, ethical codes, and the ultimate scope and aims of engineering. To satisfy the independent inquiry component of this subject, students expand the scope of their term project.
<br><I>B. Trout</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.905"></a>
<p><h3>6.905 Large-scale Symbolic Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.945">6.945</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.034">6.034</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Concepts and techniques for the design and implementation of large software systems that can be adapted to uses not anticipated by the designer. Applications include compilers, computer-algebra systems, deductive systems, and some artificial intelligence applications. Covers means for decoupling goals from strategy, mechanisms for implementing additive data-directed invocation, work with partially-specified entities, and how to manage multiple viewpoints. Topics include combinators, generic operations, pattern matching, pattern-directed invocation, rule systems, backtracking, dependencies, indeterminacy, memoization, constraint propagation, and incremental refinement. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.906"></a>
<p><h3>6.906 StartMIT: Workshop for Entrepreneurs and Innovators
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.936">6.936</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Designed for students who are interested in entrepreneurship and want to explore the potential commercialization of their research project. Introduces practices for building a successful company, such as idea creation and validation, defining a value proposition, building a team, marketing, customer traction, and possible funding models. Students taking graduate version complete different assignments.
<br><I>M. Vabulas</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.907"></a>
<p><h3>6.907[J] Entrepreneurship in Engineering
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2c.html#2.913">2.913[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.933">6.933</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Immerses students in the experience of an engineer who founds a start-up company. Examines leadership, innovation, and creativity through the lens of an entrepreneur. Suitable for students interested in transforming an idea into a business or other realization for wide-scale societal impact. Covers critical aspects of validating ideas and assessing personal attributes needed to activate and lead a growing organization. Teams explore the basics of new venture creation and experimentation. Emphasizes personal skills and practical experiences. Students taking graduate version will complete additional assignments. No listeners.
<br>Fall: <I>C. Chase</I><br>Spring: <I>C. Chase</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.910"></a>

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Opportunity for independent study at the undergraduate level under regular supervision by a faculty member. Projects require prior approval.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Hunter</I><br>IAP: <I>A. Hunter</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Hunter</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.911"></a>
<p><h3>6.911 Engineering Leadership Lab
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Engineering School-Wide Elective Subject. <br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m6c.html#6.911">6.911</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.650">16.650</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.913">6.913[J]</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.667">16.667[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="m6c.html#6.912">6.912</a></I> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 0-2-1
<br><b>Lab:</b> <i>F9-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-144</a>) or <i>F1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-144</a>) or <i>F3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-144</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Exposes students to leadership frameworks, models and cases within an engineering context, in an interactive, practice-based environment, honing leadership and teamwork skills. Students participate in guided reflections on individual and team successes, and discover opportunities for improvement in controlled settings. Activities include design-implement activities, role-plays, simulations, small group discussions, and performance and peer assessments by and of other students. Content throughout the term is frequently student-driven. First year Gordon Engineering Leadership Program (GEL) students register for 6.911. Second year GEL Program students register for 6.913. Preference to students enrolled in the Bernard M. Gordon-MIT Engineering Leadership Program.
<br>Fall: <I>L. Mcgonagle</I><br>Spring: <I>L. Mcgonagle</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.912"></a>
<p><h3>6.912 Engineering Leadership
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Engineering School-Wide Elective Subject. <br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m6c.html#6.912">6.912</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.651">16.651</A>)
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="m6c.html#6.911">6.911</a></I> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 1-0-2
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M9-10.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-233</a>) or <i>M11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-233</a>) or <i>T9-10.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-233</a>) or <i>T11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-233</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Exposes students to the models and methods of engineering leadership within the contexts of conceiving, designing, implementing and operating products, processes and systems. Introduces the Capabilities of Effective Engineering Leaders, and models and theories related to the capabilities. Discusses the appropriate times and reasons to use particular models to deliver engineering success. Includes occasional guest speakers or panel discussions. May be repeated for credit once with permission of instructor. Preference to first-year students in the Gordon Engineering Leadership Program.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Magarian</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Magarian</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.913"></a>
<p><h3>6.913 Engineering Leadership Lab
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Engineering School-Wide Elective Subject. <br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m6c.html#6.913">6.913</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.667">16.667</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.911">6.911[J]</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.650">16.650[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6c.html#6.911">6.911</a>
<br>Units: 0-2-4
<br><b>Lab:</b> <i>F9-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-144</a>) or <i>F1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-144</a>) or <i>F3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-144</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Exposes students to leadership frameworks, models and cases within an engineering context, in an interactive, practice-based environment, honing leadership and teamwork skills. Students participate in guided reflections on individual and team successes, and discover opportunities for improvement in controlled settings. Activities include design-implement activities, role-plays, simulations, small group discussions, and performance and peer assessments by and of other students. Content throughout the term is frequently student-driven. First year Gordon Engineering Leadership Program (GEL) students register for 6.911. Second year GEL Program students register for 6.913. Preference to students enrolled in the second year of the Gordon-MIT Engineering Leadership Program.
<br>Fall: <I>L. Mcgonagle</I><br>Spring: <I>L. Mcgonagle</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.914"></a>
<p><h3>6.914 Project Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Engineering School-Wide Elective Subject. <br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m6c.html#6.914">6.914</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.669">16.669</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6c.html#6.911">6.911</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 1-2-1 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students attend a four-day off-site workshop where an introduction to basic principles, methods, and tools for project management in a realistic context are covered. In teams, students create a plan for a project of their choice in one of several areas, including aircraft modification, factory automation, enterprise software, flood prevention engineering, solar farm engineering, among others. Develops skills applicable to the management of complex development projects. Topics include cost-benefit analysis, resource and cost estimation, and project control and delivery, which are practiced during an experimental, team-based activity. Case studies highlight projects in both hardware/construction and software. Preference to students in the Bernard M. Gordon-MIT Engineering Leadership Program.
<br><I>O. de Weck, J. Feiler, L. McGonagle</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.915"></a>
<p><h3>6.915[J] Leading Innovation in Teams
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m16b.html#16.671">16.671[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Empowers future innovators in engineering and technology with a foundation of leadership and teamwork skills. Grounded in research but practical in focus, equips students with leadership competencies such as building self-awareness, motivating and developing others, influencing without authority, managing conflict, and communicating effectively.  Teamwork skills include how to convene, launch, and develop various types of teams, including project teams. Reviews recent advances in implementing innovations and building personal capacity for lifelong learning as a leading innovator. Enrollment limited to seating capacity of classroom. Admittance may be controlled by lottery.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.920"></a>
<p><h3>6.920 Practical Work Experience
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 0-1-0 [P/D/F]
<br>IAP URL: <a href="http://www.eecs.mit.edu/ug/programs.html#6.910">http://www.eecs.mit.edu/ug/programs.html#6.910</a><br>Spring URL: <a href="http://www.eecs.mit.edu/ug/programs.html#6.910">http://www.eecs.mit.edu/ug/programs.html#6.910</a>
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For Course 6 students participating in curriculum-related off-campus work experiences in electrical engineering or computer science. Before enrolling, students must have an employment offer from a company or organization and must find an EECS supervisor. Upon completion of the work the student must submit a letter from the employer evaluating the work accomplished, a substantive final report from the student, approved by the MIT supervisor. Subject to departmental approval. Consult Department Undergraduate Office for details on procedures and restrictions.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Hunter</I><br>IAP: <I>A. Hunter</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Hunter</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->

<a name="6.928"></a>
<p><h3>6.928[J] Leading Creative Teams
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m16b.html#16.990">16.990[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>F9.30-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-233</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Prepares students to lead teams charged with developing creative solutions in engineering and technical environments. Grounded in research but practical in focus, equips students with leadership competencies such as building self-awareness, motivating and developing others, creative problem solving, influencing without authority, managing conflict, and communicating effectively. Teamwork skills include how to convene, launch, and develop various types of teams, including project teams. Learning methods emphasize personalized and professional skill development.
<br>Fall: <I>D. Nino</I><br>Spring: <I>D. Nino</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.929"></a>
<p><h3>6.929[J] Energy Technology and Policy:  From Principles to Practice
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m5a.html#5.00">5.00[J]</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.579">10.579[J]</A>, <A HREF="m22c.html#22.813">22.813[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops analytical skills to lead a successful technology implementation with an integrated approach that combines technical, economical and social perspectives. Considers corporate and government viewpoints as well as international aspects, such as nuclear weapons proliferation and global climate issues.  Discusses technologies such as oil and gas, nuclear, solar, and energy efficiency. Limited to 100.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.930"></a>
<p><h3>6.930 Management in Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Engineering School-Wide Elective Subject. <br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m2c.html#2.96">2.96</A>, <A HREF="m6c.html#6.930">6.930</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.806">10.806</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.653">16.653</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-1-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction and overview of engineering management. Financial principles, management of innovation, technical strategy and best management practices. Case study method of instruction emphasizes participation in class discussion. Focus is on the development of individual skills and management tools. Restricted to juniors and seniors.
<br><I>J. Chun</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.933"></a>
<p><h3>6.933 Entrepreneurship in Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2c.html#2.913">2.913[J]</A>, <A HREF="m6c.html#6.907">6.907[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR EVE (7-9 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-141</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Immerses students in the experience of an engineer who founds a start-up company. Examines leadership, innovation, and creativity through the lens of an entrepreneur. Suitable for students interested in transforming an idea into a business or other realization for wide-scale societal impact. Covers critical aspects of validating ideas and assessing personal attributes needed to activate and lead a growing organization. Teams explore the basics of new venture creation and experimentation. Emphasizes personal skills and practical experiences. Students taking graduate version will complete additional assignments. No listeners.
<br><I>C. Chase</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.935"></a>
<p><h3>6.935[J] Financial Market Dynamics and Human Behavior
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m15b.html#15.481">15.481[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.401">15.401</a>, <a href="m15b.html#15.414">15.414</a>, or <a href="m15b.html#15.415">15.415</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops a new perspective on the dynamics of financial markets and the roles that human behavior and the business environment play in determining the evolution of behavior and institutions. Draws on a variety of disciplines to develop a more complete understanding of human behavior in the specific context of markets and other economic institutions. Incorporates practical applications from financial markets, the hedge fund industry, private equity, government regulation, and political economy. Students use ideas from this new perspective to formulate several new hypotheses regarding recent challenges to traditional economic thinking.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.936"></a>
<p><h3>6.936 StartMIT: Workshop for Entrepreneurs and Innovators
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.906">6.906</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Designed for students who are interested in entrepreneurship and want to explore the potential commercialization of their research project. Introduces practices for building a successful company, such as idea creation and validation, defining a value proposition, building a team, marketing, customer traction, and possible funding models. Students taking graduate version complete different assignments.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.941"></a>
<p><h3>6.941 Statistics for Research Projects: Statistical Modeling and Experiment Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-2-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Practical introduction to data analysis, statistical modeling, and experimental design, intended to provide essential skills for conducting research.   Covers basic techniques such as hypothesis-testing and regression models for both traditional experiments and newer paradignms such as evaluating simulations.  Assignments reinforce techniques through analyzing sample datasets and reading case studies. Students with research projects will be encouraged to share their experiences and project-specific questions.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.943"></a>
<p><h3>6.943[J] How to Make (Almost) Anything
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m4a.html#4.140">4.140[J]</A>, <A HREF="mMASa.html#MAS.863">MAS.863[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-9-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a practical hands-on introduction to digital fabrication, including CAD/CAM/CAE, NC machining, 3-D printing and scanning, molding and casting, composites, laser and waterjet cutting, PCB design and fabrication; sensors and actuators; mixed-signal instrumentation, embedded processing, and wired and wireless communications. Develops an understanding of these capabilities through projects using them individually and jointly to create functional systems.
<br><I>N. Gershenfeld</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.945"></a>
<p><h3>6.945 Large-scale Symbolic Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.905">6.905</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.034">6.034</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Concepts and techniques for the design and implementation of large software systems that can be adapted to uses not anticipated by the designer. Applications include compilers, computer-algebra systems, deductive systems, and some artificial intelligence applications. Covers means for decoupling goals from strategy, mechanisms for implementing additive data-directed invocation, work with partially-specified entities, and how to manage multiple viewpoints. Topics include combinators, generic operations, pattern matching, pattern-directed invocation, rule systems, backtracking, dependencies, indeterminacy, memoization, constraint propagation, and incremental refinement. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.946"></a>
<p><h3>6.946[J] Classical Mechanics: A Computational Approach
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m8b.html#8.351">8.351[J]</A>, <A HREF="m12c.html#12.620">12.620[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m12a.html#12.008">12.008</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Classical mechanics in a computational framework, Lagrangian formulation, action, variational principles, and Hamilton's principle. Conserved quantities, Hamiltonian formulation, surfaces of section, chaos, and Liouville's theorem. Poincar&eacute; integral invariants, Poincar&eacute;-Birkhoff and KAM theorems. Invariant curves and cantori. Nonlinear resonances, resonance overlap and transition to chaos. Symplectic integration. Adiabatic invariants. Applications to simple physical systems and solar system dynamics. Extensive use of computation to capture methods, for simulation, and for symbolic analysis. Programming experience required. Students taking the graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.951"></a>
<p><h3>6.951 Graduate 6-A Internship
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>

<br>TBA. <!--s-->

<a name="6.952"></a>
<p><h3>6.952 Graduate 6-A Internship
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)

This academic credit is for registration purposes only and cannot be used toward fulfilling the requirements of any degree program. <a name="6.960"></a>
<p><h3>6.960 Introductory Research in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Enrollment restricted to first-year graduate students in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science who are doing introductory research leading to an SM, EE, ECS, PhD, or ScD thesis. Opportunity to become involved in graduate research, under guidance of a staff member, on a problem of mutual interest to student and supervisor. Individual programs subject to approval of professor in charge.
<br>Fall: <I>L. Kolodziejski</I><br>Spring: <I>L. Kolodziejski</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="6.961"></a>
<p><h3>6.961 Introduction to Research in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-0
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar on topics related to research leading to an SM, EE, ECS, PhD, or ScD thesis. Limited to first-year regular graduate students in EECS with a fellowship or teaching assistantship.
<br>Fall: <I>L. Kolodziejski</I><br>Spring: <I>L. Kolodziejski</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->

<p><h3>6.991 Research in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science
