<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Course 8: Physics<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/"><i>Course 8 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course8.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=8&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=+++8&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>8.01-8.299 plus UROP and THU</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m8b.html">8.300-8.999 plus THG</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<h2>Undergraduate Subjects</h2>
<a name="8.01"></a>
<p><h3>8.01 Physics I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/phys1.gif" alt="Physics I" title="Physics I" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m8a.html#8.011">8.011</A>, <A HREF="m8a.html#8.012">8.012</A>, <A HREF="m8a.html#8.01L">8.01L</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.801">CC.801</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.8012">CC.8012</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.801">ES.801</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.8012">ES.8012</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces classical mechanics. Space and time: straight-line kinematics; motion in a plane; forces and static equilibrium; particle dynamics, with force and conservation of momentum; relative inertial frames and non-inertial force; work, potential energy and conservation of energy; kinetic theory and the ideal gas; rigid bodies and rotational dynamics; vibrational motion; conservation of angular momentum; central force motions; fluid mechanics.  Subject taught using the TEAL (Technology-Enabled Active Learning) format which features students working in groups of three, discussing concepts, solving problems, and doing table-top experiments with the aid of computer data acquisition and analysis.
<br>Fall: <I>D. Chakrabarty</I><br>IAP: <I>D. Chakrabarty</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.011"></a>
<p><h3>8.011 Physics I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/phys1.gif" alt="Physics I" title="Physics I" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m8a.html#8.01">8.01</A>, <A HREF="m8a.html#8.012">8.012</A>, <A HREF="m8a.html#8.01L">8.01L</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.801">CC.801</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.8012">CC.8012</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.801">ES.801</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.8012">ES.8012</A>
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW10-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-144</a>) or <i>MW12-2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-144</a>) or <i>MW2-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=36">36-144</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-124</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces classical mechanics. Space and time: straight-line kinematics; motion in a plane; forces and equilibrium; experimental basis of Newton's laws; particle dynamics; universal gravitation; collisions and conservation laws; work and potential energy; vibrational motion; conservative forces; inertial forces and non-inertial frames; central force motions; rigid bodies and rotational dynamics. Designed for students with previous experience in 8.01; the subject is designated as 8.01 on the transcript.
<br><I>Katsavounidis, Erik</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=8.011');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.012"></a>
<p><h3>8.012 Physics I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/phys1.gif" alt="Physics I" title="Physics I" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m8a.html#8.01">8.01</A>, <A HREF="m8a.html#8.011">8.011</A>, <A HREF="m8a.html#8.01L">8.01L</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.801">CC.801</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.8012">CC.8012</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.801">ES.801</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.8012">ES.8012</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Elementary mechanics, presented in greater depth than in 8.01. Newton's laws, concepts of momentum, energy, angular momentum, rigid body motion, and non-inertial systems. Uses elementary calculus freely; concurrent registration in a math subject more advanced than 18.01 is recommended. In addition to covering the theoretical subject matter, students complete a small experimental project of their own design. Freshmen admitted via AP or Math Diagnostic for Physics Placement results.
<br><I>M. Soljacic</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.01L"></a>
<p><h3>8.01L Physics I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img src="/icns/phys1.gif" alt="Physics I" title="Physics I" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m8a.html#8.01">8.01</A>, <A HREF="m8a.html#8.011">8.011</A>, <A HREF="m8a.html#8.012">8.012</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.801">CC.801</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.8012">CC.8012</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.801">ES.801</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.8012">ES.8012</A>
<br>IAP URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to classical mechanics (see description under 8.01). Includes components of the TEAL (Technology-Enabled Active Learning) format. Material covered over a longer interval so that the subject is completed by the end of the IAP. Substantial emphasis given to reviewing and strengthening necessary mathematics tools, as well as basic physics concepts and problem-solving skills. Content, depth, and difficulty is otherwise identical to that of 8.01. The subject is designated as 8.01 on the transcript.
<br>Fall: <I>P. Jarillo-Herrero</I><br>IAP: <I>P. Jarillo-Herrero</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.02"></a>
<p><h3>8.02 Physics II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/phys2.gif" alt="Physics II" title="Physics II" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m8a.html#8.021">8.021</A>, <A HREF="m8a.html#8.022">8.022</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.802">CC.802</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.8022">CC.8022</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.802">ES.802</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.8022">ES.8022</A>
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br>F meets in 32-082. For lecture 4 & 6. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9-11,F9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-152</a>) or <i>MW11-1,F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-152</a>) or <i>MW1-3,F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-152</a>) or <i>MW3-5,F3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-152</a>) or <i>TR9-11,F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-152</a>) or <i>TR11-1,F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-152</a>) or <i>TR1-3,F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-152</a>) or <i>TR3-5,F3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-152</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to electromagnetism and electrostatics: electric charge, Coulomb's law, electric structure of matter; conductors and dielectrics. Concepts of electrostatic field and potential, electrostatic energy. Electric currents, magnetic fields and Ampere's law. Magnetic materials. Time-varying fields and Faraday's law of induction. Basic electric circuits. Electromagnetic waves and Maxwell's equations. Subject taught using the TEAL (Technology Enabled Active Learning) studio format which utilizes small group interaction and current technology to help students develop intuition about, and conceptual models of, physical phenomena.
<br><I>Redwine, Robert; Dourmashkin, Peter</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=8.02');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.021"></a>
<p><h3>8.021 Physics II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/phys2.gif" alt="Physics II" title="Physics II" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m8a.html#8.02">8.02</A>, <A HREF="m8a.html#8.022">8.022</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.802">CC.802</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.8022">CC.8022</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.802">ES.802</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.8022">ES.8022</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to electromagnetism and electrostatics: electric charge, Coulomb's law, electric structure of matter; conductors and dielectrics. Concepts of electrostatic field and potential, electrostatic energy. Electric currents, magnetic fields and Ampere's law. Magnetic materials. Time-varying fields and Faraday's law of induction. Basic electric circuits. Electromagnetic waves and Maxwell's equations. Designed for students with previous experience in 8.02; the subject is designated as 8.02 on the transcript. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>G. Stephans</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.022"></a>
<p><h3>8.022 Physics II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/phys2.gif" alt="Physics II" title="Physics II" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, <I>Coreq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a></I>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m8a.html#8.02">8.02</A>, <A HREF="m8a.html#8.021">8.021</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.802">CC.802</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.8022">CC.8022</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.802">ES.802</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.8022">ES.8022</A>
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=6">6-120</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-314</a>) or <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-314</a>) or <i>TR2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-314</a>) or <i>TR3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-314</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Parallel to 8.02, but more advanced mathematically. Some knowledge of vector calculus assumed. Maxwell's equations, in both differential and integral form. Electrostatic and magnetic vector potential. Properties of dielectrics and magnetic materials. In addition to the theoretical subject matter, several experiments in electricity and magnetism are performed by the students in the laboratory.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Checkelsky</I><br>Spring: <I>Gedik, Nuh</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=8.022');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.03"></a>
<p><h3>8.03 Physics III
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1.30-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=6">6-120</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>MW10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-302</a>) or <i>MW11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-302</a>) or <i>MW1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-302</a>) or <i>MW2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-302</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Mechanical vibrations and waves; simple harmonic motion, superposition, forced vibrations and resonance, coupled oscillations, and normal modes; vibrations of continuous systems; reflection and refraction; phase and group velocity. Optics; wave solutions to Maxwell's equations; polarization; Snell's Law, interference, Huygens's principle, Fraunhofer diffraction, and gratings.
<br>Fall: <I>Y. Lee</I><br>Spring: <I>Comin, Riccardo</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=8.03');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.033"></a>
<p><h3>8.033 Relativity
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Einstein's postulates; consequences for simultaneity, time dilation, length contraction, and clock synchronization; Lorentz transformation; relativistic effects and paradoxes; Minkowski diagrams; invariants and four-vectors; momentum, energy, and mass; particle collisions. Relativity and electricity; Coulomb's law; magnetic fields. Brief introduction to Newtonian cosmology. Introduction to some concepts of general relativity; principle of equivalence. The Schwarzchild metric; gravitational red shift; particle and light trajectories; geodesics; Shapiro delay.
<br><I>J. Thaler</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.04"></a>
<p><h3>8.04 Quantum Physics I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.03">8.03</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.032">18.032</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m8a.html#8.S04">8.S04</A>
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=6">6-120</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-322</a>) or <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-322</a>) or <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-322</a>) or <i>TR2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-322</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Experimental basis of quantum physics: photoelectric effect, Compton scattering, photons, Franck-Hertz experiment, the Bohr atom, electron diffraction, deBroglie waves, and wave-particle duality of matter and light. Introduction to wave mechanics: Schroedinger's equation, wave functions, wave packets, probability amplitudes, stationary states, the Heisenberg uncertainty principle, and zero-point energies. Solutions to Schroedinger's equation in one dimension: transmission and reflection at a barrier, barrier penetration, potential wells, the simple harmonic oscillator. Schroedinger's equation in three dimensions: central potentials and introduction to hydrogenic systems.
<br><I>M. Vogelsberger</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=8.04');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.S04"></a>
<p><h3>8.S04 Special Subject:  Quantum Physics I
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.03">8.03</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.032">18.032</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-10
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m8a.html#8.04">8.04</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Experimental version of 8.04, which offers a combination of online and in-person instruction. See description of 8.04. Licensed by the Committee on Curricula as an acceptable alternative to 8.04 for Fall 2017.
<br><I>B. Zwiebach</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.044"></a>
<p><h3>8.044 Statistical Physics I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.03">8.03</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=6">6-120</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>MW10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-204</a>) or <i>MW11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-204</a>) or <i>MW3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-302</a>) or <i>MW4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-302</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to probability, statistical mechanics, and thermodynamics. Random variables, joint and conditional probability densities, and functions of a random variable. Concepts of macroscopic variables and thermodynamic equilibrium, fundamental assumption of statistical mechanics, microcanonical and canonical ensembles. First, second, and third laws of thermodynamics. Numerous examples illustrating a wide variety of physical phenomena such as magnetism, polyatomic gases, thermal radiation, electrons in solids, and noise in electronic devices. Concurrent enrollment in 8.04 is recommended.
<br><I>N. Fakhri</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=8.044');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.05"></a>
<p><h3>8.05 Quantum Physics II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.04">8.04</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m8a.html#8.051">8.051</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Together 8.05 and 8.06 cover quantum physics with applications drawn from modern physics. General formalism of quantum mechanics: states, operators, Dirac notation, representations, measurement theory. Harmonic oscillator: operator algebra, states. Quantum mechanics in three dimensions: central potentials and the radial equation, bound and scattering states, qualitative analysis of wavefunctions. Angular momentum: operators, commutator algebra, eigenvalues and eigenstates, spherical harmonics. Spin: Stern-Gerlach devices and measurements, nuclear magnetic resonance, spin and statistics. Addition of angular momentum: Clebsch-Gordan series and coefficients, spin systems, and allotropic forms of hydrogen.
<br><I>W. Detmold</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.051"></a>
<p><h3>8.051 Quantum Physics II
<br>(8.S05)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.04">8.04</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-10
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m8a.html#8.05">8.05</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>WF10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-310</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Blended version of 8.05 using a combination of online and in-person instruction. Together with 8.06 covers quantum physics with applications drawn from modern physics. General formalism of quantum mechanics: states, operators, Dirac notation, representations, measurement theory. Harmonic oscillator: operator algebra, states. Quantum mechanics in three dimensions: central potentials and the radial equation, bound and scattering states, qualitative analysis of wave functions. Angular momentum: operators, commutator algebra, eigenvalues and eigenstates, spherical harmonics. Spin: Stern-Gerlach devices and measurements, nuclear magnetic resonance, spin and statistics. Addition of angular momentum: Clebsch-Gordan series and coefficients, spin systems, and allotropic forms of hydrogen. Limited to 20.
<br><I>J. Thaler</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=8.051');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.06"></a>
<p><h3>8.06 Quantum Physics III
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.05">8.05</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=6">6-120</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>MW10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-322</a>) or <i>MW11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-322</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Continuation of 8.05. Units: natural units, scales of microscopic phenomena, applications. Time-independent approximation methods: degenerate and nondegenerate perturbation theory, variational method, Born-Oppenheimer approximation, applications to atomic and molecular systems. The structure of one- and two-electron atoms: overview, spin-orbit and relativistic corrections, fine structure, variational approximation, screening, Zeeman and Stark effects. Charged particles in a magnetic field: Landau levels and integer quantum hall effect. Scattering: general principles, partial waves, review of one-dimension, low-energy approximations, resonance, Born approximation. Time-dependent perturbation theory. Students research and write a paper on a topic related to the content of 8.05 and 8.06.
<br><I>B. Zwiebach</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=8.06');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.07"></a>
<p><h3>8.07 Electromagnetism II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.03">8.03</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Survey of basic electromagnetic phenomena: electrostatics, magnetostatics; electromagnetic properties of matter. Time-dependent electromagnetic fields and Maxwell's equations. Electromagnetic waves, emission, absorption, and scattering of radiation. Relativistic electrodynamics and mechanics.
<br><I>A. Guth</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.08"></a>
<p><h3>8.08 Statistical Physics II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.044">8.044</a>, <a href="m8a.html#8.05">8.05</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>WF1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-322</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>M1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-322</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Probability distributions for classical and quantum systems. Microcanonical, canonical, and grand canonical partition-functions and associated thermodynamic potentials. Conditions of thermodynamic equilibrium for homogenous and heterogenous systems. Applications: non-interacting Bose and Fermi gases; mean field theories for real gases, binary mixtures, magnetic systems, polymer solutions; phase and reaction equilibria, critical phenomena. Fluctuations, correlation functions and susceptibilities, and Kubo formulae. Evolution of distribution functions: Boltzmann and Smoluchowski equations.
<br><I>L. Fu</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=8.08');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.09"></a>
<p><h3>8.09 Classical Mechanics III
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m8b.html#8.309">8.309</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.223">8.223</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers Lagrangian and Hamiltonian mechanics, systems with constraints, rigid body dynamics, vibrations, central forces, Hamilton-Jacobi theory, action-angle variables, perturbation theory, and continuous systems. Provides an introduction to ideal and viscous fluid mechanics, including turbulence, as well as an introduction to nonlinear dynamics, including chaos. Students taking graduate version complete different assignments.
<br><I>I. Stewart</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Undergraduate Laboratory and Special Project Subjects</h2>
<a name="8.13"></a>
<p><h3>8.13 Experimental Physics I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.04">8.04</a>
<br>Units: 0-6-12
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lab:</b> <i>MW9-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-361</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Four fundamental laboratory experiments are carried out each term, covering most aspects of modern physics relating to names such as Rutherford, Franck-Hertz, Hall, Ramsauer, Doppler, Fraunhofer, Faraday, Mossbauer, Compton, and Stern-Gerlach. Stresses basic experimental techniques and data analysis, and written and oral presentation of experiment results.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Formaggio</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Levine</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=8.13');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.14"></a>
<h3>8.14 Experimental Physics II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.05">8.05</a>, <a href="m8a.html#8.13">8.13</a>
<br>Units: 0-6-12
<br><b>Lab:</b> <i>TR9-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-361</a>) or <i>TR2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-361</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Four fundamental laboratory experiments are carried out each term, covering most aspects of modern physics relating to names such as Rutherford, Franck-Hertz, Hall, Ramsauer, Doppler, Fraunhofer, Faraday, Mossbauer, Compton, and Stern-Gerlach. Stresses basic experimental techniques and data analysis, and written and oral presentation of experiment results. 8.14 requires knowledge of quantum mechanics at the 8.05 level.
<br><I>G. Roland</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=8.14');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.18"></a>
<p><h3>8.18 Research Problems in Undergraduate Physics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<p><h3>8.19 Readings in Physics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<h2>Undergraduate Elective Subjects</h2>
<a name="8.20"></a>
<p><h3>8.20 Introduction to Special Relativity
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-7
<br>IAP URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the basic ideas and equations of Einstein's special theory of relativity. Topics include Lorentz transformations, length contraction and time dilation, four vectors, Lorentz invariants, relativistic energy and momentum, relativistic kinematics, Doppler shift, space-time diagrams, relativity paradoxes, and some concepts of general relativity. Intended for freshmen and sophomores. Not usable as a restricted elective by Physics majors. Credit cannot be received for 8.20 if credit for 8.033 is or has been received in the same or prior terms.
<br><I>S. Vitale</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018JA&Subject=8.20');" >Textbooks (IAP 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.21"></a>
<p><h3>8.21 Physics of Energy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-270</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-145</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A comprehensive introduction to the fundamental physics of energy systems that emphasizes quantitative analysis.  Focuses on the fundamental physical principles underlying energy processes and on the application of these principles to practical calculations.  Applies mechanics and electromagnetism to energy systems; introduces and applies basic ideas from thermodynamics, quantum mechanics, and nuclear physics. Examines energy sources, conversion, transport, losses, storage, conservation, and end uses.  Analyzes the physics of side effects, such as global warming and radiation hazards. Provides students with technical tools and perspective to evaluate energy choices quantitatively at both national policy and personal levels.
<br><I>R. Jaffe</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=8.21');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.223"></a>
<p><h3>8.223 Classical Mechanics II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A broad, theoretical treatment of classical mechanics, useful in its own right for treating complex dynamical problems, but essential to understanding the foundations of quantum mechanics and statistical physics. Generalized coordinates, Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formulations, canonical transformations, and Poisson brackets.  Applications to continuous media. The relativistic Lagrangian and Maxwell's equations.
<br><I>M. Evans</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018JA&Subject=8.223');" >Textbooks (IAP 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.224"></a>
<p><h3>8.224 Exploring Black Holes: General Relativity and Astrophysics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.033">8.033</a> or <a href="m8a.html#8.20">8.20</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Study of physical effects in the vicinity of a black hole as a basis for understanding general relativity, astrophysics, and elements of cosmology. Extension to current developments in theory and observation. Energy and momentum in flat space-time; the metric; curvature of space-time near rotating and nonrotating centers of attraction; trajectories and orbits of particles and light; elementary models of the Cosmos. Weekly meetings include an evening seminar and recitation. The last third of the term is reserved for collaborative research projects on topics such as the Global Positioning System, solar system tests of relativity, descending into a black hole, gravitational lensing, gravitational waves, Gravity Probe B, and more advanced models of the cosmos. Subject has online components that are open to selected MIT alumni. Alumni wishing to participate should contact Professor Bertschinger at edbert@mit.edu. Limited to 40.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.225"></a>
<p><h3>8.225[J] Einstein, Oppenheimer, Feynman: Physics in the 20th Century
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassH.gif" alt="HASS Humanities" title="HASS Humanities" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mSTSa.html#STS.042">STS.042[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the changing roles of physics and physicists during the 20th century. Topics range from relativity theory and quantum mechanics to high-energy physics and cosmology. Examines the development of modern physics within shifting institutional, cultural, and political contexts, such as physics in Imperial Britain, Nazi Germany, US efforts during World War II, and physicists' roles during the Cold War. Enrollment limited.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.226"></a>
<p><h3>8.226 Forty-three Orders of Magnitude
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.04">8.04</a>, <a href="m8a.html#8.044">8.044</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the widespread societal implications of current scientific discoveries in physics across forty-three orders of magnitude in length scale.  Addresses topics ranging from climate change to nuclear nonproliferation.  Students develop their ability to express concepts at a level accessible to the public and to present a well-reasoned argument on a topic that is a part of the national debate.  Requires diverse writing assignments, including substantial papers. Enrollment limited.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.231"></a>
<p><h3>8.231 Physics of Solids I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.044">8.044</a>, <I>Coreq: <a href="m8a.html#8.05">8.05</a></I>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the basic concepts of the quantum theory of solids. Topics: periodic structure and symmetry of crystals; diffraction; reciprocal lattice; chemical bonding; lattice dynamics, phonons, thermal properties; free electron gas; model of metals; Bloch theorem and band structure, nearly free electron approximation; tight binding method; Fermi surface; semiconductors, electrons, holes, impurities; optical properties, excitons; and magnetism.
<br><I>L. Fu</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.241"></a>
<p><h3>8.241 Introduction to Biological Physics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m20a.html#20.315">20.315</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.415">20.415</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m8a.html#8.044">8.044</a> or <a href="m5b.html#5.60">5.60</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-257</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>T4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the main concepts of biological physics, with a focus on biophysical phenomena at the molecular and cellular scales. Presents the role of entropy and diffusive transport in living matter; challenges to life resulting from the highly viscous environment present at microscopic scales, including constraints on force, motion and transport within cells, tissues, and fluids; principles of how cellular machinery (e.g., molecular motors) can convert electro-chemical energy sources to mechanical forces and motion. Also covers polymer physics relevant to DNA and other biological polymers, including the study of configurations, fluctuations, rigidity, and entropic elasticity.
<br>Staff<br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=8.241');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.251"></a>
<p><h3>8.251 String Theory for Undergraduates
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.033">8.033</a>, <a href="m8a.html#8.044">8.044</a>, <a href="m8a.html#8.05">8.05</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m8b.html#8.821">8.821</A>
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the main concepts of string theory, i.e., quantum mechanics of a relativistic string. Develops aspects of string theory and makes it accessible to students familiar with basic electromagnetism and statistical mechanics, including the study of D-branes and string thermodynamics.  Meets with 8.821 when offered concurrently.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.276"></a>
<p><h3>8.276 Nuclear and Particle Physics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.033">8.033</a>, <a href="m8a.html#8.04">8.04</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents a modern view of the fundamental structure of matter. Starting from the Standard Model, which views leptons and quarks as basic building blocks of matter, establishes the properties and interactions of these particles. Explores applications of this phenomenology to both particle and nuclear physics. Emphasizes current topics in nuclear and particle physics research at MIT. Intended for students with a basic knowledge of relativity and quantum physics concepts.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.277"></a>
<p><h3>8.277 Introduction to Particle Accelerators
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.013">6.013</a> or <a href="m8a.html#8.07">8.07</a>; permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Principles of acceleration: beam properties; linear accelerators, synchrotrons, and storage rings.  Accelerator technologies: radio frequency cavities, bending and focusing magnets, beam diagnostics. Particle beam optics and dynamics. Special topics: measures of accelerators performance in science, medicine and industry; synchrotron radiation sources; free electron lasers; high-energy colliders; and accelerators for radiation therapy.  May be repeated for credit for a maximum of 12 units.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.282"></a>
<p><h3>8.282[J] Introduction to Astronomy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m12a.html#12.402">12.402[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-231</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Quantitative introduction to physics of the solar system, stars, interstellar medium, the galaxy, and universe, as determined from a variety of astronomical observations and models. Topics: planets, planet formation; stars, the Sun, "normal" stars, star formation; stellar evolution, supernovae, compact objects (white dwarfs, neutron stars, and black holes), plusars, binary x-ray sources; star clusters, globular and open clusters; interstellar medium, gas, dust, magnetic fields, cosmic rays; distance ladder; galaxies, normal and active galaxies, jets; gravitational lensing; large scaling structure; Newtonian cosmology, dynamical expansion and thermal history of the universe; cosmic microwave background radiation; big bang nucleosynthesis. No prior knowledge of astronomy necessary. Not usable as a restricted elective by Physics majors.
<br><I>A. Frebel</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=8.282');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.284"></a>
<p><h3>8.284 Modern Astrophysics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.04">8.04</a>, <I>Coreq: <a href="m8a.html#8.05">8.05</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html">http://web.mit.edu/physics/subjects/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2-3.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=8">8-205</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Applications of physics (Newtonian, statistical, and quantum mechanics) to fundamental processes that occur in celestial objects. Includes main-sequence stars, collapsed stars (white dwarfs, neutron stars, and black holes), pulsars, supernovae, the interstellar medium, galaxies, and as time permits, active galaxies, quasars, and cosmology. Observational data discussed. No prior knowledge of astronomy is required.
<br><I>N. Weinberg</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.286"></a>
<p><h3>8.286 The Early Universe
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to modern cosmology. First half deals with the development of the big bang theory from 1915 to 1980, and latter half with recent impact of particle theory. Topics: special relativity and the Doppler effect, Newtonian cosmological models, introduction to non-Euclidean spaces, thermal radiation and early history of the universe, big bang nucleosynthesis, introduction to grand unified theories and other recent developments in particle theory, baryogenesis, the inflationary universe model, and the evolution of galactic structure.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.287"></a>
<p><h3>8.287[J] Observational Techniques of Optical Astronomy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m12a.html#12.410">12.410[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.282">8.282J</a>, <a href="m12a.html#12.402">12.402J</a>, <a href="m12a.html#12.409">12.409</a>, or other introductory astronomy course; <I>Coreq: <a href="m8a.html#8.03">8.03</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-4-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Fundamental physical and optical principles used for astronomical measurements at visible wavelengths and practical methods of astronomical observations. Topics: astronomical coordinates, time, optics, telescopes, photon counting, signal-to-noise ratios, data analysis (including least-squares model fitting), limitations imposed by the Earth's atmosphere on optical observations, CCD detectors, photometry, spectroscopy, astrometry, and time variability. Project at Wallace Astrophysical Observatory. Written and oral project reports. Limited to 18; preference to Course 8 and Course 12 majors and minors.
<br><I>R. Binzel</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.290"></a>
<p><h3>8.290[J] Extrasolar Planets: Physics and Detection Techniques
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m12a.html#12.425">12.425[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m12c.html#12.625">12.625</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.03">8.03</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>
<br>Units: 2-1-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents basic principles of planet atmospheres and interiors applied to the study of extrasolar planets. Focuses on fundamental physical processes related to observable extrasolar planet properties. Provides a quantitative overview of detection techniques. Introduction to the feasibility of the search for Earth-like planets, biosignatures and habitable conditions on extrasolar planets. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>S. Seager</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.292"></a>
<p><h3>8.292[J] Fluid Physics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m12a.html#12.330">12.330[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.044">8.044</a>, <a href="m5b.html#5.60">5.60</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A physics-based introduction to the properties of fluids and fluid systems, with examples drawn from a broad range of sciences, including atmospheric physics and astrophysics. Definitions of fluids and the notion of continuum. Equations of state and continuity, hydrostatics and conservation of momentum; ideal fluids and Euler's equation; viscosity and the Navier-Stokes equation. Energy considerations, fluid thermodynamics, and isentropic flow. Compressible versus incompressible and rotational versus irrotational flow; Bernoulli's theorem; steady flow, streamlines and potential flow. Circulation and vorticity. Kelvin's theorem. Boundary layers. Fluid waves and instabilities. Quantum fluids.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.295"></a>
<p><h3>8.295 Practical Work Experience
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 0-1-0 [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For Course 8 students participating in off-campus work experiences in physics. Before registering for this subject, students must have an employment offer from a company or organization and must identify a Physics supervisor. Upon completion of the work, student must submit a letter from the employer describing the work accomplished, along with a substantive final report from the student approved by the MIT supervisor. Subject to departmental approval. Consult departmental academic office.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.297"></a>
<p><h3>8.297 Physics of the 21st Century
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: <a href="m8a.html#8.033">8.033</a>, <a href="m8a.html#8.044">8.044</a>, <a href="m8a.html#8.05">8.05</a>, <a href="m8a.html#8.13">8.13</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students study four topics in depth from themes of current interest over the course of the term.  Topic examples include Bose-Einstein condensates, dark energy, neutrino interactions, superconductivity, photonics, semiconductor nanostructures, exoplanets, and space plasmas.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.298"></a>
<p><h3>8.298 Selected Topics in Physics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=6C">6C-442</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presentation of topics of current interest, with content varying from year to year.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="8.299"></a>
<p><h3>8.299 Physics Teaching
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For qualified undergraduate students interested in gaining some experience in teaching. Laboratory, tutorial, or classroom teaching under the supervision of a faculty member. Students selected by interview.
<br><I>N. Mavalvala</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
