<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Course 9: Brain and Cognitive Sciences<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://bcs.mit.edu/"><i>Course 9 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course9.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=9&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=+++9&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m9a.html">9.00-9.499</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>9.50-9.999 plus Thesis, UROP</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<a name="9.50"></a>
<p><h3>9.50 Research in Brain and Cognitive Sciences
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m9a.html#9.00">9.00</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 0-12-0
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Laboratory research in brain and cognitive science, using physiological, anatomical, pharmacological, developmental, behavioral, and computational methods. Each student carries out an experimental study under the direction of a member of the faculty. Project must be approved in advance by the faculty supervisor and the Director of the Undergraduate Program. Written presentation of results is required.
<br>Fall: <I>L. Schulz</I><br>Spring: <I>L. Schulz</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.520"></a>
<p><h3>9.520[J] Statistical Learning Theory and Applications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6c.html#6.860">6.860[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6c.html#6.867">6.867</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.041B">6.041B</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides students with the knowledge needed to use and develop advanced machine learning solutions to challenging problems. Covers foundations and recent advances of machine learning in the framework of statistical learning theory. Focuses on regularization techniques key to high-dimensional supervised learning. Starting from classical methods such as regularization networks and support vector machines, addresses state-of-the-art techniques based on principles such as geometry or sparsity, and discusses a variety of algorithms for supervised learning, feature selection, structured prediction, and multitask learning. Also focuses on unsupervised learning of data representations, with an emphasis on hierarchical (deep) architectures.
<br><I>T. Poggio</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.523"></a>
<p><h3>9.523[J] Aspects of a Computational Theory of Intelligence
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6c.html#6.861">6.861[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Integrates neuroscience, cognitive and computer science to explore the nature of intelligence, how it is produced by the brain, and how it can be replicated in machines. Discusses an array of current research connected through an overarching theme of how it contributes to a computational account of how humans analyze dynamic visual imagery to understand objects and actions in the world.
<br><I>T. Poggio</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.54"></a>
<p><h3>9.54 Computational Aspects of Biological Learning
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: <a href="m9a.html#9.40">9.40</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Takes a computational approach to learning in the brain by neurons and synapses. Examines supervised and unsupervised learning as well as possible biological substrates, including Hebb synapses and the related topics of Oja flow and principal components analysis. Discusses hypothetical computational primitives in the nervous system, and the implications for unsupervised learning algorithms underlying the development of tuning properties of cortical neurons. Also focuses on a broad class of biologically plausible learning strategies.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.56"></a>
<p><h3>9.56[J] Abnormal Language
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m24b.html#24.907">24.907[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m24b.html#24.900">24.900</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the linguistic study of language pathology, concentrating on experimental approaches and theoretical explanations. Discussion of Specific Language Impairment, Down syndrome, William's syndrome, autism, normal aging, Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's disease, hemispherectomy, and aphasia. Focuses on the comparison of linguistic abilities among these syndromes, while drawing clear comparisons with first- and second-language acquisition. Topics include the lexicon, morphology, syntax, semantics, and pragmatics. Relates the lost linguistic abilities in these syndromes to properties of the brain.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.583"></a>
<p><h3>9.583[J] Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging: Data Acquisition and Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.583">HST.583[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.05">18.05</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-3-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides background necessary for designing, conducting, and interpreting fMRI studies in the human brain. Covers in depth the physics of image encoding, mechanisms of anatomical and functional contrasts, the physiological basis of fMRI signals, cerebral hemodynamics, and neurovascular coupling. Also covers design methods for stimulus-, task-driven and resting-state experiments, as well as workflows for model-based and data-driven analysis methods for data. Instruction in brain structure analysis and surface- and region-based analyses. Laboratory sessions include data acquisition sessions at the 3 Tesla MRI scanner at MIT and the Connectom and 7 Tesla scanners at the MGH/HST Martinos Center, as well as hands-on data analysis workshops. Introductory or college-level neurobiology, physics, and signal processing are helpful.
<br><I>S. Whitfield-Gabrieli, J. Polimeni, A. Yendiki</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.59"></a>
<p><h3>9.59[J] Laboratory in Psycholinguistics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m24b.html#24.905">24.905[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m9a.html#9.00">9.00</a> or <a href="m24b.html#24.900">24.900</a>
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-5056</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>F9-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-4062</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Hands-on experience designing, conducting, analyzing, and presenting experiments on the structure and processing of human language. Focuses on constructing, conducting, analyzing, and presenting an original and independent experimental project of publishable quality. Develops skills in reading and writing scientific research reports in cognitive science, including evaluating the methods section of a published paper, reading and understanding graphical displays and statistical claims about data, and evaluating theoretical claims based on experimental data.  Instruction and practice in oral and written communication provided.
<br><I>E. Gibson</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.60"></a>
<p><h3>9.60 Machine-Motivated Human Vision
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m9a.html#9.00">9.00</a>, <a href="m9a.html#9.07">9.07</a>
<br>Units: 2-1-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-3015</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores how studies of human vision can be motivated by, and enhance the capabilities of, machine-based systems. Considers the twin questions of how the performance of state-of-the-art machine vision systems compares with that of humans, and what kinds of strategies the human visual system uses in tasks where human performance exceeds that of machines. Includes presentations by engineers from companies with significant engineering efforts in vision. Based on these presentations, students define and conduct studies to address the two aforementioned questions and present their results to the public at the end of the term. Directed towards students interested in exploring vision from computational, experimental and practical perspectives. Provides instruction and practice in written and oral communication.
<br><I>P. Sinha</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.601"></a>
<p><h3>9.601[J] Language Acquisition I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m24b.html#24.949">24.949[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Lectures, reading, and discussion of current theory and data concerning the psychology and biology of language acquisition. Emphasizes learning of syntax, semantics, and morphology, together with some discussion of phonology, and especially research relating grammatical theory and learnability theory to empirical studies of children.
<br><I>m. Hackl</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.611"></a>
<p><h3>9.611[J] Natural Language and the Computer Representation of Knowledge
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6c.html#6.863">6.863[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.034">6.034</a>
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br>1st mtg at 1.00 in 10-250. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW12.30-2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=6">6-120</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the relationship between the computer representation and acquisition of knowledge and the structure of human language, its acquisition, and hypotheses about its differentiating uniqueness.  Emphasizes development of analytical skills necessary to judge the computational implications of grammatical formalisms and their role in connecting human intelligence to computational intelligence. Uses concrete examples to illustrate particular computational issues in this area.
<br><I>R. Berwick</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.63"></a>
<p><h3>9.63 Laboratory in Visual Cognition
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m9a.html#9.00">9.00</a>
<br>Units: 2-1-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Teaches principles of experimental methods in human visual perception and attention, including how to design, conduct, analyze, and present experiments in visual cognition. Combines lectures and hands-on experimental exercises. Requires two experimental projects, at least one of which is conducted independently; the other may be done as part of a team. Assignments include individual reports on experimental designs, written articles, and presentations critiquing three team experiments observed in class. Instruction and practice in written and oral communication provided. Experience with MATLAB is recommended. Limited to 16.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.65"></a>
<p><h3>9.65 Cognitive Processes
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: <a href="m9a.html#9.00">9.00</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to human information processing and learning. Topics include the nature of mental representation and processing, memory and learning, pattern recognition, attention, imagery and mental codes, concepts and prototypes, as well as reasoning and problem-solving.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.66"></a>
<p><h3>9.66[J] Computational Cognitive Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6c.html#6.804">6.804[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m9b.html#9.660">9.660</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.008">6.008</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.036">6.036</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.041B">6.041B</a>, <a href="m9a.html#9.40">9.40</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.05">18.05</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to computational theories of human cognition. Focus on principles of inductive learning and inference, and the representation of knowledge. Computational frameworks covered include Bayesian and hierarchical Bayesian models; probabilistic graphical models; nonparametric statistical models and the Bayesian Occam's razor; sampling algorithms for approximate learning and inference; and probabilistic models defined over structured representations such as first-order logic, grammars, or relational schemas. Applications to understanding core aspects of cognition, such as concept learning and categorization, causal reasoning, theory formation, language acquisition, and social inference. Graduate students complete a final project.
<br><I>J. Tenenbaum</I><br>
<a name="9.660"></a>
<h3>9.660 Computational Cognitive Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.804">6.804[J]</A>, <A HREF="m9b.html#9.66">9.66[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to computational theories of human cognition. Focuses on principles of inductive learning and inference, and the representation of knowledge. Computational frameworks include Bayesian and hierarchical Bayesian models, probabilistic graphical models, nonparametric statistical models and the Bayesian Occam's razor, sampling algorithms for approximate learning and inference, and probabilistic models defined over structured representations such as first-order logic, grammars, or relational schemas. Applications to understanding core aspects of cognition, such as concept learning and categorization, causal reasoning, theory formation, language acquisition, and social inference. Graduate students complete a final project.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.71"></a>
<p><h3>9.71 Functional MRI Investigations of the Human Brain
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: <a href="m9a.html#9.07">9.07</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.05">18.05</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers design and interpretation of fMRI experiments, and the relationship between fMRI and other techniques. Focuses on localization of cognitive function in the human brain. Students write papers and give presentations, explain and critique published papers, and design but do not conduct their own fMRI experiments. Upon completion, students should be able to understand and critique published fMRI papers and have a good grasp of what is known about localization of cognitive function from fMRI. Limited to 12.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.77"></a>
<p><h3>9.77 Computational Perception
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: <a href="m9a.html#9.00">9.00</a>, <a href="m9a.html#9.40">9.40</a>; <a href="m9a.html#9.35">9.35</a> or <a href="m9b.html#9.65">9.65</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Begins with a review of the experimental paradigms, findings and theories used to evaluate the capabilities and limits of human visual perception. Assesses how knowledge of human perception may be used to guide machine vision systems. Second part of the subject focuses on models in computational perception. Describes how computer vision systems can perform image analysis and synthesis; face, object and scene perception; texture synthesis, segmentation, and navigation. Introduces various simulation methods. A MATLAB-based project in computational perception is required. Limited to 8.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.822"></a>
<p><h3>9.822[J] Psychology and Economics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m14a.html#14.137">14.137[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W EVE (4-7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E52">E52-164</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines "psychology appreciation" for economics students. Aims to enhance knowledge and intuition about psychological processes in areas relevant to economics. Increases understanding of psychology as an experimental discipline, with its own distinct rules and style of argument. Topics include self-knowledge, cognitive dissonance, self-deception, emotions, social norms, self-control, learning, mental accounting, memory, individual and group behavior, and some personality and psycho-analytic models. Within each of these topics, we showcase effective and central experiments and discuss their role in the development of psychological theory. Term paper required.
<br><I>D. Prelec</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.85"></a>
<p><h3>9.85 Infant and Early Childhood Cognition
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m9a.html#9.00">9.00</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to cognitive development focusing on childrens' understanding of objects, agents, and causality. Develops a critical understanding of experimental design. Discusses how developmental research might address philosophical questions about the origins of knowledge, appearance and reality, and the problem of other minds.  Provides instruction and practice in written communication as necessary to research in cognitive science (including critical reviews of journal papers, a literature review and an original research proposal), as well as instruction and practice in oral communication in the form of a poster presentation of a journal paper.
<br><I>L. Schulz</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.901"></a>
<p><h3>9.901 Responsible Conduct in Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-0-1 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides instruction and dialogue on practical ethical issues relating to the responsible conduct of human and animal research in the brain and cognitive sciences. Specific emphasis on topics relevant to young researchers including data handling, animal and human subjects, misconduct, mentoring, intellectual property, and publication. Preliminary assigned readings and initial faculty lecture followed by discussion groups of four to five students each. A short written summary of the discussions submitted at the end of each class. See IAP Guide for registration information.
<br><I>M. Wilson</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018JA&Subject=9.901');" >Textbooks (IAP 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->

<a name="9.95"></a>
<p><h3>9.95 Research Topics in Neuroscience
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-0-0 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Lecture series that highlights faculty research in various fields of neuroscience. Each of the six lectures focuses on a specific area of brain research, delineating issues, methods, and findings pertinent to the topic. Exam administered during seventh and final class session. Pre-register on WebSIS; must attend first class.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.97"></a>
<p><h3>9.97 Introduction to Neuroanatomy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-0-0 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Intensive introduction to neuroanatomy that consists of lectures, demonstrations, and interactive laboratories, including a brain dissection. No prior knowledge of neuroanatomy required, although general knowledge of brain structures is helpful. Pre-register on WebSIS; must attend first class. Limited to 100.
<br><I>R. Ellis-Behnke</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="9.S51"></a>
<p><h3>9.S51 Special Subject in Brain and Cognitive Sciences
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m9a.html#9.00">9.00</a> and any other two subjects in Brain and Cognitive Sciences
<br>Units arranged
<br><b>9.S51:</b> <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-3310</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Undergraduate study in brain and cognitive sciences; covers material not offered in regular curriculum.
<br><I>I. Pepperberg</I><br><b>9.S51:</b> No textbook information available
<a name="9.S52"></a>

<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Course 10: Chemical Engineering<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://web.mit.edu/cheme/"><i>Course 10 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course10.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=10&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=++10&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>10.00-10.899</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m10b.html">10.90-10.999 plus THG, THU, UROP, UPOP</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<a name="10.00"></a>
<p><h3>10.00 Molecule Builders
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 1-6-2
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-154</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>MW2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E18">E18-676</a>) or <i>TR2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E18">E18-676</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Project-based introduction to the applications of engineering design at the molecular level. Working in teams, students complete an open-ended design project that focuses on a topic such as reactor or biomolecular engineering, chemical process design, materials and polymers, or energy.  Provides students practical exposure to the field of chemical engineering as well as potential opportunities to continue their project designs in national/international competitions. Limited to 36; preference to first year students.
<br><I>B. Olsen</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=10.00');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.01"></a>
<p><h3>10.01 Ethics for Engineers
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Engineering School-Wide Elective Subject. <br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m1a.html#1.082">1.082</A>, <A HREF="m2c.html#2.900">2.900</A>, <A HREF="m6c.html#6.904">6.904</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.01">10.01</A>, <A HREF="m22a.html#22.014">22.014</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.9041">6.9041</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-168</a>) or <i>T3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-168</a>) or <i>T EVE (7.30-9.30 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-144</a>) or <i>W3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>) or <i>T EVE (7.30-9.30 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-156</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Integrates classical readings that provide an overview of ethics with a survey of case studies that focus on ethical problems arising in the practice of engineering. Readings taken from a variety of sources, such as Aristotle, Machiavelli, Bacon, Hobbes, Locke, the Founding Fathers, and the Bible. Case studies include written analyses and films that address engineering disasters, biotechnology, court cases, ethical codes, and the ultimate scope and aims of engineering. Students taking independent inquiry version 6.9041 expand the scope of their term project.
<br>Fall: <I>B. Trout</I><br>Spring: <I>B. Trout</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.02"></a>
<p><h3>10.02 Foundations of Entrepreneurship for Engineers
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-169</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies economic and leadership foundations of entrepreneurship as they relate to engineering.  Case studies illustrate major impacts of engineering on the world and examine the leaders responsible for such impacts. Authors include Franklin, Keynes, Leonardo, Lincoln, Locke, Machiavelli, Marx, Schmidt, Schumpeter, Smith, Thiel, and Tocqueville. Discusses topics such as the difference between an entrepreneur and a manager, the entrepreneur as founder, and characteristics of principled entrepreneurship.
<br><I>B. Trout</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.03"></a>
<p><h3>10.03[J] Advances in Biomanufacturing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); second half of term
<br>(Same subject as 7.458[J])<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m7a.html#7.548">7.548[J]</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.53">10.53[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-0-2 [P/D/F]
<br>Begins Apr 2. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-148</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar examines how biopharmaceuticals, an increasingly important class of pharmaceuticals, are manufactured. Topics range from fundamental bioprocesses to new technologies to the economics of biomanufacturing. Also covers the impact of globalization on regulation and quality approaches as well as supply chain integrity. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>C. Love</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.04"></a>
<p><h3>10.04 A Philosophical History of Energy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Philosophic and historical approach to conceptions of energy through the 19th century. Relation of long standing scientific and philosophic problems in the field of energy to 21st-century debates. Topics include the development of thermodynamics and kinetic theories, the foundation of the scientific project, the classical view of energy, and the harnessing of nature. Authors include Bacon, Boltzmann, Carnot, Compte, Descartes, Gibbs, Plato, Aristotle, Leibniz, Kant, Hegel, Mill, Peirce, Whitehead, and Maxwell. Key texts and controversies form topics of weekly writing assignments and term papers.
<br><I>B. Trout</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.05"></a>
<p><h3>10.05 Foundational Analyses of Problems in Energy and the Environment
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-191</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Investigates key texts and papers on the foundational thought of current issues in energy and environmental science. Builds an understanding of key debates (scientific, ethical, and political). Aims to inform solutions to key problems related to procurement of energy and environmental degradation. Topics address alternative energy technologies and fossil fuel utilization and emissions, especially carbon dioxide, carbon dioxide sequestration, and geoengineering. Foundational readings from Homer and Greek playwrights, Aristotle, Genesis, Bacon, Locke, Rousseau, Coleridge, Carnot, Clausius, Marx, Heidegger, Carson, Gore, Singer, and Brundtland. Assignments include weekly analyses of readings, videos and related engineering calculations in addition to a final project. Limited to 18.
<br>Fall: <I>B. Trout</I><br>Spring: <I>B. Trout</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.06"></a>
<p><h3>10.06 Advanced Topics in Ethics for Engineers
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m10a.html#10.01">10.01</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.05">10.05</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E19">E19-506B</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>In-depth study of varying advanced topics in ethics for engineers. Focuses on foundational works and their significance for the choices that engineers make, both as students and as practicing engineers. Each semester, different works and topics, based on current and perennial issues in ethics and engineering, will be chosen in order to explore facets of the extremely complex and varied subject of the place of engineering for the individual and society. Examples of topics include genetic engineering and what it means to be human, artificial intelligence and thought, the scope and limits of engineering, and engineering and freedom. May be repeated for credit with permission of instructor. Limited to 20.
<br>Fall: <I>B. Trout</I><br>Spring: <I>B. Trout</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.10"></a>
<p><h3>10.10 Introduction to Chemical Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>F2 meets in 56-114. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-110</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>T11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-110</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>The diverse applications of chemical engineering are explored through example problems. Solutions require application of fundamental concepts of mass and energy conservation to batch and continuous systems, involving chemical and biological processes. Computer skills and the elements of engineering design are taught in the context of these example problems. The objective is to acquaint the student with the field of chemical engineering and to enable use of computer methods to solve chemical and biological engineering problems.
<br>Fall: <I>K. Prather</I><br>Spring: <I>K. Prather</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=10.10');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.213"></a>
<p><h3>10.213 Chemical and Biological Engineering Thermodynamics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5b.html#5.60">5.60</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.10">10.10</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-110</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-144</a>) or <i>W11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-144</a>) or <i>W12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-168</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Thermodynamics of multicomponent, multiphase chemical and biological systems. Applications of first, second, and third laws of thermodynamics to open and closed systems. Properties of mixtures, including colligative properties, chemical reaction equilibrium, and phase equilibrium; non-ideal solutions; power cycles; refrigeration; separation systems.
<br><I>C. Love</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=10.213');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.22"></a>
<p><h3>10.22 Molecular Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5b.html#5.60">5.60</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.213">10.213</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces molecular concepts in relation to engineering thermodynamics. Includes topics in statistical mechanics, molecular description of gases and liquids, property estimation, description of equilibrium and dynamic properties of fluids from molecular principles, and kinetics of activated processes. Also covers some basic aspects of molecular simulation and applications in systems of engineering interest.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.25"></a>
<p><h3>10.25 Industrial Chemistry and Chemical Process Pathways
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.213">10.213</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.37">10.37</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Chemical and engineering principles involved in creation and operation of viable industrial processes. Topics: analysis of process chemistry by p-pathways (i.e., radical, ionic, and pericyclic reactions of organic syntheses) and d-pathways (i.e., catalysis by transition-metal complexes). Use of reaction mechanisms for inference of co-product formation, kinetics, and equilibria: process synthesis logic related to reaction selectivity, recycle, separations. Illustrations drawn from current and contemplated commercial practice.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.26"></a>
<p><h3>10.26 Chemical Engineering Projects Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>

<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m10a.html#10.27">10.27</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.29">10.29</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2b.html#2.671">2.671</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.014">3.014</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.310">5.310</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.02">7.02</a>, <a href="m12a.html#12.335">12.335</a>, or <a href="m1a.html#1.106">1.106</a> and <a href="m1a.html#1.107">1.107</a>; <a href="m10a.html#10.302">10.302</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-8-4
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-370</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=76">76-653</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=76">76-653</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E18">E18-566</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0064</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0064</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0064</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0064</a>)<!--s-->

<br>Projects in applied chemical engineering research. Students work in teams on one project for the term. Projects often suggested by local industry. Includes training in research planning and project management, execution of experimental work, data analysis, oral presentation skills and individual report writing, and team-building.

<a name="10.27"></a>
<p><h3>10.27 Energy Engineering Projects Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m10a.html#10.26">10.26</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.29">10.29</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2b.html#2.671">2.671</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.014">3.014</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.310">5.310</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.02">7.02</a>, <a href="m12a.html#12.335">12.335</a>, or <a href="m1a.html#1.106">1.106</a> and <a href="m1a.html#1.107">1.107</a>; <a href="m10a.html#10.302">10.302</a>; or permission of instructor

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Projects in applied energy engineering research. Students work in teams on one project for the term. Projects often suggested by local industry. Includes training in research planning and project management, execution of experimental work, data analysis, oral presentation skills and technical report writing, and team-building. Projects consider social science issues in addition to technical issues. Intended for students with diverse technical backgrounds. Preference to Energy Studies minors.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.28"></a>
<p><h3>10.28 Chemical-Biological Engineering Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.310">5.310</a> or <a href="m10a.html#10.702">10.702</a>; <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a> or <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-8-5
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m10a.html#10.28L">10.28L</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the complete design of the bioprocess: from vector selection to production, separation, and characterization of recombinant products. Utilize concepts from many fields, such as, chemical and electrical engineering, and biology. Student teams work through parallel modules spanning microbial fermentation and animal cell culture. With the bioreactor at the core of the experiments, students study cell metabolism and biological pathways, kinetics of cell growth and product formation, oxygen mass transport, scale-up and techniques for the design of process control loops. Introduces novel bioreactors and powerful analytical instrumentation. Downstream processing and recombinant product purification also included. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>J. Hamel</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.28L"></a>
<p><h3>10.28L Chemical-Biological Engineering Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.310">5.310</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.02">7.02</a>, or <a href="m10a.html#10.702">10.702</a>; <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a> or <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-8-5
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m10a.html#10.28">10.28</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-148</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TBA</i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Spans IAP and spring term. Same as 10.28, but with the lab portion of the class held during IAP rather than during the regular term. Content, depth, and difficulty are otherwise identical to that of 10.28. The class is designated as 10.28 on students' transcripts. Enrollment limited.
<br>IAP: <I>J. Hamel</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Hamel</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.29"></a>
<p><h3>10.29 Biological Engineering Projects Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m10a.html#10.26">10.26</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.27">10.27</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2b.html#2.671">2.671</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.014">3.014</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.310">5.310</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.02">7.02</a>, <a href="m12a.html#12.335">12.335</a>, or <a href="m1a.html#1.106">1.106</a> and <a href="m1a.html#1.107">1.107</a>; <a href="m10a.html#10.302">10.302</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-8-4
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-370</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=76">76-653</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=76">76-653</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E18">E18-566</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0064</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0064</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0064</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0044</a>) or <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-0064</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Projects in applied biological engineering research. Students work in teams on one project for the term. Projects often suggested by local industry. Includes training in research planning and project management, execution of experimental work, data analysis, oral presentation skills and report writing, and team-building.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.291"></a>
<p><h3>10.291[J] Introduction to Sustainable Energy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.650">2.650[J]</A>, <A HREF="m22a.html#22.081">22.081[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m1c.html#1.818">1.818[J]</A>, <A HREF="m2b.html#2.65">2.65[J]</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.391">10.391[J]</A>, <A HREF="m11c.html#11.371">11.371[J]</A>, <A HREF="m22c.html#22.811">22.811[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-1-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Assessment of current and potential future energy systems. Covers resources, extraction, conversion, and end-use technologies, with emphasis on meeting 21st-century regional and global energy needs in a sustainable manner. Examines various renewable and conventional energy production technologies, energy end-use practices and alternatives, and consumption practices in different countries. Investigates their attributes within a quantitative analytical framework for evaluation of energy technology system proposals. Emphasizes analysis of energy propositions within an engineering, economic and social context. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to juniors and seniors.
<br><I>M. Golay</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.301"></a>
<p><h3>10.301 Fluid Mechanics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.10">10.10</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR12-1.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-110</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>M11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-156</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>) or <i>M12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-156</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the mechanical principles governing fluid flow. Stress in a fluid. Conservation of mass and momentum, using differential and integral balances. Elementary constitutive equations. Hydrostatics. Exact solutions of the Navier-Stokes equations. Approximate solutions using control volume analysis. Mechanical energy balances and Bernoulli's equation. Dimensional analysis and dynamic similarity. Introduces boundary-layer theory and turbulence.
<br><I>F. Brushett</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=10.301');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.302"></a>
<p><h3>10.302 Transport Processes
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5b.html#5.60">5.60</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.301">10.301</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.213">10.213</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Principles of heat and mass transfer. Steady and transient conduction and diffusion. Radiative heat transfer. Convective transport of heat and mass in both laminar and turbulent flows.  Emphasis on the development of a physical understanding of the underlying phenomena and upon the ability to solve real heat and mass transfer problems of engineering significance.
<br><I>W. Tisdale</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.31"></a>
<p><h3>10.31 Nanoscale Energy Transport Processes
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m10a.html#10.51">10.51</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m10a.html#10.302">10.302</a> or <a href="m2b.html#2.51">2.51</a>; <a href="m3a.html#3.024">3.024</a>, <a href="m5b.html#5.61">5.61</a>, or <a href="m6a.html#6.007">6.007</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the impact of nanoscale phenomena on macroscale transport of energy-carrying molecules, phonons, electrons, and excitons. Studies the effect of structural and energetic disorder, wave-like vs. particle-like transport, quantum and classical size effects, and quantum coherence. Emphasizes quantitative analysis, including the Boltzmann transport equation, Einstein relation, Wiedemann-Franz law, and Marcus electron transfer theory.  Also addresses percolation theory and the connection to energy conversion technologies, such as solar cells, thermoelectrics, and LEDs. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.32"></a>
<p><h3>10.32 Separation Processes
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m10a.html#10.213">10.213</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.302">10.302</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br>Ends Apr 13. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-110</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>General principles of separation by equilibrium and rate processes. Staged cascades. Applications to distillation, absorption, adsorption, and membrane processes. Use of material balances, phase equilibria, and diffusion to understand and design separation processes.
<br><I>T. Hatton</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=10.32');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.333"></a>
<p><h3>10.333 Introduction to Modeling and Simulation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Engineering School-Wide Elective Subject. <br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m1a.html#1.021">1.021</A>, <A HREF="m3a.html#3.021">3.021</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.333">10.333</A>, <A HREF="m22a.html#22.00">22.00</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.016">3.016</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR3-4.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-231</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>M4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=8">8-205</a>) or <i>F4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=8">8-205</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Basic concepts of computer modeling and simulation in science and engineering. Uses techniques and software for simulation, data analysis and visualization. Continuum, mesoscale, atomistic and quantum methods used to study fundamental and applied problems in physics, chemistry, materials science, mechanics, engineering, and biology. Examples drawn from the disciplines above are used to understand or characterize complex structures and materials, and complement experimental observations.
<br><I>M. Buehler, R. Gomez-Bombarelli</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.34"></a>
<p><h3>10.34 Numerical Methods Applied to Chemical Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Numerical methods for solving problems arising in heat and mass transfer, fluid mechanics, chemical reaction engineering, and molecular simulation. Topics: numerical linear algebra, solution of nonlinear algebraic equations and ordinary differential equations, solution of partial differential equations (e.g., Navier-Stokes), numerical methods in molecular simulation (dynamics, geometry optimization). All methods are presented within the context of chemical engineering problems. Familiarity with structured programming is assumed.
<br><I>W. Green</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.345"></a>
<p><h3>10.345 Fundamentals of Metabolic and Biochemical Engineering: Applications to Biomanufacturing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m10a.html#10.545">10.545</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i> <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the fundamentals of cell and metabolic engineering for biocatalyst design and optimization, as well as biochemical engineering principles for bioreactor design and operation, and downstream processing. Presents applications of microbial processes for production of commodity and specialty chemicals and biofuels in addition to mammalian cell cultures for production of biopharmaceuticals. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.37"></a>
<p><h3>10.37 Chemical Kinetics and Reactor Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5b.html#5.60">5.60</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.301">10.301</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/10.37/www/">http://web.mit.edu/10.37/www/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>WF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-110</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>M11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-110</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Applies the concepts of reaction rate, stoichiometry and equilibrium to the analysis of chemical and biological reacting systems. Derivation of rate expressions from reaction mechanisms and equilibrium or steady state assumptions. Design of chemical and biochemical reactors via synthesis of chemical kinetics, transport phenomena, and mass and energy balances. Topics: chemical/biochemical pathways; enzymatic, pathway and cell growth kinetics; batch, plug flow and well-stirred reactors for chemical reactions and cultivations of microorganisms and mammalian cells; heterogeneous and enzymatic catalysis; heat and mass transport in reactors, including diffusion to and within catalyst particles and cells or immoblized enzymes.
<br><I>H. Kulik</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.390"></a>
<p><h3>10.390[J] Fundamentals of Advanced Energy Conversion
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.60">2.60[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2b.html#2.62">2.62[J]</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.392">10.392[J]</A>, <A HREF="m22b.html#22.40">22.40[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.006">2.006</a>, or <a href="m2a.html#2.051">2.051</a> and <a href="m2a.html#2.06">2.06</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Fundamentals of thermodynamics, chemistry, and transport applied to energy systems. Analysis of energy conversion and storage in thermal, mechanical, chemical, and electrochemical processes in power and transportation systems, with emphasis on efficiency, performance, and environmental impact. Applications to fuel reforming and alternative fuels, hydrogen, fuel cells and batteries, combustion, catalysis, combined and hybrid power cycles using fossil, nuclear and renewable resources. CO<SUB>2</SUB> separation and capture. Biomass energy. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.391"></a>
<p><h3>10.391[J] Sustainable Energy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1c.html#1.818">1.818[J]</A>, <A HREF="m2b.html#2.65">2.65[J]</A>, <A HREF="m11c.html#11.371">11.371[J]</A>, <A HREF="m22c.html#22.811">22.811[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2b.html#2.650">2.650[J]</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.291">10.291[J]</A>, <A HREF="m22a.html#22.081">22.081[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-1-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Assessment of current and potential future energy systems. Covers resources, extraction, conversion, and end-use technologies, with emphasis on meeting 21st-century regional and global energy needs in a sustainable manner. Examines various energy technologies in each fuel cycle stage for fossil (oil, gas, synthetic), nuclear (fission and fusion) and renewable (solar, biomass, wind, hydro, and geothermal) energy types, along with storage, transmission, and conservation issues. Emphasizes analysis of energy propositions within an engineering, economic and social context. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>M. Golay</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.392"></a>
<p><h3>10.392[J] Fundamentals of Advanced Energy Conversion
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.62">2.62[J]</A>, <A HREF="m22b.html#22.40">22.40[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2b.html#2.60">2.60[J]</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.390">10.390[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.006">2.006</a>, or <a href="m2a.html#2.051">2.051</a> and <a href="m2a.html#2.06">2.06</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Fundamentals of thermodynamics, chemistry, and transport applied to energy systems. Analysis of energy conversion and storage in thermal, mechanical, chemical, and electrochemical processes in power and transportation systems, with emphasis on efficiency, performance and environmental impact. Applications to fuel reforming and alternative fuels, hydrogen, fuel cells and batteries, combustion, catalysis, combined and hybrid power cycles using fossil, nuclear and renewable resources. CO<SUB>2</SUB> separation and capture. Biomass energy. Meets with 2.60 when offered concurrently; students taking the graduate version complete additional assignments.
