<a name="10.805"></a>
<p><h3>10.805[J] Technology, Law, and the Working Environment
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.436">IDS.436[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m1c.html#1.802">1.802[J]</A>, <A HREF="m1c.html#1.812">1.812[J]</A>, <A HREF="m11a.html#11.022">11.022[J]</A>, <A HREF="m11c.html#11.631">11.631[J]</A>, <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.061">IDS.061[J]</A>, <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.541">IDS.541[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Addresses relationship between technology-related problems and the law applicable to work environment. National Labor Relations Act, Occupational Safety and Health Act. Toxic Substances Control Act, state worker's compensation, and suits by workers in the courts discussed. Problems related to occupational health and safety, collective bargaining as a mechanism for altering technology in the workplace, job alienation, productivity, and the organization of work addressed. Prior courses or experience in the environmental, public health, or law-related areas.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.806"></a>
<p><h3>10.806 Management in Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Engineering School-Wide Elective Subject. <br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m2c.html#2.96">2.96</A>, <A HREF="m6c.html#6.930">6.930</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.806">10.806</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.653">16.653</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-1-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction and overview of engineering management. Financial principles, management of innovation, technical strategy and best management practices. Case study method of instruction emphasizes participation in class discussion. Focus is on the development of individual skills and management tools. Restricted to juniors and seniors.
<br><I>J. Chun</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.807"></a>
<p><h3>10.807[J] Innovation Teams
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m15b.html#15.371">15.371[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15c.html#15.911">15.911</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-4-4
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-114</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>F10-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-154</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces skills and capabilities for systematic technical and functional exploration, opportunity discovery, market understanding, value economics, innovation scale-up, intellectual property, elements of technology commercialization at scale, and communicating/working for impact inside and outside home disciplines. Students work in multidisciplinary teams formed around MIT research breakthroughs, with extensive in-class coaching from faculty and guidance from lab members and select mentors. Demonstrates a structured approach to innovating in which everything is a variable and the product, technology, and opportunities for new ventures can be seen as an act of synthesis. Teams gather evidence that permits a fact-based iteration across multiple application domains, markets, functionalities, technologies, and products, leading to a recommendation that maps a space of opportunity and includes actionable next steps to evolve the market and technology. Applications, resumes, and a brief statement of interest are required prior to registration.
<br>Fall: <I>L. Perez-Breva</I><br>Spring: <I>L. Perez-Breva</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.817"></a>
<p><h3>10.817[J] Atmospheric Chemistry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1c.html#1.84">1.84[J]</A>, <A HREF="m12c.html#12.807">12.807[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5b.html#5.60">5.60</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a detailed overview of the chemical transformations that control the abundances of key trace species in the Earth's atmosphere. Emphasizes the effects of human activity on air quality and climate. Topics include photochemistry, kinetics, and thermodynamics important to the chemistry of the atmosphere; stratospheric ozone depletion; oxidation chemistry of the troposphere; photochemical smog; aerosol chemistry; and sources and sinks of greenhouse gases and other climate forcers.
<br><I>J. Kroll</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<h2>School of Chemical Engineering Practice</h2>
<a name="10.80"></a><a name="10.82"></a><a name="10.84"></a><a name="10.86"></a>
<p><h3>10.80 (10.82, 10.84, 10.86) School of Chemical Engineering Practice -- Technical Accomplishment
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 0-6-0
<br><b>10.80:</b> TBA. <!--s--><br><b>10.82:</b> TBA. <!--s--><br><b>10.84:</b> TBA. <!--s--><br><b>10.86:</b> TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Conducted at industrial field stations of the School of Chemical Engineering Practice. Group problem assignments include process development design, simulation and control, technical service, and new-product development. Grading based on technical accomplishment. Credit granted in lieu of master's thesis. See departmental descripton on School of Chemical Engineering Practice for details. Enrollment limited and subject to plant availability.
<br>Fall: <I>T. Hatton</I><br>Spring: <I>T. Hatton</I><br><b>10.80:</b> No textbook information available<br><b>10.82:</b> No textbook information available<br><b>10.84:</b> No textbook information available<br><b>10.86:</b> No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.81"></a><a name="10.83"></a><a name="10.85"></a><a name="10.87"></a>
<p><h3>10.81 (10.83, 10.85, 10.87) School of Chemical Engineering Practice -- Communication Skills and Human Relations
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 0-6-0
<br><b>10.81:</b> TBA. <!--s--><br><b>10.83:</b> TBA. <!--s--><br><b>10.85:</b> TBA. <!--s--><br><b>10.87:</b> TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Conducted at industrial field stations of the School of Chemical Engineering Practice. Group problem assignments include process development, design, simulation and control, technical service, and new-product development. Grading based on communication skills and human relations in group assignments. Credit granted in lieu of master's thesis; see departmental description on School of Chemical Engineering Practice for details. Enrollment limited and subject to plant availability.
<br>Fall: <I>T. Hatton</I><br>Spring: <I>T. Hatton</I><br><b>10.81:</b> No textbook information available<br><b>10.83:</b> No textbook information available<br><b>10.85:</b> No textbook information available<br><b>10.87:</b> No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
</td></tr></table>

<h1 align="center">Course 10: Chemical Engineering<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://web.mit.edu/cheme/"><i>Course 10 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course10.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=10&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=++10&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m10a.html">10.00-10.899</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>10.90-10.999 plus THG, THU, UROP, UPOP</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>

<h2>General</h2>
<a name="10.90"></a>
<p><h3>10.90 Independent Research Problem
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For special and graduate students who wish to carry out some minor investigation in a particular field. Subject and hours to fit individual requirements.
<br>Fall: <I>R. Braatz</I><br>Spring: <I>R. Braatz</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.910"></a>
<p><h3>10.910 Independent Research Problem
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For undergraduate students who wish to carry out a special investigation in a particular field. Topic and hours arranged.
<br>Fall: <I>B. Johnston</I><br>IAP: <I>B. Johnston</I><br>Spring: <I>B. Johnston</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.911"></a>
<h3>10.911 Independent Research Problem
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For undergraduate students who wish to carry out a special investigation in a particular field. Topic and hours arranged.
<br>Fall: <I>B. Johnston</I><br>IAP: <I>B. Johnston</I><br>Spring: <I>B. Johnston</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.953"></a>
<p><h3>10.953 Seminar in Heterogeneous Catalysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R12-2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-517</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students present their research to other students and staff. Research topics include heterogeneous catalysis, design of catalytic materials, biomass conversion, biofuels, and CO<sub>2</sub> utilization.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.954"></a>
<p><h3>10.954 Seminar in Applied Optical Spectroscopy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T2-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-360</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Research seminars given by students, postdocs, and visitors. Topics covered include applied optical spectroscopy and imaging, with particular emphasis on nanomaterials and how they relate to alternative energy technologies.
<br>Fall: <I>W. Tisdale</I><br>Spring: <I>W. Tisdale</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.955"></a>
<p><h3>10.955 Seminar in Electrochemical Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R EVE (5-7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-360</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Designed to allow students to present and discuss their research in the area of electrochemical engineering with a particular emphasis on energy storage and conversion (e.g., batteries, fuel cells, electroreactors).  Specific topics include active materials design, electroanalytical platform development, and integration of electrochemical and imaging techniques.
<br>Fall: <I>F. Brushett</I><br>Spring: <I>F. Brushett</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.956"></a>
<p><h3>10.956 Seminar in Atomistic Simulation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-269</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar allows students to present their research to other students and staff. The research topics include electronic structure theory, computational chemistry techniques, and density functional theory with a focus on applications to catalysis and materials science.
<br>Fall: <I>H. Kulik</I><br>Spring: <I>H. Kulik</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.957"></a>
<p><h3>10.957 Seminar in Bioengineering Technology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W9-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-5305</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Research seminars presented by students and guest speakers on emerging biotechnologies.
<br>Fall: <I>K. Chung</I><br>Spring: <I>K. Chung</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.958"></a>
<p><h3>10.958 Seminar in the Fluid Mechanics and Self-assembly of Soft Matter
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M EVE (4-6 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-319</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers topics related to low Reynolds number hydrodynamics and the statistical physics of particulate media.  Specifics include the kinetics of phase transitions in soft matter and the time-varying deformation of colloidal dispersions, glasses and gels.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Swan</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Swan</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.960"></a>
<p><h3>10.960[J] Seminar in Polymers and Soft Matter
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m3b.html#3.903">3.903[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-0 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-237</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A series of seminars covering a broad spectrum of topics in polymer science and engineering, featuring both on- and off-campus speakers.
<br>Fall: <I>D. Irvine</I><br>Spring: <I>D. Irvine</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.961"></a>
<p><h3>10.961 Seminar in Advanced Air Pollution Research
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Research seminars, presented by students engaged in thesis work in the field of air pollution. Particular emphasis given to atmospheric chemistry, mathematical modeling, and policy analysis.

<a name="10.962"></a>
<p><h3>10.962 Seminar in Molecular Cell Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W8-10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-614</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Weekly seminar with discussion of ongoing research and relevant literature by graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and visiting scientists on issues at the interface of chemical engineering with molecular cell biology.  Emphasis is on quantitative aspects of physicochemical mechanisms involved in receptor/ligand interactions, receptor signal transduction processes, receptor-mediated cell behavioral responses, and applications of these in biotechnology and medicine.
<br>Fall: <I>D. Lauffenburger</I><br>Spring: <I>D. Lauffenburger</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.964"></a>
<p><h3>10.964 Seminar on Transport Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M12-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-319</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Research seminars presented by students and guest speakers on mathematical modeling of transport phenomena, focusing on electrochemical systems, electrokinetics, and microfluidics.
<br>Fall: <I>M. Bazant</I><br>Spring: <I>M. Bazant</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.965"></a>
<p><h3>10.965 Seminar in Biosystems Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T9-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=76">76-258</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Advanced topics on the state-of-the-art in design and implementation of analytical processes for biological systems, including single-cell analysis, micro/nanotechnologies, systems biology, biomanufacturing, and process engineering.  Seminars and discussions guided by the research interests of participating graduate students, postdoctoral associates, faculty, and visiting lecturers.
<br>Fall: <I>C. Love</I><br>Spring: <I>C. Love</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->

<p><h3>10.966 Seminar in Drug Delivery, Biomaterials, and Tissue Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on presentations by students and staff on current research in the area of drug delivery, biomaterials, and tissue engineering. Includes topics such as nanotherapeutics, intracellular delivery, and therapies for diabetes.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->

<p><h3>10.976 Process Design, Operations, and Control
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R4-5.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-319</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminars on the state of the art in design, operations, and control of processing systems, with emphasis on computer-based tools. Discussions guided by the research interests of participating students. Topics include mathematical and numerical techniques, representational methodologies, and software development.
<br>Fall: <I>P. Barton</I><br>Spring: <I>P. Barton</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.977"></a>
<p><h3>10.977 Seminar in Electrocatalysis
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of Instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar held every week, with presentations by graduate students and postdoctoral researchers on topics related to the molecular engineering of electrocatalysts. Emphasis on correlating atomic-level understanding of surfaces, their interactions with adsorbates, and the resulting impact on catalytic mechanisms.
<br>Fall: <I>G. Stephanopoulos</I><br>Spring: <I>G. Stephanopoulos</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->

<p><h3>10.978 Seminar in Advanced Materials for Energy Applications
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<a name="10.981"></a>
<p><h3>10.981 Seminar in Colloid and Interface Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T3.30-5.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-480</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Review of current topics in colloid and interface science. Topics include statistical mechanics and thermodynamics of micellar solutions, self-assembling systems, and microemulsions; solubilization of simple ions, amino acids, and proteins in reversed micelles; enzymatic reactions in reversed micelles; phase equilibria in colloidal systems; interfacial phenomena in colloidal systems; biomedical aspects of colloidal systems.
<br>Fall: <I>D. Blankschtein</I><br>Spring: <I>D. Blankschtein</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.982"></a>
<p><h3>10.982 Seminar in Experimental Colloid and Surface Chemistry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T EVE (4-6 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-360</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>In-depth discussion of fundamental physical relationships underlying techniques commonly used in the study of colloids and surfaces with a focus on recent advances and experimental applications. Topics have included the application of steady-state and time-resolved fluorescence spectroscopies, infrared spectroscopy, and scanning probe microscopies.
<br>Fall: <I>T. Hatton</I><br>Spring: <I>T. Hatton</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.983"></a>
<p><h3>10.983 Reactive Processing and Microfabricated Chemical Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W EVE (4-6 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-360</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Advanced topics in synthesis of materials through processes involving transport phenomena and chemical reactions. Chemical vapor deposition, modeling, and experimental approaches to kinetics of gas phase and surface reactions, transport phenomena in complex systems, materials synthesis, and materials characterization. Design fabrication and applications of microfabricated chemical systems. Seminars by graduate students, postdoctoral associates, participating faculty, and visiting lecturers.
<br>Fall: <I>K. Jensen</I><br>Spring: <I>K. Jensen</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.984"></a>
<p><h3>10.984 Biomedical Applications of Chemical Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W EVE (5-6.30 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=76">76-156</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Weekly seminar with lectures on current research by graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and visiting scientists on topics related to biomedical applications of chemical engineering. Specific topics include polymeric controlled release technology, extracorporal reactor design, biomedical polymers, bioengineering aspects of pharmaceuticals, and biomaterials/tissue and cell interactions.
<br>Fall: <I>R. Langer</I><br>Spring: <I>R. Langer</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.985"></a>
<p><h3>10.985 Seminar in Materials Systems Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-517</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the state of the art in the systems engineering of materials products and materials manufacturing processes. Addresses topics such as pharmaceuticals manufacturing, polymeric drug delivery systems, and nano- and microstructured materials. Discussions guided by the research interests of participating students. Includes techniques from applied mathematics and numerical methods, multiscale systems analysis, and control theory.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.987"></a>
<p><h3>10.987 Solid Thin Films and Interfaces
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-360</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Current research topics and fundamental issues relating to the deposition and properties of solid thin films and interfaces. Emphasis on applying analytical techniques, such as solid-state NMR, to explore the thermodynamics and kinetics of growth, defect formation, and structural modification incurred during film growth and post processing.
<br>Fall: <I>K. Gleason</I><br>Spring: <I>K. Gleason</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.989"></a>
<p><h3>10.989 Seminar in Biotechnology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R12-2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-360</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Research seminars, presented by graduate students and visitors from industry and academia, covering a broad range of topics of current interest in biotechnology. Discussion focuses on generic questions with potential biotechnological applications and the quest for solutions through a coordinated interdisciplinary approach.
<br>Fall: <I>G. Stephanopoulos</I><br>Spring: <I>G. Stephanopoulos</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.990"></a>
<p><h3>10.990 Introduction to Chemical Engineering Research
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-4-0 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to research in chemical engineering by faculty of chemical engineering department. Focus is on recent developments and research projects available to new graduate students.
<br><I>P. Hammond</I><br>
</p><!--end-->

<a name="10.994"></a>
<p><h3>10.994 Molecular Bioengineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R12-1.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=76">76-261D</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presentations and discussion by graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and visiting scientists of current literature and research on the engineering of protein biopharmaceuticals. Topics include combinatorial library construction and screening strategies, antibody engineering, gene therapy, cytokine engineering, and immunotherapy engineering strategies.
<br>Fall: <I>K. Wittrup</I><br>Spring: <I>K. Wittrup</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.995"></a>
<p><h3>10.995 Cellular and Metabolic Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T9-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-502</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, visiting scientists, and guest industrial practitioners to present their own research and highlight important advances from the literature in biochemical and bioprocess engineering. Topics of interest include metabolic engineering, novel microbial pathway design and optimization, synthetic biology, and applications of molecular biology to bioprocess development.
<br>Fall: <I>K. Prather</I><br>Spring: <I>K. Prather</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.997"></a>
<p><h3>10.997 Theoretical and Computational Immunology Seminar
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>F12.30-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-502</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presentations and discussions of current literature and research in theoretical and computational immunology.  Topics include T cell biology, cell-cell recognition in immunology, polymers and membranes, and statistical mechanics.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Chakraborty</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Chakraborty</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.998"></a>
<p><h3>10.998 Seminar in Crystallization Science and Technology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W2-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E17">E17-517</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on current topics related to crystallization science and technology in the chemical, pharmaceutical and food industries. Discusses fundamental work on nucleation, polymorphism, impurity crystal interactions and nano-crystal formation, along with industrial applications of crystallization.
<br>Staff<br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.EPE"></a>
<p><h3>10.EPE UPOP Engineering Practice Experience
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Engineering School-Wide Elective Subject. <br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m1c.html#1.EPE">1.EPE</A>, <A HREF="m2c.html#2.EPE">2.EPE</A>, <A HREF="m3b.html#3.EPE">3.EPE</A>, <A HREF="m6c.html#6.EPE">6.EPE</A>, <A HREF="m10b.html#10.EPE">10.EPE</A>, <A HREF="m16a.html#16.EPE">16.EPE</A>, <A HREF="m22a.html#22.EPE">22.EPE</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2c.html#2.EPW">2.EPW</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 0-0-1 [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides sophomores with guided practice in finding opportunities and excelling in the world of practice. Building on the skills and relationships acquired in the Engineering Practice Workshop, students receive coaching to articulate goals, invoke the UPOP network of mentors and employers, identify and pursue opportunities and negotiate terms of their summer assignment. Students complete a 10-12 week internship, which includes filing three progress reports, conducting one informational interview, and possibly hosting a site visit by MIT staff.  Returning to campus as juniors, UPOP students take part in reflective exercises that aid assimilation of learning objectives and reinforce the cognitive link between all aspects of the UPOP experience and disciplinary fields of study. Sequence begins in the spring of sophomore year and ends in the fall of junior year.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Crim</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Crim</I><br>No textbook information available
<a name="10.EPW"></a>
<p><h3>10.EPW UPOP Engineering Practice Workshop
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Engineering School-Wide Elective Subject. <br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m1c.html#1.EPW">1.EPW</A>, <A HREF="m2c.html#2.EPW">2.EPW</A>, <A HREF="m3b.html#3.EPW">3.EPW</A>, <A HREF="m6c.html#6.EPW">6.EPW</A>, <A HREF="m10b.html#10.EPW">10.EPW</A>, <A HREF="m16a.html#16.EPW">16.EPW</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.EPW">20.EPW</A>, <A HREF="m22a.html#22.EPW">22.EPW</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-0-0 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops foundational skills for the world of practice in science, technology, and engineering. Sophomores receive classroom instruction, and one-on-one and small-group coaching in basics of professional identity building. They attend field trips to local employers and receive job interview practice, coached by industry volunteers. Over IAP, students attend a weeklong Team Training Camp of experiential learning modules - led by MIT faculty with the help of MIT alums and other senior professionals in business, engineering, and science where students participate in creative simulations, team problem-solving challenges, and oral presentations, and practice networking with employers. Enrollment limited.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Crim</I><br>IAP: <I>J. Crim</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="10.S94"></a>
<p><h3>10.S94 Special Problems in Chemical Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
