<a name="14.444"></a>
<p><h3>14.444[J] Energy Economics and Policy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m15a.html#15.038">15.038[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a> or <a href="m15a.html#15.0111">15.0111</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m14b.html#14.44">14.44</A>, <A HREF="m15a.html#15.037">15.037</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-149</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-395</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Theoretical and empirical perspectives on individual and industrial demand for energy, energy supply, energy markets, and public policies affecting energy markets. Discusses aspects of the oil, natural gas, electricity, and nuclear  power sectors. Examines energy tax, price regulation, deregulation, energy efficiency and policies for controlling pollution and CO<SUB>2</SUB> emissions.  Students taking the graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 60.
<br><I>C. Knittel</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.451"></a>
<p><h3>14.451 Dynamic Optimization Methods with Applications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.06">14.06</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to dynamic optimization methods, including discrete-time dynamic programming in non-stochastic and stochastic environments, and continuous time methods including the Pontryagin maximum principle.  Applications may include the Ramsey model, irreversible investment models, and consumption choices under uncertainty. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>A. Simsek</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.452"></a>
<p><h3>14.452 Economic Growth
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">); second half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14b.html#14.451">14.451</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the sources and modeling of economic growth and income differences across nations.  Topics include an introduction to dynamic general equilibrium theory, the neoclassical growth model, overlapping  generations, determinants of technological progress, endogenous growth models, measurement of technological progress, the role of human capital in economic growth, and growth in a global economy. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>K. Acemoglu</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.453"></a>
<p><h3>14.453 Economic Fluctuations
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14b.html#14.452">14.452</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br>Ends Mar 23. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9-10.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-395</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F9-10.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-395</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Investigation of why aggregate economic activity fluctuates, and the role of policy in affecting fluctuations. Topics include the link between monetary policy and output, the economic cost of aggregate  fluctuations, the costs and benefits of price stability, and the role of central banks.  Introduction to real business cycle and new Keynesian models. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>G. Angeletos</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.454"></a>
<p><h3>14.454 Economic Crises
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); second half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14b.html#14.453">14.453</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br>Begins Apr 2. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9-10.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-395</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F9-10.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-395</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an overview of models of the business cycle caused by financial markets' frictions and shocks. Topics include credit crunch, collateral shocks, bank runs, contagion, speculative bubbles, credit booms,  leverage, safe asset shortages, capital flows and sudden stops. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>R. Caballero</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.46"></a>
<p><h3>14.46 Innovation Policy and the Economy
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9-10.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-124</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-151</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-372</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Designed for students interested in how to best design innovation-related public policies. Addresses questions such as whether the patent system helps or hinders innovation, how the US National Institutes of Health (NIH) should allocate its funding across diseases, and whether the US would benefit from raising caps on the employment of skilled immigrants through the H-1B visa program. Presentations and writing assignments strengthen skills for effective communication.
<br><I>H. Williams</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.461"></a>
<p><h3>14.461 Advanced Macroeconomics I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.122">14.122</a>, <a href="m14b.html#14.452">14.452</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Advanced subject in macroeconomics that seeks to bring students to the research frontier. Topics vary from year to year, covering a wide spectrum of classical and recent research. Topics may include business cycles, optimal monetary and tax policy, monetary economics, banking, and financial constraints on investment and incomplete markets.
<br><I>I. Werning</I><br>
<a name="14.462"></a>
<p><h3>14.462 Advanced Macroeconomics II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14b.html#14.461">14.461</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-372</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-376</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Advanced topics in financial frictions and obstacles to trade;  DSGE and micro founded macro models; analysis and design of financial systems; liquidity, payments systems, and monetary policy; intermediation, financial markets and platforms; business cycles, transitions, and financial crises; implementation and coordination game.
<br><I>G. M. Angeletos, R. Caballero</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.47"></a>
<p><h3>14.47[J] Global Energy: Politics, Markets, and Policy
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11a.html#11.167">11.167[J]</A>, <A HREF="m15a.html#15.2191">15.2191[J]</A>, 17.399[J])
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m11b.html#11.267">11.267</A>, <A HREF="m15a.html#15.219">15.219</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10-11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-372</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the ways economics and politics influence the fate of energy technologies, business models, and policies around the world. Extends fundamental concepts in the social sciences to case studies and simulations that illustrate how corporate, government, and individual decisions shape energy and environmental outcomes. In a final project, students apply the concepts in order to assess the prospects for an energy innovation to scale and advance sustainability goals in a particular regional market. Recommended prerequisite: 14.01. Meets with 15.219 when offered concurrently. Expectations and evaluation criteria differ for students taking graduate version; consult syllabus or instructor for specific details. Preference to juniors, seniors, and Energy Minors.
<br><I>V. Karplus</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.471"></a>
<p><h3>14.471 Public Economics I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.04">14.04</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Theory and evidence on government taxation policy. Topics include tax incidence; optimal tax theory; the effect of taxation on labor supply and savings; taxation and corporate behavior; and tax expenditure policy.
<br><I>J. Poterba</I><br>
<a name="14.472"></a>
<p><h3>14.472 Public Economics II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14b.html#14.471">14.471</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E52">E52-432</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-395</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Theory and evidence on government expenditure policy and on regulatory and tax responses to problems of market failure.   Focuses on social insurance programs such as social security and unemployment insurance, and on the causes and consequences of rising health expenditures.
<br><I>A. Finkelstein</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.473"></a>
<p><h3>14.473 Public Policy in Health Economics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)

<h2>Labor Economics and Industrial Relations</h2>
<a name="14.64"></a>
<p><h3>14.64 Labor Economics and Public Policy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.30">14.30</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to the labor market, how it functions, and the important role it plays in people's lives. Topics include supply and demand, minimum wages, labor market effects of social insurance and welfare programs, the collective bargaining relationship, discrimination, human capital, and unemployment. Completion of or concurrent enrollment in 14.03 or 14.04 recommended.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.661"></a>
<p><h3>14.661 Labor Economics I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.04">14.04</a>, <a href="m14a.html#14.32">14.32</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A systematic development of the theory of labor supply, labor demand, and human capital. Topics include wage and employment determination, turnover, search, immigration, unemployment, equalizing differences, and institutions in the labor market. Particular emphasis on the interaction between theoretical and empirical modeling.
<br><I>J. Angrist</I><br>
<a name="14.662"></a>
<p><h3>14.662 Labor Economics II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.04">14.04</a>, <a href="m14a.html#14.32">14.32</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9-10.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E52">E52-432</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-085</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Theory and evidence on the determinants of earnings levels, inequality, intergenerational mobility, skill demands, and employment structure.  Particular focus on the determinants of worker- and firm-level productivity; and the roles played by supply, demand, institutions, technology and trade in the evolving distribution of income.
<br><I>D. Autor</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Economic History</h2>
<a name="14.70"></a>
<p><h3>14.70[J] Medieval Economic History in Comparative Perspective
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Ha.html#21H.134">21H.134[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Surveys the conditions of material life and changing social and economic relations in medieval Europe using the comparative context of contemporary Islamic, Chinese, and Japanese experiences. Covers the emergence and decline of feudal institutions, the transformation of peasant agriculture, living standards and the course of epidemic disease, and the ebb and flow of long-distance trade across the Eurasian system. Particular emphasis placed on the study of those factors, both institutional and technological, which contributed to the emergence of capitalist organization and economic growth in western Europe in contrast to the trajectories followed by the other major medieval economies.
<br><I>S. Bobrycki</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.73"></a>
<p><h3>14.73 The Challenge of World Poverty
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Designed for students who are interested in the challenge posed by massive and persistent world poverty. Examines extreme poverty over time to see if it is no longer a threat, why some countries grow fast and others fall further behind, if growth or foreign aid help the poor, what we can do about corruption, if markets or NGOs should be left to deal with poverty, where to intervene, and how to deal with the disease burden and improve schools.
<br><I>F. Schilbach</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Economic Development</h2>
<a name="14.74"></a>
<p><h3>14.74 Foundations of Development Policy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m14b.html#14.740">14.740</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>, <a href="m14a.html#14.30">14.30</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the foundations of policy making in developing countries. Goal is to spell out various policy options and to quantify the trade-offs between them. Special emphasis on education, health, gender, fertility, adoption of technological innovation, and the markets for land, credit, and labor.  Students taking the graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>B. Olken</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.740"></a>
<h3>14.740 Foundations of Development Policy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m14b.html#14.74">14.74</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>, <a href="m14a.html#14.30">14.30</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the foundations of policy making in developing countries. Goal is to spell out various policy options and to quantify the trade-offs between them. Special emphasis on education, health, gender, fertility, adoption of technological innovation, and the markets for land, credit, and labor.  Students taking the graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.75"></a>
<p><h3>14.75 Political Economy and Economic Development
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>, <a href="m14a.html#14.30">14.30</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the relationship between political institutions and economic development, covering key theoretical issues as well as recent empirical evidence. Topics include corruption, democracy, dictatorship, and war. Discusses not just what we know on these topics, but how we know it, covering how to craft a good empirical study or field experiment and how to discriminate between reliable and unreliable evidence.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.770"></a>
<p><h3>14.770 Introduction to Collective Choice and Political Economy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Broad introduction to political economy. Covers topics from social choice theory to political agency models, including theories of voter turnout and comparison of political institutions.
<br><I>B. Olken</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.771"></a>
<p><h3>14.771 Development Economics: Microeconomic Issues
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.121">14.121</a>, <a href="m14a.html#14.122">14.122</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A rigorous introduction to core micro-economic issues in economic development, focusing on both key theoretical contributions and empirical applications to understand both why some countries are poor and on how markets function differently in poor economies. Topics include human capital (education and health); labor markets; credit markets; land markets; firms; and the role of the public sector.
<br><I>B. Olken</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.772"></a>
<p><h3>14.772 Development Economics: Macroeconomics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.121">14.121</a>, <a href="m14b.html#14.451">14.451</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-151</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-151</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Dynamic models of growth and development emphasizing migration, modernization, risk and finance, and technological change; static and dynamic models of political economy; the dynamics of income distribution and institutional change; SME and larger firm structure in developing countries; development, transparency, and information systems; and functioning of financial markets and institutions in emerging markets, their design and regulation.
<br><I>R. Townsend</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.773"></a>
<p><h3>14.773 Political Economy: Institutions and Development
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.121">14.121</a>,<a href="m14b.html#14.451">14.451</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10.30-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E52">E52-432</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F4-5.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E52">E52-432</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Economists and policymakers increasingly realize the importance of political institutions in shaping economic performance, especially in the context of understanding economic development. Work on the determinants of economic policies and institutions is in its infancy, but is growing rapidly. Subject provides an introduction to this area. Topics covered: the economic role of institutions; the effects of social conflict and class conflict on economic development; political economic determinants of macro policies; political development; theories of income distribution and distributional conflict; the efficiency effects of distributional conflict; the causes and consequences of corruption; the role of colonial history; and others. Both theoretical and empirical approaches discussed. Subject can be taken either as part of the Development Economics or the Positive Political Economy fields.
<br><I>D. Acemoglu, L. Fergusson</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.781"></a>
<p><h3>14.781[J] Political Economy I: Theories of the State and the Economy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m15b.html#15.678">15.678[J]</A>, <A HREF="m17a.html#17.100">17.100[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-550</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Critical analysis of liberal, neoclassical, and Marxist perspectives on modern society. Alternative theories of economic growth, historical change, the state, classes, and ideology.
<br><I>M. Piore, S. Berger</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.999"></a>
<p><h3>14.999 Topics in Inequality
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14b.html#14.452">14.452</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Addresses empirical and theoretical issues of inequality from various perspectives, such as macroeconomic, labor, public finance, and political economy.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="14.THG"></a>

<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->

</p><!--end-->

<h1 align="center">Course 15: Management<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://mitsloan.mit.edu/"><i>Course 15 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course15.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=15&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=++15&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>15.00-15.299</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m15b.html">15.30-15.699</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m15c.html">15.70-15.999 plus UROP and Thesis</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<h2>Managerial Economics</h2>
<a name="15.002"></a>
<p><h3>15.002 Sloan Innovation Period Requirement
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Units assigned to MBA students upon completion of the Sloan Innovation Period requirement. MBAs only.
<br>Fall: <I>E. Seidman</I><br>IAP: <I>E. Seidman</I><br>Spring: <I>E. Seidman</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.003"></a>
<p><h3>15.003 Analytics Tools
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-1 [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Units assigned to Master of Business Analytics students upon completion of the Analytics Tools requirement. Restricted to Master of Business Analytics students.
<br>Fall: <I>D. Bertsimas</I><br>IAP: <I>D. Bertsimas</I><br>Spring: <I>D. Bertsimas</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.010"></a>
<p><h3>15.010 Economic Analysis for Business Decisions
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces principles of microeconomics as a framework for making more informed managerial decisions. Includes the analysis of competitive markets with supply and demand, sources of market power and strategic pricing. Provides an introduction to game theory to study how firms compete, anti -trust policy, and how to generate cooperation both within and between firms. Restricted to first-year Sloan MBA students.
<br><I>A. Bonatti</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.011"></a>
<h3>15.011 Economic Analysis for Business Decisions
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m15a.html#15.0111">15.0111</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces principles of microeconomics as a framework for making more informed managerial decisions. Includes the analysis of competitive markets with supply and demand, sources of market power and strategic pricing. Provides an introduction to game theory to study how firms compete, anti-trust policy, and how to generate cooperation both within and between firms. Expectations and evaluation criteria differ for students taking graduate version; consult syllabus or instructor for specific details. Intended for non-Sloan graduate students.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.0111"></a>
<p><h3>15.0111 Economic Analysis for Business Decisions
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m15a.html#15.011">15.011</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces principles of microeconomics as a framework for making more informed managerial decisions. Includes the analysis of competitive markets with supply and demand, sources of market power and strategic pricing. Provides an introduction to game theory to study how firms compete, anti-trust policy, and how to generate cooperation both within and between firms. Expectations and evaluation criteria differ for students taking graduate version; consult syllabus or instructor for specific details.
<br><I>J. Denrell</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.012"></a>
<p><h3>15.012 Applied Macro- and International Economics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-2
<br>Ends Mar 16. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-145</a>) or <i>MWF10-11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-315</a>) or <i>MWF2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-145</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Uses case studies to investigate the macroeconomic environment in which firms operate. Subject develops the basic tools of macro and international economics: monetary and fiscal policy, growth theory and exchange rates. Discusses recent emerging market and financial crises, examining their causes, how best to address them, and how to prevent them from recurring in the future. Evaluates different strategies of economic development, including an understanding of growth and development and the role of debt and foreign aid.
<br><I>R. Rigobon, C. Steinwender</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.013"></a>
<p><h3>15.013 Industrial Economics for Strategic Decisions
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15a.html#15.010">15.010</a> or <a href="m15a.html#15.011">15.011</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Applies principles of industrial economics most relevant for corporate strategy to analysis of particular industries. Topics include market structure and its determinants; rational strategic behavior in small numbers situations; strategies for price and nonprice competition; dynamic pricing, output, and advertising decisions; entry and entry deterrence; competition with network externalities; investments under uncertainty; R&D and patent licensing; and the growth and evolution of industries.
<br><I>R. Pindyck</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.014"></a>
<p><h3>15.014 Applied Macro- and International Economics II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); second half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15a.html#15.012">15.012</a> or <a href="m15a.html#15.015">15.015</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-2
<br>Begins Apr 2. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF8.30-10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-315</a>) or <i>MWF10-11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-315</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Establishes understanding of the development processes of societies and economies. Studies several dimensions of sustainability (environmental, social, political, institutional, economy, organizational, relational, and personal) and the balance among them. Explores the basics of governmental intervention, focusing on areas such as the judicial system, environment, social security, and health. Builds skills to determine what type of policy is most appropriate. Considers implications of new technologies on the financial sector: internationalization of currencies, mobile payment systems, and cryptocurrencies. Discusses the institutional framework to ensure choices are sustainable across all dimensions and applications.
<br><I>R. Rigobon</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.015"></a>
<p><h3>15.015 Macro and International Economics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the policy and economic environment of firms. Subject divided in two parts: study of the closed economy and how monetary and fiscal policy interacts with employment, GNP, inflation, and interest rates; and study of the open economy with discussion of recent financial and currency crises in developed and emerging markets. Restricted to Sloan Fellows.
<br><I>A. Cavallo</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.017"></a>
<p><h3>15.017 Planning, Policy, and Technology for Energy Access in Developing Countries
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces students to the complex challenges of providing universal energy access in developing countries. Examines the technical, political, and social trade-offs inherent in designing energy solutions that can ensure universal access, particularly for very poor, sometimes remote communities. Discusses several aspects of energy poverty including electrification, heating, and cooking, and reviews the range of technologies being developed to meet these needs. Students make extensive use of optimization models to plan on- and off-grid energy systems, and discover how to use these models within the existing social, political, regulatory, and financial constraints.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.021"></a>
<p><h3>15.021[J] Real Estate Economics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.433">11.433[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>, <a href="m15a.html#15.010">15.010</a>, or <a href="m15a.html#15.011">15.011</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops understanding of the fundamental economic factors that shape the market for real property, as well as the influence of capital markets in asset pricing. Analyzes of housing as well as commercial real estate. Covers demographic analysis, regional growth, construction cycles, urban land markets, and location theory. Exercises and modeling techniques for measuring and predicting property demand, supply, vacancy, and prices.
<br><I>W. Wheaton</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.023"></a>
<p><h3>15.023[J] Global Climate Change: Economics, Science, and Policy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m12c.html#12.848">12.848[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m12a.html#12.348">12.348[J]</A>, <A HREF="m15a.html#15.026">15.026[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m5b.html#5.60">5.60</a>; <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a> or <a href="m15a.html#15.010">15.010</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces scientific, economic, and ecological issues underlying the threat of global climate change, and the institutions engaged in negotiating an international response. Develops an integrated approach to analysis of climate change processes, and assessment of proposed policy measures, drawing on research and model development within the MIT Joint Program on the Science and Policy of Global Change. Graduate students are expected to explore the topic in greater depth through reading and individual research.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.024"></a>
<p><h3>15.024 Applied Economics for Managers
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m15c.html#15.722">15.722</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops facility with concepts, language and tools of micro economics. Primary focus on the analysis of markets, strategic interactions among firms and organizational structure within firms. Emphasizes integration of theory, data, and judgment in the analysis of a wide range of corporate decisions, both between and within firms. Restricted to MIT Sloan Fellows.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.025"></a>
<p><h3>15.025 Game Theory for Strategic Advantage
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m15a.html#15.0251">15.0251</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15a.html#15.010">15.010</a>, <a href="m15a.html#15.011">15.011</a>, <a href="m15a.html#15.015">15.015</a>, or <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10-11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-223</a>) or <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-223</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops and applies principles of game theory relevant to managers' strategic decisions. Topics include how to reason about strategies and opponents; strategic commitment and negotiations; reputation and seemingly irrational actions; bidding in auctions; and the design of auctions, contests and markets. Applications to a variety of business decisions that arise in different industries, both within and outside the firm. Meets with 15.0251 when offered concurrently. Expectations and evaluation criteria differ for students taking graduate version; consult syllabus or instructor for specific details.
<br><I>A. Bonatti, G. Cisternas</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=15.025');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.0251"></a>
<p><h3>15.0251 Game Theory for Strategic Advantage
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">

Topics include how to reason about strategies and opponents; strategic commitment and negotiations; reputation and seemingly irrational actions; bidding in auctions; and the design of auctions, contests and markets. Applications to a variety of business decisions that arise in different industries, both within and outside the firm. Meets with 15.025 when offered concurrently. Expectations and evaluation criteria differ for students taking graduate version; consult syllabus or instructor for specific details.
<br><I>A. Bonatti, G. Cisternas</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=15.0251');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>

<a name="15.026"></a>
<p><h3>15.026[J] Global Climate Change: Economics, Science, and Policy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m12a.html#12.348">12.348[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m12c.html#12.848">12.848[J]</A>, <A HREF="m15a.html#15.023">15.023[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>, <a href="m5b.html#5.60">5.60</a>, <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces scientific, economic, and ecological issues underlying the threat of global climate change, and the institutions engaged in negotiating an international response. Develops an integrated approach to analysis of climate change processes, and assessment of proposed policy measures, drawing on research and model development within the MIT Joint Program on the Science and Policy of Global Change. Graduate students are expected to explore the topic in greater depth through reading and individual research. 12.340 recommended.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.027"></a>
<p><h3>15.027 Opportunities in Developing Economies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Investigates the role of the private sector in developing economies, highlighting how solving market failures can improve overall welfare. Covers constraints faced by firms in developing economies: contract enforcement, corruption, political risk, human rights, IP and infrastructure. Uses case studies to discuss successful firms and innovative solutions to these constraints, including public-private partnerships, the role of technology, the role of finance and impact investing.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.031"></a>
<p><h3>15.031[J] Energy Decisions, Markets, and Policies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11a.html#11.161">11.161[J]</A>, <A HREF="m14b.html#14.43">14.43[J]</A>, <A HREF="m17a.html#17.397">17.397[J]</A>, <A HREF="m21Aa.html#21A.415">21A.415[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>, <a href="m15a.html#15.0111">15.0111</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Structured around choices and constraints regarding sources and uses of energy by households, firms, and governments, introduces managerial, economic, political, social and cultural frameworks for describing and explaining behavior at various levels of aggregation. Includes examples of cost-benefit, organizational and institutional analyses of energy generation, distribution, and consumption. Topics include the role of markets and prices; financial analysis of energy-related investments; institutional path dependence; economic and political determinants of government regulation and the impact of regulation on decisions; and other forms of government action and social norms regarding desired behavior and opportunities for businesses and consumers, including feedback into the political/regulatory system. Examples drawn from a wide range of countries and settings.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.032"></a>
<p><h3>15.032[J] Engineering, Economics and Regulation of the Electric Power Sector
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6b.html#6.695">6.695[J]</A>, <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.505">IDS.505[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.064">IDS.064</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a>, <a href="m22a.html#22.081">22.081</a>, <a href="mIDSa.html#IDS.060">IDS.060</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://stellar.mit.edu/S/course/IDS/sp18/IDS.505/">http://stellar.mit.edu/S/course/IDS/sp18/IDS.505/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10.30-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-395</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an in-depth and interdisciplinary look at electric power systems, focusing on regulation as the link among engineering, economic, legal, and environmental viewpoints. Topics include electricity markets, incentive regulation of network utilities, retail competition, tariff design, distributed generation, rural electrification, multinational electricity markets, environmental impacts, and the future of utilities and strategic sustainability issues under both traditional and competitive regulatory frameworks. Background in policy, microeconomics, or engineering desirable. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>C. Batlle Lopez, J. Jenkins, I. Perez-Arriaga</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.034"></a>
<p><h3>15.034 Metrics for Managers
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m15a.html#15.0341">15.0341</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Enables students to evaluate the quality of evidence supported by data and to implement an empirical toolkit that provides credible answers to questions in finance, marketing, human resources, strategy, and general business planning. Uses econometrics as the underlying framework to develop deep understanding of regression modelling and its insights for data analytics using big and small data. Focuses primarily on empirical work conducted by students via in-class labs, problem sets, and projects. Expectations and evaluation criteria differ for students taking graduate version; consult syllabus or instructor for specific details.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.0341"></a>
<p><h3>15.0341 Metrics for Managers
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)

<br>Units: 4-0-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">

Uses econometrics as the underlying framework to develop deep understanding of regression modelling and its insights for data analytics using big and small data. Focuses primarily on empirical work conducted by students via in-class labs, problem sets, and projects. Expectations and evaluation criteria differ for students taking graduate version; consult syllabus or instructor for specific details.

<a name="15.037"></a>
<p><h3>15.037[J] Energy Economics and Policy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m14b.html#14.44">14.44[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a> or <a href="m15a.html#15.0111">15.0111</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m14b.html#14.444">14.444</A>, <A HREF="m15a.html#15.038">15.038</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-149</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-149</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analyzes business and public policy issues in energy markets and in the environmental markets to which they are closely tied. Examines the economic determinants of industry structure and evolution of competition among firms in these industries. Investigates successful and unsuccessful strategies for entering new markets and competing in existing markets. Industries studied include oil, natural gas, coal, electricity, and transportation. Topics include climate change and environmental policy, the role of speculation in energy markets, the political economy of energy policies, and market power and antitrust. Two team-based simulation games, representing the world oil market and a deregulated electricity market, act to cement the concepts covered in lecture. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 60.
<br><I>C. Knittel</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.038"></a>
<h3>15.038[J] Energy Economics and Policy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m14b.html#14.444">14.444[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m14a.html#14.01">14.01</a> or <a href="m15a.html#15.0111">15.0111</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m14b.html#14.44">14.44</A>, <A HREF="m15a.html#15.037">15.037</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-149</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-395</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Theoretical and empirical perspectives on individual and industrial demand for energy, energy supply, energy markets, and public policies affecting energy markets. Discusses aspects of the oil, natural gas, electricity, and nuclear  power sectors. Examines energy tax, price regulation, deregulation, energy efficiency and policies for controlling pollution and CO<SUB>2</SUB> emissions.  Students taking the graduate version complete additional assignments. Limited to 60.
<br><I>C. Knittel</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Operations Research/Statistics</h2>
<a name="15.053"></a>
<p><h3>15.053 Optimization Methods in Business Analytics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m1a.html#1.00">1.00</a>, <a href="m1a.html#1.000">1.000</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.00">6.00</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.0001">6.0001</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10-11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-145</a>) or <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-335</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-085</a>) or <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-315</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-315</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces optimization methods with a focus on modeling, solution techniques, and analysis. Covers linear programming, network optimization, integer programming, nonlinear programming, and dynamic programming.  Applications to logistics, manufacturing, statistics, machine learning, transportation, game theory, marketing, project management, and finance. Includes a project in which student teams select and solve an optimization problem (possibly a large-scale problem) of practical interest.
<br><I>J. Orlin</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.054"></a>
<p><h3>15.054[J] The Airline Industry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1b.html#1.232">1.232[J]</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.71">16.71[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Overview of the global airline industry, focusing on recent industry performance, current issues and challenges for the future. Fundamentals of airline industry structure, airline economics, operations planning, safety, labor relations, airports and air traffic control, marketing, and competitive strategies, with an emphasis on the interrelationships among major industry stakeholders. Recent research findings of the MIT Global Airline Industry Program are showcased, including the impacts of congestion and delays, evolution of information technologies, changing human resource management practices, and competitive effects of new entrant airlines. Taught by faculty participants of the Global Airline Industry Program.
<br><I>P. Belobaba</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.060"></a>
<p><h3>15.060 Data, Models, and Decisions
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m15c.html#15.730">15.730</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces students to the basic tools in using data to make informed management decisions. Covers introductory probability, decision analysis, basic statistics, regression, simulation, linear and nonlinear optimization, and discrete optimization. Computer spreadsheet exercises, cases, and examples drawn from marketing, finance, operations management, and other management functions. Restricted to first-year Sloan master's students.
<br><I>J. Vielma Centeno</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.062"></a>
<p><h3>15.062[J] Data Mining: Finding the Data and Models that Create Value
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.145">IDS.145[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m15a.html#15.0621">15.0621</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15a.html#15.060">15.060</a> or <a href="m15a.html#15.075">15.075</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br>Ends Mar 16. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW4-5.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-345</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>T4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-335</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to data mining and machine learning, a class of methods that assist in recognizing patterns and making intelligent use of massive amounts of data collected via the internet, e-commerce, electronic banking, point-of-sale devices, bar-code readers, medical databases, search engines, and social networks. Includes topics in logistic regression, association rules, tree-structured classification and regression, cluster analysis, discriminant analysis, and neural network methods. Presents examples of successful applications in areas such as credit ratings, fraud detection, marketing, customer relationship management, and investments. Introduces data-mining software. Term project required. Meets with 15.0621 when offered concurrently. Expectations and evaluation criteria differ for students taking graduate version; consult syllabus or instructor for specific details.
<br><I>R. Welsch</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=15.062');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">

<a name="15.066"></a>
<p><h3>15.066[J] System Optimization and Analysis for Operations
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2c.html#2.851">2.851[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to mathematical modeling, optimization, and simulation, as applied to manufacturing and operations. Specific methods include linear programming, network flow problems, integer and nonlinear programming, discrete-event simulation, heuristics and computer applications for manufacturing processes, operations and systems. Restricted to Leaders for Global Operations students.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.068"></a>
<p><h3>15.068 Statistical Consulting
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15a.html#15.060">15.060</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW4-5.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-145</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Addresses statistical issues as a consultant would face them: deciphering the client's question; finding appropriate data; performing a viable analysis; and presenting the results in compelling ways. Real-life cases and examples.
<br><I>A. Barnett</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=15.068');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>

<a name="15.070"></a>
<p><h3>15.070[J] Advanced Stochastic Processes
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6a.html#6.265">6.265[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6b.html#6.431B">6.431B</a>, <a href="m15a.html#15.085">15.085J</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100A">18.100A</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100B">18.100B</a>, or <a href="m18a.html#18.100Q">18.100Q</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-154</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analysis and modeling of stochastic processes. Topics include measure theoretic probability, martingales, filtration, and stopping theorems; elements of large deviations theory; Brownian motion and reflected Brownian motion; stochastic integration and Ito calculus; functional limit theorems. Applications to finance theory, insurance, queueing and inventory models.
<br><I>D. Gamarnik</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=15.070');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.071"></a>
<p><h3>15.071 The Analytics Edge
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15a.html#15.053">15.053</a> or <a href="m15a.html#15.060">15.060</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m15a.html#15.0711">15.0711</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-345</a>) or <i>MW2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-345</a>) or <i>MW4-5.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-315</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-345</a>) or <i>F3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-345</a>) or <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-315</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-345</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents real-world examples in which quantitative methods provide a significant competitive edge that has led to a first order impact on some of today's most important companies. Examples include finance (quantitative asset management and options pricing), sports, health care, revenue management, supply chains, and the Internet. Outlines the competitive landscape. Presents the key quantitative methods that created the edge (data-mining, dynamic optimization, simulation), and discusses their impact. Uses R programming language. Includes team projects. Meets with 15.0711 when offered concurrently. Expectations and evaluation criteria differ for students taking graduate version; consult syllabus or instructor for specific details.
<br>Fall: <I>R. Freund, D. Bertsimas</I><br>Spring: <I>R. Freund, D. Bertsimas</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=15.071');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.0711"></a>
<p><h3>15.0711 The Analytics Edge
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15a.html#15.053">15.053</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8

<br>Presents real-world examples in which quantitative methods provide a significant competitive edge that has led to a first order impact on some of today's most important companies. Examples include finance (quantitative asset management and options pricing), sports, health care, revenue management, supply chains, and the Internet. Outlines the competitive landscape. Presents the key quantitative methods that created the edge (data-mining, dynamic optimization, simulation), and discusses their impact. Uses R programming language. Includes team projects. Meets with 15.071 when offered concurrently. Expectations and evaluation criteria differ for students taking graduate version; consult syllabus or instructor for specific details.
<br><I>R. Freund</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=15.0711');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
