<h2>Finance</h2>
<a name="15.401"></a>
<p><h3>15.401 Managerial Finance
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-5
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-111</a>) or <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-111</a>) or <i>MW10-11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-345</a>) or <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-262</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-345</a>) or <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-345</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-335</a>) or <i>F9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-335</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers the fundamentals of modern financial analysis that are essential to any manager, entrepreneur, investor, or other business professional.  Topics include valuation, risk analysis, personal and corporate investment decisions, and an introduction to security analysis and asset management. A prerequisite for all other finance electives offered by the Finance Group. Meets with 15.417 when offered concurrently. Expectations and evaluation criteria differ for students taking graduate version; consult syllabus or instructor for specific details.
<br>Fall: <I>D. Greenwald</I><br>Spring: <I>D. Greenwald</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=15.401');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
<a name="15.402"></a>
<p><h3>15.402 Corporate Finance
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.401">15.401</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m15b.html#15.418">15.418</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E52">E52-164</a>) or <i>MW2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E52">E52-164</a>) or <i>TR8.30-10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-262</a>) or <i>TR10-11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-262</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to corporate financial management. Topics include capital budgeting, investment decisions and valuation; working capital management, security issues; dividend policy; optimal capital structure; and real options analysis. Meets with 15.418 when offered concurrently.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Malenko</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Malenko</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=15.402');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.403"></a>
<p><h3>15.403 Introduction to the Practice of Finance
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-1 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar exposes students to some of the basic institutions and practices of the financial industry. Includes panel discussions with representatives from leading financial institutions, MIT alumni currently engaged in the financial services sector, and leading industry vendors. Restricted to first-year Finance track MBA students.
<br><I>J. Parsons</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.414"></a>
<p><h3>15.414 Financial Management
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.511">15.511</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m15c.html#15.724">15.724</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to corporate finance and capital markets. Topics include project and company valuation, real options, measuring risk and return, stock pricing and the performance of trading strategies, corporate financing policy, the cost of capital, and risk management. Provides a broad overview of both theory and practice. Restricted to MIT Sloan Fellows.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.415"></a>
<p><h3>15.415 Finance Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 6-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Core theory of capital markets and corporate finance. Topics include functions and operations of capital markets, analysis of consumption-investment decisions of investors, valuation theory, financial securities, risk analysis, portfolio theory, pricing models of risky assets, theory of efficient markets, as well as investment, financing and risk management decisions of firms. Provides a theoretical foundation of finance and its applications. Restricted to students in the Master of Finance Program.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.417"></a>
<p><h3>15.417 Laboratory in Investments
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-2-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-111</a>) or <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E25">E25-111</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>F1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-221</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-345</a>) or <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-345</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers fundamentals of modern financial analysis that are essential to any manager, entrepreneur, investor, or other business professional. Topics include valuation, risk analysis, personal and corporate investment decisions, and an introduction to security analysis and asset management.  Laboratory introduces students to methods of modern quantitative finance and to practices of the investment management industry.  Projects include implementation and testing of investment strategies and asset pricing models using real-world market data. Instruction and practice in oral and written communication provided.
<br><I>P. Mende</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.418"></a>
<p><h3>15.418 Laboratory in Corporate Finance
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.417">15.417</a>
<br>Units: 4-2-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m15b.html#15.402">15.402</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers capital budgeting, investment decisions and valuation; working capital management, security issues; dividend policy; optimal capital structure; and real options analysis. Laboratory involves projects of an applied nature in which students either conduct an event study and analyze its impact on firm capital market value, or conduct a merger model between two firms of the student's choosing. Emphasizes use of research databases to test hypotheses. Instruction and practice in communication includes report writing, team projects, and oral and visual presentation. Expectations and evaluation criteria differ for students taking graduate version; consult syllabus or instructor for specific details.
<br><I>S. Myers</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.425"></a>
<p><h3>15.425 Corporate Finance
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.415">15.415</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to corporate financial management. Topics include capital budgeting, investment decisions and valuation; working capital management, security issues; dividend policy; optimal capital structure; and real options analysis. Restricted to students in the Master of Finance Program.
<br><I>K. Asquith</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.426"></a>
<p><h3>15.426[J] Real Estate Finance and Investment
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.431">11.431[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Concepts and techniques for analyzing financial decisions in commercial property development and investment. Topics include property income streams, urban economics, discounted cash flow, equity valuation, leverage and income tax considerations, development projects, and joint ventures.
<br><I>D. Geltner</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.427"></a>
<p><h3>15.427[J] Real Estate Capital Markets
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.432">11.432[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m11c.html#11.431">11.431</a>; <a href="m15b.html#15.402">15.402</a> or <a href="m15b.html#15.414">15.414</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br>Ends Mar 23. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=9">9-354</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>T EVE (5.30-7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=9">9-354</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces real estate capital markets for institutional investors. Topics include real estate investment trusts (REIT), commercial mortgage-backed securities (CMBS), and private equity.  Concepts and techniques for investment analysis include portfolio theory and equilibrium asset pricing. Additional topics may include price indexing and derivatives.
<br><I>D. Geltner</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=15.427');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.428"></a>
<p><h3>15.428[J] Tools for Analysis:  Design for Real Estate and Infrastructure Development
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); second half of term
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.434">11.434[J]</A>, <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.720">IDS.720[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br>Begins Apr 2. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR4-5.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=9">9-354</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>T EVE (5.30-7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=9">9-354</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to analytical tools to support design and decision-making in real estate, infrastructure development, and investment. Particular focus on identifying and valuing sources of flexibility using "real options," Monte-Carlo simulation, and other techniques from the field of engineering systems. Integrates economic and engineering perspectives, and is suitable for students with various backgrounds. Provides useful preparation for thesis work in the area.
<br><I>D. Geltner</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.429"></a>
<p><h3>15.429[J] Securitization of Mortgages and Other Assets
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.353">11.353[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.426">15.426</a>, <a href="m15b.html#15.401">15.401</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Investigates the economics and finance of securitization, a practice that allows illiquid assets to be transformed into more liquid securities. Considers the basic mechanics of structuring deals for various asset-backed securities. Investigates the pricing of pooled assets, using Monte Carlo and other option pricing techniques, as well as various trading strategies used in these markets.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.431"></a>
<p><h3>15.431 Entrepreneurial Finance and Venture Capital
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.402">15.402</a>, <a href="m15b.html#15.414">15.414</a>, or <a href="m15b.html#15.415">15.415</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m15b.html#15.4311">15.4311</A>, <A HREF="m15c.html#15.719">15.719</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the elements of entrepreneurial finance, focusing on technology-based start-up ventures, and the early stages of company development. Addresses key questions which challenge all entrepreneurs: how much money can and should be raised; when should it be raised and from whom; what is a reasonable valuation of a company; and how funding, employment contracts and exit decisions should be structured. Aims to prepare students for these decisions, both as entrepreneurs and venture capitalists. In-depth analysis of the structure of the private equity industry. Meets with 15.4311 when offered concurrently. Expectations and evaluation criteria for graduate students will differ from those of undergraduates; consult syllabus or instructor for specific details.
<br><I>M. Rhodes-Kropf</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.4311"></a>
<p><h3>15.4311 Entrepreneurial Finance and Venture Capital
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.418">15.418</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m15b.html#15.431">15.431</A>, <A HREF="m15c.html#15.719">15.719</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-057</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the elements of entrepreneurial finance, focusing on technology-based start-up ventures, and the early stages of company development. Addresses key questions which challenge all entrepreneurs: how much money can and should be raised; when should it be raised and from whom; what is a reasonable valuation of a company; and how funding, employment contracts and exit decisions should be structured. Aims to prepare students for these decisions, both as entrepreneurs and venture capitalists. In-depth analysis of the structure of the private equity industry. Meets with 15.431 when offered concurrently. Expectations and evaluation criteria for graduate students will differ from those of undergraduates; consult syllabus or instructor for specific details.
<br><I>D. Nandy</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=15.4311');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.433"></a>
<p><h3>15.433 Financial Markets
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m15b.html#15.4331">15.4331</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.401">15.401</a>, <a href="m15b.html#15.414">15.414</a>, or <a href="m15b.html#15.415">15.415</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Financial theory and empirical evidence for making investment decisions. Topics include portfolio theory; equilibrium models of security prices, including the capital asset pricing model and the arbitrage pricing theory; the empirical behavior of security prices; market efficiency; performance evaluation; and behavioral finance. Meets with 15.4331 when offered concurrently. Expectations and evaluation criteria differ for students taking graduate version; consult syllabus or instructor for specific details.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.4331"></a>
<p><h3>15.4331 Financial Markets
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m15b.html#15.433">15.433</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.411">15.411</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers financial theory and empirical evidence for making investment decisions. Topics include portfolio theory; equilibrium models of security prices, including the capital asset pricing model and the arbitrage pricing theory; empirical behavior of security prices; market efficiency; performance evaluation; and behavioral finance. Meets with 15.433 when offered concurrently. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Preference to Course 15 students.
<br><I>J. Pan</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.434"></a>
<p><h3>15.434 Advanced Corporate Finance
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.402">15.402</a>, <a href="m15b.html#15.414">15.414</a>, or <a href="m15b.html#15.415">15.415</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m15b.html#15.4341">15.4341</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers advanced topics in corporate finance, including complex valuations, static and dynamic capital structure, risk management, and real options. Also considers security design, restructuring, bankruptcy, corporate control and governance, and international finance issues. Expectations and evaluation criteria differ for students taking graduate version; consult syllabus or instructor for specific details. Meets with 15.4341 when offered concurrently.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.4341"></a>
<p><h3>15.4341 Advanced Corporate Finance
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.418">15.418</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m15b.html#15.434">15.434</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers advanced topics in corporate finance, including complex valuations, static and dynamic capital structure, risk management, and real options. Also considers security design, restructuring, bankruptcy, corporate control and governance, and international finance issues. Expectations and evaluation criteria differ for students taking graduate version; consult syllabus or instructor for specific details. Meets with 15.434 when offered concurrently.
<br><I>E. Matveyev</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.436"></a>
<p><h3>15.436 Cases in Corporate Finance: Bridging Theory and Practice
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.402">15.402</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-223</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a bridge between theory and practice, taking the perspectives of investment bankers and corporate executives responsible for financial strategy. Case-based, covering a wide range of topics, including corporate valuation tools; IPOs, convertible securities and other types of financings; cash policy and leveraged recapitalizations; spinoffs, special purpose vehicles and corporate restructurings; risky debt and bankruptcy; and various other topics in applied corporate finance. Recommended prereq. 15.434.
<br>Fall: <I>N. Gregory</I><br>Spring: <I>N. Gregory</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=15.436');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.437"></a>
<p><h3>15.437 Options and Futures Markets
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.401">15.401</a>, <a href="m15b.html#15.414">15.414</a>, or <a href="m15b.html#15.415">15.415</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m15b.html#15.4371">15.4371</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the economic role of options and futures markets. Topics include determinants of forward and futures prices, hedging and synthetic asset creation with futures, uses of options in investment strategies, relation between puts and calls, option valuation using binomial trees and Monte Carlo simulation, implied binomial trees, advanced hedging techniques, exotic options, and applications to corporate securities and other financial instruments. Meets with 15.4371 when offered concurrently. Expectations and evaluation criteria differ for students taking graduate version; consult syllabus or instructor for specific details.
<br><I>S. Kogan</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.4371"></a>
<p><h3>15.4371 Options and Futures Markets
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.417">15.417</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m15b.html#15.437">15.437</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the economic role of options and futures markets. Topics include determinants of forward and futures prices, hedging and synthetic asset creation with futures, uses of options in investment strategies, relation between puts and calls, option valuation using binomial trees and Monte Carlo simulation, implied binomial trees, advanced hedging techniques, exotic options, and applications to corporate securities and other financial instruments. Meets with 15.437 when offered concurrently. Expectations and evaluation criteria differ for students taking graduate version; consult syllabus or instructor for specific details.
<br><I>S. Kogan</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.438"></a>
<p><h3>15.438 Fixed Income Securities and Derivatives
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.401">15.401</a>, <a href="m15b.html#15.414">15.414</a>, or <a href="m15b.html#15.415">15.415</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW8.30-10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-262</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Designed for students seeking to develop a sophisticated understanding of fixed income valuation and hedging methods, and to gain familiarity with the major markets and instruments. Emphasizes tools for quantifying, hedging, and speculating on risk. Topics include duration; convexity; modern approaches to modeling the yield curve; interest rate forwards, futures, swaps and options; credit risk and credit derivatives; mortgages; and securitization. 15.437 strongly recommended.
<br><I>M. Pritsker</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=15.438');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.439"></a>
<p><h3>15.439 Investment Management
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.401">15.401</a>, <a href="m15b.html#15.414">15.414</a>, or <a href="m15b.html#15.415">15.415</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R EVE (4.30-7.30 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-335</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers the business of investment management from the perspective of running a successful investment management firm, with an emphasis on studying financial markets, principally equity markets. Covers the three elements required for an investment company to be successful: an effective investment strategy, efficient implementation of the strategy, and handling non-investment activities such as compliance. Emphasizes the first two elements and touches on quantitative investment strategies. Includes a mix of textbook readings, journal articles, and case studies, as well as outside speakers from the finance industry.
<br><I>M. Rothman</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=15.439');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.444"></a>
<p><h3>15.444 International Corporate Finance
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.402">15.402</a>, <a href="m15b.html#15.414">15.414</a>, or <a href="m15b.html#15.415">15.415</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Addresses issues relating to valuation, risk management, financing and contractual design for firms operating in international markets, providing exposure to emerging markets. Students analyze how risk and cash flows should be evaluated in environments with varying levels of risk, such as currency fluctuation, sovereign default, weak property rights, etc. Discusses how certain types of risk can be eliminated or managed through the appropriate design of financial contracts, and how institutional differences across countries shape the structure and efficacy of private equity contracts. Other topics include firm policy and international tax regimes, microfinance, and valuing social return. Concludes with a discussion on the impact of global financial crises on firm financial policy.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.445"></a>
<p><h3>15.445 Mergers, Acquisitions and Private Equity
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.515">15.515</a> or <a href="m15b.html#15.516">15.516</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m15b.html#15.402">15.402</a>, <a href="m15b.html#15.414">15.414</a>, or <a href="m15b.html#15.415">15.415</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m15b.html#15.4451">15.4451</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR8.30-10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-315</a>) or <i>TR10-11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-315</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Using case examples, covers classic stock and cash mergers; minority squeeze-outs; tax inversions; company sale process and auction design; hostile takeover law and strategy; the structuring, financing and valuation of leveraged buyouts; the structure, history and returns of private equity buyout funds; publicly traded private equity firms; blank-check companies; and a variety of other topics on M&A and leveraged buyouts. Provides an opportunity for group work, both in and out of class, including a full-term student project involving the mock sale of a company. Meets with 15.4451 when offered concurrently. Consult the syllabus for expectations and evaluation criteria.
<br><I>N. Gregory</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.4451"></a>
<p><h3>15.4451 Mergers, Acquisitions, and Private Equity
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.501">15.501</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m15b.html#15.402">15.402</a>, <a href="m15b.html#15.414">15.414</a>, or <a href="m15b.html#15.415">15.415</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m15b.html#15.445">15.445</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR8.30-10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-315</a>) or <i>TR10-11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-315</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Discusses a wide range of topics in corporate mergers and buyout transactions. Covers the mergers and acquisitions market, including classic merger agreements, tax inversions, sale auctions, and hostile takeover law and strategy. Also touches on activist investing and shareholder contests for corporate control. Studies how private equity firms operate and how leveraged buyouts are structured, financed, and valued. Provides opportunity for group work, both in and out of class. Meets with 15.445 when offered concurrently. Expectations and evaluation criteria for graduate students will differ from those of undergraduates; consult syllabus or instructor for specific details.
<br><I>N. Gregory</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.447"></a>
<p><h3>15.447 International Capital Markets
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.401">15.401</a>, <a href="m15b.html#15.414">15.414</a>, or <a href="m15b.html#15.415">15.415</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10-11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-149</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers globalization of capital markets and implications for financial management of domestic businesses, multinationals, and portfolios. Topics include currency markets, measuring and managing exchange rate exposure, exchange rate determination and forecasting, international financial instruments and institutions, international trading strategies, and global financial crises.
<br><I>J. Parker</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=15.447');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<a name="15.450"></a>
<p><h3>15.450 Analytics of Finance
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.401">15.401</a>, <a href="m15b.html#15.414">15.414</a>, or <a href="m15b.html#15.415">15.415</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-262</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R4-5.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-149</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces a set of modern analytical tools to solve practical problems in finance. Aims to build operational models, take them to the data, and use them to aid financial decision making. Topics include statistical inference and forecasting, event study analysis, structural approach to extract information from financial data, machine learning methods, and static and dynamic optimization in finance. Example applications include the development of quantitative trading strategies, credit scoring models, portfolio optimization under constraints, and private equity valuation.
<br><I>H. Chen</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.451"></a>
<p><h3>15.451 Proseminar in Capital Markets/Investment Management
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.401">15.401</a>, <a href="m15b.html#15.414">15.414</a>, or <a href="m15b.html#15.415">15.415</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a unique opportunity to tackle original research problems in capital market analysis and investment management that have been posed by leading experts from the financial community. Students are assigned to teams, and each team is assigned one such problem. Teams present their solutions at a seminar which is attended by representatives of the sponsoring organization and open to the entire MIT community. Not open to students from other institutions.
<br><I>M. Kritzman</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.452"></a>
<p><h3>15.452 Proseminar in Corporate Finance/Investment Banking
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.402">15.402</a>, <a href="m15b.html#15.414">15.414</a>, or <a href="m15b.html#15.415">15.415</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Bridges the gap between finance theory and finance practice, and introduces students to the broader financial community. Students participate in a series of proseminars with industry guest speakers. Each guest, in collaboration with finance faculty, provides a problem and materials to a team of students. Each team then prepares a report and presents their analysis to the guest speaker and other students for evaluation and feedback. Not open to students from other institutions.
<br><I>J. Parsons</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.453"></a>
<p><h3>15.453 Finance Research Practicum
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.401">15.401</a>, <a href="m15b.html#15.414">15.414</a>, or <a href="m15b.html#15.415">15.415</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>Ends Mar 16. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW EVE (4-6 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-395</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students work with leading industry practitioners on topical and important business problems, bridging the gap between theory and practice. Provides a full-time immersive learning experience during IAP, followed by a classroom segment in the first half of the spring term. Students work in small teams on finance research questions posed by external sponsors, then deliver a nuanced analysis to the sponsor and report findings to their peers in the classroom. Sponsors represent a range of financial institutions, including investment management, hedge funds, private equity, venture capital, risk, and consulting. Examples of project topics include equity and fixed income research, trading, risk analysis, venture capital valuation, private equity due diligence, and industry analysis. Application required; restricted to MIT students.
<br>IAP: <I>G. Rao</I><br>Spring: <I>G. Rao</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.454"></a>
<p><h3>15.454 Fundamentals of Financial Mathematics
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers fundamental mathematics essential for the study of modern finance: probability, stochastic processes, linear algebra, statistics, optimization, and basic programming in R. Restricted to students in the Master of Finance Program.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.455"></a>
<p><h3>15.455 Advanced Financial Mathematics
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers advanced mathematical topics essential for financial engineering and quantitative finance:  linear algebra, optimization, probability, stochastic processes, statistics, and basic programming in R.  Covers topics at a more advanced level and at a faster pace than 15.453. Restricted to students in the Master of Finance Program.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.456"></a>
<p><h3>15.456 Financial Engineering
<br>(15.460)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.401">15.401</a> or <a href="m15b.html#15.414">15.414</a> or <a href="m15b.html#15.415">15.415</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to financial engineering. Covers analytical and computational techniques, including dynamic optimization, stochastic calculus, and Monte Carlo simulation; and topics including dynamic asset pricing theories, market equilibrium and portfolio choice with frictions and constraints, risk management. Assumes solid undergraduate-level background in calculus, probability, statistics, and programming and includes a substantial coding component. Materials and review sessions use R. Students are encouraged but not required to use R for assignments and projects.
<br><I>L. Kogan</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.466"></a>
<p><h3>15.466 Functional and Strategic Finance
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.433">15.433</a> or <a href="m15b.html#15.437">15.437</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW10-11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-276</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-149</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Organized around applying finance science and financial engineering in the design and management of global financial institutions, markets, and the financial system - the approach used to understand the dynamics of institutional change and the design of financial products and services. Examines the needs of government as user, producer and overseer of the financial system, including the issues surrounding measuring and managing risks in financial crises. Develops the necessary tools of derivative pricing and risk measurement, portfolio analysis and risk accounting, and performance measurement to analyze and implement concepts and new product ideas. Applies these tools to analyze aspects of the financial crisis of 2007-2009. Preference to MBA and MFin students.
<br><I>R. Merton</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=15.466');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.467"></a>
<p><h3>15.467 Asset Management, Lifecycle Investing, and Retirement Finance
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.433">15.433</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-276</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-335</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Organized around applying finance science and financial engineering in three related financial-service activities: asset management, lifecycle investing, and retirement finance. Develops the necessary tools of derivative pricing and risk measurement, portfolio analysis and risk accounting, and performance measurement to analyze and implement concepts and new product ideas. Students should be familiar with basic portfolio-selection theory, CAPM, options, futures, swaps and other derivative securities. Preference to MBA and MFin students.
<br><I>R. Merton</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=15.467');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.470"></a>
<p><h3>15.470[J] Introduction to Financial Economics
<br>(15.416)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m14b.html#14.416">14.416[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Foundations of modern financial economics; individuals' consumption and portfolio decisions under uncertainty; valuation of financial securities. Topics include expected utility theory; stochastic dominance; mutual fund separation; portfolio frontiers; capital asset pricing model; arbitrage pricing theory; Arrow-Debreu economies; consumption and portfolio decisions; consumption beta models; spanning; options; market imperfections; no-trade theorems; rational expectations; financial signaling. Primarily for doctoral students in accounting, economics, and finance.
<br><I>L. Kogan</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.471"></a>
<p><h3>15.471[J] Advanced Corporate Finance
<br>(15.441)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m14b.html#14.441">14.441[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Surveys selected topics in current advanced research in corporate finance. Theoretical and empirical analyses of corporate financing and investment decisions. Some background in information economics and game theory is useful. Primarily for doctoral students in accounting, economics, and finance.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.472"></a>
<p><h3>15.472[J] Advanced Topics in Financial Economics I
<br>(15.442)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m14b.html#14.442">14.442[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on evaluation and estimation of theories of asset prices and financial markets and their macro- and micro-economic foundations. Discusses theory and econometric methods, and provides a critical review of empirical studies. Broadly covers cross-sectional and time-series models in asset pricing, consumption-based models, household finance, housing, and banking, while emphasizing empirical methodology. Students complete term paper and presentation. Primarily for doctoral students in finance, economics, and accounting.
<br><I>A. Verdelhan</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.473"></a>
<p><h3>15.473[J] Advanced Topics in Financial Economics II
<br>(15.440)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m14b.html#14.440">14.440[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M1-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-450</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers advanced topics in the theory of financial markets. Topics include multiperiod securities markets and martingales; pricing of contingent securities such as options; optimal consumption and portfolio problems of an individual; dynamic equilibrium theory and the intertemporal capital asset pricing model; term structure of interest rates; equilibrium with asymmetric information, transaction costs, borrowing constraints, agency problems, and financial intermediaries; dynamic models of corporate finance. Primarily for doctoral students in finance, economics, and accounting.
<br><I>H. Chen</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.474"></a>
<p><h3>15.474 Current Topics in Finance
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)

<br>Units: 3-0-9
