<a name="15.828"></a>
<p><h3>15.828 Product Management
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-372</a>) or <i>MW2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-372</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Practical introduction to the process of product management. Provides opportunities for experiential learning through projects with companies and organizations. Exposes students to state-of-the-art frameworks and tools that bring to market elegant and efficient solutions to strong customer needs. Covers the major phases of product management: opportunity identification (customer insights, interviews and surveys, ideation and brainstorming), design (product strategy and conjoint analysis), testing (concept testing, prototyping and A/B testing), and launch (choice of media and channel).
<br><I>T. Ke</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.830"></a>
<p><h3>15.830 Enterprise Management Lab
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="m15c.html#15.810">15.810</a>, <a href="m15c.html#15.761">15.761</a>, or <a href="m15c.html#15.900">15.900</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Lays the foundation for the Enterprise Management (EM Lab)Track by developing students' ability to apply integrated management perspectives and practices in their roles within large organizations.  Lectures, faculty mentors and cross-functional teams equip students with tools and knowledge to implement this track vision through classroom and project-based activities.  Small teams of students deliver quality deliverables working on live integrative projects focused on marketing, operations, and/or Strategy sourced from large organizations, both for-profit and not-for-profit. Management guest speakers from Marketing, Operations and Strategy discuss their interrelated activities.  The overall goal is to promote an integrated mindset towards viewing and addressing business issues. Students must register for both the fall term and IAP. Restricted to MBA students in EM Track.
<br>Fall: <I>S. Chatterjee</I><br>IAP: <I>S. Chatterjee</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.833"></a>
<p><h3>15.833 Business-to-Business Marketing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">); second half of term
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Applies marketing concepts, analyses and tools used in business-to-business (B2B) marketing. Develops an understanding of customer value management and value quantification as a strategy for delivering superior value to targeted business segments while maintaining equitable returns. Focuses on B2B pricing, brand building, web and technology facilitation of the supply chain, and customer relationship management. Underscores sales force management within the context of go-to-market strategy; however, does not address selling per se. Discusses ethical issues and various B2B contexts, such as products and services, for- and non-profits, and domestic and global markets. Emphasizes applications in technology and healthcare domains. Includes value-based pricing project, case studies, applied exercises, and readings.
<br><I>S. Chatterjee</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.834"></a>
<p><h3>15.834 Marketing Strategy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Uses case studies to introduce economic tools to look systematically at marketing strategy. Topics include how to use marketing tools to exploit and develop competitive advantages and how to choose the most efficient business model. Examples include two-sided markets, digital marketing, social media marketing, and the marketing of experiences.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.835"></a>
<p><h3>15.835 Entrepreneurial Marketing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); second half of term
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores a basic marketing framework in depth as it applies to start-ups. Students then apply this framework to a project.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.838"></a>

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>

<a name="15.846"></a>
<p><h3>15.846 Branding
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); second half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15c.html#15.810">15.810</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br>Begins Apr 2. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10-11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-325</a>) or <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-315</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a foundation for building, managing, and defending brands at various stages in the brand life cycle. Introduces the fundamentals of brand architecture and management relevant for B2C and B2B Marketing. Examples from a variety of industries cover topics that include brand co-creation, diffusion, imitation, and authenticity. Explores theory and practice using cases and academic research. Also looks at the development of leadership branding.
<br><I>R. Gosline</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.847"></a>
<p><h3>15.847 Consumer Behavior
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); second half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15c.html#15.810">15.810</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>Begins Apr 2. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR4-5.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-325</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines models of consumer behavior and methods for its analysis and prediction. Focuses on theories developed in marketing, psychology, and other behavioral sciences, and their role in understanding consumer preferences and decision making. Reviews theories in the context of a variety of industry applications. Students apply theories to their own market research projects.
<br><I>T. Rai</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<h2>System Dynamics</h2>
<a name="15.871"></a>
<h3>15.871 Introduction to System Dynamics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m15c.html#15.736">15.736</A>
<br>Ends Mar 16. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-325</a>) or <i>MW2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-325</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-325</a>) or <i>F1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-325</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to systems thinking and system dynamics modeling applied to strategy, organizational change, and policy design. Students use simulation models, management flight simulators, and case studies to develop conceptual and modeling skills for the design and management of high-performance organizations in a dynamic world. Case studies of successful applications of system dynamics in growth strategy, management of technology, operations, supply chains, product development, and others. Principles for effective use of modeling in the real world. Meets with 15.8741 first half of term when offered concurrently. Expectations and evaluation criteria differ for students taking half-term graduate version; consult syllabus or instructor for specific details.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Sterman</I><br>Spring: <I>D. Keith</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=15.871');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.872"></a>
<p><h3>15.872 System Dynamics II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); second half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15c.html#15.871">15.871</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m15c.html#15.737">15.737</A>
<br>Begins Apr 2. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-325</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F10-11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-145</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Continuation of 15.871, emphasizing tools and methods needed to apply systems thinking and simulation modeling successfully in complex real-world settings. Uses simulation models, management flight simulators, and case studies to deepen the conceptual and modeling skills introduced in 15.871.  Through models and case studies of successful applications students learn how to use qualitative and quantitative data to formulate and test models, and how to work effectively with senior executives to implement change successfully.  Prerequisite for further work in the field. Meets with 15.8741 second half of term when offered concurrently. Expectations and evaluation criteria differ for students taking half-term graduate version; consult syllabus or instructor for specific details.
<br>Fall: <I>R. Oliva Pue</I><br>Spring: <I>D. Keith</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.874"></a>
<p><h3>15.874[J] People and the Planet:  Environmental Governance and Science
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m12a.html#12.387">12.387[J]</A>, <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.063">IDS.063[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces governance and science aspects of complex environmental problems and approaches to solutions. Introduces quantitative analyses and methodological tools to analyze environmental issues that have human and natural components. Demonstrates concepts through a series of in-depth case studies of environmental governance and science problems. Students develop writing, quantitative modeling, and analytical skills in assessing environmental systems problems and developing solutions. Through experiential activities, such as modeling and policy exercises, students engage with the challenges and possibilities of governance in complex, interacting systems, including biogeophysical processes and societal and stakeholder interactions.
<br><I>N. Selin, S. Solomon, J. Sterman</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.8741"></a>
<p><h3>15.8741 System Dynamics for Business Policy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to systems thinking and system dynamics modeling applied to strategy, organizational change, and policy design. Students use simulation models, management flight simulators, and case studies to develop conceptual and modeling skills for the design and management of high-performance organizations in a dynamic world. Case studies cover successful applications of system dynamics in growth strategy, management of technology, operations, supply chains, product development, and other areas. When offered concurrently, meets with 15.871 first half of term and with 15.872 second half of term. Expectations and evaluation criteria differ for students taking the half-term graduate subjects; consult syllabus or instructor for specific details.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.875"></a>
<p><h3>15.875 Applications of System Dynamics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15c.html#15.872">15.872</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores how system dynamics can help organizations achieve important goals. Student teams pair with clients to tackle a pressing issue framed by the client and its partners. In interactive classroom sessions, and via client engagement, students learn modeling and consulting skills they need to be effective. Focuses on gaining practical insight from system dynamics and its application across a wide range of organizations and challenges.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.878"></a>
<p><h3>15.878 Capstone Seminar in Sustainability
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); second half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15c.html#15.913">15.913</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br>Begins Apr 2. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-145</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an opportunity for students to synthesize their coursework and experiences in sustainability. Involves deep intellectual exploration of fundamental debates in sustainability through classic and current readings that are essential for working in the field.  Students link ideas to practice through an analysis of the industry they plan to enter after graduation.
<br><I>J. Jay</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.879"></a>
<p><h3>15.879 Research Seminar in System Dynamics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15c.html#15.872">15.872</a> and permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>F9-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-450</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Doctoral level seminar in system dynamics modeling, with a focus on social, economic and technical systems. Covers classic works in dynamic modeling from various disciplines and current research problems and papers. Participants critique the theories and models, often including replication, testing, and improvement of various models, and lead class discussion. Topics vary from year to year.
<br><I>D. Keith</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Strategic Management</h2>
<a name="15.900"></a>
<p><h3>15.900 Competitive Strategy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m15c.html#15.9001">15.9001</A>
<br>Ends Mar 16. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-335</a>) or <i>MWF2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-335</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores a wide range of strategic problems, focusing particularly on the sources of competitive advantage and the interaction between industry structure and organizational capabilities. Introduces a wide variety of modern strategy frameworks and methodologies. Builds upon and integrates material from core topics, such as economics and organizational processes. Meets with 15.9001 when offered concurrently. Expectations and evaluation criteria differ for students taking graduate version; consult syllabus or instructor for specific details.
<br>Fall: <I>D. Sull</I><br>Spring: <I>D. Li</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.9001"></a>
<p><h3>15.9001 Competitive Strategy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m15c.html#15.900">15.900</A>
<br>Ends Mar 16. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-335</a>) or <i>MWF2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-335</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores a wide range of strategic problems, focusing particularly on the sources of competitive advantage and the interaction between industry structure and organizational capabilities. Introduces a wide variety of modern strategy frameworks and methodologies. Builds upon and integrates material from core topics, such as economics and organizational processes. Meets with 15.900 when offered concurrently. Expectations and evaluation criteria differ for students taking graduate version; consult syllabus or instructor for specific details.
<br><I>D. Li</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.902"></a>
<p><h3>15.902 Advanced Strategic Management
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m15c.html#15.714">15.714</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on developing skills and applying frameworks for the conduct of competitive and corporate strategy. Develops tools from earlier core subjects, especially those from strategic marketing, organizational processes, innovation-driven advantage, and economics.  Emphasis is placed on the role of strategic commitments, social networks, strategic coherence, and adapting to environmental and technological change. Restricted to MIT Sloan Fellows.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.903"></a>
<p><h3>15.903 Managing the Modern Organization: Organizational Economics and Corporate Strategy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15a.html#15.010">15.010</a> or <a href="m15b.html#15.311">15.311</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br>Ends Mar 16. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10-11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-325</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on how managers build and manage complex organizations to achieve strategic goals. Develops theoretical frameworks that build on 15.010 and 15.311. Applies these frameworks to corporate strategy (i.e., the design and management of the multi-business firm) and extended enterprises (i.e., the design and management of multi-firm structures such as supply chains, alliances, joint ventures, and networks).
<br>Fall: <I>R. Gibbons</I><br>Spring: <I>R. Gibbons</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.904"></a>
<p><h3>15.904 Advanced Strategic Management
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15c.html#15.900">15.900</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br>Ends Mar 16. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW4-5.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-276</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Builds on 15.900 and 15.902 to explore key concepts that have shaped the field of strategic management and strategy consulting over the past several decades. Uses lectures, readings, case studies, and videos to review the evolution of strategy teaching, research, and practice; the role of randomness in strategic outcomes; the difference between strategic thinking versus planning; and enduring principles related to competitive advantage. Key themes include the role of platform strategies and services, as well as capabilities, pull mechanisms, economies of scope, and flexibility, with examples from a variety of industries. Develops an understanding of what has made some firms successful in the past as well as what managers can do to compete in an uncertain future.
<br>Fall: <I>M. Cusumano</I><br>Spring: <I>M. Cusumano</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.905"></a>
<p><h3>15.905 Technology Strategy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a series of strategic frameworks for managing high-technology businesses. Emphasis on the development and application of conceptual models which clarify the interactions between competition, patterns of technological and market change, and the structure and development of internal firm capabilities.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.910"></a>
<p><h3>15.910 Innovation Strategy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br>Ends Mar 16. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW10-11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-250</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Establishes a solid foundation for students interested in formulating and executing a strategy for developing new-to-the-world products in a technology-intensive business. Clarifies the interactions among competition, patterns of technological and market change, and the development of internal firm capabilities. Topics include "crossing the chasm" with new technologies, appropriating the returns from innovation, platform strategy, and the role of intellectual property and government regulations.  Key conceptual frameworks are linked to applications in a variety of industry and case settings.
<br><I>A. Hagiu</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.911"></a>
<p><h3>15.911 Entrepreneurial Strategy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); second half of term
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-2
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m15c.html#15.715">15.715</A>
<br>Begins Apr 2. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-335</a>) or <i>MWF2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-335</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a deep understanding of the core strategic choices facing start-up innovators, as well as a synthetic framework for the development and implementation of entrepreneurial strategy in dynamic environments. Identifies the key choices entrepreneurs make to take advantage of opportunity and the logic of particular strategic commitments that allow entrepreneurs to establish competitive advantage.
<br><I>S. Stern</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.912"></a>
<p><h3>15.912 Strategic Management of Innovation and Entrepreneurship
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); second half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15c.html#15.910">15.910</a>, <a href="m15c.html#15.911">15.911</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a series of strategic frameworks for managing high-technology businesses with a particular focus on innovation and entrepreneurship, especially as it builds upon patterns of technological and market change, prior research on product development and new ventures, and the structure and development of organizational capabilities. Includes case analyses and simulations, as well as independent readings drawn from research in technological innovation, entrepreneurial management, and organizational theory.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.913"></a>
<p><h3>15.913 Strategies for Sustainable Business
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br>Ends Mar 16. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10-11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-276</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops a pragmatic, action-oriented approach to sustainability: the alignment between healthy businesses, healthy environments, healthy societies, and an economy that meets human needs.  In-class simulations and role-playing provide a robust foundation for understanding sustainability challenges.  Cases analyze innovative strategies for sustainable businesses and organizations.  Class discussions explore how sustainability is changing existing business models and market structures, how to develop sustainable management practices, and how firms can implement those practices successfully.
<br><I>J. Jay</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.914"></a>
<p><h3>15.914 Competitive Dynamics and Strategy: Winning in Technology Markets
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15c.html#15.872">15.872</a>; <a href="m15b.html#15.369">15.369</a>, <a href="m15b.html#15.567">15.567</a>, <a href="m15c.html#15.900">15.900</a>, or <a href="m15c.html#15.902">15.902</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T EVE (4-6 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-149</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on competitive strategy in technology-driven markets. Students acquire a portfolio of models of the signature dynamics in these markets and use the models in projects with participating companies to analyze technology markets, formulate competitive strategies, and illuminate the challenges of execution. Addresses issues critical for both established incumbents and new market entrants. Restricted to graduate students.
<br><I>H. Weil</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.915"></a>
<p><h3>15.915 Laboratory for Sustainable Business
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); second half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15c.html#15.913">15.913</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-2
<br>Begins Apr 2. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10-11.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-276</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides students with the opportunity to apply the concepts, theories, and tools of sustainability by working with a host organization on a real management project during the semester. Classroom lectures and simulations complement project work to give greater depth in techniques for managing sustainability. Topics include start-up dynamics, certification programs, evaluating the environmental impact of products and services, and leveraging consumers to advance sustainability.
<br><I>J. Jay</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.928"></a>
<p><h3>15.928 The Sociology of Strategy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.342">15.342</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Doctoral seminar in theory building for social scientists interested in economic sociology, organization theory, strategic management, and related fields. Builds skills for developing social scientific theory. Focuses on assessing and developing the relevance of sociological research for key questions in strategy research: what explains the relative performance of firms and the variety of their strategies for achieving performance. Students also develop skills in evaluating academic research in this area. Restricted to doctoral students.
<br><I>E. Zuckerman</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.929"></a>
<p><h3>15.929 Identity and Action
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15b.html#15.342">15.342</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Doctoral seminar in theory building for social scientists. Primary goal is to build skills for developing social scientific theory. Secondary goals are to review and integrate a broad array of ideas concerning the foundations of identity and its relation to action, and to suggest how such issues relate to a broader set of questions in the social sciences.   Students learn that any account of action is based on ascribing desires, beliefs, and opportunities to specific actors, but such actors cannot be easily explained except as a result of action by prior actors.  The focus of this course is around developing this paradox and providing a foundation for resolving it. Restricted to doctoral students.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.933"></a>
<p><h3>15.933 Strategic Opportunities in Energy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m15c.html#15.900">15.900</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-2
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the energy system in terms of sources and uses, market characteristics, and key metrics.  Provides frameworks for understanding the structure and dynamics of the sector and the drivers of the energy future.  Opportunities resulting from demand growth, supply challenges, environmental constraints, security of supply, technology breakthroughs, and regulation are analyzed from the perspectives of both established players and entrepreneurs.  Student teams engage in projects that evaluate a segment of the energy landscape and develop a strategic prospectus for a new business opportunity.
<br><I>H. Weil</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.941"></a>
<p><h3>15.941[J] Leadership in Real Estate
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">); first half of term
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m11c.html#11.430">11.430[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Designed to help students deepen their understanding of leadership and increase self-awareness. They examine authentic leadership styles and create goals and a learning plan to develop their capabilities. They also participate in activities to strengthen their "leadership presence" - the ability to authentically connect with people's hearts and minds. Students converse with leaders to learn from their insights, experiences, and advice. Limited to 15.
<br><I>G. Schuck</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.949"></a>

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>

<a name="15.S10"></a><a name="15.S11"></a><a name="15.S12"></a>
<p><h3>15.S10-15.S12 Special Seminar in Management
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">; second half of term

<h2>Thesis, Research, and Practice</h2>
<a name="15.UR"></a>
<p><h3>15.UR Undergraduate Research in Management
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Participation in the work of a research group which includes such activities as independent study of the literature, direct involvement in the group's research (commensurate with the student's skills and preparation), or project work under an individual faculty member possibly extending over more than one term. Admission by arrangement with individual faculty member. Requires written project report.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Carroll</I><br>IAP: <I>J. Carroll</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Carroll</I><br>Textbooks arranged individually
</p><!--end-->

<p><h3>15.950 Independent Study in Management
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Advanced work, special investigation or application of a management topic, on an individual basis, under faculty supervision. May include readings, conferences, laboratory and fieldwork, and reports. Projects require prior approval, as well as a written proposal and a final report.
<br>Fall: <I>S. Alessandro</I><br>IAP: <I>S. Alessandro</I><br>Spring: <I>S. Alessandro</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->

<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Advanced work, special investigation or application of a management topic, on an individual basis, under faculty supervision. May include readings, conferences, laboratory and fieldwork, and reports. Projects require prior approval, as well as a written proposal and a final report.
<br>Fall: <I>E. Seidman</I><br>IAP: <I>E. Seidman</I><br>Spring: <I>E. Seidman</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.962"></a>
<p><h3>15.962 Pre-Thesis Research
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Pre-thesis research conducted under faculty supervision; advance approval of project proposal required. Restricted to PhD students.
<br>Fall: <I>H. Ross</I><br>IAP: <I>H. Ross</I><br>Spring: <I>H. Ross</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.998"></a>
<p><h3>15.998 Independent Group Study in Action Learning
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Team-based opportunities for application management tools, under faculty supervision, on dynamic projects that provide a wide array of operational challenges facing organizations around the world. May include travel to on-site locales. Projects require prior approval, as well as a written proposal and a final report.
<br>Fall: <I>E. Seidman</I><br>IAP: <I>E. Seidman</I><br>Spring: <I>E. Seidman</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.999"></a>
<p><h3>15.999 Internship
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br><b>15.999:</b> TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students participate in an off-campus internship experience and apply topics of management and/or culture to their experience. Requirements include mandatory attendance at one workshop and a written deliverable. Students must have a formal offer letter from host employer/organization prior to enrolling. Restricted to MIT Sloan students who wish to intern in an area related to their field of study. Additional restrictions may apply.
<br>Fall: <I>E. Seidman</I><br>IAP: <I>E. Seidman</I><br>Spring: <I>E. Seidman</I><br><b>15.999:</b> No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="15.THG"></a>
<p><h3>15.THG Graduate Thesis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Research and writing of thesis; to be arranged by the student with supervising committee.
<br>Fall: <I>E. Seidman</I><br>IAP: <I>E. Seidman</I><br>Spring: <I>E. Seidman</I><br>Textbooks arranged individually
</p><!--end-->
</td></tr></table>

<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Course 16: Aeronautics and Astronautics<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://web.mit.edu/aeroastro/www/"><i>Course 16 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course16.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=16&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=++16&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>16.00-16.599 plus UROP and EP</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m16b.html">16.60-16.999 plus ThG</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<a name="16.00"></a>
<p><h3>16.00 Introduction to Aerospace and Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-2-2
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-144</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TBA</i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Highlights fundamental concepts and practices of aerospace engineering through lectures on aeronautics, astronautics, and the principles of project design and execution. Provides training in the use of Course 16 workshop tools and 3-D printers, and in computational tools, such as CAD. Students engage in teambuilding during an immersive, semester-long project in which teams design, build, and fly radio-controlled lighter-than-air (LTA) vehicles. Emphasizes connections between theory and practice and introduces students to fundamental systems engineering practices, such as oral and written design reviews, performance estimation, and post-flight performance analysis.
<br><I>J. A. Hoffman, R. J. Hansman, D. W. Miller</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.001"></a>
<p><h3>16.001 Unified Engineering: Materials and Structures
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m16a.html#16.002">16.002</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a></I>
<br>Units: 5-1-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents fundamental principles and methods of materials and structures for aerospace engineering, and engineering analysis and design concepts applied to aerospace systems.  Topics include statics; analysis of trusses; analysis of statically determinate and indeterminate systems; stress-strain behavior of materials; analysis of beam bending, buckling, and torsion; material and structural failure, including plasticity, fracture, fatigue, and their physical causes. Experiential lab and aerospace system projects provide additional aerospace context.
<br><I>R. Radovitzky</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.002"></a>
<p><h3>16.002 Unified Engineering: Signals and Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m16a.html#16.001">16.001</a>; <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.032">18.032</a></I>
<br>Units: 5-1-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents fundamental principles and methods of signals and systems for aerospace engineering, and engineering analysis and design concepts applied to aerospace systems.  Topics include linear and time invariant systems; convolution; transform analysis; and modulation, filtering, and sampling.  Experiential lab and aerospace system projects provide additional aerospace context.
<br><I>K. Willcox</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.003"></a>
<p><h3>16.003 Unified Engineering: Fluid Dynamics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>;<a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.032">18.032</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m16a.html#16.004">16.004</a></I>
<br>Units: 5-1-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MF9,TF10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-225</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TBA</i> <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-225</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents fundamental principles and methods of fluid dynamics for aerospace engineering, and engineering analysis and design concepts applied to aerospace systems. Topics include aircraft and aerodynamic performance, conservation laws for fluid flows, quasi-one-dimensional compressible flows, shock and expansion waves, streamline curvature, potential flow modeling, an introduction to three-dimensional wings and induced drag. Experiential lab and aerospace system projects provide additional aerospace context.
<br><I>D. Darmofal</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=16.003');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.004"></a>
<p><h3>16.004 Unified Engineering: Thermodynamics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>;<a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.032">18.032</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m16a.html#16.003">16.003</a>; <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a></I>
<br>Units: 5-1-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MTR10,R9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-225</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TBA</i> <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-225</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents fundamental principles and methods of thermodynamics for aerospace engineering, and engineering analysis and design concepts applied to aerospace systems. Topics include thermodynamic state of a system, forms of energy, work, heat, the first law of thermodynamics, heat engines, reversible and irreversible processes, entropy and the second law of thermodynamics, ideal and non-ideal cycle analysis, two-phase systems, and introductions to thermochemistry and heat transfer. Experiential lab and aerospace system projects provide additional aerospace context.
<br><I>Z. Spakovszky</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=16.004');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Core Undergraduate Subjects</h2>
<a name="16.06"></a>
<p><h3>16.06 Principles of Automatic Control
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m16a.html#16.002">16.002</a>; <a href="m16a.html#16.003">16.003</a> or <a href="m16a.html#16.004">16.004</a>
<br>Units: 3-1-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to design of feedback control systems. Properties and advantages of feedback systems. Time-domain and frequency-domain performance measures. Stability and degree of stability. Root locus method, Nyquist criterion, frequency-domain design, and some state space methods. Strong emphasis on the synthesis of classical controllers. Application to a variety of aerospace systems.  Hands-on experiments using simple robotic systems.
<br><I>J. P. How</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.07"></a>
<p><h3>16.07 Dynamics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m16a.html#16.001">16.001</a> or <a href="m16a.html#16.002">16.002</a>; <a href="m16a.html#16.003">16.003</a> or <a href="m16a.html#16.004">16.004</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Fundamentals of Newtonian mechanics. Kinematics, particle dynamics, motion relative to accelerated reference frames, work and energy, impulse and momentum, systems of particles and rigid body dynamics. Applications to aerospace engineering including introductory topics in orbital mechanics, flight dynamics, inertial navigation and attitude dynamics.
<br><I>D. Miller</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.09"></a>
<p><h3>16.09 Statistics and Probability
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=37">37-212</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>T4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=33">33-319</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to statistics and probability with applications to aerospace engineering.  Covers essential topics, such as sample space, discrete and continuous random variables, probability distributions, joint and conditional distributions, expectation, transformation of random variables, limit theorems, estimation theory, hypothesis testing, confidence intervals, statistical tests, and regression.
<br><I>L. Stirling</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=16.09');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Mechanics and Physics of Fluids</h2>
<a name="16.100"></a>
<p><h3>16.100 Aerodynamics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m16a.html#16.003">16.003</a>, <a href="m16a.html#16.004">16.004</a>
<br>Units: 3-1-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Extends fluid mechanic concepts from Unified Engineering to aerodynamic performance of wings and bodies in sub/supersonic regimes. Addresses themes such as subsonic potential flows, including source/vortex panel methods; viscous flows, including laminar and turbulent boundary layers; aerodynamics of airfoils and wings, including thin airfoil theory, lifting line theory, and panel method/interacting boundary layer methods; and supersonic and hypersonic airfoil theory. Material may vary from year to year depending upon focus of design problem.
<br><I>D. Darmofal</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.101"></a>
<p><h3>16.101 Topics in Fluids and Propulsion
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: Permission of department
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides credit for work on material in fluids or propulsion outside of regularly scheduled subjects. Intended for transfer credit and study abroad. Credit may be used to satisfy specific degree requirements in the Course 16 program. Requires prior approval. Consult department.
<br>Fall: <I>N. Roy</I><br>IAP: <I>N. Roy</I><br>Spring: <I>N. Roy</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.110"></a>
<p><h3>16.110 Flight Vehicle Aerodynamics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m16a.html#16.100">16.100</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-1-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Aerodynamic analysis of flight vehicles using analytical, numerical, and experimental techniques separately and in combination. Matched asymptotic expansions. Farfield behavior. Finite wing theory. Trefftz-plane analysis. Laminar and turbulent boundary layers. Slender body theory. Calculation and measurement of drag components. Aerodynamic stability derivatives.
<br><I>M. Drela</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.120"></a>
<p><h3>16.120 Compressible Internal Flow
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2b.html#2.25">2.25</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i>  <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Internal compressible flow with applications in propulsion and fluid systems. Control volume analysis of compressible flow devices. Compressible channel flow and extensions, including effects of shock waves, momentum, energy and mass addition, swirl, and flow non-uniformity on Mach numbers, flow regimes, and choking.
<br><I>E. M. Greitzer</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.121"></a>
<p><h3>16.121 Analytical Subsonic Aerodynamics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">); partial term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2b.html#2.25">2.25</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.085">18.085</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analysis of external inviscid, subsonic, flow over aerodynamic thin airfoils and slender lifting bodies. Analyses formulated using singular perturbation and multiple scale methods. Linearized theory.  Similarity. Rayleigh-Janzen method. Prandtl-Glauert method. G&ouml;thert similarity rule. Subsonic flow past a wave-shaped wall.
<br><I>W. Harris</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.122"></a>
<p><h3>16.122 Analytical High Speed Aerodynamics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); partial term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2b.html#2.25">2.25</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.085">18.085</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br>Begins Apr 2. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=33">33-422</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analysis of external inviscid, transonic, supersonic, and hypersonic flows over thin airfoils and lifting bodies of revolution. Analyses formulated using singular perturbation and multiple scale methods and parametric differentiation. Non-linear, unsteady transonic flow. Prandtl-Meyer flow. Body of minimum wave drag. Sonic boom. Hypersonic equivalence principle. Hypersonic similarity rule (matched asymptotic expansions).
<br><I>W. Harris</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.13"></a>
<p><h3>16.13 Aerodynamics of Viscous Fluids
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m16a.html#16.100">16.100</a>, <a href="m16a.html#16.110">16.110</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Boundary layers as rational approximations to the solutions of exact equations of fluid motion. Physical parameters influencing laminar and turbulent aerodynamic flows and transition. Effects of compressibility, heat conduction, and frame rotation. Influence of boundary layers on outer potential flow and associated stall and drag mechanisms. Numerical solution techniques and exercises.
<br><I>M. Drela</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Materials and Structures</h2>
<a name="16.20"></a>
<p><h3>16.20 Structural Mechanics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m16a.html#16.001">16.001</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/16.20/www/">http://web.mit.edu/16.20/www/</a>
<br>T10 meets in 33-418. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11,T10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=33">33-319</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>T3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=33">33-319</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Applies solid mechanics to analysis of high-technology structures. Structural design considerations. Review of three-dimensional elasticity theory; stress, strain, anisotropic materials, and heating effects. Two-dimensional plane stress and plane strain problems. Torsion theory for arbitrary sections. Bending of unsymmetrical section and mixed material beams. Bending, shear, and torsion of thin-wall shell beams. Buckling of columns and stability phenomena. Introduction to structural dynamics. Exercises in the design of general and aerospace structures.
<br><I>P. A. Lagace</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=16.20');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.201"></a>
<p><h3>16.201 Topics in Materials and Structures
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of department
