<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Course 16: Aeronautics and Astronautics<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://web.mit.edu/aeroastro/www/"><i>Course 16 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course16.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=16&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=++16&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m16a.html">16.00-16.599 plus UROP and EP</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>16.60-16.999 plus ThG</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<a name="16.621"></a>
<p><h3>16.621 Experimental Projects I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="m16a.html#16.06">16.06</a> or <a href="m16a.html#16.07">16.07</a></I>
<br>Units: 2-1-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=33">33-419</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>T2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=31">31-GELB LAB</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>First in a two-term sequence that addresses the conception and design of a student-defined or selected experimental research project carried out by two-person team under faculty advisement. Principles of research hypothesis formulation and assessment, experimental measurements and error analysis, and effective report writing and oral presentation, with instruction both in-class and on an individual and team basis. Selection and detailed planning of a research project, including in-depth design of experimental procedure that is then carried through to completion in 16.622.
<br>Fall: <I>S. R. Hall, J. L. Craig, P. C. Lozano, S. E. Widnall</I><br>Spring: <I>S. R. Hall, J. L. Craig, P. C. Lozano, S. E. Widnall</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.622"></a>
<p><h3>16.622 Experimental Projects II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m16b.html#16.621">16.621</a>
<br>Units: 1-7-4
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=33">33-206</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>R1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=31">31-GELB LAB</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>T2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=31">31-GELB LAB</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Execution of research project experiments based on the plan developed in 16.621. Working with their faculty advisor and course staff, student teams construct their experiment, carry out measurements of the relevant phenomena, analyze the data, and then apply the results to assess the research hypothesis. Includes instruction on effective report writing and oral presentations culminating in a written final report and formal oral presentation.
<br>Fall: <I>S. R. Hall, J. L. Craig, P. C. Lozano, S. E. Widnall</I><br>Spring: <I>S. R. Hall, J. L. Craig, P. C. Lozano, S. E. Widnall</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.63"></a>
<p><h3>16.63[J] System Safety
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.045">IDS.045[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the concepts of system safety and how to analyze and design safer systems. Topics include the causes of accidents in general, and recent major accidents in particular; hazard analysis, safety-driven design techniques; design of human-automation interaction; integrating safety into the system engineering process; and managing and operating safety-critical systems.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.64"></a>
<p><h3>16.64 Flight Measurement Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m16a.html#16.002">16.002</a>
<br>Units: 2-2-2
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Opportunity to see aeronautical theory applied in real-world environment of flight. Students assist in design and execution of simple engineering flight experiments in light aircraft. Typical investigations include determination of stability derivatives, verification of performance specifications, and measurement of navigation system characteristics. Restricted to students in Aeronautics and Astronautics.
<br><I>R. J. Hansman</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.650"></a>
<p><h3>16.650 Engineering Leadership Lab
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Engineering School-Wide Elective Subject. <br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m6c.html#6.911">6.911</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.650">16.650</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.913">6.913[J]</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.667">16.667[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="m6c.html#6.912">6.912</a></I> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 0-2-1
<br><b>Lab:</b> <i>F9-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-144</a>) or <i>F1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-144</a>) or <i>F3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-144</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Exposes students to leadership frameworks, models and cases within an engineering context, in an interactive, practice-based environment, honing leadership and teamwork skills. Students participate in guided reflections on individual and team successes, and discover opportunities for improvement in controlled settings. Activities include design-implement activities, role-plays, simulations, small group discussions, and performance and peer assessments by and of other students. Content throughout the term is frequently student-driven. First year Gordon Engineering Leadership Program (GEL) students register for 6.911. Second year GEL Program students register for 6.913. Preference to students enrolled in the Bernard M. Gordon-MIT Engineering Leadership Program.
<br>Fall: <I>L. Mcgonagle</I><br>Spring: <I>L. Mcgonagle</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.651"></a>
<p><h3>16.651 Engineering Leadership
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Engineering School-Wide Elective Subject. <br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m6c.html#6.912">6.912</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.651">16.651</A>)
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="m6c.html#6.911">6.911</a></I> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 1-0-2
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M9-10.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-233</a>) or <i>M11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-233</a>) or <i>T9-10.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-233</a>) or <i>T11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-233</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Exposes students to the models and methods of engineering leadership within the contexts of conceiving, designing, implementing and operating products, processes and systems. Introduces the Capabilities of Effective Engineering Leaders, and models and theories related to the capabilities. Discusses the appropriate times and reasons to use particular models to deliver engineering success. Includes occasional guest speakers or panel discussions. May be repeated for credit once with permission of instructor. Preference to first-year students in the Gordon Engineering Leadership Program.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Magarian</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Magarian</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.653"></a>
<p><h3>16.653 Management in Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Engineering School-Wide Elective Subject. <br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m2c.html#2.96">2.96</A>, <A HREF="m6c.html#6.930">6.930</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.806">10.806</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.653">16.653</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-1-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction and overview of engineering management. Financial principles, management of innovation, technical strategy and best management practices. Case study method of instruction emphasizes participation in class discussion. Focus is on the development of individual skills and management tools. Restricted to juniors and seniors.
<br><I>J. Chun</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.66"></a>
<p><h3>16.66 MATLAB Skills for Aeronautics and Astronautics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-0-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to basic MATLAB skills in programming, analysis, and plotting. Recommended for sophomores without previous MATLAB experience. Preference to Course 16 majors.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.662"></a>
<p><h3>16.662 Engineering Innovation and Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Engineering School-Wide Elective Subject. <br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m2b.html#2.723">2.723</A>, <A HREF="m6c.html#6.902">6.902</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.662">16.662</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-1-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M EVE (7-9 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-155</a>) <b>Design:</b> <i>M EVE (9 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-155</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Project-based seminar in innovative design thinking develops students' ability to conceive, implement, and evaluate successful projects in any engineering discipline. Lectures focus on the iterative design process and techniques to enhance creative analysis. Students use this process to design and implement robust voice recognition applications using a simple web-based system. They also give presentations and receive feedback to sharpen their communication skills for high emotional and intellectual impact. Guest lectures illustrate multidisciplinary approaches to design thinking.
<br>Fall: <I>C. Kotelly</I><br>Spring: <I>C. Kotelly</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.667"></a>
<p><h3>16.667 Engineering Leadership Lab
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Engineering School-Wide Elective Subject. <br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m6c.html#6.913">6.913</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.667">16.667</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.911">6.911[J]</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.650">16.650[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6c.html#6.911">6.911</a>
<br>Units: 0-2-4
<br><b>Lab:</b> <i>F9-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-144</a>) or <i>F1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-144</a>) or <i>F3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-144</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Exposes students to leadership frameworks, models and cases within an engineering context, in an interactive, practice-based environment, honing leadership and teamwork skills. Students participate in guided reflections on individual and team successes, and discover opportunities for improvement in controlled settings. Activities include design-implement activities, role-plays, simulations, small group discussions, and performance and peer assessments by and of other students. Content throughout the term is frequently student-driven. First year Gordon Engineering Leadership Program (GEL) students register for 6.911. Second year GEL Program students register for 6.913. Preference to students enrolled in the second year of the Gordon-MIT Engineering Leadership Program.
<br>Fall: <I>L. Mcgonagle</I><br>Spring: <I>L. Mcgonagle</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.669"></a>
<p><h3>16.669 Project Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Engineering School-Wide Elective Subject. <br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m6c.html#6.914">6.914</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.669">16.669</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6c.html#6.911">6.911</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 1-2-1 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students attend a four-day off-site workshop where an introduction to basic principles, methods, and tools for project management in a realistic context are covered. In teams, students create a plan for a project of their choice in one of several areas, including aircraft modification, factory automation, enterprise software, flood prevention engineering, solar farm engineering, among others. Develops skills applicable to the management of complex development projects. Topics include cost-benefit analysis, resource and cost estimation, and project control and delivery, which are practiced during an experimental, team-based activity. Case studies highlight projects in both hardware/construction and software. Preference to students in the Bernard M. Gordon-MIT Engineering Leadership Program.
<br><I>O. de Weck, J. Feiler, L. McGonagle</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.671"></a>
<p><h3>16.671[J] Leading Innovation in Teams
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6c.html#6.915">6.915[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Empowers future innovators in engineering and technology with a foundation of leadership and teamwork skills. Grounded in research but practical in focus, equips students with leadership competencies such as building self-awareness, motivating and developing others, influencing without authority, managing conflict, and communicating effectively.  Teamwork skills include how to convene, launch, and develop various types of teams, including project teams. Reviews recent advances in implementing innovations and building personal capacity for lifelong learning as a leading innovator. Enrollment limited to seating capacity of classroom. Admittance may be controlled by lottery.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.680"></a>
<p><h3>16.680 Project in Aeronautics and Astronautics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Opportunity to work on projects related to aerospace engineering outside the department. Requires prior approval.
<br>Fall: <I>Consult M. A. Stuppard</I><br>IAP: <I>Consult M. A. Stuppard</I><br>Spring: <I>Consult M. A. Stuppard</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.681"></a>
<p><h3>16.681 Topics in Aeronautics and Astronautics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<a name="16.682"></a>
<p><h3>16.682 Selected Topics in Aeronautics and Astronautics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.683"></a>
<p><h3>16.683 Seminar in Aeronautics and Astronautics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-0 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Speakers from campus and industry discuss current activities and advances in aeronautics and astronautics. Restricted to Course 16 students.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.687"></a>
<p><h3>16.687 Selected Topics in Aeronautics and Astronautics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i>  <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Study by qualified students. Topics selected in consultation with the instructor.  Prior approval required.
<br><I>M. Stuppard</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.691"></a>
<p><h3>16.691 Practicum Experience
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For Course 16 students participating in curriculum-related off-campus experiences in aerospace engineering and related areas. Before enrolling, a student must have an offer from a company or organization; must identify an appropriate supervisor in the AeroAstro department who, along with the off-campus supervisor, evaluate the student's work; and must receive prior approval from the AeroAstro department. At the conclusion of the training, the student submits a substantive final report for review and approval by the MIT supervisor. Can be taken for up to 3 units. Contact the AeroAstro Undergraduate Office for details on procedures and restrictions.
<br>Fall: <I>M. Stuppard</I><br>IAP: <I>M. Stuppard</I><br>Spring: <I>M. Stuppard</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Flight Transportation</h2>
<a name="16.707"></a>
<p><h3>16.707[J] The History of Aviation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mSTSb.html#STS.467">STS.467[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of Instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Reading course in the history of aviation, focusing on science and technology and cultural and political context. Themes include: the science of aeronautics, pilots and piloting, control systems and electronics, engineering epistemology, infrastructure, industry, government and politics, evolution of aeronautics research, culture and experience, automation and autonomy, role of MIT, literature and film.  Case studies of specific systems and engineering projects. Emphasis is on book-length texts, close reading, historical methods of analyzing technological change. Study of social and political dimensions of engineering projects, examination of aviation institutions. Students prepare weekly response papers to readings, make extended presentations to class twice per semester, and submit a final research paper.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.71"></a>
<p><h3>16.71[J] The Airline Industry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1b.html#1.232">1.232[J]</A>, <A HREF="m15a.html#15.054">15.054[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Overview of the global airline industry, focusing on recent industry performance, current issues and challenges for the future. Fundamentals of airline industry structure, airline economics, operations planning, safety, labor relations, airports and air traffic control, marketing, and competitive strategies, with an emphasis on the interrelationships among major industry stakeholders. Recent research findings of the MIT Global Airline Industry Program are showcased, including the impacts of congestion and delays, evolution of information technologies, changing human resource management practices, and competitive effects of new entrant airlines. Taught by faculty participants of the Global Airline Industry Program.
<br><I>P. Belobaba</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.715"></a>
<p><h3>16.715 Aerospace, Energy, and the Environment
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>; <a href="m1a.html#1.060B">1.060B</a>, <a href="m2a.html#2.006">2.006</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.301">10.301</a>, <a href="m16a.html#16.003">16.003</a>, <a href="m16a.html#16.004">16.004</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Addresses energy and environmental challenges facing aerospace in the 21st century. Topics include: aircraft performance and energy requirements, propulsion technologies, jet fuels and alternative fuels, lifecycle assessment of fuels, combustion, emissions, climate change due to aviation, aircraft contrails, air pollution impacts of aviation, impacts of supersonic aircraft, and aviation noise. Includes an in-depth introduction to the relevant atmospheric and combustion physics and chemistry with no prior knowledge assumed.  Discussion and analysis of near-term technological, fuel-based, regulatory and operational mitigation options for aviation, and longer-term technical possibilities.
<br><I>S. Barrett</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.72"></a>
<p><h3>16.72 Air Traffic Control
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the various aspects of present and future Air Traffic Control systems. Descriptions of the present system: systems-analysis approach to problems of capacity and safety; surveillance, including NAS and ARTS; navigation subsystem technology; aircraft guidance and control; communications; collision avoidance systems; sequencing and spacing in terminal areas; future directions and development; critical discussion of past proposals and of probable future problem areas. Requires term paper.
<br><I>H. Balakrishnan</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.75"></a>
<p><h3>16.75[J] Airline Management
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1b.html#1.234">1.234[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m16b.html#16.71">16.71J</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Overview of airline management decision processes, with a focus on economic issues and their relationship to operations planning models and decision support tools. Application of economic models of demand, pricing, costs, and supply to airline markets and networks. Examination of industry practice and emerging methods for fleet planning, route network design, scheduling, pricing and revenue management, with emphasis on the interactions between the components of airline management and profit objectives in competitive environments. Students participate in a competitive airline management simulation game as part of the subject requirements.
<br><I>P. P. Belobaba</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.763"></a>
<p><h3>16.763[J] Air Transportation Operations Research
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1b.html#1.233">1.233[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m16b.html#16.71">16.71</a>, <a href="m6b.html#6.431B">6.431B</a>, <a href="m15a.html#15.093">15.093</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=33">33-319</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents a unified view of advanced quantitative analysis and optimization techniques applied to the air transportation sector. Considers the problem of operating and managing the aviation sector from the perspectives of the system operators (e.g., the FAA), the airlines, and the resultant impacts on the end-users (the passengers). Explores models and optimization approaches to system-level problems, airline schedule planning problems, and airline management challenges. Term paper required.
<br><I>H. Balakrishnan, P. Belobaba</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.767"></a>
<p><h3>16.767 Introduction to Airline Transport Aircraft Systems and Automation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-2-1 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Intensive one-week subject that uses the Boeing 767 aircraft as an example of a system of systems. Focuses on design drivers and compromises, system interactions, and human-machine interface. Morning lectures, followed by afternoon desktop simulator sessions. Critique and comparison with other transport aircraft designs. Includes one evening at Boston Logan International Airport aboard an aircraft. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>C. M. Oman, B. Nield</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.781"></a>
<p><h3>16.781[J] Planning and Design of Airport Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1b.html#1.231">1.231[J]</A>, <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.670">IDS.670[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on current practice, developing trends, and advanced concepts in airport design and planning. Considers economic, environmental, and other trade-offs related to airport location, as well as the impacts of emphasizing "green" measures. Includes an analysis of the effect of airline operations on airports. Topics include demand prediction, determination of airfield capacity, and estimation of levels of congestion; terminal design; the role of airports in the aviation and transportation system; access problems; optimal configuration of air transport networks and implications for airport development; and economics, financing, and institutional aspects. Special attention to international practice and developments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Aerospace Systems</h2>
<a name="16.82"></a>
<p><h3>16.82 Flight Vehicle Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=33">33-419</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TR3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=33">33-419</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Design of an atmospheric flight vehicle to satisfy stated performance, stability, and control requirements. Emphasizes individual initiative, application of fundamental principles, and the compromises inherent in the engineering design process. Includes instruction and practice in written and oral communication, through team presentations and a written final report. Course 16 students are expected to complete two professional or concentration subjects from the departmental program before taking this capstone. Offered alternate Spring and Fall terms.
<br><I>R. J. Hansman, M. Drela</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.821"></a>
<p><h3>16.821 Flight Vehicle Development
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-10-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on implementation and operation of a flight system. Emphasizes system integration, implementation, and performance verification using methods of experimental inquiry, and addresses principles of laboratory safety. Students refine subsystem designs and fabricate working prototypes. Includes component integration into the full system with detailed analysis and operation of the complete vehicle in the laboratory and in the field, as well as experimental analysis of subsystem performance, comparison with physical models of performance and design goals, and formal review of the overall system design.  Knowledge of the engineering design process is helpful. Provides instruction in written and oral communication.
<br><I>R.J. Hansman; M. Drela</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.83"></a>
<p><h3>16.83[J] Space Systems Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as 12.43[J])
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Design of a complete space system, including systems analysis, trajectory analysis, entry dynamics, propulsion and power systems, structural design, avionics, thermal and environmental control, human factors, support systems, and weight and cost estimates. Students participate in teams, each responsible for an integrated vehicle design, providing experience in project organization and interaction between disciplines. Includes several aspects of team communication including three formal presentations, informal progress reports, colleague assessments, and written reports. Course 16 students are expected to complete two professional or concentration subjects from the departmental program before taking this capstone. Offered alternate fall and spring terms.
<br><I>D. Miller</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.831"></a>
<p><h3>16.831[J] Space Systems Development
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m12a.html#12.431">12.431[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-10-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=37">37-212</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TR3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=37">37-212</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students build a space system, focusing on refinement of sub-system designs and fabrication of full-scale prototypes. Sub-systems are integrated into a vehicle and tested. Sub-system performance is verified using methods of experimental inquiry, and is compared with physical models of performance and design goals. Communication skills are honed through written and oral reports. Formal reviews include the Implementation Plan Review and the Acceptance Review. Knowledge of the engineering design process is helpful.
<br><I>D.W. Miller; R.P. Binzel; J.A. Hoffman</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.842"></a>
<p><h3>16.842 Fundamentals of Systems Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>General introduction to systems engineering using the classical V-model. Topics include stakeholder analysis, requirements definition, system architecture and concept generation, trade-space exploration and concept selection, human factors, design definition and optimization, system integration and interface management, system safety, verification and validation, and commissioning and operations. Discusses the trade-offs between performance, life-cycle cost and system operability. Readings based on systems engineering standards. Individual homework assignments apply concepts from class and contain both aeronautical and astronautical applications. Prepares students for the systems field exam in the Department of Aeronautics and Astronautics.
<br><I>E. Crawley</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.851"></a>
<p><h3>16.851 Satellite Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Fundamentals of satellite engineering design, including distributed satellite. Studies orbital environment. Analyzes problems of station keeping, attitude control, communications, power generation, structural design, thermal balance, and subsystem integration. Considers trade-offs among weight, efficiency, cost, and reliability. Discusses choice of design parameters, such as size, weight, power levels, temperature limits, frequency, and bandwidth. Examples taken from current satellite systems.
<br><I>K. Cahoy</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.855"></a>
<p><h3>16.855[J] Systems Architecting Applied to Enterprises
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.336">IDS.336[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M EVE (4-7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-057</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on principles and practices for architecting new and evolving sociotechnical enterprises. Includes reading and discussions of enterprise theory, contemporary challenges, and case studies of evolving enterprises. Covers frameworks and methods for ecosystem analysis, stakeholder analysis, architecture design and evaluation, and implementation strategies. Students work in small teams on projects to design a future architecture for a selected real-world enterprise.
<br><I>D. Rhodes</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.861"></a>
<p><h3>16.861 Engineering Systems Analysis for Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Engineering School-Wide Elective Subject. <br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m1a.html#1.146">1.146</A>, <A HREF="m16b.html#16.861">16.861</A>, <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.332">IDS.332</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.333">IDS.333</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers theory and methods to identify, value, and implement flexibility in design, also known as "real options." Topics include definition of uncertainties, simulation of performance for scenarios, screening models to identify desirable flexibility, decision and lattice analysis, and multidimensional economic evaluation. Students demonstrate proficiency through an extended application to a systems design of their choice. Provides a complement to research or thesis projects. Meets with IDS.333 first half of term. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>R. De Neufville</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.863"></a>
<p><h3>16.863[J] System Safety Concepts
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.340">IDS.340[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers important concepts and techniques in designing and operating safety-critical systems. Topics include the nature of risk, formal accident and human error models, causes of accidents, fundamental concepts of system safety engineering, system and software hazard analysis, designing for safety, fault tolerance, safety issues in the design of human-machine interaction, verification of safety, creating a safety culture, and management of safety-critical projects. Includes a class project involving the high-level system design and analysis of a safety-critical system.
<br><I>N. Leveson</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.885"></a>
<p><h3>16.885 Aircraft Systems Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-1-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=33">33-218</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Holistic view of the aircraft as a system, covering basic systems engineering, cost and weight estimation, basic aircraft performance, safety and reliability, life cycle topics, aircraft subsystems, risk analysis and management, and system realization. Small student teams retrospectively analyze an existing aircraft covering: key design drivers and decisions; aircraft attributes and subsystems; operational experience. Oral and written versions of the case study are delivered. Focuses on a systems engineering analysis of the Space Shuttle. Studies both design and operations of the shuttle, with frequent lectures by outside experts. Students choose specific shuttle systems for detailed analysis and develop new subsystem designs using state of the art technology.
<br><I>R.J. Hansman, M. Drela</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.886"></a>
<p><h3>16.886 Air Transportation Systems Architecting
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-2-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Addresses the architecting of air transportation systems.  Focuses on the conceptual phase of product definition including  technical, economic, market, environmental, regulatory, legal,  manufacturing, and societal factors. Centers on a realistic  system case study and includes a number of lectures from industry  and government. Past examples include the Very Large Transport  Aircraft, a Supersonic Business Jet and a Next Generation Cargo  System. Identifies the critical system level issues and  analyzes them in depth via student team projects and individual  assignments. Overall goal is to produce a  business plan and a system specifications document that can be used  to assess candidate systems.
<br><I>R. Hansman</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.888"></a>
<p><h3>16.888[J] Multidisciplinary System Design Optimization
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.338">IDS.338[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.085">18.085</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-1-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Engineering systems modeling for design and optimization. Selection of design variables, objective functions and constraints. Overview of principles, methods and tools in multidisciplinary design optimization (MDO). Subsystem identification, development and interface design. Review of linear and non-linear constrained optimization formulations. Scalar versus vector optimization problems from systems engineering and architecting of complex systems. Heuristic search methods: Tabu search, simulated annealing, genetic algorithms. Sensitivity, tradeoff analysis and isoperformance. Multiobjective optimization and pareto optimality.  Surrogate and multifidelity optimization strategies. System design for value. Specific applications from aerospace, mechanical, civil engineering and system architecture.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.89"></a>
<p><h3>16.89[J] Space Systems Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.339">IDS.339[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m16b.html#16.851">16.851</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-2-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW10.30-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=33">33-218</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TBA</i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focus on developing space system architectures. Applies subsystem knowledge gained in 16.851 to examine interactions between subsystems in the context of a space system design. Principles and processes of systems engineering including developing space architectures, developing and writing requirements, and concepts of risk are explored and applied to the project. Subject develops, documents, and presents a conceptual design of a space system including a preliminary spacecraft design.
<br><I>E.F. Crawley; K. Cahoy</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=16.89');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.895"></a>
<p><h3>16.895[J] Engineering Apollo: The Moon Project as a Complex System
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mSTSb.html#STS.471">STS.471[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Detailed technical and historical exploration of the Apollo project to fly humans to the moon and return them safely to Earth as an example of a complex engineering system. Emphasizes how the systems worked, the technical and social processes that produced them, mission operations, and historical significance. Guest lectures by MIT-affiliated engineers who contributed to and participated in the Apollo missions. Students work in teams on a final project analyzing an aspect of the historical project to articulate and synthesize ideas in engineering systems.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Computation</h2>
<a name="16.90"></a>
<p><h3>16.90 Computational Modeling and Data Analysis in Aerospace Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m16a.html#16.001">16.001</a>, <a href="m16a.html#16.002">16.002</a>, <a href="m16a.html#16.003">16.003</a>, <a href="m16a.html#16.004">16.004</a>, or permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="m16a.html#16.09">16.09</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.041B">6.041B</a></I>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=33">33-319</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TBA</i> <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces principles, algorithms, and applications of computational techniques arising in aerospace engineering. Techniques include numerical integration of systems of ordinary differential equations; numerical discretization of partial differential equations; probabilistic modeling; and computational aspects of estimation and inference. Example applications will include modeling, design, and data analysis.
<br><I>Q. Wang</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.910"></a>
<p><h3>16.910[J] Introduction to Numerical Simulation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2a.html#2.096">2.096[J]</A>, <A HREF="m6b.html#6.336">6.336[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>
<br>Units: 3-3-6
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to computational techniques for the simulation of a large variety of engineering and physical systems. Applications are drawn from aerospace, mechanical, electrical, chemical engineering, biology, and materials science. Topics include mathematical formulations (techniques for automatic assembly of mathematical problems from physics' principles); sparse, direct and iterative solution techniques for linear systems; Newton and Homotopy methods for nonlinear problems; discretization methods for ordinary, time-periodic and partial differential equations; accelerated methods for integral equations; techniques for automatic generation of compact dynamical system models and model order reduction.
<br><I>L. Daniel</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.920"></a>
<p><h3>16.920[J] Numerical Methods for Partial Differential Equations
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2a.html#2.097">2.097[J]</A>, <A HREF="m6b.html#6.339">6.339[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers the fundamentals of modern numerical techniques for a wide range of linear and nonlinear elliptic, parabolic, and hyperbolic partial differential and integral equations. Topics include mathematical formulations; finite difference, finite volume, finite element, and boundary element discretization methods; and direct and iterative solution techniques. The methodologies described form the foundation for computational approaches to engineering systems involving heat transfer, solid mechanics, fluid dynamics, and electromagnetics. Computer assignments requiring programming.
<br><I>Q. Wang</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.930"></a>
<p><h3>16.930 Advanced Topics in Numerical Methods for Partial Differential Equations
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m16b.html#16.920">16.920</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers advanced topics in numerical methods for the discretization, solution, and control of problems governed by partial differential equations. Topics include the application of the finite element method to systems of equations with emphasis on equations governing compressible, viscous flows; grid generation; optimal control of PDE-constrained systems; a posteriori error estimation and adaptivity; reduced basis approximations and reduced-order modeling. Computer assignments require programming.
<br><I>Staff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.940"></a>
<p><h3>16.940 Numerical Methods for Stochastic Modeling and Inference
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m16b.html#16.920">16.920</a>, <a href="m6b.html#6.431B">6.431B</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Advanced introduction to numerical methods for treating uncertainty in computational simulation. Draws examples from a range of engineering and science applications, emphasizing systems governed by ordinary and partial differential equations. Uncertainty propagation and assessment: Monte Carlo methods, variance reduction, sensitivity analysis, adjoint methods, polynomial chaos and Karhunen-Lo&egrave;ve expansions, and stochastic Galerkin and collocation methods. Interaction of models with observational data, from the perspective of statistical inference: Bayesian parameter estimation, statistical regularization, Markov chain Monte Carlo, sequential data assimilation and filtering, and model selection.
<br><I>Y. M. Marzouk</I><br>
</p><!--end-->

<a name="16.971"></a>
<p><h3>16.971 Practicum Experience
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For Course 16 students participating in curriculum-related off-campus experiences in aerospace engineering and related areas. Before enrolling, a student must have an offer from a company or organization; must identify an appropriate supervisor in the AeroAstro department who, along with the off-campus supervisor, evaluate the student's work; and must receive prior approval from the AeroAstro department. At the conclusion of the training, the student submits a substantive final report for review and approval by the MIT supervisor. Can be taken for up to 3 units. Contact the AeroAstro Graduate Office for details on procedures and restrictions.
<br>Fall: <I>B. Marois</I><br>IAP: <I>B. Marois</I><br>Spring: <I>B. Marois</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->

<p><h3>16.985[J] Global Operations Leadership Seminar
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2c.html#2.890">2.890[J]</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.792">10.792[J]</A>, <A HREF="m15c.html#15.792">15.792[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]

</p><!--end-->
<a name="16.990"></a>
<p><h3>16.990[J] Leading Creative Teams
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6c.html#6.928">6.928[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>F9.30-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-233</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Prepares students to lead teams charged with developing creative solutions in engineering and technical environments. Grounded in research but practical in focus, equips students with leadership competencies such as building self-awareness, motivating and developing others, creative problem solving, influencing without authority, managing conflict, and communicating effectively. Teamwork skills include how to convene, launch, and develop various types of teams, including project teams. Learning methods emphasize personalized and professional skill development.
<br>Fall: <I>D. Nino</I><br>Spring: <I>D. Nino</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->

<a name="16.S498"></a>
<p><h3>16.S498 Advanced Special Subject in Humans and Automation
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
