<a name="17.568"></a>
<p><h3>17.568 Comparative Politics and International Relations of the Middle East
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Surveys both classic and cutting-edge work on the politics of the Middle East, broadly defined. Topics include the causes and consequences of political and economic development, authoritarianism and democratization, the influence of social movements, the role of women in Middle Eastern polities, regional inter-state relations, Islamism, terrorism, colonialism and foreign occupation, state-building, resistance and rebellion, and the Arab uprisings.
<br><I>R. Nielsen, F. Christia</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.569"></a>
<p><h3>17.569 Russia's Foreign Policy: Toward the Post-Soviet States and Beyond
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T11-1,R12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-167</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analyzes Russia's foreign policy, with a focus on relations with the other post-Soviet states. Frames the discussion with examination of US-Russian and Sino-Russian relations. Looks at legacies of the Soviet collapse, strengths and vulnerabilities of Russia, and the ability of other states to maintain their sovereignty. Topics include the future of Central Asia, the Georgian war, energy politics, and reaction to the European Union's Eastern Partnership. Readings focus on international relations, historical sources, and contemporary Russian and Western sources.
<br><I>C. Saivetz</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=17.569');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.57"></a>
<p><h3>17.57[J] Soviet and Post-Soviet Politics and Society: 1917 to the Present
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m21Ga.html#21G.086">21G.086[J]</A>, <A HREF="m21Ha.html#21H.245">21H.245[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the political and historical evolution of the Soviet state and society from the 1917 Revolution to the present. Covers the creation of a revolutionary regime, causes and nature of the Stalin revolution, post-Stalinist efforts to achieve political and social reform, and causes of the Soviet collapse. Also examines current developments in Russia in light of Soviet history. Enrollment limited
<br><I>E. Wood</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=17.57&Source=21H.245');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.571"></a>
<p><h3>17.571 Engineering Democratic Development in Africa
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T11-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-277</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TBA</i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the varied relationship between democracy and human development in sub-Saharan Africa. Encourages students to apply engineering thinking to better understand which institutions, practices, and technologies have helped, and which have hindered, the achievement of health, education, infrastructure, and other outcomes. Addresses many of the challenges and dilemmas of democratic practice in poor, diverse, and unequal societies, while inviting students to propose practical interventions.
<br><I>E. Lieberman</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.572"></a>
<p><h3>17.572 African Politics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the major arguments, hypotheses and debates in the literature on African politics and development, with the goal of helping students develop the skills to become both more intelligent consumers and more effective producers of this literature. Covers both classic contributions to the literature and more recent research.
<br><I>E. Lieberman</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.578"></a>
<p><h3>17.578 Elections and Political Representation in the Developing World
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of Instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on the theoretical and empirical study of elections, representation, and governance in non-industrialized democratic societies. Surveys the contemporary literature on topics such as party systems, clientelism, electorally-motivated violence, ethnic politics, and federalism.
<br><I>D. Hidalgo</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.581"></a>
<p><h3>17.581 Riots, Rebellions, Revolutions
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR3-4.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-375</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines different types of violent political conflict. Compares and contrasts several social science approaches (psychological, sociological, and political) and analyzes their ability to explain variation in outbreak, duration and outcome of conflict.  Examines incidents such as riots in the US during the 1960's, riots in India, the Yugoslav wars, and the Russian Revolution, in addition to current international events.
<br><I>R. Petersen</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=17.581');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.582"></a>
<p><h3>17.582 Civil War
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Surveys the social science literature on civil war. Studies the origins of civil war, discusses variables affecting duration, and examines termination of conflict. Highly interdisciplinary and covers a wide variety of cases. Open to advanced undergraduates with permission of instructor.
<br><I>F. Christia</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.584"></a>
<p><h3>17.584 Civil-Military Relations
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W3.30-5.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E53">E53-485</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Subject consists of five sections. After a general survey of the field, students consider cases of stable civilian control, military rule, and transitions from military to civilian rule. Cases are selected from around the world.
<br><I>R. Petersen</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=17.584');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.588"></a>
<p><h3>17.588 Field Seminar in Comparative Politics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/polisci/www/courses/17.588.html">http://web.mit.edu/polisci/www/courses/17.588.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>W1.30-3.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E53">E53-438</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to the field of comparative politics. Readings include both classic and recent materials. Discusses research design and research methods, in addition to topics such as political culture, social cleavages, the state, and democratic institutions. Emphasis on each issue depends in part on the interests of the students.
<br><I>B. Schneider</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.590"></a>
<p><h3>17.590 State Building
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the process of building modern, national states across regions at different levels of development. Focuses on conceptualizing and measuring state power; and on the range of political, economic, and social explanations that account for variation, including the role of technology, war, material endowments, geography, trust, ethnic diversity, and democratic regimes. Evaluates the quality of evidence for different accounts. Theoretical orientation intended for Ph.D. students in political science.
<br><I>E. Lieberman</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.591"></a>
<p><h3>17.591 Research Seminar in Applied International Studies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom"> <img src="/icns/cih1.gif" alt="Communication Intensive HASS" title="Communication Intensive HASS" width="28" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=5">5-231</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on research methods in the social sciences as they relate to topics in international studies. Students complete an independent research project on a topic chosen in consultation with the instructor; class presentation required. Limited to 18; preference to Applied International Studies minors.
<br><I>B. Schneider</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Models and Methods</h2>
<a name="17.800"></a>
<p><h3>17.800 Quantitative Research Methods I: Regression
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to statistical research in political science and public policy, with a focus on linear regression. Teaches students how to apply multiple regression models as used in much of political science and public policy research. Also covers elements of probability and sampling theory.
<br><I>F. Hidalgo</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.801"></a>
<p><h3>17.801 Political Science Scope and Methods
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces principles of empirical and theoretical analysis in political science through research projects currently conducted in the department. Different department faculty lead modules that introduce students to major research questions and different ways of examining those questions. Emphasizes how this research in progress relates to larger themes, and how researchers confront obstacles to inference in political science. Includes substantial instruction and practice in writing (with revision) and oral presentations. Intended primarily for majors and minors.
<br><I>C. Lawson</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.802"></a>
<p><h3>17.802 Quantitative Research Methods II: Causal Inference
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m17b.html#17.800">17.800</a>, <a href="m17b.html#17.803">17.803</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/17.802/www/">http://web.mit.edu/17.802/www/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-361</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-143</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Survey of statistical methods for causal inference in political science and public policy research. Covers a variety of causal inference designs, including experiments, matching, regression, panel methods, difference-in-differences, synthetic control methods, instrumental variables, regression discontinuity designs, quantile regression, and bounds.
<br><I>T. Yamamoto</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.803"></a>
<p><h3>17.803 Political Science Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m17b.html#17.801">17.801</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-6-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR3-4.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E53">E53-438</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TBA</i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces students to the conduct of political research using quantitative methodologies. The methods are examined in the context of specific political research activities like public opinion surveys, voting behavior, Congressional behavior, comparisons of political processes in different countries, and the evaluation of public policies. Students participate in joint class projects and conduct individual projects. Does <I>not</I> count toward HASS Requirement. Enrollment limited; preference to Course 17 majors who have pre-registered.
<br><I>T. Yamamoto</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=17.803');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.804"></a>
<p><h3>17.804 Quantitative Research Methods III: Generalized Linear Models and Extensions
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m17b.html#17.802">17.802</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides a survey of statistical tools for model-based inference in political science and public policy. Topics include generalized linear models for various data types and their extensions, such as discrete choice models, survival outcome models, mixed effects and multilevel models. Covers both frequentist and Bayesian approaches.
<br><I>T. Yamamoto</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.806"></a>
<p><h3>17.806 Quantitative Research Methods IV: Advanced Topics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m17b.html#17.804">17.804</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW3.30-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E53">E53-438</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>F9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E53">E53-438</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers advanced statistical tools that are useful for empirical research in political science and public policy. Possible topics include missing data, survey sampling and experimental designs for field research, machine learning, text mining, clustering, Bayesian methods, spatial statistics, and web scraping.
<br><I>I. Kim</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.810"></a>
<p><h3>17.810 Game Theory and Political Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m17b.html#17.811">17.811</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces students to the rudiments of game theory within political science. Provides all students with the ability to solve simple games. Readings draw from basic texts on game theoretic modeling and applied articles in American Politics, International Relations, and Comparative Politics. Students taking the graduate version evaluate applied theory articles in the major journals.
<br><I>I. S. Kim</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.811"></a>
<h3>17.811 Game Theory and Political Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m17b.html#17.810">17.810</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces students to the rudiments of game theory within political science. Provides students with the ability to solve simple games. Readings draw from basic texts on game theoretic modeling and applied articles in American politics, international relations, and comparative politics. Students taking the graduate version evaluate applied theory articles in the major journals.
<br><I>I. Kim</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.830"></a>
<p><h3>17.830 Empirical Methods in Political Economy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Reviews recent quantitative empirical studies on important, substantive questions in political economy. Designed to increase students' understanding of the core research designs and measurement strategies employed in the empirical analysis of political institutions and political behavior. Topics include the political and economic consequences of direct democracy, reservations for political minorities, corruption, political effects of the media, and politics in authoritarian regimes.
<br><I>D. Hidalgo</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.831"></a>
<p><h3>17.831 Data and Politics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Explores the intersection between politics and data. Introduces principles and practice of data-driven methods used to understand electoral and other types of political behavior. Students use real world datasets to explore topics such as election polling and prediction, the determinants of voter turnout, how campaigns target voters, and how public opinion changes over time.
<br><I>D. Hidalgo</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.835"></a>
<p><h3>17.835 Machine Learning and Data Science in Politics
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/hassS.gif" alt="HASS Social Sciences" title="HASS Social Sciences" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.0001">6.0001</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=3">3-133</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-242</a>) or <i>R4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-379</a>) or <i>F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=1">1-379</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces students to politics by analyzing political science data sets with machine learning methodologies. Covers a variety of data science tools, including supervised and unsupervised learning methods, visualization techniques, text analysis, and network analysis. Emphasizes how the research methodologies can be used for studying political science. Topics include lobbying, international trade, political networks, and estimating ideologies of political leaders.
<br><I>I. Kim</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.850"></a>
<p><h3>17.850 Political Science Scope and Methods
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces principles of empirical and theoretical analysis in political science. Exposes students to major research questions and different ways of examining them. Limited to Course 17 PhD students.
<br><I>D. Caughey</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.878"></a>
<p><h3>17.878 Qualitative Research: Design and Methods
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>R3-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E51">E51-085</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Prepares students to conduct independent qualitative research. Topics include research design, human subjects protocols and research ethics, risk management, participant observation and interview techniques, and data collection and analysis. During the term, students complete a qualitative research project in the Boston area. Especially appropriate for students planning to do fieldwork.
<br><I>C. Lawson</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=17.878');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->

<p><h3>17.901 Political Science Internship and Research
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<br>Units arranged
<br>IAP URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/17.901/">http://web.mit.edu/17.901/</a><br>Spring URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/17.901/">http://web.mit.edu/17.901/</a>
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Independent research enabling students to do work in an agency, state, or local government, or other public organization. The academic component involves close contact between the student and a faculty advisor and written work. Work may be done during the summer.

<a name="17.903"></a>
<p><h3>17.903 Community Service: Experience and Reflection
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>IAP URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/17.901/">http://web.mit.edu/17.901/</a><br>Spring URL: <a href="http://web.mit.edu/17.901/">http://web.mit.edu/17.901/</a>
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar involves students in the community that exists beyond the labs and classrooms of the MIT campus. Through a combination of community service and academic study, students learn about political, economic, and social issues that confront residents in Boston and Cambridge. Students volunteer in a community service agency or private organization devoted to community needs and development. Students also responsible for directed readings, short writing assignments, and six seminar sessions. Subject can only be repeated for credit if area of community service is different.
<br>Fall: <I>T. Weiner</I><br>IAP: <I>T. Weiner</I><br>Spring: <I>T. Weiner</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.905"></a><a name="17.906"></a><a name="17.907"></a><a name="17.908"></a><a name="17.909"></a><a name="17.910"></a><a name="17.911"></a>
<p><h3>17.905-17.911 Reading Seminar in Social Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged
<br><b>17.905:</b> TBA. <!--s--><br><b>17.906:</b> TBA. <!--s--><br><b>17.910:</b> TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Reading and discussion of special topics in the fields of social science. Open to advanced undergraduates by arrangement with individual staff members. 17.909 is taught P/D/F.
<br>Staff<br><b>17.905:</b> No textbook information available<br><b>17.906:</b> No textbook information available<br><b>17.910:</b> No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.922"></a>
<p><h3>17.922 Martin Luther King, Jr. Design Seminar
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Facilitates design and construction of installations and other community projects in conjunction with and beyond MIT's celebration of Dr. King. Students discuss the ideas and goals of Dr. King and other human rights leaders in the US and the world. The first half of the class develops in-depth understanding of the history of US racial issues as well as past and present domestic and international political struggles. Addresses issues of justice, equality and racism through videos, readings and writings, and class discussions. In the second half, students work as a group complete the installation and projects which serve as models for connecting academics with real life problems and struggle.
<br><I>T. Weiner</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.923"></a>
<p><h3>17.923 Martin Luther King, Jr. Design Seminar for Facilitators/Teachers
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m17b.html#17.922">17.922</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students participate in the class but also assist instructor in the design and execution of the curriculum and actively participate in the instruction and monitoring of class participants. Students prepare subject materials, lead discussion groups, and review progress. Includes daily evaluation and meetings to reflect on the class itself and the students' performance as leaders.
<br><I>T. Weiner</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.925"></a>
<p><h3>17.925 Fundamentals of Science and Technology Public Policy Making: Science and Technology Policy Boot Camp
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines the public policy behind, and the government's role in, the science and technology-based innovation system. Focuses on the US, but also discusses international examples. Prepares students planning careers in and around science and technology with the basic background for involvement in science policy making. Students may register for 3-6 units.
<br><I>W. Bonvillian</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.959"></a>

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>

<p><h3>17.THG Graduate Political Science Thesis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>

<a name="17.THT"></a>
<p><h3>17.THT Thesis Research Design Seminar
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m17b.html#17.803">17.803</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students writing a thesis in Political Science develop their research topics, review relevant research and scholarship, frame their research questions and arguments, choose an appropriate methodology for analysis, and draft the introductory and methodology sections of their theses. Includes substantial instruction and practice in writing with revision and oral presentations.
<br><I>D. Singer</I><br>
</p><!--end-->

<p><h3>17.S917 Special Undergraduate Subject in Political Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Reading and discussion of topics in the field of social science not covered in the regular curriculum.
<br>IAP: <I>L. Rabieh</I><br>Spring: <I>L. Rabieh</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="17.S918"></a>

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom"><br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: None

<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->

<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Course 18: Mathematics<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://www-math.mit.edu/"><i>Course 18 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course18.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=18&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=++18&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>18.01-18.499</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m18b.html">18.50-18.THG</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<h2>General Mathematics</h2>
<a name="18.01"></a>
<p><h3>18.01 Calculus
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/calc1.gif" alt="Calculus I" title="Calculus I" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.01A">18.01A</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.181A">CC.181A</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.1801">ES.1801</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.181A">ES.181A</A>
<br><a href="http://stellar.mit.edu/S/course/18/sp18/18.01/">http://stellar.mit.edu/S/course/18/sp18/18.01/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11,F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-135</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>MW2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-135</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Differentiation and integration of functions of one variable, with applications.  Informal treatment of limits and continuity.  Differentiation: definition, rules, application to graphing, rates, approximations, and extremum problems. Indefinite integration; separable first-order differential equations.  Definite integral; fundamental theorem of calculus. Applications of integration to geometry and science.  Elementary functions.  Techniques of integration.  Polar coordinates. L'Hopital's rule.  Improper integrals.  Infinite series: geometric, p-harmonic, simple comparison tests, power series for some elementary functions.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Speck</I><br>IAP: <I>B. Peskin</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Bush</I><br>No textbook information available (IAP 2018); <a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.01');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.01A"></a>
<p><h3>18.01A Calculus
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/calc1.gif" alt="Calculus I" title="Calculus I" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">; first half of term
<br>Prereq: Knowledge of differentiation and elementary integration
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.01">18.01</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.181A">CC.181A</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.1801">ES.1801</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.181A">ES.181A</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Six-week review of one-variable calculus, emphasizing material not on the high-school AB syllabus: integration techniques and applications, improper integrals, infinite series, applications to other topics, such as probability and statistics, as time permits. Prerequisites: one year of high-school calculus or the equivalent, with a score of 5 on the AB Calculus test (or the AB portion of the BC test, or an equivalent score on a standard international exam), or equivalent college transfer credit, or a passing grade on the first half of the 18.01 advanced standing exam.
<br><I>D. Maulik</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.02"></a>
<p><h3>18.02 Calculus
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/calc2.gif" alt="Calculus II" title="Calculus II" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.022">18.022</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.02A">18.02A</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.1802">CC.1802</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.182A">CC.182A</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.1802">ES.1802</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.182A">ES.182A</A>
<br><a href="http://stellar.mit.edu/S/course/18/sp18/18.02/">http://stellar.mit.edu/S/course/18/sp18/18.02/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11,F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=54">54-100</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>MW10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-136</a>) or <i>MW11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-143</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-142</a>) or <i>MW12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-142</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-147</a>) or <i>MW1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-142</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-147</a>) or <i>MW2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-132</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Calculus of several variables. Vector algebra in 3-space, determinants, matrices. Vector-valued functions of one variable, space motion. Scalar functions of several variables: partial differentiation, gradient, optimization techniques. Double integrals and line integrals in the plane; exact differentials and conservative fields; Green's theorem and applications, triple integrals, line and surface integrals in space, Divergence theorem, Stokes' theorem; applications.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Bush</I><br>Spring: <I>L. Guth</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.02');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.02A"></a>
<p><h3>18.02A Calculus
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/calc2.gif" alt="Calculus II" title="Calculus II" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.02">18.02</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.022">18.022</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.1802">CC.1802</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.182A">CC.182A</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.1802">ES.1802</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.182A">ES.182A</A>
<br>IAP URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.02A">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.02A</a><br>Spring URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.02A">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.02A</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11,F2 (BEGINS APR 2)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=54">54-100</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TBA</i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>First half is taught during the last six weeks of the Fall term; covers material in the first half of 18.02 (through double integrals). Second half of 18.02A can be taken either during IAP (daily lectures) or during the second half of the Spring term; it covers the remaining material in 18.02.
<br>Fall: <I>T. Beck</I><br>IAP: <I>T. Beck</I><br>Spring: <I>L. Guth</I><br>No textbook information available (IAP 2018); <a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.02A');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.022"></a>
<p><h3>18.022 Calculus
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/calc2.gif" alt="Calculus II" title="Calculus II" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.02">18.02</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.02A">18.02A</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.1802">CC.1802</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.182A">CC.182A</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.1802">ES.1802</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.182A">ES.182A</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Calculus of several variables. Topics as in 18.02 but with more focus on mathematical concepts. Vector algebra, dot product, matrices, determinant. Functions of several variables, continuity, differentiability, derivative. Parametrized curves, arc length, curvature, torsion. Vector fields, gradient, curl, divergence. Multiple integrals, change of variables, line integrals, surface integrals. Stokes' theorem in one, two, and three dimensions.
<br><I>P. Etingof</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.03"></a>
<p><h3>18.03 Differential Equations
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a></I>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.032">18.032</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.1803">CC.1803</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.1803">ES.1803</A>
<br><a href="https://learning-modules.mit.edu/class/index.html?uuid=/course/18/sp18/18.03#info">https://learning-modules.mit.edu/class/index.html?uuid=/course/18/sp18/18.03#info</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-100</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-143</a>) or <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-136</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-142</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-143</a>) or <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-131</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-132</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-142</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-146</a>) or <i>TR12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-131</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-132</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-142</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-146</a>) or <i>TR1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-142</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=35">35-308</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-310</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-328</a>) or <i>TR2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-328</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-142</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-143</a>) or <i>TR3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-142</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-143</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Study of differential equations, including modeling physical systems. Solution of first-order ODEs by analytical, graphical, and numerical methods. Linear ODEs with constant coefficients. Complex numbers and exponentials. Inhomogeneous equations: polynomial, sinusoidal, and exponential inputs. Oscillations, damping, resonance. Fourier series. Matrices, eigenvalues, eigenvectors, diagonalization. First order linear systems: normal modes, matrix exponentials, variation of parameters. Heat equation, wave equation. Nonlinear autonomous systems: critical point analysis, phase plane diagrams.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Negut</I><br>Spring: <I>B. Poonen</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.031"></a>
<p><h3>18.031 System Functions and the Laplace Transform
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); second half of term
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a></I>
<br>Units: 1-0-2 [P/D/F]
<br><a href="https://math.mit.edu/18.031">https://math.mit.edu/18.031</a>
<br>Begins Apr 2. <b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-151</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies basic continuous control theory as well as representation of functions in the complex frequency domain. Covers generalized functions, unit impulse response, and convolution; and Laplace transform, system (or transfer) function, and the pole diagram.  Includes examples from mechanical and electrical engineering.
<br>Fall: <I>P. Pearce</I><br>Spring: <I>P. Pearce</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.032"></a>
<p><h3>18.032 Differential Equations
<br>(18.034)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a></I>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</A>, <A HREF="mCCa.html#CC.1803">CC.1803</A>, <A HREF="mESa.html#ES.1803">ES.1803</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-159</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-261</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers much of the same material as 18.03 with more emphasis on theory. The point of view is rigorous and results are proven.  Local existence and uniqueness of solutions.
<br><I>N. Edelen</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.032');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.04"></a>
<p><h3>18.04 Complex Variables with Applications
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.032">18.032</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.075">18.075</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.0751">18.0751</A>
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/18.04/">http://math.mit.edu/18.04/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-143</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-143</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Complex algebra and functions; analyticity; contour integration, Cauchy's theorem; singularities, Taylor and Laurent series; residues, evaluation of integrals; multivalued functions, potential theory in two dimensions; Fourier analysis, Laplace transforms, and partial differential equations.
<br><I>J. Orloff</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.05"></a>
<p><h3>18.05 Introduction to Probability and Statistics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11,F10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-082</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Elementary introduction with applications. Basic probability models. Combinatorics. Random variables. Discrete and continuous probability distributions. Statistical estimation and testing. Confidence intervals. Introduction to linear regression.
<br><I>D. Vogan</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.05');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.06"></a>
<p><h3>18.06 Linear Algebra
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</A>
<br><a href="http://stellar.mit.edu/S/course/18/sp18/18.06/">http://stellar.mit.edu/S/course/18/sp18/18.06/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-250</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>T10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-328</a>) or <i>T11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-328</a>) or <i>T12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-149</a>) or <i>T1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-149</a>) or <i>T2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-149</a>) or <i>T3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-261</a>) or <i>T12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-153</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Basic subject on matrix theory and linear algebra, emphasizing topics useful in other disciplines, including systems of equations, vector spaces, determinants, eigenvalues, singular value decomposition, and positive definite matrices. Applications to least-squares approximations, stability of differential equations, networks, Fourier transforms, and Markov processes. Uses MATLAB. Compared with 18.700, more emphasis on matrix algorithms and many applications.
<br>Fall: <I>S. Johnson</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Edelman</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.06');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.062"></a>
<p><h3>18.062[J] Mathematics for Computer Science
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6a.html#6.042">6.042[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><a href="https://courses.csail.mit.edu/6.042/spring18/">https://courses.csail.mit.edu/6.042/spring18/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-082</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-044</a>) or <i>MWF2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-044</a>, <a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-124</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Elementary discrete mathematics for computer science and engineering. Emphasis on mathematical definitions and proofs as well as on applicable methods.  Topics include formal logic notation, proof methods; induction, well-ordering; sets, relations; elementary graph theory; asymptotic notation and growth of functions; permutations and combinations, counting principles; discrete probability.  Further selected topics include recursive definition and structural induction, state machines and invariants, integer congruences, recurrences, generating functions.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Meyer</I><br>Spring: <I>Z. Abel</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.065"></a>
<p><h3>18.065 Matrix Methods in Data Analysis, Signal Processing, and Machine Learning
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m18a.html#18.0651">18.0651</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-190</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Reviews linear algebra with applications to life sciences, finance, engineering, and big data. Covers singular value decomposition, weighted least squares, signal and image processing, principal component analysis, covariance and correlation matrices, directed and undirected graphs, matrix factorizations, neural nets, machine learning, and computations with large matrices.
<br><I>W. Strang</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m18a.html#18.065">18.065</A>)

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Reviews linear algebra with applications to life sciences, finance, engineering, and big data. Covers singular value decomposition, weighted least squares, signal and image processing, principal component analysis, covariance and correlation matrices, directed and undirected graphs, matrix factorizations, neural nets, machine learning, and computations with large matrices. <a name="18.075"></a>
<p><h3>18.075 Methods for Scientists and Engineers
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m18a.html#18.0751">18.0751</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.04">18.04</A>
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.075">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.075</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-142</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers functions of a complex variable; calculus of residues. Includes ordinary differential equations; Bessel and Legendre functions; Sturm-Liouville theory; partial differential equations; heat equation; and wave equations.
<br><I>H. Cheng</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.075');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.0751"></a>
<p><h3>18.0751 Methods for Scientists and Engineers
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>

<a name="18.085"></a>
<p><h3>18.085 Computational Science and Engineering I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m18a.html#18.0851">18.0851</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.032">18.032</a>

Frequent use of MATLAB in a wide range of scientific and engineering applications.
<br>Fall: <I>W. Strang</I><br>Spring: <I>P. Saenz Hervias</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.085');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.0851"></a>
<p><h3>18.0851 Computational Science and Engineering I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m18a.html#18.085">18.085</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.032">18.032</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-163</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Review of linear algebra, applications to networks, structures, and estimation, finite difference and finite element solution of differential equations, Laplace's equation and potential flow, boundary-value problems, Fourier series, discrete Fourier transform, convolution. Frequent use of MATLAB in a wide range of scientific and engineering applications. Students in Course 18 must register for the undergraduate version, 18.085.
<br>Fall: <I>W. Gilbert Strang</I><br>Spring: <I>Pedro Saenz</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.0851');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.086"></a>
<p><h3>18.086 Computational Science and Engineering II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m18a.html#18.0861">18.0861</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.032">18.032</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/18086/">http://math.mit.edu/18086/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Initial value problems: finite difference methods, accuracy and stability, heat equation, wave equations, conservation laws and shocks, level sets, Navier-Stokes.  Solving large systems: elimination with reordering, iterative methods, preconditioning, multigrid, Krylov subspaces, conjugate gradients. Optimization and minimum principles: weighted least squares, constraints, inverse problems, calculus of variations, saddle point problems, linear programming, duality, adjoint methods.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.0861"></a>
<p><h3>18.0861 Computational Science and Engineering II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m18a.html#18.086">18.086</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m18a.html#18.032">18.032</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Initial value problems: finite difference methods, accuracy and stability, heat equation, wave equations, conservation laws and shocks, level sets, Navier-Stokes.  Solving large systems: elimination with reordering, iterative methods, preconditioning, multigrid, Krylov subspaces, conjugate gradients. Optimization and minimum principles: weighted least squares, constraints, inverse problems, calculus of variations, saddle point problems, linear programming, duality, adjoint methods. Students in Course 18 must register for the undergraduate version, 18.086.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.089"></a>
<p><h3>18.089 Review of Mathematics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>One-week review of one-variable calculus (18.01), followed by concentrated study covering multivariable calculus (18.02), two hours per day for five weeks. Primarily for graduate students in Course 2N. Degree credit allowed only in special circumstances.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.094"></a>
<p><h3>18.094[J] Teaching College-Level Science and Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1c.html#1.95">1.95[J]</A>, <A HREF="m5b.html#5.95">5.95[J]</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.59">7.59[J]</A>, <A HREF="m8b.html#8.395">8.395[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2c.html#2.978">2.978</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Participatory seminar focuses on the knowledge and skills necessary for teaching science and engineering in higher education. Topics include theories of adult learning; course development; promoting active learning, problemsolving, and critical thinking in students; communicating with a diverse student body; using educational technology to further learning; lecturing; creating effective tests and assignments; and assessment and evaluation. Students research and present a relevant topic of particular interest. Appropriate for both novices and those with teaching experience.
<br><I>J. Rankin</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.095"></a>
<p><h3>18.095 Mathematics Lecture Series
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m1" title="18.01, 18.01A, 18.014">Calculus I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br>IAP URL: <a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.095/">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.095/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Ten lectures by mathematics faculty members on interesting topics from both classical and modern mathematics. All lectures accessible to students with calculus background and an interest in mathematics. At each lecture, reading and exercises are assigned. Students prepare these for discussion in a weekly problem session.
<br><I>A. Edelman</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->

<h2>Analysis</h2>
<a name="18.1001"></a>
<p><h3>18.1001 Real Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m18a.html#18.100A">18.100A</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.100B">18.100B</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.100P">18.100P</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.100Q">18.100Q</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-163</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Four options offered, each covering fundamentals of mathematical analysis: convergence of sequences and series, continuity, differentiability, Riemann integral, sequences and series of functions, uniformity, interchange of limit operations. Each option shows the utility of abstract concepts and teaches understanding and construction of proofs. Option A: Proofs and definitions are less abstract. Gives applications where possible. Concerned primarily with the real line. Option B: More demanding; for students with more mathematical maturity. Places more emphasis on point-set topology and n-space. Option P: 15-unit (4-0-11) variant of Option A, with further instruction and practice in written communication. Option Q: 15-unit (4-0-11) variant of Option B, with further instruction and practice in written communication. Students in Course 18 must register for one of the undergraduate versions of this subject: 18.100A, 18.100B, 18.100P, or 18.100Q.
<br>Fall: <I>A. P. Mattuck</I><br>Spring: <I>K. Choi</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.1001');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Three options offered, each covering fundamentals of mathematical analysis: convergence of sequences and series, continuity, differentiability, Riemann integral, sequences and series of functions, uniformity, interchangeFour options offered, each covering fundamentals of mathematical analysis: convergence of sequences and series, continuity, differentiability, Riemann integral, sequences and series of functions, uniformity, interchange of limit operations. <p><h3>18.100P Real Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-11
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.1001">18.1001</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.100A">18.100A</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.100B">18.100B</A>, <A HREF="m18a.html#18.100Q">18.100Q</A>

Concerned primarily with the real line. <i>Option B:</i> More demanding; for students with more mathematical maturity. Places more emphasis on point-set topology and n-space. <i>Option P:</i> 15-unit (4-0-11) variant of Option A, with further instruction and practice in written communication.  <i>Option Q:</i> 15-unit (4-0-11) variant of Option B, with further instruction and practice in written communication. <p><h3>18.101 Analysis and Manifolds
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m18a.html#18.1011">18.1011</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.100A">18.100A</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100B">18.100B</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100P">18.100P</a>, or <a href="m18a.html#18.100Q">18.100Q</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>, <a href="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</a>, or <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to the theory of manifolds: vector fields and densities on manifolds, integral calculus in the manifold setting and the manifold version of the divergence theorem. 18.901 helpful but not required.
<br><I>V. Guillemin</I><br>
</p><!--end-->

<p><h3>18.1011 Analysis and Manifolds
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>

<a name="18.102"></a>
<p><h3>18.102 Introduction to Functional Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m18a.html#18.1021">18.1021</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.100A">18.100A</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100B">18.100B</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100P">18.100P</a>, or <a href="m18a.html#18.100Q">18.100Q</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>, <a href="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</a>, or <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.102">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.102</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-370</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Normed spaces, completeness, functionals, Hahn-Banach theorem, duality, operators. Lebesgue measure, measurable functions, integrability, completeness of L-p spaces. Hilbert space. Compact, Hilbert-Schmidt and trace class operators. Spectral theorem.
<br><I>R. Melrose</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.1021"></a>
<p><h3>18.1021 Introduction to Functional Analysis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">

Compact, Hilbert-Schmidt and trace class operators. Spectral theorem. Students in Course 18 must register for the undergraduate version, 18.102.
