<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Course 18: Mathematics<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://www-math.mit.edu/"><i>Course 18 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course18.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=18&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=++18&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b><a href="m18a.html">18.01-18.499</a></b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>18.50-18.THG</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<h2>Logic</h2>
<a name="18.504"></a>
<p><h3>18.504 Seminar in Logic
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.100A">18.100A</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100B">18.100B</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100P">18.100P</a>, or <a href="m18a.html#18.100Q">18.100Q</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>, <a href="m18b.html#18.510">18.510</a>, <a href="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</a>, or <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.504">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.504</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students present and discuss the subject matter taken from current journals or books. Topics vary from year to year. Instruction and practice in written and oral communication provided. Enrollment limited.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.510"></a>
<p><h3>18.510 Introduction to Mathematical Logic and Set Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Propositional and predicate logic. Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory. Ordinals and cardinals. Axiom of choice and transfinite induction. Elementary model theory: completeness, compactness, and Lowenheim-Skolem theorems. Godel's incompleteness theorem.
<br><I>H. Cohn</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.515"></a>
<p><h3>18.515 Mathematical Logic
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.515">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.515</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>More rigorous treatment of basic mathematical logic, Godel's theorems, and Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory. First-order logic. Models and satisfaction. Deduction and proof. Soundness and completeness. Compactness and its consequences. Quantifier elimination. Recursive sets and functions. Incompleteness and undecidability. Ordinals and cardinals. Set-theoretic formalization of mathematics.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Probability and Statistics</h2>
<a name="18.600"></a>
<p><h3>18.600 Probability and Random Variables
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m15a.html#15.079">15.079</A>, <A HREF="m15a.html#15.0791">15.0791</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=10">10-250</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>R12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-155</a>) or <i>R4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-163</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Probability spaces, random variables, distribution functions. Binomial, geometric, hypergeometric, Poisson distributions. Uniform, exponential, normal, gamma and beta distributions. Conditional probability, Bayes theorem, joint distributions. Chebyshev inequality, law of large numbers, and central limit theorem. Credit cannot also be received for 6.041A or 6.041B.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Kelner</I><br>Spring: <I>S. Sheffield</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.615"></a>
<p><h3>18.615 Introduction to Stochastic Processes
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.600">18.600</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.041B">6.041B</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-163</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Basics of stochastic processes.  Markov chains, Poisson processes, random walks, birth and death processes, Brownian motion.
<br><I>A. Bufetov</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.642"></a>
<p><h3>18.642 Topics in Mathematics with Applications in Finance
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.05">18.05</a> or <a href="m18b.html#18.600">18.600</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-11
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to mathematical concepts and techniques used in finance. Lectures focusing on linear algebra, probability, statistics, stochastic processes, and numerical methods are interspersed with lectures by financial sector professionals illustrating the corresponding application in the industry. Prior knowledge of economics or finance helpful but not required. Instruction and practice in written communication provided. Limited to 30.
<br><I>P. Kempthorne</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.650"></a>
<p><h3>18.650[J] Fundamentals of Statistics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.014">IDS.014[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m18b.html#18.6501">18.6501</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.600">18.600</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.041B">6.041B</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m15a.html#15.075">15.075</A>, <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.013">IDS.013</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-190</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-163</a>) or <i>W4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-231</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A broad treatment of statistics, concentrating on specific statistical techniques used in science and industry. Topics: hypothesis testing and estimation. Confidence intervals, chi-square tests, nonparametric statistics, analysis of variance, regression, correlation, decision theory, and Bayesian statistics.
<br>Fall: <I>P. Rigollet</I><br>Spring: <I>V. Brunel</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.6501"></a>
<p><h3>18.6501 Fundamentals of Statistics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m18b.html#18.650">18.650[J]</A>, <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.014">IDS.014[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.600">18.600</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.041B">6.041B</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m15a.html#15.075">15.075</A>, <A HREF="mIDSa.html#IDS.013">IDS.013</A>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-190</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-163</a>) or <i>W4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-231</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A broad treatment of statistics, concentrating on specific statistical techniques used in science and industry. Topics: hypothesis testing and estimation. Confidence intervals, chi-square tests, nonparametric statistics, analysis of variance, regression, correlation, decision theory, and Bayesian statistics. Students in Course 18 must register for the undergraduate version, 18.650.
<br>Fall: <I>P. Rigollet</I><br>Spring: <I>V.-E. Brunel</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.655"></a>
<p><h3>18.655 Mathematical Statistics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-146</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Decision theory, estimation, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing. Introduces large sample theory. Asymptotic efficiency of estimates. Exponential families. Sequential analysis.
<br><I>P. Kempthorne</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.655');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->

<h2>Algebra and Number Theory</h2>
<a name="18.700"></a>
<p><h3>18.700 Linear Algebra
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Vector spaces, systems of linear equations, bases, linear independence, matrices, determinants, eigenvalues, inner products, quadratic forms, and canonical forms of matrices. More emphasis on theory and proofs than in 18.06.
<br><I>G. Oberdieck</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.701"></a>
<p><h3>18.701 Algebra I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.100A">18.100A</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100B">18.100B</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100P">18.100P</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100Q">18.100Q</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>More extensive and theoretical than the 18.700-18.703 sequence. Experience with proofs necessary. First term: group theory, geometry, and linear algebra. Second term: group representations, rings, ideals, fields, polynomial rings, modules, factorization, integers in quadratic number fields, field extensions, Galois theory.
<br><I>M. Artin</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.702"></a>
<h3>18.702 Algebra II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.702">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.702</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-190</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>More extensive and theoretical than the 18.700-18.703 sequence. Experience with proofs necessary. First term: group theory, geometry, and linear algebra. Second term: group representations, rings, ideals, fields, polynomial rings, modules, factorization, integers in quadratic number fields, field extensions, Galois theory.
<br><I>D. Ranganathan</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.702');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.703"></a>
<p><h3>18.703 Modern Algebra
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.703/">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.703/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-139</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on traditional algebra topics that have found greatest application in science and engineering as well as in mathematics: group theory, emphasizing finite groups; ring theory, including ideals and unique factorization in polynomial and Euclidean rings; field theory, including properties and applications of finite fields. 18.700 and 18.703 together form a standard algebra sequence.
<br><I>C. Negron</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.703');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.704"></a>
<p><h3>18.704 Seminar in Algebra
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a>; or <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>, <a href="m18b.html#18.703">18.703</a>; or <a href="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</a>, <a href="m18b.html#18.703">18.703</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.704">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.704</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-135</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Topics vary from year to year. Students present and discuss the subject matter. Instruction and practice in written and oral communication provided.  Some experience with proofs required. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>V. Kac</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.704');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.705"></a>
<p><h3>18.705 Commutative Algebra
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.702">18.702</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Exactness, direct limits, tensor products, Cayley-Hamilton theorem, integral dependence, localization, Cohen-Seidenberg theory, Noether normalization, Nullstellensatz, chain conditions, primary decomposition, length, Hilbert functions, dimension theory, completion, Dedekind domains.
<br><I>A. Pixton</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.706"></a>
<p><h3>18.706 Noncommutative Algebra
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.702">18.702</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.706/">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.706/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Topics may include one or more of the following: Coxeter groups, Hecke algebras, their canonical bases and their representations.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.708"></a>
<p><h3>18.708 Topics in Algebra
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.705">18.705</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-146</a>)<!--s-->

<br>Topics vary from year to year.
<br><I>P. Etingof</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.715"></a>
<p><h3>18.715 Introduction to Representation Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.702">18.702</a> or <a href="m18b.html#18.703">18.703</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Algebras, representations, Schur's lemma. Representations of SL(2). Representations of finite groups, Maschke's theorem, characters, applications. Induced representations, Burnside's theorem, Mackey formula, Frobenius reciprocity.  Representations of quivers.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.721"></a>
<p><h3>18.721 Introduction to Algebraic Geometry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.702">18.702</a>, <a href="m18b.html#18.901">18.901</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.721">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.721</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-131</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Presents basic examples of complex algebraic varieties, affine and projective algebraic geometry, sheaves, cohomology.
<br><I>M. Artin</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.725"></a>
<p><h3>18.725 Algebraic Geometry I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="m18b.html#18.705">18.705</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the basic notions and techniques of modern algebraic geometry. Covers fundamental notions and results about algebraic varieties over an algebraically closed field; relations between complex algebraic varieties and complex analytic varieties; and examples with emphasis on algebraic curves and surfaces. Introduction to the language of schemes and properties of morphisms. Knowledge of elementary algebraic topology, elementary differential geometry recommended, but not required.
<br><I>G. Sacca</I><br>
<a name="18.726"></a>
<p><h3>18.726 Algebraic Geometry II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.725">18.725</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.726">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.726</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-143</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Continuation of the introduction to algebraic geometry given in 18.725.  More advanced properties of the varieties and morphisms of schemes, as well as sheaf cohomology.
<br><I>G. Sacca</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.726');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.727"></a>
<p><h3>18.727 Topics in Algebraic Geometry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.725">18.725</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Topics vary from year to year.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.737"></a>
<p><h3>18.737 Algebraic Groups
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.705">18.705</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Structure of linear algebraic groups over an algebraically closed field, with emphasis on reductive groups.  Representations of groups over a finite field using methods from etale cohomology. Some results from algebraic geometry are stated without proof.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.745"></a>
<p><h3>18.745 Introduction to Lie Algebras
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a> or <a href="m18b.html#18.703">18.703</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.745">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.745</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-136</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Topics may include structure of finite-dimensional Lie algebras; theorems of Engel and Lie; Cartan subalgebras and regular elements; trace form and Cartan's criterion; Chevalley's conjugacy theorem; classification and construction of semisimple Lie algebras; Weyl group; universal enveloping algebra and the Casimir operator; Weyl's complete reducibility theorem, Levi and Maltsev theorems;  Verma modules; classification of irreducible finite-dimensional representations of semisimple Lie algebras; Weyl's character and dimension formulas.
<br><I>G. Lusztig</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.747"></a>
<p><h3>18.747 Infinite-dimensional Lie Algebras
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.745">18.745</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Topics vary from year to year.
<br><I>R. Bezrukavnikov</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.748"></a>
<p><h3>18.748 Topics in Lie Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Topics vary from year to year.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.755"></a>
<p><h3>18.755 Introduction to Lie Groups
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.100A">18.100A</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100B">18.100B</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100P">18.100P</a>, or <a href="m18a.html#18.100Q">18.100Q</a>; <a href="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</a> or <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>A general introduction to manifolds and Lie groups. The role of Lie groups in mathematics and physics. Exponential mapping. Correspondence with Lie algebras. Homogeneous spaces and transformation groups. Adjoint representation. Covering groups. Automorphism groups. Invariant differential forms and cohomology of Lie groups and homogeneous spaces. 18.101 recommended but not required.
<br><I>D. Vogan</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.757"></a>
<p><h3>18.757 Representations of Lie Groups
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.745">18.745</a> or <a href="m18b.html#18.755">18.755</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://www-math.mit.edu/~laurajoy/rep.html">http://www-math.mit.edu/~laurajoy/rep.html</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers representations of locally compact groups, with emphasis on compact groups and abelian groups. Includes Peter-Weyl theorem and Cartan-Weyl highest weight theory for compact Lie groups.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.781"></a>
<p><h3>18.781 Theory of Numbers
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.781">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.781</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-105</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>An elementary introduction to number theory with no algebraic prerequisites. Primes, congruences, quadratic reciprocity, diophantine equations, irrational numbers, continued fractions, partitions.
<br><I>A. Shankar</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.781');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.782"></a>
<p><h3>18.782 Introduction to Arithmetic Geometry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" title="Not offered academic year 2018-2019" src="/icns/nonext.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.702">18.702</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Exposes students to arithmetic geometry, motivated by the problem of finding rational points on curves. Includes an introduction to p-adic numbers and some fundamental results from number theory and algebraic geometry, such as the Hasse-Minkowski theorem and the Riemann-Roch theorem for curves. Additional topics may include Mordell's theorem, the Weil conjectures, and Jacobian varieties.
<br><I>D. Ranganathan</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.783"></a>
<p><h3>18.783 Elliptic Curves
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m18b.html#18.7831">18.7831</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.703">18.703</a>, or <I>Coreq: <a href="m18b.html#18.702">18.702</a></I>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.783">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.783</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Computationally focused introduction to elliptic curves, with applications to number theory and cryptography. Topics include point-counting, isogenies, pairings, and the theory of complex multiplication, with applications to integer factorization, primality proving, and elliptic curve cryptography. Includes a brief introduction to modular curves and the proof of Fermat's Last Theorem.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.7831"></a>
<p><h3>18.7831 Elliptic Curves
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m18b.html#18.783">18.783</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.703">18.703</a>, <I>Coreq: <a href="m18b.html#18.702">18.702</a></I>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Computationally focused introduction to elliptic curves, with applications to number theory and cryptography. Topics include point-counting, isogenies, pairings, and the theory of complex multiplication, with applications to integer factorization, primality proving, and elliptic curve cryptography. Includes a brief introduction to modular curves and the proof of Fermat's Last Theorem. Students in Course 18 must register for the undergraduate version, 18.783.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.784"></a>
<p><h3>18.784 Seminar in Number Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.100A">18.100A</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100B">18.100B</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100P">18.100P</a>, or <a href="m18a.html#18.100Q">18.100Q</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Topics vary from year to year. Students present and discuss the subject matter. Instruction and practice in written and oral communication provided. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>A. Shankar</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.785"></a>
<p><h3>18.785 Number Theory I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None. <I>Coreq: <a href="m18b.html#18.705">18.705</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Dedekind domains, unique factorization of ideals, splitting of primes. Lattice methods, finiteness of the class group, Dirichlet's unit theorem. Local fields, ramification, discriminants. Zeta and L-functions, analytic class number formula.  Adeles and ideles. Statements of class field theory and the Chebotarev density theorem.
<br><I>A. Sutherland</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.786"></a>
<p><h3>18.786 Number Theory  II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.785">18.785</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.786">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.786</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-139</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Continuation of 18.785.  More advanced topics in number theory, such as Galois cohomology, proofs of class field theory, modular forms and automorphic forms, Galois representations, or quadratic forms.
<br><I>A. Sutherland</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.787"></a>
<p><h3>18.787 Topics in Number Theory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Topics vary from year to year.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Mathematics Laboratory</h2>
<a name="18.821"></a>
<p><h3>18.821 Project Laboratory in Mathematics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Two mathematics subjects numbered <a href="m18a.html#18.100">18.100</a> or above
<br>Units: 3-6-3
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.821/">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.821/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M1,WF1-3</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-143</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>M2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-143</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Guided research in mathematics, employing the scientific method. Students confront puzzling and complex mathematical situations, through the acquisition of data by computer, pencil and paper, or physical experimentation, and attempt to explain them mathematically. Students choose three projects from a large collection of options. Each project results in a laboratory report subject to revision; oral presentation on one or two projects. Projects drawn from many areas, including dynamical systems, number theory, algebra, fluid mechanics, asymptotic analysis, knot theory, and probability. Enrollment limited.
<br>Fall: <I>R. Bezrukavnikov</I><br>Spring: <I>H. Miller</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<h2>Topology and Geometry</h2>
<a name="18.901"></a>
<p><h3>18.901 Introduction to Topology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m18b.html#18.9011">18.9011</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.100A">18.100A</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100B">18.100B</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100P">18.100P</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100Q">18.100Q</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.901/">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.901/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-132</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces topology, covering topics fundamental to modern analysis and geometry. Topological spaces and continuous functions, connectedness, compactness, separation axioms, covering spaces, and the fundamental group.
<br>Fall: <I>G. Lusztig</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Lin</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.901');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.9011"></a>
<p><h3>18.9011 Introduction to Topology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m18b.html#18.901">18.901</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.100A">18.100A</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100B">18.100B</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100P">18.100P</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100Q">18.100Q</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-132</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces topology, covering topics fundamental to modern analysis and geometry. Topological spaces and continuous functions, connectedness, compactness, separation axioms, covering spaces, and the fundamental group. Students in Course 18 must register for the undergraduate version, 18.901.
<br>Fall: <I>G. Lusztig</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Lin</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.9011');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.904"></a>
<p><h3>18.904 Seminar in Topology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.901">18.901</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Topics vary from year to year and include the fundamental group and covering spaces. Time permitting, also covers the relationship between these objects and the theory of knots.  Students present and discuss the subject matter. Instruction and practice in written and oral communication provided. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>Z. Xu</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.905"></a>
<p><h3>18.905 Algebraic Topology I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a> or <a href="m18b.html#18.703">18.703</a>; <a href="m18b.html#18.901">18.901</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Singular homology, CW complexes, universal coefficient and K&uuml;nneth theorems, cohomology, cup products, Poincar&eacute; duality.
<br><I>G. Tabuada</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.906"></a>
<p><h3>18.906 Algebraic Topology II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.905">18.905</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.906/">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.906/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-147</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Continues the introduction to Algebraic Topology from 18.905. Topics include basic homotopy theory, spectral sequences, characteristic classes, and cohomology operations.
<br><I>Z. Xu</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.917"></a>
<p><h3>18.917 Topics in Algebraic Topology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.906">18.906</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.917/">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.917/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-146</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Content varies from year to year. Introduces new and significant developments in algebraic topology with the focus on homotopy theory and related areas.
<br><I>G. Tabuada</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.919"></a>
<p><h3>18.919 Graduate Topology Seminar
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.906">18.906</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Study and discussion of important original papers in the various parts of algebraic topology. Open to all students who have taken 18.906 or the equivalent, not only prospective topologists.
<br><I>H. Miller</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.937"></a>
<p><h3>18.937 Topics in Geometric Topology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.937">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.937</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Content varies from year to year.  Introduces new and significant developments in geometric topology.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.950"></a>
<p><h3>18.950 Differential Geometry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m18b.html#18.9501">18.9501</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.100A">18.100A</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100B">18.100B</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100P">18.100P</a>, or <a href="m18a.html#18.100Q">18.100Q</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>, <a href="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</a>, or <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.950/2016fa/index.html">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.950/2016fa/index.html</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-143</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to differential geometry, centered on notions of curvature. Starts with curves in the plane, and proceeds to higher dimensional submanifolds. Computations in coordinate charts: first and second fundamental form, Christoffel symbols. Discusses the distinction between extrinsic and intrinsic aspects, in particular Gauss' theorema egregium. The Gauss-Bonnet theorem.  Geodesics. Examples such as hyperbolic space.
<br><I>B. Wilson</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.950');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.9501"></a>
<p><h3>18.9501 Differential Geometry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m18b.html#18.950">18.950</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.100A">18.100A</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100B">18.100B</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.100P">18.100P</a>, or <a href="m18a.html#18.100Q">18.100Q</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.06">18.06</a>, <a href="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</a>, or <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-143</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to differential geometry, centered on notions of curvature. Starts with curves in the plane, and proceeds to higher dimensional submanifolds. Computations in coordinate charts: first and second fundamental form, Christoffel symbols. Discusses the distinction between extrinsic and intrinsic aspects, in particular Gauss' theorema egregium. The Gauss-Bonnet theorem.  Geodesics. Examples such as hyperbolic space. Students in Course 18 must register for the undergraduate version, 18.950.
<br><I>B. Wilson</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=18.9501');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.952"></a>
<p><h3>18.952 Theory of Differential Forms
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.101">18.101</a>; <a href="m18b.html#18.700">18.700</a> or <a href="m18b.html#18.701">18.701</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.952/">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.952/</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-136</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Multilinear algebra: tensors and exterior forms. Differential forms on R<SUP>n</SUP>: exterior differentiation, the pull-back operation and the Poincar&eacute; lemma. Applications to physics: Maxwell's equations from the differential form perspective. Integration of forms on open sets of R<SUP>n</SUP>. The change of variables formula revisited. The degree of a differentiable mapping. Differential forms on manifolds and De Rham theory. Integration of forms on manifolds and Stokes' theorem. The push-forward operation for forms. Thom forms and intersection theory. Applications to differential topology.
<br><I>V. Guillemin</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.965"></a>
<p><h3>18.965 Geometry of Manifolds I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.101">18.101</a>, <a href="m18b.html#18.950">18.950</a> or <a href="m18b.html#18.952">18.952</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Differential forms, introduction to Lie groups, the DeRham theorem, Riemannian manifolds, curvature, the Hodge theory. 18.966 is a continuation of 18.965 and focuses more deeply on various aspects of the geometry of manifolds. Contents vary from year to year, and can range from Riemannian geometry (curvature, holonomy) to symplectic geometry, complex geometry and Hodge-Kahler theory, or smooth manifold topology. Prior exposure to calculus on manifolds, as in 18.952, recommended.
<br><I>W. Minicozzi</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="18.966"></a>
<p><h3>18.966 Geometry of Manifolds II
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18b.html#18.965">18.965</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.966">http://math.mit.edu/classes/18.966</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-131</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Differential forms, introduction to Lie groups, the DeRham theorem, Riemannian manifolds, curvature, the Hodge theory. 18.966 is a continuation of 18.965 and focuses more deeply on various aspects of the geometry of manifolds. Contents vary from year to year, and can range from Riemannian geometry (curvature, holonomy) to symplectic geometry, complex geometry and Hodge-Kahler theory, or smooth manifold topology.  Prior exposure to calculus on manifolds, as in 18.952, is recommended.
<br><I>R. Melrose</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<a name="18.994"></a>
<p><h3>18.994 Seminar in Geometry
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m18a.html#18.101">18.101</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.102">18.102</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.103">18.103</a>, or <a href="m18a.html#18.112">18.112</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR9.30-11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=2">2-151</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students present and discuss subject matter taken from current journals or books. Topics vary from year to year. Instruction and practice in written and oral communication provided. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>C. Mantoulidis</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->

<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Course 20: Biological Engineering<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://web.mit.edu/be/"><i>Course 20 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim/course20.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=20&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="https://sisapp.mit.edu/ose-rpt/subjectEvaluationSearch.htm?departmentId=++20&search=Search"><i>Evaluations</i></a> <a href="http://ist.mit.edu/certificates"><i>(Certificates Required)</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>20.00-20.ZZZZ</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<a name="20.001"></a>
<p><h3>20.001 Introduction to Professional Success and Leadership in Biological Engineering
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-0-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i> <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Interactive introduction to the discipline of Biological Engineering through presentations by alumni practitioners, with additional panels and discussions on skills for professional development. Presentations emphasize the roles of communication through writing and speaking, building and maintaining professional networks, and interpersonal and leadership skills in building successful careers. Provides practical advice about how to prepare for job searches and graduate or professional school applications from an informed viewpoint. Prepares students for UROPs, internships, and selection of BE electives.
<br><I>L. Griffith</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.002"></a>
<p><h3>20.002 Metakaryotic Biology and Epidemiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m20a.html#20.A02">20.A02</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces non-eukaryotic metakaryotic cells that serve as the stem cells of human fetal/juvenile growth and development. Considers their peculiar modes of genome organization in chromosomal rings, replication via dsRNA/DNA intermediates and amitotic segregation. Explores the hypothesis that high mutation rates in these cells lead to cancers and atherosclerotic plaques and account for the increasing death rates observed with human age.
<br><I>W. Thilly</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.020"></a>
<p><h3>20.020 Introduction to Biological Engineering Design Using Synthetic Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m20a.html#20.385">20.385</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-3-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Project-based introduction to the engineering of synthetic biological systems. Throughout the term, students develop projects that are responsive to real-world problems of their choosing, and whose solutions depend on biological technologies. Lectures, discussions, and studio exercises will introduce components and control of prokaryotic and eukaryotic behavior; DNA synthesis, standards, and abstraction in biological engineering; and issues of human practice, including biological safety, security, ethics, and ownership, sharing, and innovation. Preference to freshmen.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.102"></a>
<p><h3>20.102 Stem Cells in Organogenesis, Carcinogenesis, and Atherogenesis
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m20a.html#20.215">20.215</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Study of the amitotic metakaryotic stem cells in fetal/juvenile organogenesis and wound healing. Explores their roles as stem cells in clonal diseases such as cancers and atherosclerosis. Application of a hypermutable/mutator stem cell model to the analysis of age-specific mortality from clonal diseases. Students taking 20.215 do additional research and computer modeling.
<br><I>W. Thilly</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.104"></a>
<p><h3>20.104[J] Environmental Cancer Risks, Prevention, and Therapy
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1a.html#1.081">1.081[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-220</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analysis of the history of cancer and vascular disease mortality rates in predominantly European- and African-American US cohorts, 1895-2010, to discover specific historical shifts. Shifts identified are explored in terms of contemporaneously changing environmental risk factors: air-, food- and water-borne chemicals; subclinical infections; diet and lifestyles. Role of occupational data identifying general risk factors.  Considers the hypotheses that environmental factors affect metakaryotic stem cell  mutation rates in fetuses and juveniles and/or the growth rates of preneoplastic stem cells in adults. Interaction of environmental and inherited risks. Introduces the use of metakaryocidal drugs to treat cancer in clinical trials.
<br><I>W. Thilly</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.106"></a>
<p><h3>20.106[J] Systems Microbiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1a.html#1.084">1.084[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introductory microbiology from a systems perspective - considers microbial diversity and the integration of data from a molecular, cellular, organismal, and ecological context to understand the interaction of microbial organisms with their environment. Special emphasis on specific viral, bacterial, and eukaryotic microorganisms and their interaction with animal hosts with focus on contemporary problems in areas such as vaccination, emerging disease, antimicrobial drug resistance, and toxicology.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.109"></a>
<p><h3>20.109 Laboratory Fundamentals in Biological Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.0002">6.0002</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.110">20.110</a>
<br>Units: 2-8-5
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-149</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TR1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-322</a>) or <i>WF1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-322</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces experimental biochemical and molecular techniques from a quantitative engineering perspective. Experimental design, data analysis, and scientific communication form the underpinnings of this subject. Examples of discovery-based experimental modules include DNA engineering in which students design, construct, and use genetic material; parts engineering, which emphasizes protein design and quantitative assessment of protein performance; systems engineering, in which students consider genome-wide consequences of genetic perturbations; and biomaterials engineering, in which students use biologically-encoded devices to design and build materials. Students complete some laboratory time online in advance of each class. Enrollment limited; priority to Course 20 majors.
<br>Fall: <I>N. Lyell</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Belcher, A. Koehler, E. Fraenkel, J. Bagnall, N. Lyell, L. McClain, S. Clarke</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.110"></a>
<p><h3>20.110[J] Thermodynamics of Biomolecular Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.772">2.772[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=c" title="3.091, 5.111, 5.112">Chemistry (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p1" title="8.01, 8.01L, 8.011, 8.012">Physics I (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-149</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>W2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-167</a>) or <i>F8</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-167</a>) or <i>W8</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-167</a>) or <i>F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-167</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Equilibrium properties of macroscopic and microscopic systems. Basic thermodynamics: state of a system, state variables. Work, heat, first law of thermodynamics, thermochemistry. Second and third law of thermodynamics: entropy and its statistical basis, Gibbs function. Chemical equilibrium of reactions in gas and solution phase. Macromolecular structure and interactions in solution. Driving forces for molecular self-assembly. Binding cooperativity, solvation, titration of macromolecules.
<br>Fall: <I>M. Birnbaum</I><br>Spring: <I>M. Birnbaum, C. Voigt</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.129"></a>
<p><h3>20.129[J] Biological Circuit Engineering Laboratory
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/Lab.gif" alt="Institute Lab" title="Institute Lab" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6a.html#6.129">6.129[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 2-8-2
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-121</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>MW1-5</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=68">68-077</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students assemble individual genes and regulatory elements into larger-scale circuits; they experimentally characterize these circuits in yeast cells using quantitative techniques, including flow cytometry, and model their results computationally. Emphasizes concepts and techniques to perform independent experimental and computational synthetic biology research. Discusses current literature and ongoing research in the field of synthetic biology. Instruction and practice in oral and written communication provided. Enrollment limited.
<br><I>J. Niles, R. Weiss</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.200"></a>
<p><h3>20.200 Biological Engineering Seminar
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 1-0-2 [P/D/F]
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>F12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=32">32-155</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Weekly one-hour seminars covering graduate student research and presentations by invited speakers. Limited to BE graduate students.
<br>Fall: <I>B. Engelward</I><br>Spring: <I>B. Engelward</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.201"></a>
<p><h3>20.201 Fundamentals of Drug Development
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Addresses the scientific basis for the development of new drugs. First half of term begins with an overview of the drug discovery process, followed by fundamental principles of pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, metabolism, and the mechanisms by which drugs cause therapeutic and toxic responses. Second half applies principles to case studies and literature discussions of current problems with specific drugs, drug classes, and therapeutic targets.
<br><I>P. C. Dedon, R. Sasisakharan</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.202"></a>
<p><h3>20.202 In vivo Models: Principles and Practices
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 1-1-4
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR1-2.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-802</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Selected aspects of anatomy, histology, immuno-cytochemistry, in situ hybridization, physiology, and cell biology of mammalian organisms and their pathogens. Subject material integrated with principles of toxicology, in vivo genetic engineering, and molecular biology. A lab/demonstration period each week involves experiments in anatomy (in vivo), physiology, and microscopy to augment the lectures. Offered first half of spring term.
<br><I>J. Fox</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.203"></a>
<p><h3>20.203[J] Neurotechnology in Action
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9a.html#9.123">9.123[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-6-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR2.30-4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=46">46-4062</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Offers a fast-paced introduction to numerous laboratory methods at the forefront of modern neurobiology. Comprises a sequence of modules focusing on neurotechnologies that are developed and used by MIT research groups. Each module consists of a background lecture and 1-2 days of firsthand laboratory experience. Topics typically include optical imaging, optogenetics, high throughput neurobiology, MRI/fMRI, advanced electrophysiology, viral and genetic tools, and connectomics.
<br><I>A. Jasanoff, E. Boyden, M. Jonas</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.205"></a>
<p><h3>20.205[J] Principles and Applications of Genetic Engineering for Biotechnology and Neuroscience
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9a.html#9.26">9.26[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.28">7.28</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.32">7.32</a>, or <a href="m20a.html#20.020">20.020</a>; <a href="m9a.html#9.01">9.01</a> or <a href="m9a.html#9.09">9.09</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>F10-1</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-251</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers principles underlying current and future genetic engineering approaches, ranging from single cellular organisms to whole animals. Focuses on development and invention of technologies for engineering biological systems at the genomic level, and applications of engineered biological systems for medical and biotechnological needs, with particular emphasis on genetic manipulation of the nervous system. Design projects by students.
<br><I>F. Zhang</I><br>No required or recommended textbooks
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.207"></a>
<p><h3>20.207 Biotechnologies in Infectious Disease
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Team-based exploration of current and emerging technologies used in the surveillance, diagnosis, understanding, treatment and prevention of infectious diseases, drawing on basic science and bio-engineering principles. In a term-long project, student teams develop novel technologies to solve major problems in global infectious disease, with a trajectory to a start-up company. Industry experts and academic entrepreneurs present case studies throughout the term, including technology innovations, regulatory sciences, intellectual property and clinical development. Term culminates with team presentations to a panel of industry and scientific leaders.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.213"></a>
<p><h3>20.213 Genome Stability and Engineering in the Context of Diseases, Drugs, and Public Health
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">); second half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW10-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-191</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TBA</i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies how DNA damage leads to diseases, and how DNA repair modulates cancer risk and treatment. Also covers how DNA repair impacts genetic engineering, whether by targeted gene therapy or CRISPR-mediated genetic changes. Students gain a public health perspective by examining how DNA-damaging agents in our environment can lead to downstream cancer. Explores the underlying chemical, molecular and biochemical processes of DNA damage and repair, and their implications for disease susceptibility and treatment.
<br><I>B. Engelward</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.215"></a>
<p><h3>20.215 Macroepidemiology, Population Genetics, and Stem Cell Biology of Human Clonal Diseases
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m20a.html#20.102">20.102</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=m2" title="18.02, 18.02A, 18.022, 18.023, 18.024">Calculus II (GIR)</a>, <a href="m1a.html#1.00">1.00</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-15
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Studies the logic and technology needed to discover genetic and environmental risks for common human cancers and vascular diseases. Includes an introduction to metakaryotic stem cell biology. Analyzes large, organized historical public health databases using quantitative cascade computer models that include population stratification of stem cell mutation rates in fetal/juvenile tissues  and  growth rates in preneoplastic colonies and atherosclerotic plaques. Means to test hypotheses (CAST) that certain genes carry mutations conferring risk for common cancers via genetic analyses in large human cohorts.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.219"></a>
<p><h3>20.219 Selected Topics in Biological Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Detailed discussion of selected topics of current interest. Classwork in various areas not covered by regular subjects.
<br>Fall: <I>D. Fares</I><br>Spring: <I>D. Fares</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.260"></a>
<p><h3>20.260 Analysis and Presentation of Complex Biological Data
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Illustrates best practices in the statistical analysis of complex biological datasets and the graphical representation of such analyses. Covers fundamental concepts in probability and statistical theory as well as principles of information design.  Provides mathematical concepts and tools that enable students to make sound judgments about the application of statistical methods and to present statistical results in clear and compelling visual formats. Assignments focus on key concepts and their application to practical examples. Assumes basic knowledge of calculus and programming in MATLAB or R.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.300"></a>
<p><h3>20.300 Advanced Workshop in Biological Engineering Communication: Professors Share Their Practices
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-0 [P/D/F]
