<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Working scientists and engineers discuss best practices for written, visual, and oral communication in the classroom, the lab, and the workplace. In a series of lectures, successful academics and industry professionals share how they prepare papers, talks, and graphics. Recitations allow deeper exploration of the lecture topics. With faculty guidance, students develop their own projects during workshops. Emphasizes systematic approaches and transferable skills such as effective drafting and revision. Topics include creating compelling visuals to represent data and concepts; formal/informal writing, from research papers to cover letters; and developing memorable talks and presentations. Examples drawn from biological engineering research. Enrollment limited; preference to Course 20 majors.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.305"></a>
<p><h3>20.305[J] Principles of Synthetic Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6b.html#6.580">6.580[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6b.html#6.589">6.589[J]</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.405">20.405[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the basics of synthetic biology, including quantitative cellular network characterization and modeling. Considers the discovery and genetic factoring of useful cellular activities into reusable functions for design. Emphasizes the principles of biomolecular system design and diagnosis of designed systems. Illustrates cutting-edge applications in synthetic biology and enhances skills in analysis and design of synthetic biological applications. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.309"></a>
<p><h3>20.309[J] Instrumentation and Measurement for Biological Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.673">2.673[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m20a.html#20.409">20.409</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.0002">6.0002</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-6-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TRF12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-237</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TBA</i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Sensing and measurement aimed at quantitative molecular/cell/tissue analysis in terms of genetic, biochemical, and biophysical properties. Methods include light and fluorescence microscopies, and electro-mechanical probes (atomic force microscopy, optical traps, MEMS devices). Application of statistics, probability, signal and noise analysis, and Fourier techniques to experimental data. Enrollment limited; preference to Course 20 undergraduates.
<br>Fall: <I>S. Manalis</I><br>Spring: <I>E. Boyden, A. Jasanoff, P. So, M. Jonas, J. Sutton, S. Wasserman</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.310"></a>
<p><h3>20.310[J] Molecular, Cellular, and Tissue Biomechanics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.797">2.797[J]</A>, <A HREF="m3a.html#3.053">3.053[J]</A>, <A HREF="m6a.html#6.024">6.024[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2b.html#2.370">2.370</a> or <a href="m2b.html#2.772">2.772J</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a> or <a href="m3a.html#3.016">3.016</a>; <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops and applies scaling laws and the methods of continuum mechanics to biomechanical phenomena over a range of length scales. Topics include structure of tissues and the molecular basis for macroscopic properties; chemical and electrical effects on mechanical behavior; cell mechanics, motility and adhesion; biomembranes; biomolecular mechanics and molecular motors. Experimental methods for probing structures at the tissue, cellular, and molecular levels.
<br><I>M. Bathe</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.315"></a>
<p><h3>20.315 Physical Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m8a.html#8.241">8.241</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.415">20.415</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m20a.html#20.110">20.110</a>, <a href="m5b.html#5.60">5.60</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-257</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>T4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on current major research topics in quantitative, physical biology. Covers synthetic structural biology, synthetic cell biology, microbial systems biology and evolution, cellular decision making, neuronal circuits, and development and morphogenesis. Emphasizes current motivation and historical background, state-of-the-art measurement methodologies and techniques, and quantitative physical modeling frameworks. Experimental techniques include structural biology, next-generation sequencing, fluorescence imaging and spectroscopy, and quantitative biochemistry. Modeling approaches include stochastic rate equations, statistical thermodynamics, and statistical inference. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>I. Cisse</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=20.315');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.320"></a>
<p><h3>20.320 Analysis of Biomolecular and Cellular Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m20a.html#20.110">20.110</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.0002">6.0002</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a> or <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a></I>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Analysis of molecular and cellular processes across a hierarchy of scales, including genetic, molecular, cellular, and cell population levels. Topics include gene sequence analysis, molecular modeling, metabolic and gene regulation networks, signal transduction pathways and cell populations in tissues. Emphasis on experimental methods, quantitative analysis, and computational modeling.
<br><I>F. White</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.330"></a>
<p><h3>20.330[J] Fields, Forces and Flows in Biological Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.793">2.793[J]</A>, <A HREF="m6a.html#6.023">6.023[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m2a.html#2.005">2.005</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.021">6.021</a>, or permission of instructor, <I>Coreq: <a href="m20a.html#20.309">20.309</a></I>
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF11</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-163</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>T10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-169</a>) or <i>T4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-167</a>) or <i>W12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=26">26-168</a>) or <i>R2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-191</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to electric fields, fluid flows, transport phenomena and their application to biological systems. Flux and continuity laws, Maxwell's equations, electro-quasistatics, electro-chemical-mechanical driving forces, conservation of mass and momentum, Navier-Stokes flows, and electrokinetics. Applications include biomolecular transport in tissues, electrophoresis, and microfluidics.
<br><I>A. Grodzinsky, S. Manalis</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.334"></a>
<p><h3>20.334 Biological Systems Modeling
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">); first half of term
<br>Prereq: <a href="m20a.html#20.330">20.330</a> or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 1-0-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Practices the use of modern numerical analysis tools (e.g., COMSOL) for biological systems with multi-physics behavior. Covers modeling of diffusion, reaction, convection and other transport mechanisms. Analysis of microfluidic devices as examples. Discusses practical issues and challenges in numerical modeling. No prior knowledge of modeling software required. Includes weekly modeling homework and one final modeling project.
<br><I>J. Han</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.345"></a>
<p><h3>20.345[J] Bioinstrumentation Project Lab
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6a.html#6.123">6.123[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, and <a href="m2a.html#2.004">2.004</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a>; or <a href="m20a.html#20.309">20.309</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-7-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TRF12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-336</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TBA</i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>In-depth examination of instrumentation design, principles and techniques for studying biological systems, from single molecules to entire organisms. Lectures cover optics, advanced microscopy techniques, electronics for biological measurement, magnetic resonance imaging, computed tomography, MEMs, microfluidic devices, and limits of detection. Students select two lab exercises during the first half of the semester and complete a final design project in the second half. Lab emphasizes design process and skillful realization of a robust system. Enrollment limited; preference to Course 20 majors and minors.
<br><I>E. Boyden, A. Jasanoff, P. So, M. Jonas, J. Sutton, S. Wasserman</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.352"></a>
<p><h3>20.352 Principles of Neuroengineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m9a.html#9.422">9.422[J]</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.452">20.452[J]</A>, <A HREF="mMASa.html#MAS.881">MAS.881[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers how to innovate technologies for brain analysis and engineering, for accelerating the basic understanding of the brain, and leading to new therapeutic insight and inventions. Focuses on using physical, chemical and biological principles to understand technology design criteria governing ability to observe and alter brain structure and function. Topics include optogenetics, noninvasive brain imaging and stimulation, nanotechnologies, stem cells and tissue engineering, and advanced molecular and structural imaging technologies. Includes design projects.  Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments. Designed for students with engineering maturity who are ready for design.
<br><I>E. Boyden</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.361"></a>
<p><h3>20.361[J] Molecular and Engineering Aspects of Biotechnology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.37">7.37[J]</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.441">10.441[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m2a.html#2.005">2.005</a>, <a href="m3a.html#3.012">3.012</a>, <a href="m5b.html#5.60">5.60</a>, or <a href="m20a.html#20.110">20.110</a>; <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m7a.html#7.371">7.371</A>
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/7.37j/">http://web.mit.edu/7.37j/</a>
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i>  <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers biological and bioengineering principles underlying the development and therapeutic use of recombinant proteins and stem cells; glycoengineering of recombinant proteins; normal and pathological signaling by growth factors and their receptors; receptor trafficking; monoclonal antibodies as therapeutics; protein pharmacology and delivery; stem cell-derived tissues as therapeutics; RNA therapeutics; combinatorial protein engineering; and new antitumor drugs.
<br><I>H. Lodish, L. Griffith</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.363"></a>
<p><h3>20.363[J] Biomaterials Science and Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m3a.html#3.055">3.055[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m3b.html#3.963">3.963[J]</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.463">20.463[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.034">3.034</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.110">20.110</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers, at a molecular scale, the analysis and design of materials used in contact with biological systems, and biomimetic strategies aimed at creating new materials based on principles found in biology. Topics include molecular interaction between bio- and synthetic molecules and surfaces; design, synthesis, and processing approaches for materials that control cell functions; and application of materials science to problems in tissue engineering, drug delivery, vaccines, and cell-guiding surfaces. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>D. Irvine</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.365"></a>
<p><h3>20.365 Engineering the Immune System in Cancer and Beyond
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m20a.html#20.465">20.465</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m20a.html#20.110">20.110</a> or <a href="m5b.html#5.60">5.60</a>; permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines strategies in clinical and preclinical development for manipulating the immune system to treat and protect against disease. Begins with brief review of immune system. Discusses interaction of tumors with the immune system, followed by approaches by which the immune system can be modulated to attack cancer. Also covers strategies based in biotechnology, chemistry, materials science, and molecular biology to induce immune responses to treat infection, transplantation, and autoimmunity. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.370"></a>
<p><h3>20.370[J] Cellular Neurophysiology and Computing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.791">2.791[J]</A>, <A HREF="m6a.html#6.021">6.021[J]</A>, <A HREF="m9a.html#9.21">9.21[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2b.html#2.794">2.794[J]</A>, <A HREF="m6b.html#6.521">6.521[J]</A>, <A HREF="m9a.html#9.021">9.021[J]</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.470">20.470[J]</A>, <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.541">HST.541[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>; <a href="m2a.html#2.005">2.005</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.002">6.002</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.301">10.301</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.110">20.110</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-2-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Integrated overview of the biophysics of cells from prokaryotes to neurons, with a focus on mass transport and electrical signal generation across cell membrane. First third of course focuses on mass transport through membranes: diffusion, osmosis, chemically mediated, and active transport. Second third focuses on electrical properties of cells: ion transport to action potential generation and propagation in electrically excitable cells. Synaptic transmission. Electrical properties interpreted via kinetic and molecular properties of single voltage-gated ion channels. Final third focuses on biophysics of synaptic transmission and introduction to neural computing. Laboratory and computer exercises illustrate the concepts. Students taking graduate version complete different assignments. Preference to juniors and seniors.
<br><I>T. Heldt</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.375"></a>
<p><h3>20.375 Applied Developmental Biology and Tissue Engineering
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m20a.html#20.475">20.475</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.320">20.320</a>, and <a href="m7a.html#7.02">7.02</a> or <a href="m20a.html#20.109">20.109</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-220</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Addresses the integration of engineering and biology design principles to create human tissues and organs for regenerative medicine to drug development. Provides an overview of embryogenesis, how morphogenic phenomena are governed by biochemical and biophysical cues. Analyzes <i>in vitro</i> generation of human brain, gut, and other organoids from stem cells. Studies the roles of biomaterials and microreactors in improving organoid formation and function; organoid use in modeling disease and physiology <i>in vitro</i>; and engineering and biological principles of reconstructing tissues and organs from postnatal donor cells using biomaterials scaffolds and bioreactors. Includes select applications, such as liver disease, brain disorders, and others. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>L. Griffith</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.380"></a>
<p><h3>20.380 Biological Engineering Design
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.320">20.320</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.330">20.330</a>; <I>Coreq: <a href="m20a.html#20.309">20.309</a></I>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TR10-12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-614</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>TR9</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-614</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Illustrates how knowledge and principles of biology, biochemistry, and engineering are integrated to create new products for societal benefit. Uses case study format to examine recently developed products of pharmaceutical and biotechnology industries: how a product evolves from initial idea, through patents, testing, evaluation, production, and marketing. Emphasizes scientific and engineering principles, as well as the responsibility scientists, engineers, and business executives have for the consequences of their technology. Instruction and practice in written and oral communication provided. Enrollment limited; preference to Course 20 undergraduates.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Koehler</I><br>Spring: <I>J. Essigmann, K. Ribbeck, S. Clarke</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.385"></a>
<p><h3>20.385 Understanding Current Research in Synthetic Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m20a.html#20.020">20.020</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m20a.html#20.109">20.109</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.320">20.320</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-3-3
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an in-depth understanding of the state of research in synthetic biology. Critical evaluation of primary research literature covering a range of approaches to the design, modeling and programming of cellular behaviors. Focuses on developing the skills needed to read, present and discuss primary research literature, and to manage and lead small teams. Students mentor a small undergraduate team of 20.020 students. Open to advanced students with appropriate background in biology.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.390"></a>
<p><h3>20.390[J] Foundations of Computational and Systems Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6c.html#6.802">6.802[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.874">6.874[J]</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.490">20.490</A>, <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.506">HST.506[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.0002">6.0002</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.01">6.01</a>; <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/7.91/">http://web.mit.edu/7.91/</a>
<br><img align="bottom" width=16 height=16 alt="Subject Cancelled" title="Subject Cancelled" src="/icns/buttonx.gif"> <i><b>Subject Cancelled</b></i>  <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to computational and systems biology. Includes units on the analysis of protein and nucleic acid sequences, protein structures, and biological networks. Presents principles and methods used for sequence alignment, motif finding, expression array analysis, structural modeling, structure design and prediction, and network analysis and modeling. Techniques include dynamic programming, Markov and hidden Markov models, Bayesian networks, clustering methods, and energy minimization approaches. Exposes students to emerging research areas. Designed for students with strong backgrounds in either molecular biology or computer science. Some foundational material covering basic programming skills, probability and statistics is provided for students with less quantitative backgrounds. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.405"></a>
<p><h3>20.405[J] Principles of Synthetic Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6b.html#6.589">6.589[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6b.html#6.580">6.580[J]</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.305">20.305[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the basics of synthetic biology, including quantitative cellular network characterization and modeling. Considers the discovery and genetic factoring of useful cellular activities into reusable functions for design. Emphasizes the principles of biomolecular system design and diagnosis of designed systems. Illustrates cutting-edge applications in synthetic biology and enhances skills in analysis and design of synthetic biological applications. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>R. Weiss</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.409"></a>
<p><h3>20.409 Biological Engineering II: Instrumentation and Measurement
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2b.html#2.673">2.673[J]</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.309">20.309[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-7-3
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>TRF12</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-237</a>) <b>Lab:</b> <i>TBA</i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Sensing and measurement aimed at quantitative molecular/cell/tissue analysis in terms of genetic, biochemical, and biophysical properties. Methods include light and fluorescence microscopies, electronic circuits, and electro-mechanical probes (atomic force microscopy, optical traps, MEMS devices). Application of statistics, probability, signal and noise analysis, and Fourier techniques to experimental data. Limited to 5 graduate students.
<br><I>E. Boyden, A. Jasanoff, P. So, M. Jonas, J. Sutton, S. Wasserman</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.410"></a>
<p><h3>20.410[J] Molecular, Cellular, and Tissue Biomechanics
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.798">2.798[J]</A>, <A HREF="m3b.html#3.971">3.971[J]</A>, <A HREF="m6b.html#6.524">6.524[J]</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.537">10.537[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>; <a href="m2a.html#2.002">2.002</a>, <a href="m2a.html#2.006">2.006</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.013">6.013</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.301">10.301</a>, or <a href="m10a.html#10.302">10.302</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops and applies scaling laws and the methods of continuum mechanics to biomechanical phenomena over a range of length scales. Topics include structure of tissues and the molecular basis for macroscopic properties; chemical and electrical effects on mechanical behavior; cell mechanics, motility and adhesion; biomembranes; biomolecular mechanics and molecular motors. Experimental methods for probing structures at the tissue, cellular, and molecular levels.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.415"></a>
<p><h3>20.415 Physical Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m8a.html#8.241">8.241</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.315">20.315</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW11-12.30</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=4">4-257</a>) <b>Recitation:</b> <i>T4</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=66">66-160</a>) <i><b>+final</b></i><!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Focuses on current major research topics in quantitative, physical biology. Topics include synthetic structural biology, synthetic cell biology, microbial systems biology and evolution, cellular decision making, neuronal circuits, and development and morphogenesis. Emphasizes current motivation and historical background, state-of-the-art measurement methodologies and techniques, and quantitative physical modeling frameworks. Experimental techniques include structural biology, next-generation sequencing, fluorescence imaging and spectroscopy, and quantitative biochemistry. Modeling approaches include stochastic rate equations, statistical thermodynamics, and statistical inference. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>I. Cisse</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=20.415');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.416"></a>
<p><h3>20.416[J] Topics in Biophysics and Physical Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.74">7.74[J]</A>, <A HREF="m8b.html#8.590">8.590[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides broad exposure to research in biophysics and physical biology, with emphasis on the critical evaluation of scientific literature. Weekly meetings include in-depth discussion of scientific literature led by distinct faculty on active research topics. Each session also includes brief discussion of non-research topics including effective presentation skills, writing papers and fellowship proposals, choosing scientific and technical research topics, time management, and scientific ethics.
<br><I>N. Fakhri</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.420"></a>
<p><h3>20.420[J] Principles of Molecular Bioengineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m10a.html#10.538">10.538[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to the mechanistic analysis and engineering of biomolecules and biomolecular systems. Covers methods for measuring, modeling, and manipulating systems, including biophysical experimental tools, computational modeling approaches, and molecular design. Equips students to take systematic and quantitative approaches to the investigation of a wide variety of biological phenomena.
<br><I>A. Jasanoff</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.430"></a>
<p><h3>20.430[J] Fields, Forces, and Flows in Biological Systems
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.795">2.795[J]</A>, <A HREF="m6b.html#6.561">6.561[J]</A>, <A HREF="m10a.html#10.539">10.539[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Molecular diffusion, diffusion-reaction, conduction, convection in biological systems; fields in heterogeneous media; electrical double layers; Maxwell stress tensor, electrical forces in physiological systems. Fluid and solid continua: equations of motion useful for porous, hydrated biological tissues. Case studies of membrane transport, electrode interfaces, electrical, mechanical, and chemical transduction in tissues, convective-diffusion/reaction, electrophoretic, electroosmotic flows in tissues/MEMs, and ECG. Electromechanical and physicochemical interactions in cells and biomaterials; musculoskeletal, cardiovascular, and other biological and clinical examples. Prior undergraduate coursework in transport recommended.
<br><I>A. Grodzinsky</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.440"></a>
<p><h3>20.440 Analysis of Biological Networks
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 6-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MW2-3.30,F2</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-614</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Conceptual and experimental approaches to analyzing complex biological networks and systems, from molecules to human populations, focusing on human pathophysiology and disease. Moving from single component analysis to pathways and networks, combines didactic lectures with in-depth analysis of current literature and computational analysis. Emphasizes the chemistry and biochemistry of underlying biological processes. Topics include linking genes/SNPs to disease, defining pathways, analysis of pathways <i>in vivo</i>, systems-level analysis, and applications of network biology. First half of term focuses on fundamental biological processes and tools/analyses needed by biological engineers, and the second half elaborates on these fundamentals by covering complex biological processes. Students acquire skills in the fundamentals of grant preparation using an NIH format and make an oral presentation.
<br><I>P. Blainey, F. White, M. Yaffe</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=20.440');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.445"></a>
<p><h3>20.445[J] Methods and Problems in Microbiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1c.html#1.86">1.86[J]</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.492">7.492[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Students will read and discuss primary literature covering key areas of microbial research with emphasis on methods and approaches used to understand and manipulate microbes. Preference to first-year Microbiology and Biology students.
<br><I>M. Laub</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.446"></a>
<p><h3>20.446[J] Microbial Genetics and Evolution
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m1c.html#1.87">1.87[J]</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.493">7.493[J]</A>, <A HREF="m12b.html#12.493">12.493[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m7a.html#7.03">7.03</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers aspects of microbial genetic and genomic analyses, central dogma, horizontal gene transfer, and evolution.
<br><I>A. D. Grossman, E. Alm</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.450"></a>
<p><h3>20.450 Molecular and Cellular Pathophysiology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m20a.html#20.420">20.420</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.440">20.440</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 4-0-8
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Compares the complex molecular and cellular interactions in health and disease between commensal microbial communities,  pathogens and the human or animal host. Special focus is given to current research on microbe/host interactions, infection of significant importance to public health, and chronic infectious disease. Classwork will include lecture, but emphasize critical evaluation and class discussion of recent scientific papers, and the development of new research agendas in the fields presented.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.452"></a>
<p><h3>20.452[J] Principles of Neuroengineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9a.html#9.422">9.422[J]</A>, <A HREF="mMASa.html#MAS.881">MAS.881[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m20a.html#20.352">20.352</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers how to innovate technologies for brain analysis and engineering, for accelerating the basic understanding of the brain, and leading to new therapeutic insight and inventions. Focuses on using physical, chemical and biological principles to understand technology design criteria governing ability to observe and alter brain structure and function. Topics include optogenetics, noninvasive brain imaging and stimulation, nanotechnologies, stem cells and tissue engineering, and advanced molecular and structural imaging technologies. Includes design projects. Designed for students with engineering maturity who are ready for design. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>E. Boyden</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.454"></a>
<p><h3>20.454[J] Revolutionary Ventures: How to Invent and Deploy Transformative Technologies
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m9a.html#9.455">9.455[J]</A>, <A HREF="m15a.html#15.128">15.128[J]</A>, <A HREF="mMASa.html#MAS.883">MAS.883[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-7
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Seminar on envisioning and building ideas and organizations to accelerate engineering revolutions. Focuses on emerging technology domains, such as neurotechnology, imaging, cryotechnology, gerontechnology, and bio-and-nano fabrication. Draws on historical examples as well as live case studies of existing or emerging organizations, including labs, institutes, startups, and companies. Goals range from accelerating basic science to developing transformative products or therapeutics. Each class is devoted to a specific area, often with invited speakers, exploring issues from the deeply technical through the strategic. Individually or in small groups, students prototype new ventures aimed at inventing and deploying revolutionary technologies.
<br><I>E. Boyden</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.463"></a>
<p><h3>20.463[J] Biomaterials Science and Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m3b.html#3.963">3.963[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m3a.html#3.055">3.055[J]</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.363">20.363[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m3a.html#3.034">3.034</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.110">20.110</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers, at a molecular scale, the analysis and design of materials used in contact with biological systems, and biomimetic strategies aimed at creating new materials based on principles found in biology. Topics include molecular interaction between bio- and synthetic molecules and surfaces; design, synthesis, and processing approaches for materials that control cell functions; and application of materials science to problems in tissue engineering, drug delivery, vaccines, and cell-guiding surfaces. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br><I>D. Irvine</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.465"></a>
<p><h3>20.465 Engineering the Immune System in Cancer and Beyond
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m20a.html#20.365">20.365</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Examines strategies in clinical and preclinical development for manipulating the immune system to treat and protect against disease. Begins with brief review of immune system. Discusses interaction of tumors with the immune system, followed by approaches by which the immune system can be modulated to attack cancer. Also covers strategies based in biotechnology, chemistry, materials science, and molecular biology to induce immune responses to treat infection, transplantation, and autoimmunity. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.470"></a>
<p><h3>20.470[J] Cellular Neurophysiology and Computing
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.794">2.794[J]</A>, <A HREF="m6b.html#6.521">6.521[J]</A>, <A HREF="m9a.html#9.021">9.021[J]</A>, <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.541">HST.541[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m2b.html#2.791">2.791[J]</A>, <A HREF="m6a.html#6.021">6.021[J]</A>, <A HREF="m9a.html#9.21">9.21[J]</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.370">20.370[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=p2" title="8.02, 8.021, 8.022">Physics II (GIR)</a>; <a href="m18a.html#18.03">18.03</a>; <a href="m2a.html#2.005">2.005</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.002">6.002</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.003">6.003</a>, <a href="m10a.html#10.301">10.301</a>, <a href="m20a.html#20.110">20.110</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 5-2-5
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Integrated overview of the biophysics of cells from prokaryotes to neurons, with a focus on mass transport and electrical signal generation across cell membrane. First third of course focuses on mass transport through membranes: diffusion, osmosis, chemically mediated, and active transport. Second third focuses on electrical properties of cells: ion transport to action potential generation and propagation in electrically excitable cells. Synaptic transmission. Electrical properties interpreted via kinetic and molecular properties of single voltage-gated ion channels. Final third focuses on biophysics of synaptic transmission and introduction to neural computing. Laboratory and computer exercises illustrate the concepts. Students taking graduate version complete different assignments.
<br><I>T. Heldt</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.475"></a>
<p><h3>20.475 Applied Developmental Biology and Tissue Engineering
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m20a.html#20.375">20.375</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>MWF10</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=16">16-220</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>This subject addresses the integration of engineering and biology design principles to create human tissues and organs for regenerative medicine to drug development. Overview of embryogenesis; how morphogenic phenomena are governed by biochemical and biophysical cues. Analysis of in vitro generation of human brain, gut, and other organoids from stem cells. Roles of biomaterials and microreactors in improving organoid formation and function. Organoid use in modeling disease and physiology in vitro. Engineering and biological principles of reconstructing tissues and organs from postnatal donor cells using biomaterials scaffolds and bioreactors. Select applications such as liver disease, brain disorders, and others. Graduate students will have additional assignments.
<br><I>L. Griffith</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.482"></a>
<p><h3>20.482[J] Foundations of Algorithms and Computational Techniques in Systems Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m6b.html#6.581">6.581[J]</A>)<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6b.html#6.503">6.503</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m6a.html#6.021">6.021</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.034">6.034</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.046">6.046</a>, <a href="m6b.html#6.336">6.336</a>, <a href="m18a.html#18.417">18.417</a>, or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Illustrates computational approaches to solving problems in systems biology. Uses a series of case studies to demonstrate how an effective match between the statement of a biological problem and the selection of an appropriate algorithm or computational technique can lead to fundamental advances. Covers several discrete and numerical algorithms used in simulation, feature extraction, and optimization for molecular, network, and systems models in biology. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.486"></a>
<p><h3>20.486[J] Case Studies and Strategies in Drug Discovery and Development
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.549">7.549[J]</A>, <A HREF="m15a.html#15.137">15.137[J]</A>, <A HREF="mHSTb.html#HST.916">HST.916[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><a href="http://mit.edu/7.549j">http://mit.edu/7.549j</a>
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>M EVE (4-6 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=56">56-614</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Aims to develop appreciation for the stages of drug discovery and development, from target identification, to the submission of preclinical and clinical data to regulatory authorities for marketing approval. Following introductory lectures on the process of drug development, students working in small teams analyze how one of four new drugs or drug candidates traversed the discovery/development landscape. For each case, an outside expert from the sponsoring drug company or pivotal clinical trial principal investigator provides guidance and critiques the teams' presentations to the class.
<br><I>A. Wood</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.487"></a>
<p><h3>20.487[J] Optical Microscopy and Spectroscopy for Biology and Medicine
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)<br>Not offered regularly; consult department
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m2b.html#2.715">2.715[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduces the theory and the design of optical microscopy and its applications in biology and medicine.  The course starts from an overview of basic optical principles allowing an understanding of microscopic image formation and common contrast modalities such as dark field, phase, and DIC.  Advanced microscopy imaging techniques such as total internal reflection, confocal, and multiphoton will also be discussed.  Quantitative analysis of biochemical microenvironment using spectroscopic techniques based on fluorescence, second harmonic, Raman signals will be covered.  We will also provide an overview of key image processing techniques for microscopic data.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.490"></a>
<p><h3>20.490 Foundations of Computational and Systems Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Subject meets with <A HREF="m6c.html#6.802">6.802[J]</A>, <A HREF="m6c.html#6.874">6.874[J]</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.390">20.390[J]</A>, <A HREF="mHSTa.html#HST.506">HST.506[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="./search.cgi?search=&cred=b" title="7.012, 7.013, 7.014, 7.015, 7.016">Biology (GIR)</a>, <a href="m6a.html#6.0002">6.0002</a> or <a href="m6a.html#6.01">6.01</a>; or <a href="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</a>; or permission of instructor
<br>Units: 3-0-9
<br><a href="http://web.mit.edu/7.91/">http://web.mit.edu/7.91/</a>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides an introduction to computational and systems biology. Includes units on the analysis of protein and nucleic acid sequences, protein structures, and biological networks. Presents principles and methods used for sequence alignment, motif finding, expression array analysis, structural modeling, structure design and prediction, and network analysis and modeling. Techniques include dynamic programming, Markov and hidden Markov models, Bayesian networks, clustering methods, and energy minimization approaches. Exposes students to emerging research areas. Designed for students with strong backgrounds in either molecular biology or computer science. Some foundational material covering basic programming skills, probability and statistics is provided for students with less quantitative backgrounds. Students taking graduate version complete additional assignments.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.507"></a>
<p><h3>20.507[J] Biological Chemistry I
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">) <img src="/icns/rest.gif" alt="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" title="Rest Elec in Sci & Tech" width="16" height="16" align="bottom">
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m5a.html#5.07">5.07[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.12">5.12</a>
<br>Units: 5-0-7
<br>Credit cannot also be received for <A HREF="m7a.html#7.05">7.05</A>
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Chemical and physical properties of the cell and its building blocks. Structures of proteins and principles of catalysis. The chemistry of organic/inorganic cofactors required for chemical transformations within the cell. Basic principles of metabolism and regulation in pathways, including glycolysis, gluconeogenesis, fatty acid synthesis/degradation, pentose phosphate pathway, Krebs cycle and oxidative phosphorylation, DNA replication, and transcription and translation.
<br><I>A. Klibanov, E. Nolan</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.554"></a>
<p><h3>20.554[J] Frontiers in Chemical Biology
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m5b.html#5.54">5.54[J]</A>, <A HREF="m7a.html#7.540">7.540[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: <a href="m5a.html#5.13">5.13</a>, <a href="m5a.html#5.07">5.07</a>, <a href="m7a.html#7.06">7.06</a>, permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-4
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Introduction to current research at the interface of chemistry, biology, and bioengineering. Topics include imaging of biological processes, metabolic pathway engineering, protein engineering, mechanisms of DNA damage, RNA structure and function, macromolecular machines, protein misfolding and disease, metabolomics, and methods for analyzing signaling network dynamics. Lectures are interspersed with class discussions and student presentations based on current literature.
<br><I>L. Kiessling</I><br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.560"></a>
<p><h3>20.560 Statistics for Biological Engineering
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" title="Not offered academic year 2017-2018" src="/icns/nooffer.gif"><img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor
<br>Units: 2-0-2 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides basic tools for analyzing experimental data, interpreting statistical reports in the literature, and reasoning under uncertain situations. Topics include probability theory, statistical tests, data exploration, Bayesian statistics, and machine learning. Emphasizes discussion and hands-on learning. Experience with MATLAB, Python, or R recommended.
<br>Staff<br>
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.586"></a>
<p><h3>20.586[J] Science and Business of Biotechnology
<br>(New)
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.546">7.546[J]</A>, <A HREF="m15b.html#15.480">15.480[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: Permission of instructor; <I>Coreq: <a href="m15b.html#15.401">15.401</a></I>
<br>Units: 3-0-6
<br><b>Lecture:</b> <i>T EVE (4-7 PM)</i> (<a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?mapterms=E62">E62-276</a>)<!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Covers the new types of drugs and other therapeutics in current practice and under development, the financing and business structures of early-stage biotechnology companies, and the evaluation of their risk/reward profiles. Includes a series of live case studies with industry leaders of both established and emerging biotechnology companies as guest speakers, focusing on the underlying science and engineering as well as core financing and business issues. Students must possess a basic background in cellular and molecular biology.
<br><I>A. Lo</I><br><a href="javascript:PopUpHelp('http://eduapps.mit.edu/textbook/books.html?Term=2018SP&Subject=20.586');" >Textbooks (Spring 2018)</a></font>
</p><!--end-->

<a name="20.920"></a>
<p><h3>20.920 Practical Work Experience
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 0-1-0 [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>For Course 20 students participating in off-campus work experiences in biological engineering. Before registering for this subject, students must have an employment offer from a company or organization and must identify a BE supervisor. Upon completion of the work, student must submit a letter from the employer describing the work accomplished, along with a substantive final report from the student approved by the MIT supervisor. Subject to departmental approval. Consult departmental undergraduate office.
<br>Fall: <I>D. Fares</I><br>IAP: <I>D. Fares</I><br>Spring: <I>D. Fares</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->
<a name="20.930"></a>
<p><h3>20.930[J] Research Experience in Biopharma
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Graduate" title="Graduate" src="/icns/grad.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">)
<br>(Same subject as <A HREF="m7a.html#7.930">7.930[J]</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 2-10-0
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Provides exposure to industrial science and develops skills necessary for success in such an environment. Under the guidance of an industrial mentor, students participate in on-site research at a local biopharmaceutical company where they observe and participate in industrial science. Serves as a real-time case study to internalize the factors that shape R&D in industry, including the purpose and scope of a project, key decision points in the past and future, and strategies for execution. Students utilize company resources and work with a scientific team to contribute to the goals of their assigned project; they then present project results to the company and class, emphasizing the logic that dictated their work and their ideas for future directions. Lecture component focuses on professional development.
<br><I>S. Clarke</I><br>
</p><!--end-->

<a name="20.EPW"></a>
<p><h3>20.EPW UPOP Engineering Practice Workshop
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">)
<br>Engineering School-Wide Elective Subject. <br>(Offered under: <A HREF="m1c.html#1.EPW">1.EPW</A>, <A HREF="m2c.html#2.EPW">2.EPW</A>, <A HREF="m3b.html#3.EPW">3.EPW</A>, <A HREF="m6c.html#6.EPW">6.EPW</A>, <A HREF="m10b.html#10.EPW">10.EPW</A>, <A HREF="m16a.html#16.EPW">16.EPW</A>, <A HREF="m20a.html#20.EPW">20.EPW</A>, <A HREF="m22a.html#22.EPW">22.EPW</A>)
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units: 1-0-0 [P/D/F]
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Develops foundational skills for the world of practice in science, technology, and engineering. Sophomores receive classroom instruction, and one-on-one and small-group coaching in basics of professional identity building. They attend field trips to local employers and receive job interview practice, coached by industry volunteers. Over IAP, students attend a weeklong Team Training Camp of experiential learning modules - led by MIT faculty with the help of MIT alums and other senior professionals in business, engineering, and science where students participate in creative simulations, team problem-solving challenges, and oral presentations, and practice networking with employers. Enrollment limited.
<br>Fall: <I>J. Crim</I><br>IAP: <I>J. Crim</I><br>No textbook information available
</p><!--end-->

<a name="20.S940"></a>
<p><h3>20.S940 Special Subject in Biological Engineering

<p><h3>20.UR Undergraduate Research Opportunities
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->

<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">

<tr><td>
<h1 align="center">Course 21: Humanities<br>IAP / Spring
2018</h1><div id="contentmini"><b><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate"><i>Course 21 Home</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="http://web.mit.edu/commreq/cim.html"><i>CI-M Subjects for Undergraduate Majors</i></a>&nbsp; &nbsp; <a href="./search.cgi?search=21&when=J"><i>IAP only</i></a></b><hr width="90%" align="center"><table align="center"><tr><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple1.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="left arrow"></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle align=center><b>21.TH-21.URG</b></td><td valign=middle><b> | </b></td><td valign=middle><img src="/icns/purple2.gif" width="20" height="20" alt="right arrow"></td></tr></table></div>
<hr width="90%" align="center">
<table border=0 width="100%"><tr><td>
<p>Research subjects are also offered by programs within the Department of Humanities: Anthropology (21A), Comparative Media Studies/Writing (CMS/21W), Global Studies and Languages (21G), History (21H), Literature (21L), Music and Theater Arts (21M), Science, Technology, and Society (STS), and Women's and Gender Studies (WGS).  Consult those listings for details.
<a name="21.THT"></a>
<p><h3>21.THT Humanities Pre-Thesis Tutorial
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: As specified for particular field
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Definition of and early-stage work on thesis project leading to 21.THU Undergraduate Thesis in Humanities. Taken during the first term of the student's two-term commitment to the thesis project. Student works closely with an individual faculty tutor. Required for all students in Course 21, and those doing 21-E and 21-S degrees, for whom the thesis is a degree requirement.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Wirth</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Wirth</I><br>Textbooks arranged individually
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21.THU"></a>
<p><h3>21.THU Undergraduate Thesis in Humanities
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: <a href="m21a.html#21.THT">21.THT</a>
<br>Units arranged
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Completion of work on the senior major thesis under supervision of a faculty tutor. Includes oral presentation of thesis progress early in the term, assembling and revising the final text, and meeting at the close with a committee of faculty evaluators to discuss the successes and limitations of the project. Required for most students in Course 21 and those doing 21-E and 21-S degrees.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Wirth</I><br>IAP: <I>A. Wirth</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Wirth</I><br>Textbooks arranged individually
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21.UR"></a>
<p><h3>21.UR Undergraduate Research in Humanities
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif"></h3>
<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Undergrad" title="Undergrad" src="/icns/under.gif">  (<img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Fall" title="Fall" src="/icns/fall.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="IAP" title="IAP" src="/icns/iap.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Spring" title="Spring" src="/icns/spring.gif">, <img width=16 height=16 align="bottom" alt="Summer" title="Summer" src="/icns/summer.gif">) <img src="/icns/repeat.gif" alt="Can be repeated for credit" title="Can be repeated for credit" width=16 height=16 align="bottom">
<br>Prereq: None
<br>Units arranged [P/D/F]
<br>TBA. <!--s-->
<br><img alt="______" src="/icns/hr.gif">
<br>Individual participation in an ongoing research project. For students in the Undergraduate Research Opportunities Program.
<br>Fall: <I>A. Wirth</I><br>IAP: <I>A. Wirth</I><br>Spring: <I>A. Wirth</I><br>Textbooks arranged individually
</p><!--end-->
<a name="21.URG"></a>
